PREFACE 
    The Huron, South Dakota Municipal Code, originally published by Book Publishing Company in 1964, has been kept current by regular supplementation by Matthew Bender & Company, Inc., its successor in interest. 
    This Code was republished by Municipal Code Corporation in May 2009. 
    During original codification, the ordinances were compiled, edited and indexed by the editorial staff of Book Publishing Company under the direction of the city attorney. 
    The Code is organized by subject matter under an expandable three-factor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions. Each section number designates, in sequence, the numbers of the Title, chapter, and section. Thus, Section 2.12.040 is Section .040, located in Chapter 2.12 of Title 2. In most instances, sections are numbered by tens (.010, .020, .030, etc.), leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions. Similarly, chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion. 
    In parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section. This legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table, following the text of the Code, listing by number all ordinances, their subjects, and where they appear in the codification; and beginning with the 2009 republication, legislation can be tracked using the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
    A subject-matter index, with complete cross-referencing, locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers. 
    This supplement brings the Code up-to-date through Ordinance Number 2199-18-74, passed January 7, 2019. 
Municipal Code Corporation 
1700 Capital Circle SW 
Tallahassee, FL 32310 
800-262-2633 
HOW TO USE YOUR CODE 
    This code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials, city employees and private citizens. Please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code. 
Numbering System. 
    The numbering system is the backbone of a Code of Ordinances; Municipal Code Corporation uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this Code. It is based on three tiers, beginning with title, then chapter, and ending with section. Each part is represented in the code section number. For example, Section 2.04.010 is Section .010, in Chapter 2.04 of Title 2. 
Title. 
    A title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled. This code contains about 15 to 20 titles. For example, the first title is Title 1, General Provisions, which may contain ordinances about the general penalty, code adoption and definitions. The titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference. Some titles are Reserved for later use. 
Chapter. 
    Chapters deal with more specific subjects, and are often derived from one ordinance. All of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title. The chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material. For example, Chapter 2.06, City Manager, can be added between 2.04, City Council, and Chapter 2.08, City Attorney. 
Section. 
    Each section of the code contains substantive ordinance material. The sections are numbered by "tens" to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering. 
Ordinance History Note. 
    At the end of each code section, you will find an "ordinance history note," which lists the underlying ordinances for that section. The ordinances are listed by number, section (if applicable) and year. (Example: (Ord. 272 § 1, 1992).) 
    Beginning with the 2009 republication, a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections. Ordinance history notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end. These history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index. 
Ordinance List and Disposition Table. 
    To find a specific ordinance in the code, turn to the section called "Tables" for the Ordinance List and Disposition Table. This very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code. The table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance. If the ordinance is codified, the chapter (or chapters) will be indicated. (Example: (2.04, 6.12, 9.04).) If the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified, such as budgets, taxes, annexations or rezones, the disposition will be "(Special)." If the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code, usually at the direction of the municipality, the disposition will be "(Not codified)." Other dispositions sometimes used are "(Tabled)," "(Pending)," "(Number Not Used)" or "(Missing)." 
    Beginning with the 2009 republication, this table will be replaced with the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 
    Beginning with the 2009 republication, a Code Comparative Table and Disposition List has been added for use in tracking legislative history. Located in the back of this volume, this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification. The Code Comparative Table and Disposition List specifies the ordinance number, adoption date, description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance. By use of the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List, the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
Index. 
    If you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code, start with the index. This is an alphabetical multi-tier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference, and cross-references where necessary. Look for the main heading of the subject you need, then the appropriate subheadings: 
BUSINESS LICENSE 
See also BUSINESS TAX 
Fee 5.04.030 
Required when 5.04.010 
    The index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended. 
Instruction Sheet. 
    Each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an Instruction Sheet. The Instruction Sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement. It will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted. Following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current. Removed pages should be kept for future reference. 
Electronic Submission. 
    In the interests of accuracy and speed, we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible. We can accept most any file format, including Word, WordPerfect or text files. If you have a choice, we prefer Word, any version. You can send files to us as an e-mail attachment, by FTP, on a diskette or CD-ROM. Electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is error-free. Our e-mail address is: ords@municode.com . 
For hard copy, send two copies of all ordinances passed to: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
P.O. Box 2235 
Tallahassee, FL 32316

Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapter 1.04 - CODE 

1.04.010 - Definitions. 
    References and terms as used in this code, unless the context otherwise plainly requires, shall have the meanings hereinafter provided: 
(1)  PERSON includes natural persons, partnerships, associations, organizations, and corporations. 
(2)  Masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter. 
(3)  Words used in the singular number include the plural; and the plural, the singular. 
(4)  GOVERNING BODY refers to board of city commissioners of the City of Huron. 
(5)  CITY or MUNICIPALITY refer to the City of Huron. 
(6)  The provisions, regulations, restrictions, requirements, and prohibitions contained in this code apply to the area within the territorial limits of the City of Huron, unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(7)  Reference to any office or officer is to an office or officer of the City of Huron, unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(8)  The powers conferred on an officer may be exercised by his duly authorized deputy, representative, or employee acting under him, unless otherwise provided. 
(9)  STREET includes alley, avenue, drive, boulevard, and traveled road. 
(10)  LOT includes tract or parcel of ground. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0101; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.020 - Citation of code. 
    This code may be cited as the Huron Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0201; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.030 - Numbering system. 
    Each section number is divided by two decimal points. The number or numbers to the left of the first decimal always indicates the title number. The chapter number within the title is indicated by the two digits immediately to the right of the first decimal point. The last three digit positions to the right of the second decimal indicate the section number within the title and chapter. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0202; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.040 - Numbering of amendments and additions. 
    Insofar as practical, amendments of and additions to this code may be numbered as sections, chapters, or titles of this code. Generally, additions to the subject matter of a given chapter may be added as additional, numbered sections of the chapter. A new chapter may be added to the title to which it relates. New titles may be inserted in the title arrangement where openings have been reserved. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0203; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.050 - Vested rights. 
    Nothing in this code shall be so construed as to impair any vested right or valid obligation existing when it takes effect. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0402; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.060 - Franchises. 
    Ordinances heretofore adopted granting any franchise, right-of-way, easement, or contract shall not be affected by this code. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0403; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.070 - Location of poles and wires. 
    Ordinances in effect at the date of enactment of this code and relating to location of electric light, telephone, and telegraph poles and wires shall not be affected by this code. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0404; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.080 - Bonds. 
    Ordinances in effect at the date of enactment of this code and providing for the issuance of bonds shall not be affected by this code. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0405; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.090 - Appropriations. 
    Ordinances in effect at the date of enactment of this code providing for appropriations shall not be affected by this code. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0406; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.100 - Repeal. 
    All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this code or relating to the subject matter of this code and in reenactment as a part of this code, except as stated in this chapter, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0407; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.110 - Publication. 
    This code shall be printed and published in book form and shall take effect as provided by law. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0408; April 24, 1950). 
1.04.120 - Severability. 
    Should any section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this code be declared invalid or unconstitutional for any reason, the remainder of this code shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. 483 § 19.0401, 1950). 
1.04.130 - Penalty for violations. 
    Except as in this code otherwise specifically provided, any person or persons, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this code, or failing to comply with any of the provisions thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars or by imprisonment for a period of not exceeding thirty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Whenever any person shall, as clerk, servant, agent or employee of any other person, or of a firm or corporation, violate any of the provisions of this code, he shall be deemed guilty as a principal and shall be punished as herein provided. Each and every violation of the provisions of this code shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1692, 1993). 
(Ord. No. 2075, 2010) 
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND CITY GOVERNMENT 
Chapter 2.04 - GOVERNING BODY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Form of government and changes of form - See SDC 45.04, and SDC 45.0501 as amended by Chapter 245 of Session Laws of 1957; For officers generally see SDC 45.11; Provisions for acting president when mayor unable to perform duties authorized by statute-See SDC 45.0404 and 45.0808. 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ords. 483, 826 and 949. 

2.04.010 - Establishment. 
    The governing body of the city shall be established by the qualified electors of the city as to the form of municipal government in the city and in accordance with the statutes of the state. 
(Ord. 1726 (part), 1994). 
2.04.020 - Duties and term of office. 
(a)  The duties of the governing body and its members shall be determined by the form of municipal government approved by the qualified electors of the city and as prescribed for the various forms of municipal government in accordance with the statutes of the state and as prescribed by the ordinances of the city. 
(b)  The term of office for all members of the governing board shall be four years. The four-year terms shall commence with governing board members elected in 2014. In order to effectuate the change to the number of years within a term, in the 2014 municipal election, one commissioner of the governing board shall be elected to a three-year term and one commissioner shall be elected to a four-year term, in the 2015 municipal election one commissioner shall be elected to a four-year term, in the 2016 municipal election one commissioner and the mayor shall be elected to four-year terms, and in 2017 one commissioner shall be elected to a four-year term. The effective date of this provision is January 1, 2014. 
(Ord. 1726 (part), 1994). 
(Ord. No. 2123-2-5, 1-28-2013) 
2.04.030 - Compensation. 
    The compensation for the governing body and its members shall be set forth in the adopted certified pay schedule of the city and shall be provided for by the annual governing board budget and annual appropriation ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. 1726 (part), 1994). 
2.04.040 - Regular board meetings. 
    The board of commissions of the city shall meet in regular meetings at the hour of five-thirty p.m. on Monday of each week at city hall, except that if the regular meeting day has been deemed a legal holiday pursuant to Section 3.02.002(G), the weekly meeting shall not be held unless otherwise scheduled. If there is no quorum present the regular meeting shall be adjourned until the next day at the same time and place. 
(Ord. 2029, 2007: Ord. 1774, 1996: Ord. 1726 (part), 1994). 
2.04.050 - Special meetings. 
    Under the mayor and four commissioner form of municipal government, special meetings may be called by the mayor or by any two commissioners. The special meeting notice shall be written and must state the place, date and time of said special meeting, and must also state the purpose and matters that will be considered at said special meeting. Such notice shall be given to each member of the board and a signed copy of such notice by each member of the board present at said special meeting shall be filed with and become an official part of such special meeting proceedings. No other matter than the matter stated in the notice of the special meeting shall be considered at such special meeting. 
(Ord. 1726 (part), 1994). 
2.04.060 - Notice of special meetings. 
    The city finance officer shall issue a written notice for each special meeting stating by what authority the meeting is called and stating the place, time, date, purpose and matter or matters to be considered. Such notice shall be served by the police department personnel upon each member of the governing body then in the city at least two hours before the hour specified for such meeting, provided however, that if all members of the governing body are present at the meeting place prior to the hour specified for such meeting, no notice thereof shall be required to be delivered to each member. In lieu thereof, a copy of such notice signed by all board members present shall be filed as stated in Section 2.04.050. 
(Ord. 1726 (part), 1994). 
2.04.070 - Mayor's appointments. 
(a)  It shall be the mayor's duty to make all appointments with the approval of a majority vote of the governing body to the following appointed boards, commissions and committees: 
City parks and recreation board City planning commission City board of library trustees City safety council City board of appeals City airport board Electrical board Civil service board Community improvement commission Firemen's pension board Golf course commission Housing & redevelopment board Lake & riverfront committee Correction center management committee  
and any other board, commission or committee that may be established hereafter. 
(b)  All appointments shall commence on June first and expire on May thirty-first unless the appointment is a replacement appointment for a formerly appointed appointee. 
(Ord. 1726 (part), 1994). 
2.04.080 - Acting mayor. 
    In the event the mayor is unable to perform the duties of his office by reason of absence or sickness, the members of the governing body shall appoint by a majority vote of all members thereof, one of its members to act in the mayor's absence or sickness, whose official Title shall be "Acting Mayor of the Governing Board." The member so appointed shall be invested with all the powers and perform all the duties of the mayor during such sickness or absence. 
(Ord. 1726 (part), 1994). 
2.04.090 - Oath of office and loyalty oath. 
    Any person elected as a member of the governing body at an annual or special city election shall before assuming his official duties as a member of the governing body, be duly sworn in by an official of the city government and be required to take and subscribe an oath or affirmation of office and a loyalty oath as required by the statutes of the state. 
(Ord. 1726 (part), 1994). 
Chapter 2.08 - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Prior history: Ords 1340, 1187, 1176, 1175, 1138, 826, 483. 
State Law reference- Appointment and duties of municipal officers - See SDC 45.11 and amendments thereto. 
Cross reference- Bureau of fire prevention - See Ch. 19.08 of this code; Board of adjustment - See Ch. 23.01 of this code; Police department - See Ch. 3.12 of this code; Fire department - See Ch. 3.16 of this code; Water department - See Ch. 21.16 of this code; Park and recreation board - See Ch. 11.06 of this code; Planning and zoning commission - See Ch. 23.04 of this code; City health officer - See Ch. 6.04 of this code; City engineer - See Ch. 15.12 of this code; Building inspector - See Ch. 18.04 of this code; Electrical inspector - See Ch. 18.16 of this code; Board of plumbing examiners - See Ch. 18.20 of this code; Airport board - See Ch. 13.04 of this code; Retirement of appointive officers - See Ch. 3.08 of this code; Public shelter manager - See Ch. 17.04 of this code; Civil service organization - See Ch. 3.04 of this code; Traffic equipment department - See Ch. 16.32 of this code; Personnel generally - See Title 3 of this code. 

2.08.010 - Appointment of officers. 
    There shall be appointed by the governing body of the city, on the first Monday of May every year, a finance officer, deputy finance officer, city administrator, chief of police and deputy chief of police, city engineer, volunteer fire chief, and such other appointive officers as may be provided by ordinance which appointments shall be by majority vote of the mem bers of the duly elected governing body and who shall hold office until the first Monday of May of each year following their appointment or until their successors have been appointed and qualified as determined at a regular meeting of the governing body and by a majority vote of all members of the governing body. 
(Ord. 1771 (part), 1996). 
2.08.020 - Bond and oaths of appointive officers. 
    All appointive officers before entering upon the discharge of their duties, shall take and subscribe an oath or affirmation of office and sign a loyalty oath as prescribed by the statutes of the State of South Dakota and furnish bond in the required sum conditioned upon the faithful performance of their duties and to pay over and deliver all money and property coming into their hands by virtue of their office functions according to law, which bonds shall be subject to approval by the governing body. Such bond shall cover the period of appointment and be subject to renewal on an annual basis. 
(Ord. 1771 (part), 1996). 
2.08.030 - Officers' and employees' salaries. 
    The salaries of all appointive officers, employees regular or part-time, travel allowance and other pertinent items related to pay and allowance shall be provided for by resolution or in the annually adopted certified pay schedule of the city. Such salaries and allowances shall be provided for in each department's annual budget and be provided for in the annual appropriation ordinance of the city. Salaries of all city personnel shall be paid in accordance with a resolution adopted by the governing body relative to pay periods. 
(Ord. 1771 (part), 1996). 
(Ord. No. 2138-2-6, 12-30-2013) 
2.08.040 - Duties of appointive officers. 
    All appointive officers shall perform all the duties of their offices and department functions as prescribed by statutes of the State of South Dakota, and such other duties as may from time to time be prescribed by ordinances of the City of Huron or as directed by the governing board and members thereof which are not defined in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1771 (part), 1996). 
2.08.050 - City finance officer's duties. 
    The city finance officer is the official recording officer of the City of Huron and has the custody of all official documents and records not assigned to some other officer. He shall attend all meetings of the governing body and keep a record of all official proceedings. He shall draw and countersign all bonds, warrants and keep an accurate account of the city's indebtedness, countersign all contracts, certificates of work, ordinances and official documents of the city. He shall keep an accurate record of all receipts into the various cash funds and various departments as to function, activity, character and object. He shall audit, adjust and countersign all claim vouchers against all city departments and accounts before being presented to the governing board. He shall audit and compile the various department payrolls into a combined city payroll, certify all delinquent special assessment payments to the Beadle County auditor's office annually and keep an accurate record of all special assessment roll payments. He shall compile a proposed budget and appropriation ordinance for the next fiscal year based on available cash on hand, anticipated revenue and taxing ability of the city before being presented to the governing body for adoption. He shall supervise the accounting system or records for all departments and officers of the city in accordance with the recommendations of the State Department of Audits and Accounts. As of December 31st each year, he shall compile a report showing the financial condition of the city. He shall conduct and supervise all city annual and special elections. He shall issue all city licenses and permits as prescribed by city ordinances. He shall safeguard and keep the official seal of the city and perform as secretary to the various boards and commissions of the city. He shall prepare official documents, such as notice to bidders, notice of all public hearings, city election notices and proceedings, ordinances, resolutions, official minutes, and perform such other administrative duties of the office and its functions. The city finance officer shall receive and keep an accurate account by funds of all cash including taxes, licenses, permit fees, fines, special assessments, water bills and all other income from all sources for the City of Huron. He shall keep an accurate bond and interest record. He shall call in and provide payment for all general obligation, revenue and special assessment bonds and interest coupons when due or callable, keep an accurate record and account of all special assessment roll payments and send out special assessment roll notices when annual special assessment payments are due. He shall collect all fees and issue receipts for all licenses, permits, water bills, special assessments, material or damage billings, fines, rentals, parking meters, municipal court and all other miscellaneous revenues. He shall process all parking meter money collections for proper bank depositing. He shall supervise water meter billing, cut-offs, new service accounts, water meter deposits, water meter sales and service. He shall compile daily reports on bank cash balances, monthly report of all cash receipts and disbursements by funds. He shall allocate all revenues and receipts into their proper and assigned funds in accordance with and in the designated sum or percentage as authorized by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city of Huron. He shall maintain adequate collateral for the city bank accounts and perform such other duties that are required by the functions of the office or may be prescribed by ordinance or by direction of the governing body. 
(Ord. 1771 (part), 1996). 
2.08.060 - City attorney's duties. 
    The city attorney at request of the governing body or any officer of the city shall furnish an opinion on any matter relating to the affairs of the city or the duties of any city officer. He shall conduct the prosecution for violation of all city ordinances, represent the city in all court actions and perform other professional services related to his office as requested by the governing body. He shall attend all regular and special meetings of the governing body and attend regular and special meetings of all other city boards, commissions and committees when requested and necessary. He shall prepare any ordinance, resolution or legal document, requested by the governing body, review all ordinances, resolutions, contracts, bonds, leases, agreements and other legal documents to ascertain whether or not they are in legal and proper form and cover the subject matter intended, and act as legal advisor for all departments within the city municipal government. 
(Ord. 1771 (part), 1996). 
2.08.070 - City planner's duties. 
    The city planner shall be directly responsible to the mayor and shall organize the efforts of his office as so ordered by the mayor. He shall perform any and all duties requested of him by the urban renewal agency. He shall act as the secretary of the planning and zoning commission and perform all duties required as such, but shall not be a member thereof. As the duly appointed and acting secretary of the planning and zoning commission, he shall be the zoning administrator and perform the duties of said zoning administrator as provided in Section 23.04.012. He shall work with and shall be under the direction of the planning and zoning commission of the city. 
(Ord. 1771 (part), 1996). 
2.08.080 - Duties and responsibilities of city administrator. 
    The city administrator shah provide medium term and long term planning and coordination of all services provided by the city of Huron. He shall submit recommendations to the city commission, with facts and advice, on matters of policy, as a basis for making decisions and setting community goals for the future of Huron. He shall administer Huron's Comprehensive Plan, advise the city commission on future needs of the city, and inform the community on municipal affairs. He shall provide advice and assistance to the city commission and department heads on changing federal and state regulations affecting municipal services. He shall provide liaison to the city planning commission and housing and redevelopment commission. He shall encourage communications between the citizens of Huron and municipal officials. He shall emphasize friendly and courteous service to the public. He shall seek improvement in the quality and image of municipal services, and he shall complete special projects or duties as assigned by the city commission. 
(Ord. 1771 (part), 1996). 
2.08.090 - Destruction of records. 
    The city finance officer is authorized at his discretion in accordance with the statutes of the State of South Dakota to destroy duplicate water bills, paid claim vouchers, cancelled and paid warrants, duplicate city treasurer receipts, duplicate treasurer's special assessment tax receipts, poll books, voters registration lists and miscellaneous petitions not pertaining to public improvements. Obsolete insurance policies, licenses and permit bonds, reports, requests and miscellaneous items not required for permanent record purposes by the city may be destroyed within a reasonable time after they have served their intent and purpose. 
(Ord. 1771 (part), 1996). 
Chapter 2.20 - WARDS AND ELECTION PRECINCTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Division into wards - See SDC 45.0404. 

2.20.010 - Boundaries of wards and precincts. 
    The city of Huron is divided into nine wards and nine precincts, as follows: 
A.  First Ward - First Precinct. 
    That portion of the city which lies north of the Chicago Northwestern Railway tracks west of Dakota Avenue North and north of Center Street East on the east side of Dakota Avenue North extended to the city limit line is designated as the First Ward - First Precinct. 
B.  Second Ward - First Precinct. 
    That portion of the city which lies west of Dakota Avenue South, north of Fifth Street S.W., east of Nevada Avenue S.W. and south of a portion of the Chicago Northwestern Railway tracks is designated as the Second Ward - First Precinct. 
C.  Third Ward - First Precinct. 
    That portion of the city which lies west of Dakota Avenue South, north of Ninth Street S.W., thence north on Minnesota Avenue to Sixth Street S.W., thence east on Sixth Street S.W. to Nevada Avenue S.W., thence north on Nevada Avenue S.W. to Fifth Street S.W. and south of Fifth Street S.W. is designated as the Third Ward - First Precinct. 
D.  Fourth Ward - First Precinct. 
    That portion of the city which lies east of Dakota Avenue South, south of Center Street East, west of the east city limit line and north of Sixth Street S.E. is designated as the Fourth Ward - First Precinct. 
E.  Fifth Ward - First Precinct. 
    That portion of the city which lies east of Dakota Avenue South, south of Sixth Street S.E., west of the east city limit line and north of Eleventh Street S.E. is designated as the Fifth Ward - First Precinct. 
F.  Sixth Ward - First Precinct. 
    That portion of the city that lies west of Dakota Avenue South, south of Ninth Street S.W., east of Minnesota Avenue S.W., north of Thirteenth Street S.W., produced due east through Breaburn Park (residential street numbers will prevail), to Dakota Avenue South is designated as the Sixth Ward - First Precinct. 
G.  Seventh Ward - First Precinct. 
    That portion of the city that lies east of Dakota Avenue South, south of Eleventh Street S.E. and bounded by the city limits on the east and south side to Dakota Avenue South is designated as the Seventh Ward - First Precinct. 
H.  Eighth Ward - First Precinct. 
    That portion of the city that lies west of Dakota Avenue South, south of Thirteenth Street S.W., produced due west through Breaburn Park (residential street numbers will prevail), east of Minnesota Avenue S.W. and bounded by the city limits on the west and south to Dakota Avenue South, is hereby designated as the Eighth Ward-First Precinct. 
I.  NINTH WARD-FIRST PRECINCT: 
    That portion of the city that lies south of a portion of the Chicago Northwestern Railway tracks, west of Nevada Avenue S. W. to Sixth Street S. W., thence west on Sixth Street S. W. to Minnesota Avenue S. W., thence south on Minnesota Avenue S. W. to Fifteenth Street S. W. and bounded on the west by the city limits is designated as the Ninth Ward-First Precinct. (Ord. 483 § 9.0401, as amended by Ord. 773; October 2, 1961). 
2.20.020 - Voting precincts. 
    Each ward in the City of Huron shall constitute an election precinct, except as otherwise provided and each ward within the city has only one voting precinct. (Ord. 483 § 9.0402, as amended by Ord. 773; October 12, 1961). 
Chapter 2.28 - CONTINUITY OF GOVERNMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Note- Authorized by Chapter 285, Session Laws of 1961. 

2.28.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Continuity of Government Ordinance of the City of Huron, South Dakota." 
(Ord. 788 § 1; April 23, 1962). 
2.28.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise clearly indicates: 
    UNAVAILABLE shall mean either that a vacancy in office exists and there is no deputy authorized to exercise all of the powers and discharge the duties of the office, or that the lawful incumbent of the office (including any deputy exercising the powers and discharging the duties of an office because of a vacancy) and his duly authorized deputy are absent or unable, for physical, mental or legal reasons, to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office. 
    ATTACK shall mean any attack or series of attacks by an enemy of the United States causing, or which may cause, substantial damage or injury to civilian property or persons in the United States in any manner, by sabotage or by the use of bombs, missiles, shellfire, or atomic, radiological, chemical, bacteriological, or biological means or other weapons or processes. 
    DULY AUTHORIZED DEPUTY shall mean a person who is presently authorized to perform all of the functions, exercise all of the powers and discharge all of the duties of an office in the event the office is vacant or at such times as it lacks administration due to the death, absence or disability of the incumbent officer. 
    EMERGENCY INTERIM SUCCESSOR shall mean a person designated pursuant to this chapter for possible temporary succession to the powers and duties, but not the office, of a city officer in the event that such officer or any duly authorized deputy is unavailable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office. 
(Ord. 788 § 2; April 23, 1962). 
2.28.030 - Emergency interim successors-Designation, status, qualifications and terms. 
A.  ELECTIVE OFFICERS. Within thirty days after first entering upon the duties of his office, the mayor, each member of the governing body, and the municipal judge of this city shall designate such number of emergency interim successors to his office and specify their rank in order of succession so that there will be not less than three nor more than seven emergency interim successors for the office. 
B.  APPOINTIVE OFFICERS. The governing body shall within the time specified in subsection A of this section, in addition to any duly authorized deputy, designate for appointive officers including the chief of police, fire chief, city auditor, city treasurer, city attorney, city engineer, city assessor, and city health officer such number of emergency interim successors to these officers and specify their rank in order of succession after any duly authorized deputy so that there will be not less than three nor more than seven duly authorized deputies or emergency interim successors or combination thereof for each officer. 
C.  REVIEW OF DESIGNATIONS. The incumbent in the case of those elective officers specified in subsection A of this section, and the governing body in the case of those appointive officers specified in subsection B of this section, shall review and, as necessary, promptly revise the designations of emergency interim successors to insure that at all times there are at least three such qualified emergency interim successors or duly authorized deputies or any combination thereof for each officer specified. 
D.  QUALIFICATIONS. No person shall be designated or serve as an emergency interim successor unless he may, under the constitution and statutes of this state and the ordinances of this city, hold the office of the person to whose powers and duties he is designated to succeed, but no provision of any ordinance prohibiting an officer or employee of this city from holding another office shall be applicable to an emergency interim successor. 
E.  STATUS OF EMERGENCY INTERIM SUCCESSOR. A person designated as an emergency interim successor holds that designation at the pleasure of the designator, provided, that he must be replaced if removed. He retains this designation as emergency interim successor until replaced by another appointed by the authorized designator. 
(Ord. 788 § 3; April 23, 1962). 
2.28.040 - Emergency interim successors-Assumption of powers and duties. 
    If, in the event of attack, any officer named in subsections A and B of Section 2.28.030 of this chapter and any duly authorized deputy is unavailable, his emergency interim successor highest in rank in order of succession who is not unavailable shall, except for the power and duty to appoint emergency interim successors, exercise the powers and discharge the duties of such officer. Any emergency interim successor shall exercise these powers and discharge these duties only until such time as the lawful incumbent officer or any duly authorized deputy or an emergency interim successor higher in rank in order of succession exercises, or resumes the exercise of, the powers and discharge of the duties of the office, or until, where an actual vacancy exists, a successor is appointed to fill such vacancy or is elected and qualified as provided by law. 
(Ord. 788 § 4; April 23, 1962). 
2.28.050 - Recording and publication. 
    The name, address and rank in order of succession of each duly authorized deputy shall be filed with the city auditor and each designation, replacement, or change in order of succession of an emergency interim successor shall become effective when the designator files with the city auditor the successor's name, address and rank in order of succession. The city auditor shall keep on file all such data regarding duly authorized deputies and emergency interim successors and it shall be open to public inspection. 
(Ord. 788 § 5; April 23, 1962). 
2.28.060 - Formalities of taking office. 
    At the time of their designation, emergency interim successors shall take such oath and do such other things, if any, as may be required to qualify them to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office to which they may succeed. 
(Ord. 788 § 6; April 23, 1962). 
2.28.070 - Quorum and vote requirements. 
    In the event of an attack, (1) quorum requirements for the governing body shall be suspended, and (2) where the affirmative vote of a specified proportion of members for approval of an ordinance, resolution or other action would otherwise be required, the same proportion of those voting thereon shall be sufficient. 
(Ord. 788 § 7; April 23, 1962). 
Title 3 - PERSONNEL 
Chapter 3.02 - PERSONNEL REGULATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2090, adopted Jan. 31, 2011 and effective Jan. 1, 2011, amended Ch. 3.02 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 3.02, §§ 3.02.002-3.02.036, pertained to the same subject matter. See the Table of Disposition of Ordinances and the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List for complete derivation. 

3.02.002 - Definitions. 
A.  "Appointive authority" means the board of city commissioners. 
B.  "Board" means the governing body or a duly appointed board. 
C.  "Commissioner in charge" means the elected commission of the board of commissioners in charge of a particular department or departments. 
D.  "Day of compensation" means a day off in exchange for an extra day worked over the regular schedule or in exchange for working a holiday 
E.  "Employee" means any person employed by the city. This definition shall be retroactive to July 1, 2015. 
F.  "Full-time Employee" means an employee who has completed their probationary period and been granted full-time status. 
G.  "Funeral leave" means leave paid by the city without the use of sick, vacation or compensatory leave. 
H.  "Immediate family member" means spouse, children including stepchildren, brothers, sisters and parents. Including step brothers, sisters and parents. 
I.  "Legal holidays" means New Year's Day, Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, President's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Native American Day, Veteran's Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day. Christmas Eve Day: When Christmas Eve is on a Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday the last four (4) hours of the employee's work shift is deemed a holiday. 
J.  "Officers" means those employees exempt from civil service rules or regulations. 
K.  "Outside immediate family member" means son-in-law; father-in-law; mother-in-law; brother-in-law; sister-in-law; daughter-in-law; grandchildren; grandparents; and grandparents-in-law. Including step-grandchildren and step-grandparents. 
L.  "Part-time-PT" means an employee whose normal schedule of work is less than one thousand forty (1,040) hours in any one (1) year. 
M.  "Probation" means the term of employment or probationary period in which an employee works before receiving status as a full-time employee. 
N.  "Promotion" means an advancement of an employee to a higher paying position which requires a thirty-day trial period. 
O.  "Probationary Employee" means an employee who has not yet completed their probationary period and been granted full-time status. 
P.  "Seasonal employee" means an individual whose employment is fixed at the time of employment, not to exceed four (4) consecutive months. The employment may be extended at four (4) consecutive month segments, provided the total period of employment does not exceed one (1) year. Seasonal employee may be hired for the purpose of meeting staffing shortages, seasonal needs, staffing short-term projects and relieving for employee absences, or is irregular and casual. 
Q.  "Seniority" means the total years of continuous service with the city by an employee. 
R.  "Twenty-four-hour shift worker" means any person employed by the city on a full-time job basis whose normal working day is a twenty-four-hour shift. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011; Ord. No. 2164-3-88, 8-31-2015) 
3.02.004 - Salaries for mayor, commissioners and part-time city officials. 
    The base salary for the mayor, commissioners and part-time appointed officials of the city shall be as set forth in the annual certified pay schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.006 - Position classification plan. 
    A position classification plan, prepared by the governing body and filed with the city finance officer, shall apply to all personnel of the city. It shall constitute a description of the duties and responsibilities of each position. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.007 - Filling openings. 
A.  Filling an opening for a nonunion eligible position: when an opening occurs in an existing job classification or a new job classification under civil service, the position may be filled by the process identified in the civil service rules as those rules apply to nonunion positions. The position may be filled by transfer of existing employees, recall of employees on layoff or selection of new employees through the civil service procedure. An employee wishing to be considered for transfer to an open position shall apply for the position by completing a city job application to be submitted to human resources and will state the reasons why the employee wishes to transfer. Any employee transferring to a new position shall serve a probation period of thirty (30) days or one (1) year if the position is in the police department. 
B.  Filling an opening for a union eligible position: such opening will be filled according to the provisions of the union contract. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.008 - Compensation. 
A.  SALARY. 
(1)  Salaries for each position classification shall be set by the city commission through the annual certified pay schedule. The governing board shall designate in the certified pay schedule which classifications are eligible for overtime pay. 
(2)  Police Department Captains. 
(a)  Within every twenty-eight (28) day work cycle, police captains shall take eight (8) hours off without pay and for pay purposes each bi-weekly time sheet shall show four (4) hours without pay. 
(b)  Night differential pay: A police captain who works a night shift seven p.m. to seven a.m. (7 PM to 7 AM) shall receive, in addition to the employee's regular hourly wage as reflected in the pay scale, an amount equal to two and one-half percent (2.5%) of the employee's regular hourly wage. 
(3)  Fire Department-Twenty-seven (27) day schedule. Within every twenty-seven (27) day work cycle, employees shall take twelve (12) hours off without pay. 
B.  OVERTIME. 
(1)  Hours related to holiday pay, compensatory time, sick leave pay, and vacation leave pay but not worked shall be counted as hours worked for purposes of determining overtime pay for all employee groups listed below. All overtime must be approved by the employee's supervisor or reviewed by the city commissioner if the employee is supervised by a city commissioner. 
(2)  Overtime hours will be compensated as set forth below unless the hours worked over the employee's regular work day is the result of flex time scheduling pursuant to Ordinance Number 3.02.012. 
(a)  Non-exempt Non-Union employees. One and one-half (11/2) times the employee's regular hourly rate of pay shall be paid for all work performed in excess of forty (40) hours in any workweek. For employees who have a regular work shift of eight (8) hours, one and one-half (11/2) times the employee's regular hourly rate of pay shall be paid for all work performed in excess of eight (8) hours in a day. For employees who have a regular work shift other than eight (8) hours, one and one-half (11/2) times the employee's regular hourly rate of pay shall be paid for all work performed in excess of the employee's regular work shift. Hours worked in excess of the employee's regular workday for which the employee receives overtime pay shall not be counted for purposes of determining overtime in excess of forty (40) hours per week. 
(b)  Police Department Captains and Dispatchers. Police Department Captains and Dispatchers shall be paid overtime at the rate of 1 1/2 times the employee's regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of eighty (80) hours in a two (2) week period. Overtime shall be paid at the rate of one and one-half (11/2) times the employee's regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of the regular twelve (12) hour shift. 
(c)  Fire Department employees. Fire Department employees shall be paid overtime at the rate of one and one-half (11/2) times the employee's regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of the regular twenty-four (24) hour shift. 
(3)  The amendments to Section B. of Section 3.02.008 shall be effective December 21, 2008. 
C.  CALL BACK REPORTING PAY. 
(1)  Call back reporting pay for non-exempt non union employees. Any employee who is called in to work outside of their regular shift, or schedule, shall be guaranteed at least one (1) hour of work or one (1) hour of pay at the rate of time and one-half (1/2) their regular rate of pay, except that if an employee is called to work, under the conditions mentioned in this section, between the hours of ten p.m. and six a.m. (10 PM and 6 AM) shall be guaranteed at least two (2) hours of work or two (2) hours of pay at the rate of time and one-half (1/2) their regular rate of pay. Any employee who is called in to work on Saturday, Sunday or a holiday, at any hour, shall be guaranteed the two (2) hours. This provision shall not apply to employees who are called in to work prior to the start of their regularly scheduled shift and work into and throughout their regularly scheduled shift. 
(2)  Police Department Captain Call Back Reporting Pay. 
(a)  A Police Captain who, on less than eight (8) hours notice, is required to report to work outside of their regular shift or schedule shall be guaranteed at least one (1) hour of work or one (1) hour of pay at the rate of time and one-half (11/2) their regular rate of pay, except that if a captain is called to work outside their regular shift or schedule between the hours of nine p.m. and 5 a.m. (9:00 PM and 5:00 AM), or a night shift police captain is called to work outside of their regular shift or schedule between nine p.m. and 5 a.m. (9:00 PM and 5:00 AM), they shall be guaranteed at least two (2) hours of work or two (2) hours of pay at the rate of time and one-half (11/2) of their regular rate of pay. 
(b)  Police Captain SWAT team members who, on less than eight (8) hours notice, are called in to work outside their regular shift shall be guaranteed at least two (2) hours of work or two (2) hours of pay at the rate of time and one-half (11/2) of their regular rate of pay. 
(c)  Court Appearance Pay: Should a police captain be in court outside his/her regularly scheduled work hours to testify on a work related matter shall receive overtime for actual court time or two (2) hours, whichever is greater, during an eight (8) hour period. The police captain may elect to receive overtime pay or compensatory time off in lieu of overtime pay. There shall be no court appearance pay if the court hearing was cancelled and the police captain was so informed prior to arriving at court for the scheduled appearance. 
(3)  Fire Department Employee Call Back Reporting Pay. A fire department employee who is called in to work outside of their regular shift, or schedule, shall be guaranteed at least one (1) hour of work or one (1) hour of pay at the rate of time and one-half (11/2) their regular rate of pay. 
D.  COMPENSATORY TIME. 
(1)  If any employee works overtime the employee may, with the approval of his supervisor, choose to take compensatory time instead of overtime pay. Compensatory time shall be awarded at the rate of one and one-half (11/2) hours of compensatory time for each hour of overtime worked. Compensatory time will only be computed in one (1) hour increments. 
(2)  Employees may accrue up to forty-eight (48) hours of compensatory time off. Upon an employee accumulating the maximum number of hours of compensatory time off all additional overtime shall be compensated as overtime pay and the employee shall not be entitled to accrue additional compensatory time off until such time as the employee has less than forty-eight (48) hours of accrued compensatory time off. 
(3)  The employee's intent to take compensatory time instead of overtime pay must be made known prior to the payroll submission date in which the overtime is worked. 
(4)  The scheduling of the hours to be taken off shall be at the option of the employee, subject to supervisor approval. When an employee requests compensatory time off, the request to take compensatory time off shall be granted provided the time requested does not unreasonably disrupt the department operations. 
(5)  Non-exempt Non Union employees taking compensatory time off within a pay period may also accrue new compensatory time off in that same pay period. At the employee's option, any overtime earned during such a pay period may either be paid out or accrued for future compensatory time off; with any accrual not to exceed the provisions of Subsection 3.02.008 D.(2). 
(6)  Comp time rate of pay shall be at the employee's regular hourly rate of pay at the time the comp time is taken. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.011 - Seasonal or temporary employee's pay. 
    Employees employed as seasonal or temporary employees shall be paid at the rate established for such positions by the governing body. All departments employing seasonal or temporary employees under this section shall file a copy of the pay scale for such employees, when employed, at the city finance office. Such employees shall be paid on an hourly basis and shall not be paid for holidays, sick leave, vacations or be eligible for any other city employment benefits, other than those required by federal law or state statute. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.012 - Posting work schedules. 
    For nonunion employees, work schedules showing the employee's shifts, work days and hours, shall be posted on bulletin boards in the respective departments at least fourteen (14) days in advance. Posted work schedules shall not be changed without the employer notifying the employees affected. Flex schedule is a mutually agreed upon change between the employee and supervisor in the regular work schedule and used within the same work week. Police and Fire employees can flex schedule within their work period. Work schedules for union eligible employees will be posted according to the provisions of the union contract. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011; Ord. No. 2177-3-89, 8-15-2016) 
3.02.013 - Probationary period. 
(a)  Any nonunion employee who is hired to fill a full-time position will work a one thousand forty (1,040) regular hour probationary period unless the employee works in the police department. A person employed in the police department will work a two thousand eighty (2,080) regular hour probationary period. 
(b)  An employee who is hired to fill a full-time position in the Fire Department will work a one thousand three hundred seventy-eight (1,378) regular hour probationary period. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.014 - Health insurance. 
    Persons employed by the city of Huron are eligible to participate in a health insurance program arranged by the city. Employees may participate if they desire. This health insurance is provided with the following provisions: 
A.  City employees may elect to enroll in the health insurance group arranged by the city of Huron; 
B.  Effective in 2014, the city will pay for employee single coverage for whichever option within the health insurance program arranged by the city that an employee chooses; 
C.  Employees who choose to participate in the health insurance program will be enrolled in the insurance program on the first day of the month following thirty (30) calendar days of full time employment; 
D.  Health insurance is available only for full-time employees of the city of Huron; 
E.  The employee's health insurance with the city of Huron will be canceled as of the last day of the month with the city whether the employee resigns, retires, quits or is discharged. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011; Ord. No. 2133-3-85, 12-23-2013) 
3.02.015 - Term life insurance. 
    Persons employed by the city of Huron are eligible to participate in a term life insurance program arranged by the city. Employees may participate if they desire. This term life insurance is provided with the following provisions. 
A.  Full-time employees may participate if they desire in the life insurance program arranged by the city; 
B.  The city will pay half and the employee will pay half of the term life insurance for the coverage selected; 
C.  Employees who choose to participate in the term life insurance coverage will be enrolled in the life insurance program on the first day of the month following thirty (30) calendar days of employment; 
D.  The employee's life insurance with the city of Huron will be canceled as of the employee's last day of employment with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.016 - Longevity pay. 
    For all employees hired before January 1, 2000, upon five (5) years of continuous service five dollars ($5.00) per month for each year's service (or twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per month) and in addition five dollars ($5.00) per month for each year's service thereafter. Employees hired before January 1, 2000, shall receive the amount the employee is currently receiving for longevity pay but shall not be eligible to receive any future increases in longevity pay after December 31, 2006. Employees hired on or after January 1, 2000, shall not be eligible for longevity pay. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.018 - Travel expenses. 
    Allowance for travel expenses shall be at rates established by resolution of the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.022 - Paid leaves of absence. 
    Leaves of absence with pay shall be granted for the following purposes and under the following conditions: 
A.  VACATIONS. Civil service employees (including department heads) shall accrue paid vacation hours each pay period and be granted vacation leave with pay based on the date the employee was hired. An employee shall be eligible to accrue vacation hours during their probationary period and begin taking accrued vacation hours with pay upon completion of their probation period. Vacation hours shall be granted to all employees who qualify as follows: 
1.  Employees on eight (8) hour shifts: 
(a)  Group 1-During the first year of employment, forty (40) hours; 
(b)  Group 2-After one (1) year of continuous service, eighty (80) hours; 
(c)  Group 3-After seven (7) years of continuous service, one hundred twenty (120) hours; 
(d)  Group 4-After fifteen (15) years of continuous service, one hundred sixty (160) hours; 
(e)  Group 5-After twenty-five (25) years of continuous service, two hundred (200) hours. Employees hired on or after January 1, 2006, shall not be eligible for Group 5 annual vacation hours; 
(f)  Employees on a two thousand eighty (2,080) hour per year work schedule and hired by the city prior to January 1, 2006, shall be able to accrue up to a maximum of two hundred (200) vacation hours each year. Employees hired on or after January 1, 2006, shall be able to accrue up to a maximum of two hundred (200) vacation hours. 
2.  Employees on twenty-four (24) hour shifts: 
(a)  Group 1-During the first year of employment, fifty-six (56) hours; 
(b)  Group 2-After one (1) year of continuous service, one hundred twelve (112) hours; 
(c)  Group 3 - After seven (7) years of continuous service, one hundred sixty-eight (168) hours; 
(d)  Group 4 - After fifteen (15) years of continuous service, two hundred twenty-four (224) hours; 
(e)  Group 5-After twenty-five (25) years of continuous service, two hundred eighty (280) hours. Employees hired on or after January 1, 2006, shall not be eligible for Group 5 annual vacation hours; 
(f)  Employees on a two thousand seven hundred fifty-six (2,756) hour per year work schedule and hired by the city prior to January 1, 2006, shall be able to accrue up to a maximum of two hundred eighty (280) hours each year. Employees hired on or after January 1, 2006, shall be able to accrue up to a maximum of two hundred eighty (280) vacation hours. 
3.  Vacation time shall accrue as follows: 
(a)  Employees on a two thousand eighty (2,080) hour per year work schedule: 
(1)  Group 1 shall be credited with 1.54 hours vacation per pay period. 
(2)  Group 2 shall be credited with 3.08 hours vacation per pay period. 
(3)  Group 3 shall be credited with 4.62 hours vacation per pay period. 
(4)  Group 4 shall be credited with 6.16 hours vacation per pay period. 
(5)  Group 5 shall be credited with 7.7 hours vacation per pay period. Employees hired on or after January 1, 2006, shall not be eligible for Group 5 annual vacation hours. 
(b)  Employees on a two thousand seven hundred fifty-six (2,756) hour per year work schedule: 
(1)  Group 1 shall be credited with 2.16 hours vacation per pay period. 
(2)  Group 2 shall be credited with 4.31 hours vacation per pay period. 
(3)  Group 3 shall be credited with 6.47 hours vacation per pay period. 
(4)  Group 4 shall be credited with 8.62 hours vacation per pay period. 
(5)  Group 5 shall be credited with 10.77 hours vacation per pay period. Employees hired on or after January 1, 2006, shall not be eligible for Group 5 annual vacation hours. 
4.  Any employee who resigns from his employment or is terminated shall be paid for all unused vacation time that may be due such employee at the time of resignation or termination. 
5.  In the event an employee dies, the full vacation pay due to the employee will be paid in the final payroll. 
6.  All employees shall make application for vacation leave on an approved leave request form to be signed by the superintendent or department head in charge of his department except when the employee is a superintendent or department head, then the vacation request shall be signed by the commissioner-in-charge or human resources and submitted to the finance office for record filing purposes. 
(a)  All department heads and superintendents shall post vacation periods for their respective departments. 
(b)  Vacations normally will be granted at the time requested by the employee, unless operational necessity requires full staff. If there is a dispute as to operational necessity, the dispute may be presented at Step 2 of the grievance procedure. 
(c)  Vacation requests shall be submitted during January and February for the current calendar year and shall be posted by March 30th. Employees are encouraged to make requests for their full vacation entitlement. For civil service employees, vacation requests for the calendar year within a department shall be approved based on seniority provided the request has been submitted by March 1st. After March 1st, seniority shall not be applicable in granting of vacation time. 
7.  Vacation pay shall be at the employee's regular hourly rate of pay at the time vacation is taken. 
8.  Credit for up to four (4) years of prior service with the city of Huron, another municipality, county, state or federal government or branch of the U.S. Armed Services may, at the discretion of the governing board, be granted for purposes of determining vacation at time of hire, retire/rehire, retiree health insurance eligibility, and initial placement on the pay scale and promotion eligibility, provided the prior experience was in a position of similar job responsibilities. Credit for the prior service shall not apply for purposes of scheduling of vacation. 
9.  Any employee who works during his vacation due to an emergency, (emergencies including but not limited to, weather conditions requiring or prohibiting work, natural disasters, equipment malfunction or breakage, or an unscheduled absence by another employee which results in the department head calling in an employee previously scheduled not to be at work due to a scheduled vacation) shall be paid at their regular hourly rate and allowed to reschedule their vacation hours commensurate with the hours worked during their vacation. 
B.  HOLIDAYS. All holidays, as defined in this chapter, shall be observed. 
1.  With the exception of Christmas Eve Day, whenever any of the aforementioned holidays falls on Sunday, the Monday following shall be observed as the holiday and whenever any of the aforementioned holidays fall on Saturday, the preceding Friday shall be observed as the holiday. 
2.  Compensation for holidays shall be as follows: 
(a)  An eligible employee, who normally works an eight (8) or ten (10) hour shift, shall receive eight (8) hours of pay at his regular rate of pay for each holiday on which he performs no work. If the work is performed on such recognized holiday, such employee shall be paid his holiday pay and in addition, shall be paid for all hours worked. Christmas Eve holiday is the last four (4) hours of the shift. 
(b)  An eligible employee, who normally works a twenty-four (24) hour shift, shall receive a day of compensation for all recognized holidays whether they do or do not perform work on the holiday. Employees shall accumulate substitute holiday hours at the rate of 9.24 hours per pay period (two hundred forty (240) holiday hours (10 x 24 hours) divided by twenty-six (26) pay periods) during calendar years when Christmas Eve is on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday and 9.39 hours per pay period (two hundred forty-four (244) holiday hours divided by twenty-six (26) pay periods) during calendar years when Christmas Eve is on a Monday through Thursday, inclusive, Christmas Eve holiday is four (4) hours. These employees may accumulate up to one hundred twenty (120) hours of substitute holiday hours. Upon having accumulated one hundred twenty (120) hours of substitute holiday hours the employee will not accrue additional substitute holiday hours during subsequent pay periods until the employee has less than one hundred twenty (120) hours of substitute holiday hours accumulated. Use of substitute holiday hours: 
(1)  Substitute holiday hours normally will be granted at the time requested by the employee, unless operational necessity prevents approval of the request. If there is a dispute as to operational necessity, the dispute may be presented at Step 2 of the grievance procedure. 
(2)  An employee may utilize/use substitute holiday hours only if the employee has accrued and accumulated the number of substitute leave hours requested as of the date of intended use. 
(3)  There shall be no holiday pay in lieu of substitute holiday hours. 
(4)  Actual accrual of substitute holiday hours will be adjusted based upon the number of holidays remaining in the calendar year of hire or termination of employment. 
(c)  Non-union police department employees who work twelve (12) hour shifts shall accumulate substitute holiday hours at the rate of 3.08 hours per pay period (eighty (80) hours divided by twenty-six (26) pay periods) during calendar years when Christmas Eve is on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday and 3.23 hours per pay period (eighty-four (84) hours divided by twenty-six (26) pay periods) when Christmas Eve is on a Monday through Thursday, inclusive. These employees may accumulate up to a maximum of forty (40) hours of substitute holiday hours. Actual accrual of substitute holiday hours will be adjusted based upon the number of holidays remaining in the calendar year of hire or termination of employment. 
3.  Employees shall be eligible for holiday pay or a day of compensation under the following conditions: 
(a)  The employee must be in active employment when the holiday occurs unless on sick leave; 
(b)  The employee performed the required work on the last scheduled shift for him prior to the holiday and first scheduled work shift for him after the holiday, unless excused by the employer; 
(c)  If an employee was scheduled to work on the holiday (because of continuous operations or because of an emergency) and refused to do so, no payment will be made for the holiday. 
4.  The maximum holiday hour limit requirement shall not apply should operational necessity require the employee to be on duty. The department head shall determine when operational necessity exists for purposes of this provision, subject to the approval of the department's commissioner. During the period of operational necessity, the department head or his/her designee may allow or require the employee to use either accumulated substitute holiday hours in lieu of vacation hours for vacation time scheduled prior to the declaration of operational necessity and/or to accrue additional substitute holiday hours provided. Should the employee accrue additional substitute holiday hours during the period of operational necessity the employee must use the additional substitute holiday hours within one hundred twenty (120) days after the department head and department commissioner have declared the operational necessity no longer exists. The department head and department commissioner shall establish such policies as necessary to effectuate section (b). 
5.  Any employee who resigns from his employment or is terminated, shall be paid for all unused holiday hours that may be due such employee at the time of resignation or termination. 
6.  Holiday pay shall be at the employee's regular hourly rate of pay at the time the holiday is taken. 
C.  SICK LEAVE. 
1.  An employee shall be eligible for sick leave pay under the following conditions: 
(a)  Has completed one thousand forty (1040) regular work hours to the city; 
(b)  Reports to his department head not later than the start of his normal starting time, unless in the judgment of the city, the circumstances surrounding the absence made such reporting impossible, in which event such report must be made as soon thereafter as possible. 
2.  Sick leave shall be credited and accumulated as follows: 
(a)  An employee who normally works two thousand eighty (2080) hours per year shall accrue sick leave hours at a rate of 3.7 hours per full pay period. Unused sick leave may be accumulated to a maximum of six hundred (600) hours. Employees hired on or before December 31, 2005, shall be exempt from the six hundred (600) hours maximum of accumulated sick leave and may accumulate one thousand two hundred (1,200) hours of accumulated sick leave. 
(b)  An employee who normally works two thousand seven hundred fifty-six (2,756) hours per year shall be credited with 5.17 hours of sick leave per full pay period. Unused sick leave may be accumulated to a maximum of eight hundred forty (840) hours. Employees hired on or before December 31, 2005, shall be exempt from the eight hundred forty (840) hours maximum of accumulated sick leave and may accumulate one thousand six hundred eighty (1,680) hours of accumulated sick leave. 
3.  If, and when, an employee voluntarily quits or is discharged from his employment, any unused sick leave shall not be paid out. 
4.  SICK LEAVE-RETIREMENT OR DEATH. 
(a)  Employees whose maximum accumulated sick leave is one thousand two hundred (1,200) hours, in the event an employee retires and is eligible for a retirement allowance under the South Dakota Retirement System or in case of the death of an employee, accrued and unused sick leave, but not in excess of three hundred sixty (360) hours shall be paid to the employee in the final payroll provided, however, that the employee has worked for the employer at least ten (10) years, and provided also, that the employee has seven hundred twenty (720) hours of his maximum allowable accrual hours still unused. 
(b)  Employees whose maximum accumulated sick leave is six hundred (600) hours of sick leave in the event of such retirement or in case of the death of an employee after ten (10) years employment with the city shall be paid up to one hundred eighty (180) hours of unused sick leave in the final payroll provided that the employee has three hundred sixty (360) hours of accumulated sick leave. 
(c)  An employee who normally works a twenty-four (24) hour shift and whose maximum accumulated sick leave is one thousand six hundred eighty (1,680) hours: in the event an employee retires and is eligible for a retirement allowance under the South Dakota Retirement System or in case of the death of an employee, unused sick leave shall be paid in the final payroll to the employee, but not in excess of five hundred four (504) hours of the maximum accrual; provided, however, that the employee has worked for the employer at least ten (10) years, and provided also, that the employee has at least one thousand eight (1,008) hours of his maximum allowable accrual hours still unused. 
(d)  An employee who normally works a twenty-four (24) hour shift and whose maximum accumulated sick leave is eight hundred forty (840) hours: in the event an employee retires and is eligible for a retirement allowance under the South Dakota Retirement System or in case of the death of an employee, unused sick leave shall be paid to the employee in the final payroll, but not in excess of two hundred fifty two (252) hours of the maximum accrual; provided, however, that the employee has worked for the employer at least ten (10) years, and provided also, that the employee has at least five hundred four (504) hours of his maximum allowable accrual hours still unused. 
5.  Sick leave may be used to the extent of the accrued and unused sick leave as follows: 
(a)  For an employee, who normally works an eight (8) hour shift, due to the illness of a member of the employee's immediate family, two (2) days of sick leave will be allowed for attendance upon a member of the immediate family requiring the care or attention of such employee. Two (2) additional days of sick leave may be taken by the employee if necessary. In the event additional days are taken, the employee shall notify his immediate supervisor by phone of his intention of taking the additional time off. If more than two (2) days are taken, the employee may be required to provide a written statement from the attending physician attesting to the necessity of the employee's presence with the family member. If such statement is requested and is either not made available, or is insufficient, in the judgment of the supervisor, sick leave pay for the additional two (2) days may be denied. Such denial shall be subject to the grievance procedure. More than four (4) days of sick leave time for illness in the immediate family must be approved by the commissioner in charge prior to taking the time off. 
(b)  For an employee, who normally works a twenty-four (24) hour shift, due to the illness of a member of the employee's immediate family, one (1) day of sick leave will be allowed for attendance upon a member of the immediate family requiring the care or attention of such employee. One (1) additional day of sick leave may be taken by the employee if necessary. In the event additional days are taken, the employee shall notify his immediate supervisor by phone of his intention of taking the additional time off. If more than one (1) day is taken, the employee may be required to provide a written statement from the attending physician attesting to the necessity of the employee's presence with the family member. If such statement is requested and is either not made available, or is insufficient, in the judgment of the supervisor, sick leave pay for the additional one (1) day may be denied. Such denial shall be subject to the grievance procedure. 
(c)  Employee illness, including doctor, dental and vision appointments. 
(d)  If the employee is eligible for Family Medical Leave Act leave, paid sick leave days shall be applied against the number of days (sixty (60) days within a calendar year) to which the employee is entitled pursuant to the Family Medical Leave Act. In no instance shall the employee be entitled to more sick leave days (paid and/or unpaid) than that afforded through accumulated paid sick leave or the twelve (12) weeks of FMLA leave, whichever is greater, for FMLA qualifying reasons. The employee, however, shall be required to use accumulated vacation time and then accrued compensatory time should the serious health condition continue beyond the accumulated paid sick leave. An FMLA policy has been adopted by the city. That policy is consistent with the federal law. Federal law imposed FMLA upon employers and therefore the topic has been preempted by law and is not subject to mandatory negotiations. The policy is included by reference in this chapter for the sole purpose of providing information regarding FMLA to employees. 
(e)  If an employee, accidentally injured on the job, qualifies for worker compensation pay, the city will pay the employee's share of group health and group life plan provided by the city. 
6.  Employees may be required to furnish a doctor's certificate or other acceptable evidence of illness in the event they are absent more than two (2) days in any calendar month. In the event that an employee is found to be abusing his sick leave privileges, he will be informed that all future sick leave must be substantiated by a doctor's certificate. 
D.  JURY LEAVE. 
1.  Any employee called for jury service will be paid the difference between all jury duty compensation they receive and their regular wages for each day of jury service. The employee must furnish the city with a certified statement from the court setting forth the date of jury service and payment received therefore. 
2.  Employees called for jury service are expected to work full time when not actually in court or doing something in connection with such service. 
E.  FUNERAL LEAVE. 
1.  An employee shall receive funeral leave for all scheduled work hours taken within seven (7) consecutive calendar days to attend the funeral of a member of the immediate family. 
2.  An employee may use two (2) consecutive calendar sick leave days for scheduled work days missed to allow the employee to attend the funeral of a family member outside the immediate family. 
3.  If an employee is to act as a pallbearer at a funeral on a regularly scheduled work day the employee shall receive one (1) day of funeral leave. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011; Ord. No. 2154-3-87, 1-12-2015; Ord. No. 2164-3-88, 8-31-2015) 
3.02.023 - Sick leave bank. 
    The recipient and the donors must be nonbargaining unit employees or police officers, sergeants or detectives. Participation in the sick leave bank will be voluntary. All new full time nonbargaining unit employees or police officers, sergeants or detectives may elect to enroll after the completion of one thousand forty (1,040) regular work hours. Employees, who are not participating in the sick leave bank, may elect to enroll from January 1st to January 31st of each year. These employees are ineligible to receive sick leave donations until July 1 of the year of enrollment. 
A.  An employee may receive donated leave if the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The employee is employed in a position for at least six (6) months; 
(2)  The employee has been certified by a physician as: 
(a)  Terminally ill and unable to return to work, or 
(b)  Suffering from illness or injury not subject to outside or third party reimbursement which prevents the employee from working for at least sixty (60) calendar days; 
(3)  The employee has made a written request for and obtained approval from the city to receive donated leave; 
(4)  The employee has exhausted all sick leave benefits, unused compensatory time, holidays and unused vacation leave. 
B.  Donated leave benefits cease after two thousand eighty (2,080) hours (twenty-four-hour shift employees' benefits cease after two thousand seven hundred fifty-six (2,756) hours) of donated leave have been used by an employee who is terminally ill, or after one thousand forty (1,040) hours (one thousand three hundred seventy-eight (1,378) hours for twenty-four-hour shift employees) of donated leave have been used by an employee who is suffering from illness or injury. 
C.  The rate of payment of donated leave is the employee's current rate of pay. Sick and vacation leave may not be earned by an employee on donated leave.
