D.  Each participating employee will contribute sixteen (16) hours (twenty-two (22) hours for twenty-four (24) hour shift employees) of sick leave in January of each year to the sick leave bank. The annual contribution will not occur when the sick leave bank balance of January 1st is greater than three thousand (3,000) hours. Once hours have been contributed, they may not be withdrawn even if the employee withdraws. 
E.  The use of sick leave bank benefits is subject to the approval by the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.024 - Unpaid leave of absence. 
    An employee may be granted an unpaid leave of absence upon approval of the city commission not to exceed twelve (12) consecutive months. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.025 - Military leave (reserve duty). 
    An employee who is a duly qualified member of the Reserve Component of the Armed Forces, who is a member of the Individual Ready Reserve, who is a member of an organized unit, and who in order to receive military training with the Armed Forces of the United States, or other service required by law, shall be entitled to a leave of absence and shall be returned to service, provided he is still able to perform the duties of his position without the loss of status, pay and seniority in accordance with Uniformed Services Employment And Reemployment Rights Act (USERRA). In case the taxable military pay received for military training with the armed forces of the United States is less than the employee's regular wages, the city shall pay the employee the difference up to a maximum of eighty (80) work hours per calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.026 - Layoff. 
A.  In the event it becomes necessary in the opinion of the City Commission to lay off employees, all probationary, seasonal and part-time employees in the affected department(s) shall be laid off before any full time personnel in that department are laid off. After all probationary, seasonal and part-time employees in the department are laid off and if it is necessary to lay off one (1) or more full-time employees, the full-time employee(s) shall be laid off after review and consideration of the following factors: continuous length of employment in the City, length of employment within the department, performance evaluations, licenses and certifications, training, and work experience. After consideration of the factors should it be determined that two (2) employees in the department have equal qualifications the City shall lay-off the department employee with the least seniority in the department. Full-time employees who are laid off pursuant to this provision shall be placed on lay-off status and entitled to recall privileges. Lay-off status and recall privileges do not apply to probationary, seasonal and part-time employees who are laid off pursuant to this provision. 
B.  Any employee whose job is eliminated will be placed on a lay off status in accordance with the terms of this section: 
(i)  Recall rights shall exist for a period of one (1) year from the date of lay-off. 
(ii)  An employee on lay-off status shall be recalled to employment provided the person can perform, at the time notice of recall is issued, the essential job functions for the position to which recall is issued. Should two (2) or more persons on lay-off status be able to perform the essential job functions for the position the person on lay-off status having the longest consecutive years of employment with the City shall be recalled. 
(iii)  Any laid off employee who fails to accept a full time position within seven (7) days after receiving written notice of recall will lose all seniority rights and forfeit all rights to be recalled by the City. 
(iv)  Any person on lay-off status who is not eligible for recall pursuant to [subsection] (ii) above may apply for an open position. 
(v)  A laid-off employee shall be responsible for keeping the City informed in writing as to his/her current address. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.028 - Disciplinary action and discharge. 
A.  Disciplinary action may include oral reprimand, written reprimand, suspension without pay or dismissal. No employee shall be disciplined or discharged without just cause. If just cause is determined, disciplinary action shall be reasonably related to the seriousness of the offense and the past record. 
B.  Before an employee may be disciplined for unsatisfactory work performance, he shall be given notice in writing outlining the areas of work performance that must be improved. The employee will then have a minimum of thirty (30) working days to improve the performance before further action is taken. If after thirty (30) days the work performance has not improved, the employer may take such action as may be determined appropriate, including suspension or dismissal. 
C.  In the event, by reason of unsatisfactory performance, or for any other just cause, the employer may suspend or dismiss any employee and will, within five (5) days, after taking such action, notify the employee of the specific reasons(s) for such action and will advise the employee of his right to appeal such action under Chapter 3.06 of this title. 
D.  The hearing may, at the employee's request, be open to the public. The civil service board's decision shall be binding upon both the employee and the employer. 
E.  Just causes for dismissal or suspension without pay, include, but are not limited to, those areas listed in this subsection. Any employee may be given lesser disciplinary treatment than suspension without pay or dismissal. 
1.  Theft from the employer; 
2.  In possession of or being under the influence of alcohol or an illegal drug while on the job (blood, breath or chemical test showing alcohol or illegal drugs within a person's system is prima facie evidence that the individual is under the influence of alcohol or illegal drugs); 
3.  Insubordination (which includes, but is not limited to, refusal to do the work as directed, lying, and disrespect shown to any other city employee, including department heads, and disrespect shown to a member of the governing board or to the public); 
4.  Neglect of duty (neglect of duty means intentionally not doing assigned job tasks); 
5.  Willful destruction of the employer's property; 
6.  Absence without leave; 
7.  Conviction of a felony (including a suspended imposition of sentence); 
8.  Sexual harassment of another individual while at work. 
F.  Nothing in Section 3.02.028 shall be interpreted to mean that the city has relinquished its statutory rights of an employment at will employment relationship. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.029 - Employee indictment/conviction. 
    Should an employee be indicted by a grand jury or bound over for trial after a preliminary hearing on a felony charge, the employee shall be suspended without pay pending the outcome of the criminal proceedings. Should the employee be convicted of a felony offense the employee's employment shall be terminated. A conviction for purposes of this provision includes a suspended imposition of sentence. Should the felony charge be dismissed or the employee found not guilty of the charges, the employee shall be reinstated and the employee shall receive back pay and benefits up to a maximum of forty-five (45) working days. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.030 - Abolition of position. 
    Neither this chapter nor any rule hereafter adopted to carry out its provisions shall prevent the governing body from discontinuing any employment or abolishing any position or office when, in the opinion of the governing body, it is in the interest of the city to do so. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.033 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2122-3-84, adopted Dec. 31, 2012, repealed § 3.02.033, which pertained to health insurance for retired city employees and derived from Ord. No. 2090, adopted Jan. 31, 2011. 
3.02.034 - Residence of city employees. 
A.  All full-time employees of the city, while in the employment of the city, shall reside within five (5) miles of city limits as shown on a current map. For purposes of this provision, the five (5) mile limit shall include the full quarter section through which the five (5) mile limit line passes. 
B.  For good cause shown by an employee or applicant for employment, the city commission may grant an exception to the residency requirement upon such conditions as may be approved by the city commission. 
C.  Inclement weather shall not be a justifiable reason for employees who live outside city limits to be tardy or absent from work. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.02.036 - Uniforms and protective equipment. 
    Uniforms, safety or protective clothing will be provided by the employer, at no cost to an employee, where such uniforms, safety or protective clothing are deemed necessary and approved by the governing board or required by law. The city, however, shall not be responsible for providing normal clothing such as jackets/gloves/boots, etc., for employees. 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
Chapter 3.04 - CIVIL SERVICE ORGANIZATION 

3.04.010 - Department of civil service created. 
    There shall be in the city government a department of civil service. In the department, there shall be a civil service board consisting of three members. 
(Ord. 1442 (part), 1981: Ord. 483 § 4.0101, 1950). 
3.04.020 - Civil service board powers and duties. 
    Powers and duties of the board shall be to formulate and administer rules and regulations providing for the selection and discharge or discipline of covered employees. All rules and regulations shall be subject to the approval of the governing body. 
(Ord. 1442 (part), 1981: Ord. 483 § 4.0102, 1950). 
3.04.030 - Appropriations. 
    Adequate annual appropriations shall be made to enable the department to carry out effectively the provisions of this title, and the governing body shall determine the amount to be so appropriated. 
(Ord. 1442 (part), 1981: Ord. 915, 1965: Ord. 620, 1956: Ord. 483 § 4.0103, 1950). 
3.04.040 - Organization of board. 
A.  APPOINTMENT-TERM-QUALIFICATIONS. 
1.  The civil service board shall consist of three members, to be selected and appointed in the following manner: one member shall be selected by the governing body and one member shall be selected by the city employees. The two above-mentioned members after being selected shall be approved by the governing body and, when so approved, the two members shall select a third member. The third member selected shall also be approved by the governing body. The three above-mentioned selectees shall then be duly appointed members of the civil service board by the governing body. The members of the civil service board shall be qualified electors of the city for a period of at least two years immediately prior to the effective date of appointment and shall believe in the merit system of employment. No member of the board shall be a member of any local, state or national committee of a political party or an officer or member of a committee in any partisan or political club or organization, or shall hold, or be a candidate for, any elective public office. 
2.  One member shall be appointed every two years, effective July 1st, to serve for a term of six years or until his successor has been appointed and qualified. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the same manner as original appointment. 
3.  Members may be removed by the mayor with the approval of the governing body for incompetency, dereliction of duty, malfeasance, or other good cause and after notice and public hearing. 
4.  The civil service board shall serve without pay. 
B.  QUORUM-TIME OF MEETINGS. 
1.  Two members of the board shall constitute a quorum. 
2.  It shall elect one of its members chairman. 
3.  The board will meet as needed to carry out its functions. 
4.  All meetings of the board shall be open to the public, except those meetings relating to personnel matters, when the employee affected requests the meetings to be closed. 
(Ord. 1442 (part), 1981: Ord. 483 § 4.0104, 1950). 
3.04.050 - Secretary and chief examiner. 
A.  APPOINTMENT. The civil service board shall appoint and may remove a secretary and chief examiner. All of the administrative and executive powers and duties of the civil service department shall be vested in the secretary and chief examiner, subject to approval by the board to be administered by him under rules which have been adopted in accordance with this title. He shall have charge of applications for employment and examination of all applicants for positions. He shall be the custodian of all civil service records and shall be the person upon or with whom all notice of requests for hearings, complaints and other official documents relating to the civil service system shall be served or filed. 
B.  BELIEF IN MERIT SYSTEM. The secretary and chief examiner shall be in sympathy with the application of merit principals and scientific methods to public employment. 
(Ord. 1442 (part), 1981: Ord. 483 § 4.0106, 1950). 
3.04.060 - Officers and employees covered-Exceptions. 
    Officers and employees shall be selected and hold their positions pursuant to Title 3, Personnel, with the following exceptions: 
A.  All officers elected by the people; 
B.  All boards and commissions appointed by the mayor with or without the confirmation of the governing body; 
C.  Election officials, volunteer firemen and persons working on temporary employment; 
D.  Chapter 3.02, Sections 3.02.028(B), (C), and (D), Chapter 3.04, Chapter 3.12 and Chapter 3.16 of this title are not applicable to the following positions: airport manager, building inspector, city administrator, city attorney, city finance officer, city engineer, city librarian, director of park recreation and forestry, golf course superintendent, solid waste superintendent, street superintendent, traffic superintendent, and water/sewer superintendent. 
E.  Chapter 3.02, Sections 3.02.028(B), (C), and (D), Chapter 3.04 and Chapter 3.16 of this title are not applicable to the chief of police position. 
F.  Chapter 3.02, Sections 3.02.028(B), (C), and (D), Chapter 3.04 and Chapter 3.12 are not applicable to the lead fire captain position and (volunteer) chief of fire prevention position. 
G.  Chapters 3.12 and 3.16 are not applicable to the following positions: accounts supervisor, assistant city engineer, deputy finance officer, executive secretary, industrial waste program administrator, landfill coordinator, parks foreman, recreation specialist, water distribution and sewer collection foreman, and water treatment and sewer treatment foreman. 
H.  Chapter 3.16 is not applicable to the deputy chief of police. 
I.  Union eligible employees who shall be selected and hold their positions pursuant to the collective bargaining agreement between the city and union. 
(Ord. 2012 (part), 2006; Ord. 1584, 1989: Ord. 1561, 1987: Ord. 1487, 1983: Ord. 1442 (part), 1981). 
Chapter 3.06 - GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE 

3.06.010 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
A.  "Aggrieved employee" means the complaining employee or employees. 
B.  "Grievance" means a complaint by an employee or group of employees based upon misinterpretation or inequitable application of any existing policies, rules or regulations of the city as they apply to conditions of employment. 
C.  "Grievance procedure" means the procedure set out by this chapter. 
D.  "Supervisor" means the party who is directly in charge of the aggrieved employee. 
(Ord. 1443 (part), 1981: Ord. 1069 (part), 1973). 
3.06.020 - Procedure. 
A.  The aggrieved employee will discuss the grievance with his supervisor. 
B.  If discussion has failed to resolve the grievance, the employee or his representative shall, within ten calendar days, submit to the head of his department a written notice outlining the grievance. The written grievance shall state specifically the events causing the grievance, relief sought, and all actions taken by the employee to resolve it. The department head shall within seven calendar days of the receipt of the written grievance, meet with the employee and any other individuals deemed appropriate. The department head shall have seven calendar days from the meeting to render a decision in writing. 
C.  Should the department head not reply or the employee feels the grievance is not resolved, the employee may, within ten calendar days after the receipt of the decision, make a written request to the mayor or his designee. Such request will outline those factors of the grievance that he feels have not been equitably resolved. Within ten calendar days of the receipt, the aggrieved employee, the mayor or his designee shall meet with the employee to discuss the grievance. The mayor or his designee shall have ten calendar days from this meeting to render a written decision. Failure to comply with the ten-day limitation shall constitute the resolution of the grievance in favor of the employee. 
D.  In cases of discipline or discharge, within fourteen days after the receipt of the decision in subsection C of this section, the employee may request a hearing before the civil service board for a determination of whether the discipline or discharge is justified. The hearing at the employee's request may be open to the public. The civil service board's decision shall be binding upon both the employer and employee. 
(Ord. 1443 (part), 1981: Ord. 1069 (part), 1973). 
Chapter 3.12 - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

3.12.010 - Establishment. 
    The police department of the city shall consist of a chief of police, deputy chief of police, detective(s), juvenile officer(s) and such patrolmen as from time to time may be deemed necessary by the governing body; provided, however, that the chief of police and commissioner of public safety may appoint extra temporary policemen in cases of emergency. 
(Ord. 2008, 2005; Ord. 483 § 9.0301, 1950). 
3.12.020 - Appointment of police. 
    On the first Monday in May of each year, the governing body shall appoint a chief of police and a deputy chief of police. 
(Ord. 2008, 2005; Ord. 879, 1965; Ord. 483 § 9.0302, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.12.030 - Duties of chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall see that the ordinances of the city are strictly enforced. He shall at all times be subject to and obey the orders of the commissioner of public safety and perform such other additional duties and orders as the governing body may prescribe, and shall have supervision over the other members of the police department. 
(Ord. 483 § 9.0303, 1950). 
3.12.032 - Duties of deputy chief of police. 
    The deputy chief of police in the absence of the chief of police shall carry out the assigned duties of the appointed chief of police. He shall at all times be subject to and obey the orders of the chief of police, the commissioner of public safety and perform such other additional duties and orders as the chief of police, commissioners of public safety and the governing body may prescribe, and shall have supervision over the other members of the police department in the absence of the chief of police. 
(Ord. 879-3-1, 1965). 
3.12.040 - Conduct of police. 
    Other members of the police department shall be under the supervision of the chief of police and shall obey all orders, rules and regulations prescribed by the commissioner of public safety or the chief of police, and shall, when on duty, wear the insignia of their office on their outer garments in a conspicuous place, except when occasion required that it not be exposed. They shall be quiet, civil and orderly in their conduct and deportment, and refrain from violent, profane, obscene and insolent language, and abstain from intoxicating liquors, insubordination and dereliction of duty and any violation of this section shall be reported to the commissioner of public safety and to the governing body by the chief of police immediately upon obtaining knowledge thereof. 
(Ord. 483 § 9.0304, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.12.050 - Duty to enforce traffic laws. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the provisions of the traffic ordinances existing and in force in the city. Officers of the police department are authorized to direct all traffic either in person or by means of visible or audible signal in conformance with the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the city, provided that in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police or fire department may direct traffic, as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic ordinance. 
(Ord. 483 § 9.0305, 1950). 
3.12.060 - Traffic regulations. 
    The commissioner of public safety is empowered to make and enforce regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the ordinances of the city relating to traffic and to make temporary regulations to cover emergencies or special condition, provided any such regulations are not inconsistent with the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 9.0306, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
Chapter 3.14 - RETIREMENT SYSTEM 

3.14.010 - Participation-Scope. 
    The city of Huron, hereinafter called the city, is a participating municipality in the South Dakota Retirement System, hereinafter called SDRS, as provided by law. It is mandatory for all full-time employees to participate in SDRS. 
(Ord. 911-3-1, 1965: Ord. 845 § 1, 1963). 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
3.14.020 - Contributions. 
    The finance officer is directed to deduct mandatory percentages and forward same to the retirement system; said deductions to be made from each and every employee's salary on each and every payroll and for each and every payroll period subsequent to the effective date of the city's participation in SDRS, as provided by law and the rules and regulations adopted and established by the board of trustees of SDRS. 
(Ord. 1142, 1974: Ord. 911-3-1, 1965: Ord. 845 § 1, 1963). 
(Ord. No. 2090, 1-31-2011) 
Chapter 3.16 - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2096, adopted June 13, 2011, amended Ch. 3.16 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 3.16, §§ 3.16.010-3.16.060, pertained to the same subject matter. See the Table of Disposition of Ordinances and Code Comparative Table and Disposition List for complete derivation. 

3.16.010 - Establishment. 
A.  There is established a department of the municipal government of the city which shall be known as the fire department. 
B.  1.  The personnel of the fire department shall consist of a fire chief, two (2) fire captains, volunteer fire chief, three (3) fire lieutenants, three (3) firefighters, and such other personnel as the city commission may authorize. 
2.  Members of the Huron Volunteer Fire Department are considered part-time employees of the City of Huron when assisting the Huron Fire Department within the City of Huron. When assisting the Huron Fire Department within the City of Huron, the Huron Volunteer Fire Department shall constitute a component of the Huron Fire Department. The Huron Volunteer Fire Department is not deemed a component of the Huron Fire Department when involved in fire fighting activities outside the municipality and when involved in civic activities. 
C.  All officers and members of the fire department shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age; all members shall be able bodied, in good health and of good moral character. 
D.  There shall be three (3) companies within the Huron Fire Department: Delta Hose Company, Turner Hose Company, and Hook and Ladder Company. The Fire Chief and Volunteer Fire Chief shall assign volunteer fire department members into such companies as the Fire Chief and Volunteer Fire Chief may deem best. 
(Ord. No. 2096, 6-13-2011; Ord. No. 2106-3-83, 12-30-2011) 
3.16.020 - Officers. 
    The Fire Chief shall supervise the extinguishing of any fire within the City of Huron, be in control of all fire extinguishing apparatus and supervise all firefighters employed by the City, including members of the Huron Volunteer Fire Department. In the absence of the Fire Chief, the Fire Captain on duty shall be responsible for carrying out the responsibilities of the Fire Chief, and in the absence of a Fire Captain, the Volunteer Fire Chief will carry out the responsibilities of a Fire Captain. 
(Ord. No. 2096, 6-13-2011) 
3.16.030 - Authority. 
    The Fire Chief or his/her designee shall have the following authority and responsibility: 
A.  To arrest incendiaries, to investigate the causes of fires and shall keep a record of all arrests and investigations; 
B.  In cases of fire to establish limits wherein no person or persons shall be allowed to come, except firefighters, officers of the law and the owners of property within the limits so prescribed; 
C.  To summon any public or private conveyance to his assistance to haul or convey fire apparatus to a fire, and in emergencies to call any citizen to aid the fire department in extinguishing a fire; 
D.  Unless the City has entered into a governmental agreement with another governmental entity which authorizes the Fire Chief to permit fire engines, ladder truck and fire department personnel to leave the City of Huron, the Public Safety Commissioner must give consent for the fire engines, ladder truck and fire department personnel to leave the city. 
(Ord. No. 2096, 6-13-2011) 
3.16.050 - Department personnel. 
A.  All department fire fighters and volunteer firefighters shall report, upon being directed to do so, to the place of the fire with the city's fire extinguishing apparatus and work and manage the same under the direction of the fire department officer in command. 
B.  Members of the fire department who are present at the fire shall be subject and obedient to the orders of the fire department officer in command in extinguishing the fire or in removing and protecting property. Any member of the fire department failing or refusing to obey the command of the officer in charge shall be subject to disciplinary action, including termination of employment. Any member of the Volunteer Fire Department failing or refusing to obey the command of the officer in charge may have his or her authorization as a volunteer fire fighter for the City of Huron revoked by the Huron City Commission. 
C.  No employee of the Huron Fire Department or Volunteer Fire Fighter may leave the fire location with any department fire apparatus without the consent of the department officer in command. No employee of the Fire Department or Volunteer Firefighter may use or allow another to use for private use any of the City fire extinguishing apparatus. 
(Ord. No. 2096, 6-13-2011) 
3.16.060 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2096, adopted June 13, 2011, repealed § 3.16.060, which pertained to unlawful acts and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 5.0106, adopted 1950. 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapter 5.04 - GENERAL LICENSE PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities empowered to fix the amount, terms and manner of issuing and revoking licenses-See SDC 45.0201 (62). 
Cross reference- Duties of auditor-See Ch. 2.08 of this code; Special licensing provisions-See Chs. 5.08-5.56 of this code; Bicycle licenses-See Ch. 16.48 of this code; Business of installing television antennas-See Ch. 18.36 of this code; Kennel license-See Ch. 8.04 of this code; Plumbers license-See Ch. 18.20 of this code; Electricians license-See Ch. 18.16 of this code; Milk processors license-See Ch. 6.08 of this code. 

5.04.010 - Application for license. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, an applicant for license shall make and file application in writing with the auditor on the form prescribed. Such application shall contain such information as required by the licensing authority or as provided by ordinance and must show that the applicant is eligible for the license for which application is made. If required the applicant shall verify the application. 
(b)  Form of application. Unless otherwise provided an application for license shall state: 
1.  Name and address of applicant. 
2.  Trade name if any under which license is to be exercised. 
3.  If a partnership, the name and address of each partner. 
4.  If a corporation, the names and addresses of the officers. 
5.  Place of business or location where the license is to be exercised. 
6.  Description of the activity to be carried on under the license. 
7.  Such information as required by ordinance or by the governing body showing the applicant is entitled to the license and that he is a proper person and the place is a proper place for the exercise thereof. 
8.  Such information as required by ordinance as may be necessary for determination of the amount of the license fee. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0102; April 24, 1950). 
5.04.020 - Payment of license fee. 
    Except as otherwise provided an applicant for license shall first pay the amount of the license to the treasurer taking his receipt therefor showing the kind of license for which the fee was paid and the amount paid. Such receipt shall be presented to the auditor or other licensing officer to whom application for license is made. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0101; April 24, 1950). 
5.04.030 - Issuance of license. 
    Except as otherwise provided, all licenses shall be issued by the treasurer if the issuance of the license is approved by the governing body and the applicant has complied with all requirements for issuance of the license. Unless otherwise provided all licenses shall be signed by the auditor and shall have affixed thereto the official seal of the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0103; April 24, 1950). 
5.04.040 - Approval of bonds. 
    Any bond, liability insurance, or deposit required shall be subject to the approval of the governing body, and in case the governing body deems the security inadequate, it may require new or additional security. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0104; April 24, 1950). 
5.04.050 - Term of licenses. 
    Unless otherwise provided, all licenses shall take effect when issued and shall terminate on the first of the month of May following. Except as otherwise provided, the license charged shall be paid on the basis of a full year. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0105; April 24, 1950). 
5.04.060 - License posted or exhibited. 
    Every person to whom a license is issued by the city shall keep the same posted in a conspicuous place in the licensed place of business or vehicle or if there is no place of business or vehicle, then he shall exhibit the license to any person in authority or to any person who may deal with the licensee when required to do so. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0106; April 24, 1950). 
5.04.070 - Revocation. 
    The governing body shall have power to cancel any license issued by the city for failure of the licensee to comply with any ordinance or regulation of the city or state law respecting such license or the manner of exercise thereof or for other good cause after hearing upon notice of the licensee. 
    Upon conviction of a violation of any ordinance of the city by a licensee relating to the exercise of such license, the court, in addition to other penalties imposed, may enter its judgment cancelling such license. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0107; April 24, 1950). 
5.04.080 - License required. 
    No person shall engage in any activity for which a license is required without first having obtained a license therefor as required by ordinance. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0108; April 24, 1950). 
5.04.090 - Change of name. 
    If a licensee changes the name or form of organization under which he does business, the license may be so changed without payment of an additional fee except as otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0109; April 24, 1950). 
Chapter 5.06 - DOOR-TO-DOOR SALES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, and regulate transient merchants and transient stores, SDCL 9-34-7; authority to license, tax, regulate or prohibit peddlers, SDCL 9-34-8; peddlers generally, SDCL Ch. 37-13. 

5.06.010 - Definition. 
    The term "door-to-door sales" as used in this chapter means any person, whether a resident of this city or not, traveling from house to house (including apartment to apartment) who has not been invited by the resident thereof and for the purpose of selling or soliciting for sale of goods, wares, merchandise, or services, including food and beverages. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
5.06.020 - Exceptions to chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Solicitations, sales or distributions made by nonprofit civic, charitable, educational, or religious organizations which have registered with the city finance department; 
(2)  Traveling salespersons doing business exclusively with retail merchants, manufacturers, jobbers or public officials. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
5.06.030 - Permit required. 
(A)  It is unlawful for any person to engage in door-to-door sales within this city without first obtaining a permit to do so from the city finance department. 
(B)  The maximum number of days for a permit is five consecutive days unless otherwise authorized by the city commission. 
(C)  No door-to-door sales permit shall be issued to a corporation, partnership or other impersonal legal entity. Each individual person engaging in the business of door-to-door sales within the city shall be required to have a separate permit, whether acting for himself or herself or as an agent or representative of another. 
(D)  Every door-to-door salesperson having a permit issued under the provisions of this chapter and doing business within the city shall display his or her permit upon the request of any person. Failure to display his or her permit when requested to do so shall be an offense subject to the penalties prescribed in Chapter 1.04, Section 1.04.130 of this code. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
5.06.040 - Application for permit. 
    The application for a permit required by the provisions of this chapter shall: 
(1)  The name, social security number, date of birth, local and permanent address, cell phone number, vehicle license number and photo identification of the applicant; 
(2)  Contain a statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any state or federal law or municipal ordinance or code other than traffic offenses; the nature of the offense; the punishment or penalty assessed therefor, if previously convicted; and the place of conviction; 
(3)  Whether the applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand, accept or receive payment, or deposit of money in advance of final delivery; 
(4)  The period of time the applicant wishes to engage in business within the city; 
(5)  The kind of goods, wares, merchandise, or services the applicant wishes to peddle within the city; 
(6)  The last three cities or towns wherein the applicant has worked before coming to this city; 
(7)  The name of the entity, permanent address, entity's telephone number, entity's federal EIN and South Dakota sales tax license numbers that the applicant represents. 
    No person shall give any false or misleading information in connection with his or her application for a permit and giving such false or misleading information shall be an offense subject to the penalties prescribed in Chapter 1.04, Section 1.04.130 of this code. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
5.06.050 - Bond required. 
    Every door-to-door salesperson, before receiving a license, shall file with the city finance department a copy of a bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars conditioned for the faithful performance and payment of obligations of the peddler arising in connection with the business, and for payment of all claims or damages for which the peddler may become liable through fraud, deceit or otherwise in the course of business as a peddler/transient merchant. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
5.06.060 - Fee. 
    Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter, the applicant shall pay a fee of fifty dollars. Any permit authorized by the city commission beyond the five-day permit shall be assessed a fee of ten dollars per day during which time the permit is valid. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
5.06.070 - Hours of operation. 
    Door-to-door sales shall be permitted only between the hours of ten a.m. and nine p.m. Monday through Saturday and between one p.m. and five p.m. Sunday, except by specific appointment with or invitation from the prospective customer. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
5.06.080 - Prohibited conduct. 
(A)  No door-to-door salesperson shall make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality or nature of their goods, wares, merchandise, or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the goods, wares, merchandise, or services. 
(B)  No door-to-door salesperson selling or soliciting for sale goods, wares, merchandise or services by traveling from place to place, house to house, or street to street shall not remain in any one place for a period longer than necessary to make a sale after having been approached or stopped for that purpose. 
(C)  It is unlawful for any door-to-door salesperson who enters upon premises owned or leased by another to fail to promptly leave the premises after having been notified by the owner or possessor of the premises, or his agent, to leave the premises. 
(D)  It is unlawful for any door-to-door salesperson to enter upon any private premises when the premises is posted with a sign stating "No Peddlers Allowed," "No Soliciting," or words to that effect. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
5.06.090 - Revocation of permit. 
    In addition to the penalties authorized pursuant to Chapter 1.04, Section 1.04.030 of this code, any permit issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked for the violation by the permittee of any provision of this code, state law, or city ordinance by the finance director. Upon such revocation, such permit shall immediately be surrendered, and failure to do so shall be an offense and subject to the penalties prescribed in Chapter 1.04, Section 1.04.130 of this code. 
    Should a permit be revoked, the person and the business for which the person is an agent, representative or employee shall be prohibited from applying for a permit pursuant to this chapter unless such permit is authorized by the city commission. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
5.06.100 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day that the violation continues, and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provision in Section 1.04.130 of this code. 
(Ord. 2016 (part), 2006). 
Chapter 5.10 - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS 

5.10.010 - Definition. 
    The phrase "transient merchant" as used in this chapter means any person, other than a door-to-door salesperson, whether a resident of this city or not, or business transacting a temporary business within the city for the purpose of selling or soliciting for sale of goods, wares, merchandise, services, including food and beverages, for fewer than ninety days, from any building or any other structure, or from an open area, a car, truck, other motor vehicle or trailer. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
(Ord. No. 2131-5-122, 8-26-2013) 
5.10.020 - Exceptions to chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Solicitations, sales or distributions made by nonprofit civic, charitable, educational, or religious organizations which have registered with the city finance department; 
(2)  Traveling salespersons doing business exclusively with retail merchants, manufacturers, jobbers or public officials; 
(3)  Persons selling lemonade/juice/kool-ade, jams, jellies, vegetables, fruits, flowers grown or produced or crafts made by them which have registered with the city finance department when the items are sold at such places as at farmer's markets and craft shows, and provided the person has not purchased such items for resale. This exception, however, shall not apply to entities in the business of or to persons who own a business which sells jams, vegetables, fruits, or flowers; 
(4)  Bona fide garage, rummage, yard, or moving sales which do not occur at the same location more than two times per year and for more than two consecutive days per sale; 
(5)  Transient merchants doing temporary business on the grounds of the S.D. State Fair after having received permission by the S.D. State Fair to temporarily conduct the business; 
(6)  Persons having registered with the city finance department and are leasing private property for parking during the S.D. State Fair. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
5.10.030 - Misrepresentation. 
    No transient merchant shall make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality or nature of their goods, wares, merchandise, or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the goods, wares, merchandise, or services. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
5.10.040 - Permit required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in business as a transient merchant within this city without first obtaining a permit to do so from the city finance department. Permits shall be valid for either (1) three consecutive months, (2) six consecutive months, (3) nine consecutive months, or (4) twelve consecutive months. No permit shall be valid for longer than twelve consecutive months. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
(Ord. No. 2131-5-122, 8-26-2013) 
5.10.050 - Application. 
    No person shall give any false or misleading information in connection with his or her application for a permit required by this section. The application for a permit required by the provisions of this article shall: 
(1)  Contain a statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any state or federal law or municipal ordinance or code other than traffic offenses; the nature of the offense; the punishment or penalty assessed therefor, if previously convicted; and the place of conviction; 
(2)  Whether the applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand, accept or receive payment, or deposit of money in advance of final delivery; 
(3)  The period of time the applicant wishes to engage in business within the city; 
(4)  The local and permanent addresses of the applicant; 
(5)  The local and permanent addresses and the name of the entity, if any, that the applicant represents; 
(6)  The kind of goods, wares, merchandise, or services the applicant wishes to sell within the city; 
(7)  The last three cities or towns wherein the applicant has worked before coming to this city; 
(8)  The applicant's date of birth and Social Security account number or other identifying number; 
(9)  The location or locations where the applicant wishes to conduct business within the city; and 
(10)  Proof of all applicable federal or State of South Dakota permits or licenses associated with the business. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
(Ord. No. 2131-5-122, 8-26-2013) 
5.10.060 - Bond required. 
    Every transient merchant before receiving a license shall file with the city finance department a bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars conditioned for the faithful performance and payment of obligations of the peddler arising in connection with the business, and for payment of all claims or damages for which the peddler may become liable through fraud, deceit or otherwise in the course of business as a peddler. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
5.10.070 - Fee. 
    Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the applicant shall pay a fee of fifty dollars for each three month period requested on the permit application. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
(Ord. No. 2131-5-122, 8-26-2013) 
5.10.080 - Issuance restricted. 
    No transient merchant's permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid should the transient merchant's applicable federal or State of South Dakota license or permit be expired, suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
(Ord. No. 2131-5-122, 8-26-2013) 
5.10.090 - Display. 
    Every transient merchant having a permit issued under the provisions of this article and doing business within the city shall display his permit upon the request of any person, and failure to do so shall be an offense. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
5.10.100 - Suspension or revocation. 
    Any permit issued under the provisions of this article may be suspended or revoked for the violation by the transient merchant of any provision of this code, state law, or city ordinance by the finance director. Upon such suspension or revocation, such permit shall immediately be surrendered, and failure to do so shall be an offense. The decision of the finance director to suspend or revoke the permit of a transient merchant may be appealed to the City Commission. The written appeal must be filed with the city attorney within five (5) days of transient merchant's receipt of the written notice of suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
(Ord. No. 2131-5-122, 8-26-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2131-5-122, adopted August 26, 2013, amended § 5.10.100 title to read as herein set out. Former § 5.10.100 title pertained to revocation. 
5.10.110 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day that the violation continues, and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provision in Section 1.04.130 of this code. 
(Ord. 2017 (part), 2006). 
Chapter 5.12 - WHOLESALERS OF FRUIT, VEGETABLES, GARDEN TRUCK OR FARM PRODUCTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Cities empowered to regulate the place of sales and the selling of meats, poultry, fish, cheese, lard, vegetables, and similar provisions-See SDC 45.0202(3). 
Cross reference- General licensing provisions-See Ch. 5.04 of this code. 

5.12.010 - Definitions. 
(a)  The term REGULARLY ESTABLISHED PLACE OF BUSINESS when used in this chapter shall mean a warehouse or store in the City of Huron in which there is kept for sale and delivery a stock of fruits, vegetables, garden truck, or farm products, which stock is reported to the proper assessing officer of the City of Huron for the purpose of taxation, and which place is kept open to the public during the usual business hours; 
(b)  The term REGULAR EMPLOYEE OF ANY FARMER OR PRODUCER, when used in this chapter, shall mean a person employed by such farmer or producer and whose present occupation is field work upon the farm or land of such farmer or producer; 
(c)  The term COMMON CARRIER when used in this chapter shall mean one who holds himself out to the public as willing to undertake for hire to transport property from place to place for persons who may choose to employ him, by steam, electricity, or rail, or motor vehicle on the highways, or in any other mode of transportation; 
(d)  The term WHOLESALE, when used in this chapter, shall mean the sale or delivery to a hotel, restaurant, retail store, commission house, or to any person, partnership, firm, corporation, association or agency for resale, direct or indirect. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0301; April 24, 1950). 
5.12.020 - Permit fee. 
    Except as herein otherwise provided, no person, partnership, firm, corporation, association, or agency shall engage in the selling or delivery of any fruits, vegetables, garden truck, or farm products at wholesale in the City of Huron without first having obtained a permit to carry on such business from the city auditor, and without having first paid therefor the sum of fifty dollars for each calendar year or fraction thereof. Provided, if such business be conducted by a motor truck or vehicle, the aforesaid permit fee shall cover the right to use in such business one such vehicle only, and shall pay for every additional vehicle used the sum of fifty dollars per calendar year or fraction thereof. This chapter shall not apply to common carriers making deliveries as such, nor to any person, partnership, firm, corporation, association or agency selling or delivering from any established place of business located within the City of Huron, when such sale or delivery is made by or for the person, partnership, firm, corporation, association or agency selling or delivering from any established place of business located within said city, operating such legally established place of business; nor shall this chapter apply to any farmer or producer, including the regular employees of any such farmer or producer, when selling or delivering such fruits, vegetables, garden truck or farm produce as shall have been actually grown or produced by such farmer or producer, provided such farmer or producer first file with the city auditor an affidavit that he actually grew or produced such fruits, vegetables, garden truck or farm produce. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0302; April 24, 1950). 
5.12.030 - Permit regulations. 
(a)  Application for permits required by this chapter shall be filed with the city auditor, and shall contain the name of the applicant, and his address, shall show whether applicant is an individual, a partnership, or a corporation, and show the number of trucks to be used in the business. Permits shall be granted by the city auditor. 
(b)  Permits shall run from January 1 of each calendar year, and shall be for the full calendar year or the remainder of any given calendar year when not issued at the beginning of such year. Permits shall not be transferable, and shall not be prorated for any portion of a calendar year. 
(c)  No person, partnership, firm, association or agency shall have the right to conduct business under a permit issued to and in the name of some other person, firm, partnership, corporation or agency. 
(d)  Before any permit shall be issued under this chapter the applicant shall file with the city auditor a bond in the penal sum of five hundred dollars in favor of and running to the city of Huron, which bond shall be signed by the applicant as principal, and a reliable surety company as surety. Such surety shall be established in and operating in the city of Huron. The bond shall be conditioned that the principal therein holding a permit from the city under this chapter shall fully comply with all ordinances of the city of Huron relating to the conduct of the business the permittee is authorized to carry on and will pay all judgments rendered against such permittee for any violation of this chapter, and for any damage arising out of any misrepresentation or deceit practiced by such permittee in the conduct of the business authorized under the permit held. The term of the bond shall be the same as the term of the permit. 
(e)  All fees for permits shall be paid to the city treasurer. 
(Ord. 483 7.0303; April 24, 1950). 
5.12.040 - Provisions supplemental. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to supersede, repeal or affect any ordinance now or hereafter in effect in the city of Huron relating to the licensing of hawkers or peddlers, to consumers, or to the inspection of goods, wares and merchandise sold or acquired for sale in the city of Huron, or to soliciting or operating as a transient merchant. 
(Ord. 483 7.03.204; April 24, 1950). 
5.12.050 - Revocation of permit. 
    Any permit issued hereunder may be revoked by the city of Huron for violations of this chapter by the holder or holders thereof, after a hearing. Notice of such hearing shall be given to the holders of permits claimed to have been violated, at least five days prior to the date of such hearing, which notice shall be served by registered mail addressed to the holder of the permit against whom the application to revoke shall be made, at the address given by the holder of such permit in his application for his permit; or if the holder of a permit shall have changed his address, at the new address of such permittee, if the permittee shall have filed a written statement showing such named address with the city auditor. Otherwise, the mailing shall be to the address shown in the application. 
    Any permit issued hereunder may be rendered from year to year by the payment of the fees provided for in this chapter upon the issuance of permit originally. No part of the fees paid for a permit shall be refunded in case of revocation or surrender of a permit. Upon the renewal of any permit the permittee shall, before operating under such renewal, furnish and file with the city auditor a renewal bond for the amount, all as conditioned and provided in subdivision (d) of Section 5.12.030 hereof. 
(Ord. 483 7.0305; April 24, 1950). 
5.12.060 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof the person so offending shall, for each separate offense, be subject to a fine of not exceeding one hundred dollars and costs, or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than thirty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 483 7.0306; April 24, 1950). 
Chapter 5.20 - ROLLER SKATING RINKS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities specifically authorized to license, tax, regulate, or prohibit public skating rinks-See SDCL § 9-34-15. 
Cross reference- General licensing provisions-See Ch. 5.04 of this code; Minors' curfew-See Ch. 9.20 of this code. 

5.20.010 - Definitions. 
(a)  "Roller skating" means the act of a person or persons rapidly moving or gliding over a smooth surface by means of a contrivance for the foot consisting of rollers attached to a plate or frame with suitable clamps or straps for fastening it to the sole of a boot or shoe or by other similar contrivance by which the same effect or result is obtained. 
(b)  "Public roller skating rink," as used herein, means any room, place or space within a building or other structure in which roller skating, as hereinbefore defined, is conducted and to which the public generally is admitted by payment of a fee or by the purchase, possession or presentation of a ticket or token, or in which a charge is made for caring for clothing or other property, or to which the public may gain admission with or without the payment of a fee. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0501, 1950). 
5.20.020 - License. 
    It is unlawful to conduct any public roller skating rink within the limits of the city until such rink or the place within which the same may be held shall first have been duly licensed for such purposes. 
    Applications for licenses shall be made and presented upon forms supplied by the city auditor. 
    The license shall be signed by the mayor and city auditor and shall be posted in a conspicuous place within the hall or place in which roller skating is conducted. 
    Each license granted hereunder shall expire on the first day of May succeeding the date of issue. 
    The annual license fee shall be ten dollars. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0502, 1950). 
5.20.030 - Compliance with fire and health regulations. 
    No license for a public roller skating rink or place shall be issued until it shall be found that such rink or place complies with the ordinances, health and fire regulations of the city and laws of the state; that it is properly ventilated and properly supplied with toilet conveniences and is a safe and proper place for the purpose for which it is to be used. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0503, 1950). 
5.20.040 - Inspection. 
    Applications for public roller skating rink licenses shall be referred to the chief of police, city health officer, chief of fire department and building inspector, who shall severally inspect the roller skating rink, building or premises described in the application to determine whether the same complies with the regulations, ordinances and laws applicable thereto. Such officer shall furnish to the governing body the information obtained in such investigation, accompanied by a recommendation as to whether a license should be granted or refused. 
    No license shall be extended or renewed without the inspection and report and recommendation of the officers named herein as above provided. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0504, 1950). 
5.20.050 - Revocation of license. 
    The license of any public roller skating rink shall be forfeited or revoked by the governing body for violation by a person or organization holding a license for a public roller skating rink of any of the provisions of this chapter, or if such person or organization knowingly permits any person or organization to operate or conduct a public roller skating rink in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. Whenever a public roller skating rink license under the provisions of this chapter is revoked, at least six months shall elapse before another license may be issued for use of such building or premises for public roller skating purposes. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0505, 1950). 
5.20.060 - Cleanliness. 
    All public skating rinks and places and rooms and premises used in connection therewith shall be kept at all times in a safe, clean and sanitary condition, and such rink and rooms, including all stairways, passages and places connected therewith shall be kept open, well lighted and ventilated during the time that roller skating is being conducted therein. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0506, 1950). 
5.20.070 - Vacating premises. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to cause the roller skating rink and the room or place wherein same is being conducted to be vacated whenever any provision or regulation or municipal ordinances relating to public roller skating rinks is being violated or when any disorder of a gross, violent or vulgar character shall take place. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0507, 1950). 
5.20.080 - Duty of owner of premises and proprietor of rink. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of every room, place, space, or building rented or used for a public roller skating rink, as well as that of the person or organization conducting the roller skating rink, to see that provisions of all laws, ordinances and regulations relative to roller skating and roller skating rinks are complied with, and he shall also furnish to the city auditor, not less than twenty-four hours in advance a list showing the days and hours when roller skating will be conducted therein. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0508, 1950). 
5.20.090 - Proprietor or floor manager required on premises. 
    The person conducting a roller skating rink shall be present personally and in control of the premises from a half hour before the roller skating begins until the roller skating rink is closed, or may have present in his stead a floor manager. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0509, 1950). 
5.20.100 - Conduct. 
    It shall be the duty of the floor manager to see that standards of decency and good taste are maintained at all times and that disorderly, familiar or objectionable conduct is not tolerated, and to take efficient steps promptly to remove objectionable persons and stop objectionable practices. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0510, 1950). 
5.20.130 - Closing hours. 
    No public roller skating shall be conducted or allowed between the hours of twelve p.m. and ten a.m. No public roller skating shall be held or permitted on Sunday, except between the hours of two and six p.m. and eight and eleven p.m. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0513, 1950). 
5.20.140 - Intoxicating liquor. 
    It is unlawful for any person conducting a public roller skating rink, or conducting public roller skating therein, or any manager or other agent of such person: 
(a)  To permit in the roller skating rink, or on or about the premises used or connected therewith any person having in his or her possession or offering for sale, selling, giving away, or drinking any intoxicating liquors; 
(b)  To permit any person under the influence of or affected by liquor or drugs to enter or participate in any public roller skating; 
(c)  To permit idlers, loiterers, or other hangers-on to be in or about the premises used or connected with the public roller skating rink. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.05.14, 1950). 
5.20.150 - Revocation of license. 
    The license issued hereunder shall cease and be null and void upon conviction in the municipal court of the city of the holder thereof, for a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
    Any licenses issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the governing body for causes shown, after notice and hearing, and the governing body may suspend the operation of license pending the hearing, affecting or involving the same, before the governing body or the trial of any person to whom a license has been issued, before the court or courts having jurisdiction of complaints of violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.0515, 1950). 
Chapter 5.24 - GENERAL OCCUPATION TAX ON RENTED HOTEL AND MOTEL ROOMS 

5.24.010 - Establishment of the district. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of SDCL Ch. 9-55, business improvement district no. 1 of the City of Huron, S.D. is hereby created. A resolution of intent to create this district was approved by the city commission on the 23rd day of May, 2011. The public hearing on creation of the district was held in the city commission chambers located at 239 Wisconsin Ave. SW, Huron, S.D. at 5:30 p.m. on the 25th day of July, 2011. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.020 - Boundaries of the district. 
    Business improvement district no. 1 shall have the following boundaries, excluding any bed and breakfast, and motel/hotel properties with less than 25 rooms. It shall be a noncontiguous district which ends at the city limits, and includes the following properties: 
Best Western of Huron 
2000 Dakota Avenue S. 
Huron, SC 57350 
Comfort Inn Huron 
100 21st Street SW 
Huron, SD 57350 
Super 8 
2189 Dakota Avenue S. 
Huron, SD 57350 
Crossroads Hotel 
100 4th Street SW 
Huron, SD 57350 
Dakota Inn 
924 4th Street SE 
Huron, SD 57350 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.030 - Voluntary participation. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of SDCL Ch. 9-55-4, business improvement district no. 1 shall allow for the addition of properties with less than 25 rooms should they choose to participate in the occupancy tax. A lodging establishment with less than 25 rooms that wishes to voluntarily participate in the occupancy tax shall do so on a form prepared by the finance office. After twelve months of participation, a lodging establishment with less than 25 rooms and which is voluntarily participating in the occupancy tax may withdraw from participation upon thirty (30) days written notice to the finance office. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.040 - New properties within the district. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of SDCL Ch. 9-55-4, business improvement district no. 1 shall include all hotel or motel facilities constructed in the future which have 25 rooms or more. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.050 - Purpose of the district. 
    Business improvement district no. 1 is created for the purpose of funding the enhancement, expansion, marketing and promotion of visitor facilities, events, attractions and activities benefiting the city and its hotels and motels located within the district. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.060 - Occupational tax imposed. 
    Commencing September 1, 2011, an occupational tax in the amount of $2.00 per night shall be imposed upon the above hotels, motels or lodging establishments based upon rooms rented to transient guests. This occupation tax shall be fair, equitable and uniform as to class. No occupational tax may be imposed on any transient guest who has been offered a room by a lodging establishment on a complimentary basis whereby no fee or rent is charged for such room or upon any transient guest who is representing an entity which is exempt from sales tax pursuant to SDCL 10-45-10. Additionally, no occupational tax may be imposed on any room utilized by a transient guest who stays twenty-eight (28) or more consecutive nights. This tax rate may be adjusted by the city commission in accordance with SDCL § 9-55-16. For lodging establishments which have less than 25 rooms and voluntarily participating in the occupational tax, no occupational tax shall be imposed on any room utilized by a transient guest who stays seven (7) or more consecutive nights. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011; Ord. No. 2100-5-117A, 1-30-2012) 
5.24.070 - Duty to account for complimentary and lease rooms. 
    Each hotel, motel or lodging establishment shall account for complimentary or leased rooms which are also subject to audit by the city finance officer with such records to show the basis for offering such room on a complimentary or lease basis. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.080 - Computation and collection of occupational tax. 
    The city finance officer is authorized and directed to determine and compute the tax in accordance with this article. The occupational tax assessed pursuant to the terms of this article shall be remitted to the city finance director each month no later than the last day for filing monthly state sales tax, with the remittance to be for the previous calendar-month's tax collections. Each hotel, motel or lodging establishment subject to this article shall keep accurate records of amounts collected from transient guests for review by the city finance officer or his/her designee, upon request by the city finance officer. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.090 - Statement required along with occupational tax payment. 
    A person authorized by a business governed by this article shall sign a sworn statement to be submitted along with the remittance of any tax imposed by this article on or before the 20th day of each month stating as follows: 
"I declare, under penalty of perjury, that the above accounting of rooms rented is accurate and the tax payment made herein is accurate to the best of my knowledge according to my business records." 
    Such statement shall include the signature of a person authorized to make such statement on behalf of the business, that person's printed name and title, and the date such signature is made. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.100 - Penalties for failure to pay occupational tax. 
    All remittances of occupancy tax collected pursuant to this article shall be due and received in the office of the city finance director each month no later than the last day for filing monthly state sales tax following the month for which the occupancy tax remittances are due. All amounts that are not as set forth above will be charged a late fee in the amount of ten percent of the total amount due. Failure to remit such tax shall constitute a violation of this chapter which may be punishable by a fine of up to $500.00 and/or imprisonment for up to 30 days pursuant to Section 1.04.130 of the Municipal Code. Any unpaid balance under this article shall constitute a lien upon the property owned by the business or user of space being taxed and shall become a lien against and shall run with the property and may be enforced and collected in the same manner as other unpaid real property taxes and assessments. The city finance officer shall certify all unpaid amounts or balances to the county treasurer for collection in the same manner as general property taxes are collected. Further the city shall have the ability to deny the issuance of permits or licenses or any renewals thereof to any business or premise that fails to conform to the provisions of this article, including, but not limited to, building permits, malt beverage licenses, and liquor licenses. The city shall also have the right to suspend service of municipal utilities until the delinquent occupancy tax is paid in full. Nothing within this provision shall be construed as limiting any other rights which the city has, or may pursue in seeking collection of monies received but not paid under the terms of this article. In the event that this tax becomes subject to supervision by the state through the state's department of revenue, any rights which the city has herein shall be deemed cumulative to any powers which inure to the benefit of the state. 
    In the event of any legal proceeding being initiated to seek collection of any delinquent assessments, the offending hotel, motel or lodging establishment shall be responsible for and pay all attorney's fees and costs incurred by the city seeking payment under the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.110 - Costs incurred by city in administering occupational tax. 
    All costs incurred by the city or the city finance officer pursuant to this article shall be paid from occupancy taxes collected under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.120 - Payment of occupational tax proceeds to the Huron Chamber and Visitors Bureau. 
    Once the occupational tax has been collected, the city finance office shall subtract its administrative costs not to exceed two percent and forward the remaining balance to the Huron City Chamber and Visitors Bureau. The Huron Chamber and Visitors Bureau will use the proceeds for the enhancement, expansion, marketing and promotion of visitor facilities, events, attractions and activities benefiting the city and its hotels and motels located within the district through the Huron Chamber and Visitors Bureau in consultation with the Business Improvement District Board of Directors and Huron Chamber of Commerce and Visitors Bureau Board of Directors. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.130 - Creation of business improvement board of directors. 
    The Business Improvement District No. 1 Board of Directors is hereby established. The Mayor shall appoint the members of the Board of Directors, subject to the approval of the City Commission. The Board of Directors shall consist of three representatives of businesses located within Business Improvement District No.1, two business owners located outside of Business Improvement District No. 1, one member of the Huron City Commission, one member of the Huron Chamber of Commerce and Visitors Bureau Board of Directors, and two ex-officio members who shall be the executive director of the Huron Chamber and Commerce and Visitors Bureau and the City of Huron Finance Officer. Except for initial appointments, appointments to the Board of Directors shall be made annually during the month of May. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011; Ord. No. 2176-5-125, 6-6-2016) 
5.24.140 - Severability. 
    Should any section, clause or provision of this article be declared by the courts to be invalid, the same shall not affect the validity of the article as a whole or any part thereof, other than the part declared to be invalid. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.150 - Reporting. 
    The business improvement district no. 1 board of directors will provide semi-annual reports to the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
5.24.160 - Audit. 
    The business improvement district board of directors shall submit to a biennial audit by a certified public accountant. A copy of the audit shall be placed on file with the city finance office. 
(Ord. No. 2100-5-117, 8-1-2011) 
Chapter 5.36 - TAXICABS, MOTOR BUSES AND LIMOUSINES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic regulations for buses-See Ch. 16.44 of this code; General license provisions-See Ch. 5.04 of this code. 
State Law reference- State regulation of motor vehicles declared not to prevent municipal corporations from licensing, taxing, or regulating motor vehicles-See SDCL 32-5-106; Municipal license for drivers of taxicabs and motor buses authorized-See SDCL 9-34-10. 

5.36.010 - Definitions. 
    The term "taxi" or "taxicab" as used in this chapter means a self-propelled motor vehicle with a capacity for carrying seven passengers or less, and used for carrying passengers for hire. 
    The term "motor bus" as used in this chapter means any automobile or other vehicle used for the conveyance of passengers for hire upon the public streets of the city, with a carrying capacity of more than seven passengers. 
    The term "limousine" as used in this chapter means a full sized motor vehicle (automobile) with an extended wheel base, which has a passenger apartment that can be sealed from the driver's compartment, with a seating capacity for at least six persons, not including the driver, not traveling any definite or prescribed route, and operated by a driver. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 1605 (part), 1990: Ord. 483 § 7.0901, 1950). 
5.36.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate or cause to be operated upon the public thoroughfares of the city any taxi, taxicab, motor bus or limousine without first having procured a license to do so, and having paid the city finance officer the license fee hereinafter provided, and having complied with all the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 1605 (part), 1990: Ord. 483 § 7.0902, 1950). 
5.36.030 - License fee. 
    Except as otherwise provided, the owner or owners of any taxicab, taxi, motor bus or limousine operated upon the public thorough-fares of the city shall pay any annual license fee prior to January 1st of each year of twenty-five dollars per year for each vehicle operated under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 1605 (part), 1990: Ord. 483 § 7.0903, 1950). 
5.36.040 - Financial responsibility. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall hire or keep for hire any conveyance of passengers or freight from place to place within the city, without having furnished and filed with the city finance officer an owner's policy of liability insurance. Proof of insurance shall be provided each year at the time a license is obtained under Section 5.36.030. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 1605 (part), 1990: Ord. 483 § 7.0904, 1950). 
5.36.050 - Application for license. 
    Any person intending to operate a taxi, motor bus or limousine upon the highways of the city shall make application for a license to do so upon a form supplied by the city finance officer. The applicant shall state in such application the manufacturer's name, model and serial numbers, state license number, seating capacity and the name of the owner or owners of such taxi, motor bus or limousine. 
    All applications for taxi, motor bus or limousine licenses shall be sworn to by the owner or owners or by some officer of a corporation if so owned. 
    Upon presentation of the city finance officer's receipt for the license fee and a completed and sworn application accompanied by the bond or insurance policy required, the city finance officer shall issue a license to the applicant. 
    Such license shall show manufacturer's name, model and serial numbers, state license number, seating capacity and the name of the owner or owners of licensed vehicles. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 1605 (part), 1990: Ord. 483 § 7.0905, 1950). 
5.36.060 - Number plates. 
    Every owner of any licensed vehicle shall upon receipt of his license, place a number plate, to be furnished by the city, upon each licensed vehicle, which plate shall be plainly placed in a conspicuous place on the outside of such vehicle and shall be kept so placed at all times when a vehicle is operated during the continuance of the license. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 483 § 7.0906, 1950). 
5.36.070 - Doors openable from inside-Care of articles left in vehicle-Fares. 
(a)  Doors. Every licensed vehicle carrying passengers for hire in the city, which has a door or doors to the same, shall have a knob or handle upon the inside of such door or doors, by which the door or doors may be easily opened from the inside of the vehicle. 
(b)  Articles Left in Vehicle. Whenever any package or article of any kind is left in any licensed vehicle carrying passengers for hire, or when any package or article of any kind is left in the custody of the driver of such vehicle, the driver or the owner of such vehicle upon discovery of such package or article shall forthwith deliver the same to police headquarters, unless such package or article is sooner delivered to the owner. 
(c)  Maximum fares may be set by resolution of the governing board. 
(d)  The taxi operator shall conspicuously post their fares in the taxi and shall be in unrestricted view of passengers and provide a copy of said fares to the finance office each time that the fares are changed. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 1664, 1992: Ord. 1607, 1990: Ord. 1605 (part), 1990: Ord. 1374, 1979: Ord. 1213, 1976; Ord. 1100 (part), 1973; Ord. 1075 (part), 1973; Ord. 974, 1969: Ord. 726, 1959: Ord. 483 § 7.0907(3), 1950). 
5.36.080 - Revocation of licenses. 
    The governing body of the city shall have power at any time to suspend or revoke any license granted under the provisions of this chapter whenever the governing body shall be satisfied from complaint that the business for which the license issued under this chapter has been or is being conducted in an indecent, indecorous, improper or illegal manner and the governing body may refund to the holder of such license such proportionate amount of the money paid therefor as the governing body may deem just. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 483 § 7.0908, 1950). 
5.36.090 - Driver's license. 
    No person shall drive a taxicab, motor bus or limousine in the city, unless he has procured a license as provided in this chapter. The license shall be known as a taxi driver's license. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 1605 (part), 1990: Ord. 483 § 7.0909, 1950). 
5.36.100 - Application for taxi driver's license. 
    Each applicant for a driver's license must comply with the following: 
(a)  Be a citizen of the United States; 
(b)  Be of the age of eighteen years or older; 
(c)  Be of sound physique and good eyesight, and not subject to epilepsy, vertigo, heart trouble or any other infirmity of body or mind which might render him unfit for the operation of a taxicab or bus; 
(d)  Be able to read and write the English language; 
(e)  Be clean in dress and person and not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors or drugs; 
(f)  Make a sworn statement giving his full name, residence, whether he has ever been convicted of a felony, and whether he has been previously licensed as a taxi, motor bus or limousine driver, and if so, where and when, and whether his license has ever been revoked, and for what cause. 
    The applications for driver's license shall be investigated by the chief of police, who shall make a recommendation of approval to the finance officer prior to issuance of license. 
    Every taxi driver shall, upon demand by a police officer, or a passenger, exhibit his license for inspection. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 684, 1958: Ord. 483 § 7.0910, 1950). 
5.36.110 - Fee for driver's license. 
    The annual license fee for taxi driver's license or renewal shall be ten dollars for the initial license and five dollars for the renewal. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 684, 1958: Ord. 483 § 7.0911, 1950). 
5.36.120 - Penalty for violations.
