    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to the penalty as provided in Section 1.04.130, fined in a sum of not less than ten dollars and not more than one hundred dollars and shall forfeit his license. 
(Ord. 1906 (part), 2001: Ord. 483 § 7.0912, 1950). 
Chapter 5.40 - MOBILE HOME/MANUFACTURED HOME PARKS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ordinances 822, 1092, 1268 and 1333. 

5.40.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section: 
(a)  "Buffer strip" means open spaces, landscaped areas, fences, walls, berms, or any combination thereof used to physically separate or screen one use or property from another so as to visually shield or block noise, lights, or other nuisances. 
(b)  "Building inspector" means the legally designated building inspector of the city or an authorized representative. 
(c)  "City engineer" means the legally designated city engineer of the city or an authorized representative. 
(d)  "City inspector" means the building inspector, health officer, zoning administrator, fire administrator, or city engineer, as the case may be. 
(e)  "Fire administrator" means the legally designated fire administrator of the city or an authorized representative. 
(f)  "Health officer" means the legally designated health officer of the city or an authorized representative. 
(g)  "Manufactured home" means a factory-built structure that is manufactured or constructed under the authority of 42 United States Code Section 5401 or amendments thereof and has a permanent frame and is to be used as a place for human habitation, but which is not constructed or equipped with a permanent hitch or other device allowing it to be moved other than for the purpose of moving to a permanent site, which does not have permanently attached to its body or frame any wheels or axles. A mobile home is not a manufactured home. Manufactured homes are constructed in accordance with HUD standards. 
(h)  "Mobile home" means a transportable, factory-built home, designed to be used as a year-round residential dwelling and built prior to the enactment of the Federal Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, which became effective June 15, 1976. 
(i)  "Mobile home/manufactured home park" means any plot of ground of at least eight acres upon which mobile homes, manufactured homes, or recreation vehicles occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, are located. A mobile home/manufactured home park consists of a number of mobile home/manufactured home spaces. 
(j)  "Mobile home/manufactured home space" means a plot of ground within a mobile home/manufactured home park, designated for the accommodation of one mobile home/manufactured home. 
(k)  "Motor home" means a vehicular unit built on a self-propelled motor chassis. 
(l)  "Permit" means a written permit issued by the building inspector permitting the mobile home/manufactured home park to operate under this chapter and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(m)  "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company or association. 
(n)  "Placement permit" means a written permit issued by the building inspector permitting a mobile home, manufactured home, motor home or travel trailer, to be placed in a legal mobile home/manufactured home park. 
(o)  "Travel trailer" means a vehicular portable unit, mounted on wheels designed to be drawn by a motorized vehicle and does not require a special highway movement permit. 
(p)  "Zoning administrator" means the legally designated zoning administrator of the city. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.020 - Parking regulations. 
(a)  No person shall park any mobile home/manufactured home on any street, alley or highway, or other public place, or on any tract of land occupied or unoccupied, within the city except as provided by this chapter. 
(b)  Emergency or temporary stopping or parking is permitted on any street, alley or highway for not longer than four hours subject to any other regulation imposed by the traffic and parking regulations of the city. 
(c)  Any occupied mobile home/manufactured home used for sleeping or living purposes shall not be parked for any period overnight except in a mobile home/manufactured home court. 
(d)  Parking of motor homes and travel trailers shall further be controlled by regulations found in Chapter 16 of this code. 
(e)  No person shall park or occupy any motor home, travel trailer or mobile home/manufactured home on the premises of any occupied dwelling or any vacant lot which is situated outside an approved mobile home/manufactured home court. The parking of only one unoccupied motor home or travel trailer in an accessory private garage building, or in a rear yard in any district may be permitted, provided, no living quarters shall be maintained or any business practiced in such motor home or travel trailer while so parked or stored. The above section does not apply to motor home, travel trailer or mobile home/manufactured home sales or storage lots. 
(f)  It is unlawful to locate a mobile home/manufactured home so that any part of such mobile home/manufactured home will obstruct any roadway or walkway in a mobile home/manufactured home park. 
(g)  It is unlawful to allow any mobile home/manufactured home to be occupied in a mobile home/manufactured home park unless the mobile home/manufactured home is situated on a mobile home/manufactured home space. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.030 - Permits. 
    It is unlawful for any person to construct, maintain or operate any mobile home/manufactured home park within the limits of the city unless they hold a valid permit issued annually by the building inspector in the name of such person for the specific mobile home/manufactured home park. All applications for permits shall be made to the building inspector, who shall issue a permit upon compliance by the applicant with provisions of this chapter and of any regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and of any other applicable legal requirements. Every person holding such a permit shall give notice in writing to the building inspector within seventy-two hours prior to making a sale, transfer or other conveyance of their interest in or control of any mobile home/manufactured home park. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such mobile home/manufactured home park. 
(a)  All applications for permits shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name and address of applicant; 
(2)  Location and legal description of the mobile home/manufactured home park; 
(3)  Complete engineering plans and specifications of the proposed park showing but not limited to the following: 
(A)  The location, area and dimensions of the mobile home/manufactured home park; 
(B)  The number, location and size of all mobile home/manufactured home spaces together with landscaping, recreational area and buffer strip plans; 
(C)  The location and width of roadways and walkways; 
(D)  The location of water and sewer lines and riser pipes; 
(E)  Plans and specifications of the water supply and refuse and sewage disposal facilities; 
(F)  Plans and specifications of all buildings constructed or to be constructed within the mobile home/manufactured home park; 
(G)  The location and details of lighting and electrical systems; 
(H)  The plans shall be approved by the following officials before a permit will be issued: 
(i)  Building inspector, 
(ii)  Health officer, 
(iii)  City engineer, 
(iv)  Fire administrator. 
(I)  The plan shall be submitted by the building inspector to the school board for their recommendations; 
(J)  All applications shall be accompanied by the deposit of a fee of one hundred dollars, nonrefundable; 
(K)  The owner of a mobile home/manufactured home park, granted a permit under this chapter shall, after receiving the necessary permits, proceed with development of the park as indicated on the park plan so that at least fifty percent of the mobile home/manufactured home park is complete and ready for occupancy within a twenty-four month period. Utilization of any mobile home/manufactured home space is contingent on prior completion of all phases of the park plan related to such space. 
(b)  How and Where Established. A mobile home/manufactured home park conforming to the regulations of this chapter may be established upon any tract of land in any district permitted by the zoning ordinances, provided: (1) The application has been recommended by the city planning commission; and (2) approved by the governing body. 
(c)  Applications for renewals of licenses shall be made in writing by the holders of the licenses, shall be accompanied by the deposit of a fee of twenty-five dollars and in addition thereto three dollars per lot, regardless whether the lot is occupied and shall contain any change in the information submitted since the original license was issued or the latest renewal granted. 
(d)  All permits shall be for one year, shall not be prorated, and shall expire on July 31st. No permit fees shall be subject to refund. 
(e)  Any person whose application for a permit under this chapter has been denied by request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the city commission under the procedure provided by Section 5.40.050. 
(f)  Whenever, upon inspection of any mobile home/manufactured home park, the city inspector finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this chapter, or any of the regulations adopted pursuant thereto, the city inspector shall give notice in writing in accordance with Section 5.40.050(a) to the person to whom the permit was issued that unless such conditions or practices are corrected within thirty days the permit will be suspended. At the end of such period, the city inspector shall reinspect such mobile home/manufactured home park and, if such conditions or practices have not been corrected, shall suspend the permit and give notice in writing of such suspension to whom the permit is issued. Upon receipt of notice of suspension, such person shall cease operation of such mobile home/manufactured home park except as provided in Section 5.40.050(b). 
(g)  Any person whose permit has been suspended, or who has received notice from the city inspector that their permit will be suspended unless certain conditions or practices at the mobile home/manufactured home park are corrected, may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the city commission, under the procedure provided by Section 5.40.050. Provided, that when no petition for such hearing shall have been filed within ten days following the day on which notice of suspension was served, such permit shall be deemed to have been automatically revoked at the expiration of such ten-day period. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.034 - Placement permit. 
(a)  It is unlawful to allow any mobile home/manufactured home to be occupied in a mobile home/manufactured home park unless the unit is situated on a mobile home/manufactured home space and a placement permit issued as herein provided. 
(b)  It will be the duty of every mobile home/manufactured home owner to file an application for a home placement permit with the building inspector before the date of the placement of the mobile home/manufactured home in a licensed park. The building inspector will cause an inspection of the mobile home/manufactured home space to be made to verify compliance of the units placement with the provisions of this chapter as well as Chapter 23.25. 
(c)  It will be the responsibility of every mobile home/manufactured home park licensee to inform every mobile home/manufactured home owner desiring to place their unit in said licensee's park of the need to obtain a building placement permit provided by the building inspector. The mobile home/manufactured home owner will have the responsibility of obtaining said permit from the building inspector and will pay a permit fee of twenty dollars at that time. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.036 - Accessory buildings and structures. 
    It is unlawful to alter, repair, or add detached or attached accessory buildings or structures without first obtaining a building permit. Permit issuance and fees will be in conformance with the codes applicable to the type of work involved. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.040 - Inspection of mobile home/manufactured home parks. 
(a)  The city inspectors are authorized and directed to make inspections to determine the condition of mobile home/manufactured home parks located within the city, in order that they may perform their duty of safeguarding the health and safety of occupants of mobile home/manufactured home parks and of the general public. 
(b)  The city inspectors shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon the private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this chapter or of regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(c)  The city inspectors shall have the power to inspect the register containing a record of all mobile homes/manufactured homes and occupants using the mobile home/manufactured home park. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the owners or occupants of mobile home/manufactured home parks, and mobile homes/manufactured homes contained therein, or of the person in charge thereof, to give any city inspector free access to such premises at reasonable times for the purpose of inspection. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of every occupant of a mobile home/manufactured home park to give the owner thereof or an agent or employee access to any part of such mobile home/manufactured home park or its premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with this chapter, or with any lawful regulations adopted thereunder, or with any lawful order issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.050 - Notices, hearings and orders. 
(a)  Whenever any city inspector determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, or of any regulation adopted pursuant thereto, they shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person to whom the permit was issued, as hereinafter provided. Such notice shall: (1) be in writing; (2) include a statement of the reasons for its issuance; (3) allow thirty days for the compliance with this chapter; and (4) be served upon the owner or his agent as the case may require. Provided, that such notice or order shall be deemed to have been properly served upon such owner or agent when a copy thereof has been sent by registered mail to the last known address; or when they have been served with such notice by any other method authorized or required by the laws of the state. 
(b)  Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this chapter, or of any regulation adopted pursuant thereto, may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the city commission; provided, that such person shall file in the office of the finance officer a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth a brief statement of the grounds therefor within ten days after the day the notice was served. The filing of the request for a hearing shall operate as a stay of the notice and/or the suspension except in the case of an order issued under Section 5.40.050(e). Upon receipt of such petition, the city commission shall set a time and place for such hearing, and shall give the petitioner written notice thereof, a copy of said notice to be given an opportunity to be heard, and to show why such notice should be modified or withdrawn. The hearing shall be commenced not later than the next regular meeting of the city commission after the petition was filed. Provided, that upon application of the petitioner, the city commission may postpone the date of the hearing for a reasonable time beyond such regular meeting when in their judgement the petitioner has submitted good and sufficient reasons for such postponement. 
(c)  After such hearing, the city commission shall make findings as to compliance with the provisions of this chapter, and regulations issued thereunder, and shall issue an order in writing sustaining, modifying or withdrawing the notice which shall be served as provided in Section 5.40.050(a). Upon failure to comply with any order sustaining or modifying notice, the permit of the mobile home park affected by the order shall be revoked. 
(d)  The proceedings at such a hearing, including the findings and decision of the city commission and together with a copy of every notice and order related thereto shall be entered as a matter of public record in the office of the building inspector but the transcript of the proceedings need not be transcribed unless judicial review of the decision is sought as provided by this section. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city commission may seek relief therefrom in any court of competent jurisdiction, as provided by the law of the state. 
(e)  Whenever any city inspector finds that an emergency exists which requires action to protect the public health, they may, without notice or hearing, issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency and requiring that such action be taken as they may deem necessary to meet the emergency including the suspension of the permit. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, such order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom such an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but upon petition to the city commission, shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible. The provisions of Section 5.40.050(c) and (d) shall be applicable to such hearing and the order issued thereafter. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.060 - Adoption of regulations by the city commission. 
    The city commission is authorized to make and, after public hearing, to adopt such written regulations as may be necessary for the proper enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Such regulations shall have the same force and effect as the provisions of this chapter, and the penalty for violation of the provisions thereof shall be the same as the penalty for violation of the provisions of this chapter, as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.070 - Design requirements of mobile home/manufactured home parks. 
(a)  GENERAL REQUIREMENTS. Condition of soil, ground water level, drainage and topography shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the occupants. The site shall not be exposed to objectionable smoke, noise, odors or other adverse influences, and no portion subject to unpredictable and/or sudden flooding, subsidence or erosion shall be used for any purpose which would expose persons or property to hazards. 
(b)  SOIL AND GROUND COVER REQUIREMENTS. Exposed ground surfaces in all parts of every mobile home park shall be paved or covered with other materials or protected with vegetation growth approved by the city engineer so that the same complies with the requirements of preventing soil erosion and of eliminating objectionable dust. 
(c)  SITE DRAINAGE REQUIREMENTS. The ground surface in all parts of every mobile home park shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe, efficient manner. 
(d)  Exterior Appearance Standards for Mobile Homes/Manufactured Homes in Parks Established after August 29, 2000. 
(1)  The exterior wall covering shall be either: 
(A)  Wood or masonry finish, or material that appears to be wood or masonry; and/or 
(B)  Vertically or horizontally grooved siding or lap siding, or material that appears to be vertically or horizontally grooved siding or lap siding; 
(2)  The mobile home/manufactured home shall have a pitched roof; 
(3)  The roofing material of the mobile home/manufactured home shall consist of either wood shakes, asphalt, composition, or wood shingles; clay, concrete, slate or metal tiles; 
(4)  The use of flat or corrugated sheet metal for the exterior walls or roof covering is prohibited. 
(e)  Mobile home/manufactured home parks must meet location, space, and general layout requirements as defined in Chapter 23.25 "R-6 Mobile Home/Manufactured Home District." 
(f)  Any mobile home/manufactured home park established prior to August 29, 2000 which undergoes a redesign or change to fifty percent or more of the spaces in the park shall meet the requirements of Section 23.25.010. These requirements shall apply to the entire mobile home/manufactured home park. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.074 - Mobile home/manufactured home stands. 
    The area of the mobile home/manufactured home stand shall be improved to provide adequate support for the placement and tie-down of the mobile home/manufactured home, thereby securing the superstructure against uplift, sliding, rotation and overturning in accordance with the following methods: 
(1)  The mobile home/manufactured home stand shall not heave, shift or settle unevenly under the weight of the mobile home/manufactured home due to frost action, inadequate drainage, vibration or other forces acting on the structure; and 
(2)  The mobile home/manufactured home stand shall be provided with anchors and tie-downs such as cast-in-place concrete "dead men", eyelets imbedded in concrete foundation of runways, screw augers, arrowhead anchors, or other devices securing the stability of the mobile home/manufactured home; or 
(3)  Anchors and tie-downs shall be placed at least at each corner of the mobile home/manufactured home stand and each shall be able to sustain a minimum tensile strength of two thousand eight hundred pounds. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.080 - Water supply. 
(a)  An accessible, adequate, safe and potable supply of water shall be provided in each mobile home/manufactured home park, capable of furnishing a minimum of two hundred fifty gallons per day per mobile home/manufactured home space. The development of an independent water supply to serve the mobile home/manufactured home park shall be made only after express approval has been granted by the health officer and city engineer. Where a public supply of water of such quality is available, connection shall be made thereto and its supply shall be used exclusively. 
(b)  The water system of the mobile home/manufactured home park shall be connected by pipes to all buildings and all mobile home/manufactured home spaces. 
(c)  All water piping shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with state and local law; the water piping system shall not be connected with nonpotable or questionable water supplies and shall be protected against the hazards of backflow or backsiphonage. 
(d)  Where drinking fountains are provided for public use, they shall be of a type and in locations approved by the health officer. 
(e)  Individual water service connections which are provided for direct use by mobile homes/manufactured homes shall be constructed that they will not be damaged by the parking of such mobile homes/manufactured homes. The mobile home/manufactured home park water system shall be adequate to provide twenty pounds per square inch of pressure at all mobile home/manufactured home connections. 
(f)  Where an independent or nonpublic water system is used to serve the mobile home/manufactured home park with water obtained from wells, the wells shall have been approved by the health officer, and shall have been drilled or driven. Springs or other sources of supply shall not be used unless approved by the health officer. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.090 - Sewage disposal. 
(a)  All plumbing in the mobile home/manufactured home park shall comply with state and local plumbing laws and regulations. 
(b)  Each independent mobile home/manufactured home space shall be provided with at least a three-inch sewer connection. The sewer connection shall be provided with suitable fittings, so that a watertight and gastight connection can be made between the mobile home/manufactured home drain and the sewer connection. Such individual mobile home/manufactured home connection shall be so constructed that they can be closed when not linked to a mobile home/manufactured home and shall be capped so as to prevent any escape of odor. 
    Where space is provided to accommodate recreation vehicles, i.e. camper trailers, pick-up trailers, etc., at least one station shall be provided for cleaning and flushing of holding tanks and filling of water tanks. 
(c)  Sewer lines shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city engineer and in accordance with his recommendations. All sewer lines shall be adequately vented, and shall be laid with sufficient earth to prevent breakage from traffic. 
(d)  Where the sewer lines of the mobile home/manufactured home park are not connected to a public sewer, a method of sewage disposal approved by the city engineer and in accordance with state law shall be based on the maximum capacity of the mobile home/manufactured home park. Effluents from sewage treatment facilities shall not be discharged into any waters of the state except with prior approval of the appropriate state authority and the local health officer. The disposal facilities shall be located where they will not create a nuisance or health hazard to the mobile home/manufactured home park or to the owner or occupants of any adjacent property. The approval of the city engineer shall be obtained on the type of treatment proposed and on the design of the disposal plant prior to construction. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.100 - Refuse disposal. 
(a)  The storage, collection and disposal of refuse in the mobile home/manufactured home park shall be so managed as to create no health hazards, rodent harborage, insect breeding areas, accident or fire hazards or air pollution. 
(b)  All refuse shall be stored in flytight, watertight, rodent-proof containers, which shall be located not more than one hundred fifty feet from any mobile home/manufactured home space. Containers shall be provided in sufficient number and capacity to properly store all refuse, and the place where the garbage and rubbish containers are located shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times on a platform or rack fifteen inches or more above the ground surface. 
(c)  Racks or holders shall be provided for all refuse containers. Such container racks or holders shall be so designed as to prevent containers from being tipped, to minimize spilling and container deterioration, and to facilitate cleaning around them. 
(d)  All refuse shall be collected in accordance with existing ordinances of the city. Where suitable collection service is not available from municipal or private agencies, the mobile home/manufactured home park operator shall provide this service. All refuse shall be collected and transported in covered vehicles or covered containers. 
(e)  The mobile home/manufactured home park operator shall dispose of the refuse in an approved manner. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.110 - Insect and rodent control. 
(a)  Insect and rodent control measures to safeguard public health as required by the health officer, shall be applied in the mobile home/manufactured home park. 
(b)  Effective larvicidal solutions may be required by the health officer for fly or mosquito breeding areas which cannot be controlled by other more permanent measures. 
(c)  The health officer may require the mobile home/manufactured home park operator to take suitable measures to control other insects and noxious weeds. 
(d)  Accumulations of debris which may provide harborage for rodents shall not be permitted in the mobile home/manufactured home park. 
(e)  When rats or other objectionable rodents are known to be in the mobile home/manufactured home park, the park operator shall take definite action, as directed by the health officer, to exterminate them. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.120 - Utilities. 
    All utility services shall be buried and shall comply with all applicable state and local codes and ordinances. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.130 - Fuel. 
    All piping from outside fuel storage tanks or cylinders to mobile homes/manufactured homes shall be copper or other approved tubing and shall be permanently installed and securely fastened in place. All fuel storage tanks or cylinders shall be securely fastened in place and shall not be located inside or beneath the mobile home/manufactured home or less than five feet from any mobile home/manufactured home exit. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.140 - Modification of mobile home/manufactured home. 
    It is unlawful for any person owning or operating a mobile home/manufactured home park to modify any mobile home/manufactured home in a manner that would prevent the ready removal of such mobile home/manufactured home. Such alteration shall be construed as removing it from the requirements of this chapter and converting it into a dwelling, and it shall be deemed to be in violation of the building code of the city. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.150 - Fire protection. 
(a)  The mobile home/manufactured home park area shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the city, and the fire prevention code. 
(b)  Mobile home/manufactured home park areas shall be kept free of litter, rubbish and other flammable materials. 
(c)  Portable fire extinguishers of a type approved by the fire administrator shall be kept in any buildings and at all other locations designated by the fire administrator and shall be maintained in good operating condition. 
(d)  Standard fire hydrants shall be located within four hundred feet of each mobile home/manufactured home or other buildings. 
(e)  Fires shall be made only in approved equipment intended for such purpose. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.160 - Restrictions of animals and pets. 
    No owner or person in charge of a dog, cat or other pet animal shall permit it to run at large, or to commit any nuisance within the limits of any mobile home/manufactured home park. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.170 - Registration of occupants. 
(a)  Every mobile home/manufactured home park owner or operator shall maintain a register containing a record of all mobile homes/manufactured homes and occupants using the mobile home/manufactured home park. Such register shall be available to any authorized person inspecting the park, and shall be preserved for the period required by the building inspector. Such register shall contain: (1) the names and addresses of all mobile home/manufactured home occupants stopping in the park; (2) the state, territory or county issuing the mobile home/manufactured home license; and (3) the dates of arrival and departure of each mobile home/manufactured home. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.180 - Supervision. 
    The person to whom a permit for a mobile home/manufactured home park is issued shall at all times operate the park in compliance with this chapter, rules and regulations issued thereunder, and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the park, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.190 - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, or any provision of any regulation adopted by the city commission pursuant to authority granted by this chapter, shall upon conviction be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or by imprisonment for not more than thirty days, and each day's failure of compliance with any such provision shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.200 - Conflict of ordinances-Effect of partial invalidity. 
(a)  In any case where a provision in this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any zoning, building, fire, safety or health ordinance or code of the city existing on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, the provision which, in the judgment of the health officer, established the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people shall prevail. In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any other ordinance or code of the city existing on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be deemed to prevail, and such other ordinances or codes are declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in conflict with this chapter. 
(b)  If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter should be declared invalid for any reason whatsoever, such decision shall not affect the remaining portions of this chapter, which shall remain in full force and effect; and to this end the provisions of this chapter are declared to be servable. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are repealed. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
5.40.210 - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall be in full force and effect from and after is passage, approval and publication as provided by law. 
(Ord. 1867 (part), 2000). 
Chapter 5.44 - PISTOLS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- General license provisions - See Ch. 5.04 of this code. Weapons - See Ch. 9.36 of this code. 

5.44.010 - License to sell. 
    Any person, persons, firm or corporation, desiring to engage in the business of selling pistols at retail, shall, before engaging in such business, file with the city auditor, a written statement and application setting forth his or its intention to engage in such business and shall give a description by lot and block of the premises on which said business is to be carried on. Said statement and application shall be accompanied by a license fee of two dollars, which fee is to be remitted by the city to the state treasurer when the license is granted, and also accompanied by three dollars to cover the expense of the city in making an investigation and having license issued, such license to be for the period of one year. 
(Ord. 483 7.1101, 1950). 
5.44.020 - Investigation. 
    The city auditor shall refer said application to the chief of police for investigation. The chief of police shall report to the governing body at its next regular meeting. Said application shall then be acted upon by the governing body at a regular meeting thereof. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.1102, 1950). 
5.44.030 - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, punished by a fine of not exceeding one hundred dollars, or imprisonment for not more than thirty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 1230, 1976; Ord. 483 § 7.1103, 1950). 
Chapter 5.45 - SIDEWALK BUSINESSES 

5.45.010 - Purpose. 
    Retail sales, sidewalk cafés, sidewalk pubs, and other approved uses of the public sidewalk encourage a pedestrian friendly environment and help to create a visually attractive and dynamic atmosphere within the City of Huron. This sidewalk use is a privilege granted by the city so long as the use is compatible with pedestrian use of the sidewalk, the use creates a positive environment and the use complies with other relevant provisions found in the revised ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2129-5-121, 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2178-5-126, 6-26-2016) 
5.45.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
(1)  Adjacent/adjoining business. The business immediately adjacent to a portion of the public sidewalk being used by the business. An adjacent/adjoining business shall be determined by extending the business property lines perpendicular to the curb. 
(2)  Designated pedestrian walkway. The portion of the sidewalk designated by the city in front of a sidewalk business zone that is at least 66 inches in width for a business that fronts on a street with diagonal parking or 48 inches in width for a business that fronts on a street with parallel parking unless otherwise designated by the city. Distances shall be measured from the back of the curb; i.e., the part of the concrete curb and gutter that is closest to the building front. The designated pedestrian walkway shall be kept clear of intrusions and obstructions in order to provide for pedestrian travel and access. 
(3)  Sidewalk. The portion of the designated public right-of-way which is hard-surfaced and not used for motor vehicle travel or motor vehicle parking. Generally, it will be that portion of the right-of-way which is located between the street curb and the parallel property line. 
(4)  Sidewalk business zone. The portion of the right-of-way (sidewalk or designated pedestrian walkway) adjacent to or adjoining the applicant's business. 
(5)  Sidewalk business zone use permit. A permit given by the city to an adjacent/adjoining business, which authorizes the adjacent/adjoining business, during the calendar year of the permit, the use of a specific portion of the city's designated pedestrian walkway for the use set forth in the permit. 
(6)  Sidewalk café. Licensed food service establishment which is authorized by the city to use the sidewalk business zone adjacent to its place of business for the purpose of serving food from its menu in an outdoor setting. Sidewalk cafés may serve alcohol if the business is an alcohol license holder. 
(7)  Sidewalk pub. The adjacent/adjoining business establishment licensed to serve alcoholic drinks for consumption on its premises and which, is authorized by the city to use the sidewalk business zone adjacent to its place of business for the purpose of serving alcoholic beverages in an outdoor setting. A sidewalk pub may serve food. 
(Ord. No. 2129-5-121, 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2178-5-126, 6-26-2016) 
5.45.030 - Sidewalk business zone authorization. 
(1)  Subject to prior approval by the governing board, retail business, sidewalk cafés with or without alcohol sales and consumption, and sidewalk pubs in sidewalk business zones may be authorized upon sidewalks pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  South Dakota Department of Transportation (SD DOT) approval for sidewalk business zones is also required for business located adjacent to Highway 37 (Dakota Avenue) and/or Highway 14. Pursuant to SDCL 35-4-77.1, no sidewalk business zone may authorize the sale and consumption of alcohol on the public right-of-way or sidewalk adjacent to a public street eligible for federal aid unless approved in accordance with the applicable requirements for the receipt of federal aid. 
(3)  Alcohol sale and consumption in sidewalk business zone. Pursuant to SDCL 35-4-77.1, the adjacent/adjoining business to a sidewalk business zone may serve alcoholic beverages provided that the adjacent/adjoining business is an alcohol license holder. The alcohol license holder must ensure that the legal description of their property on their alcohol license includes the adjacent public sidewalk. Approval by SD DOT may be required before issuance of a sidewalk business zone use permit if alcohol is to be served in the sidewalk business zone. 
(Ord. No. 2129-5-121, 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2178-5-126, 6-26-2016) 
5.45.040 - Permit and lease duration and fees. 
(1)  A sidewalk business zone use permit may be granted on a calendar year basis (January 1-December 31). 
(2)  Sidewalk business zone fees shall be established by resolution of the governing board. 
(Ord. No. 2129-5-121, 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2178-5-126, 6-26-2016) 
5.45.050 - Application for sidewalk business zone use permit. 
(1)  All applicants for sidewalk business zone use permits shall complete an application on a form provided by the city. 
(2)  As a requirement for obtaining a sidewalk business zone use permit, the applicant shall: 
(a)  Sign a statement holding harmless the city and shall indemnify the city, its officers and employees, for any claims for damages to property or injury to persons which may occur in connection with any activity carried on pursuant to the terms of the permit; and 
(b)  Maintain a policy of insurance protecting the applicant and the city from all claims for damage to property or bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operations under the sidewalk business zone use permit, or in connection therewith. The insurance policy shall list or endorse the city as additional insured and carry minimum liability limits of at least $1,000,000.00 per occurrence. The endorsement shall provide that the policy shall not be terminated or cancelled prior to the termination without 30 days' written notice to the city. The applicant shall furnish to the city, prior to issuance of the sidewalk business zone use permit, a copy of the insurance policy required by this provision, and which policy to remain in force during the period of the sidewalk business zone use permit. Any sidewalk business zone use permit shall be deemed void in the absence of a current insurance policy meeting the above criteria. 
(3)  Each application for a sidewalk business zone use permit shall be evaluated for the following criteria prior to issuance of a permit: 
(a)  Provisions of this chapter are adequately followed; 
(b)  All additional licenses or permits required by the city or state for the proposed use activity have been obtained; 
(c)  Placement of objects within the sidewalk business zone is consistent with the policies and standards developed by the planning department; 
(d)  Adequate clearances for pedestrian circulation exist within the site, including proper clearances from items such as light and/or utility poles, trash cans and whether proper pedestrian circulation may occur around the sidewalk business zone; and 
(e)  Safety concerns related to the requested sidewalk business zone have been addressed. 
(Ord. No. 2129-5-121, 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2178-5-126, 6-26-2016) 
5.45.060 - Application approval. 
(1)  The city shall consider the impact of each proposed use of the sidewalk business zone upon public property, public investments, public rights of access and way, and to businesses owners, property owners and residents in granting permission for allowing the requested use and reserves its right as steward of public right-of-way to limit, prohibit or place conditions on nonpublic uses of the public right-of-way. 
(2)  Any sidewalk business zone use permit granted by the city pursuant to this chapter shall convey to the adjoining business the right to use a designated portion of the sidewalk only for those purposes set forth in the sidewalk business zone use permit. The permit may contain those restrictions and conditions as deemed necessary by the city. The permit may not be assigned or sublet at any time during its term. The city shall have the right to suspend or terminate the permit for violation of any material term or condition thereof. Required compliance with all city ordinances and state statutes, including but not limited to the use of the public right-of-way, sidewalk use, noise and disturbing the peace, and alcohol sales and consumption, shall be deemed to be a material condition of the permit. 
(3)  The city shall, on each sidewalk business zone use permit, identify the designated pedestrian walkway. No retail or commercial business activity associated with the sidewalk business zone use permit is allowed to be conducted upon the designated pedestrian walkway, and no equipment or fixtures shall intrude upon or extend into the designated pedestrian walkway. The designated pedestrian walkway shall not be considered part of the sidewalk business zone, nor shall the uses allowed by this chapter apply to the designated pedestrian walkway which shall at all times remain free of any intrusion and obstruction. 
(4)  The city may attach conditions to the sidewalk business zone use permit to provide for the safety and welfare of the public and neighboring property interests, or may deny the requested use permit if it determines it is in the best interest of the public and neighboring property owners to deny the use permit. Conditions may also be added to a use permit during its term to address bona fide concerns that may arise after the issuance of the use permit. 
(Ord. No. 2129-5-121, 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2178-5-126, 6-26-2016) 
5.45.070 - Sidewalk business zone regulations. 
(1)  Temporary objects such as carts, planters, sandwich board menu signs (maximum of three square feet), benches, tables, chairs and fences may be placed within the sidewalk business zone by adjacent businesses only so long as the items do not encroach upon the designated pedestrian pathway or another's sidewalk business zone. 
(2)  Plans for sidewalk business zones must be approved by the City Engineer. No fixtures may be permanently attached to the sidewalk without the prior approval of the City Engineer. A fence is not considered fixtures for purposes of this provision provided the fence can be removed without damaging the sidewalk. A decision by the City Engineer to deny a request to attach a fence or other fixture to the sidewalk may be appealed to the governing board. 
(3)  The applicant for a sidewalk business zone use permit shall provide to the city, on a form provided by the city, such information as may be required which shall identify all proposed objects to be placed within the sidewalk business zone by an adjacent/adjoining business. 
(4)  Sidewalk business zone use permit holders shall maintain the permitted area in a clean manner and shall mitigate any impact activities associated with the permitted use which contribute to the uncleanliness of the sidewalk and surrounding area. Snow shall be removed from the sidewalk business zone to keep the area free of snow and ice. 
(5)  Noise generated in a sidewalk business zone cannot exceed the volume or be of such a nature as to be offensive to a reasonable person. Violation of this provision may result in the sidewalk business zone use permit being suspended in addition to a summons and complaint for disturbing the peace being filed against the person(s) responsible for making the noise. 
(6)  Food preparation on the sidewalk business zone is not allowed unless prior written approval has been given by the City Building Official or his/her designee. 
(7)  Unless otherwise approved by the City Planner and City Public Works Director, there shall be a physical barrier not less than forty-two inches high around the sidewalk business zone if alcohol is consumed or served in the area. 
(8)  Live entertainment may be allowed after the appropriate city permits are obtained. 
(Ord. No. 2129-5-121, 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2178-5-126, 6-26-2016) 
5.45.080 - Suspension of sidewalk business zone use permit, penalties. 
(1)  The City Commission hereby authorizes the City Planner, City Engineer, City Building Official and the Director of Public Safety, individually, to suspend a sidewalk business zone use permit upon determining, after investigation and consultation with the permit holder that any provision herein or any condition set forth in the permit has been violated. Upon suspension, the City Planner or his designee shall give written notice of the action to the permit holder stating the action which has been taken and the reason therefore. The action shall be effective immediately upon receipt of the notice of the action by the permit holder, but the permit holder may appeal the action to the governing board. An appeal does not stay the immediate effect of the action. 
(2)  If a business violates any provision of this chapter after having received notice of suspension of the use permit, a summons and complaint for violation of municipal ordinance shall be served on the owner or operator and the penalties set forth in Section 1.04.130 shall apply. 
(3)  Upon the owner(s) of the adjacent/adjoining business ceasing business operations in the adjacent/adjoining business location, all material placed in the sidewalk business zone by the adjacent/adjoining business shall be removed by the holder of the permit or license from the public right-of-way within ten days of ceasing business. 
(Ord. No. 2129-5-121, 4-8-2013; Ord. No. 2178-5-126, 6-26-2016) 
Chapter 5.46 - SPECIAL LICENSES AND PERMITS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2077, adopted May 24, 2010, amended Ch. 5.46 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 5.46, §§ 5.46.010-5.46.060, pertained to the same subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 2028 (part), adopted 2007; Ord. No. 2047 (part), adopted 2008 and Ord. No. 2065, adopted Sept. 28, 2009. 

5.46.010 - Issuance of special licenses. 
(1)  Any license issued pursuant to this section shall be issued to the organization/licensee and the location specified on the application, and shall be issued in the same manner as any other alcoholic beverage license including the requirement that notice of the application be published and a public hearing be held, with the exceptions that the state does not have to grant approval, the entire license fee remains in the municipality, and no public hearing is required for the issuance of a license pursuant to this section if the organization/licensee applying for the license holds an on-sale alcoholic beverage license or a retail malt beverage license or holds an operating agreement for a municipal on-sale alcoholic beverage license, and the license is to be used in a publicly owned facility. The term, public place, means any place, whether in or out of a building, commonly and customarily open to or used by the general public, and any street or highway. 
(2)  There shall be a special license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first day and five dollars ($5.00) per day thereafter. Any license issued pursuant to this section may be issued for a period of time established by the city commission, however, such period may not exceed fifteen (15) consecutive days, with each day expiring at twelve midnight. 
(3)  The city commission shall have sole discretion to approve or disapprove the application, depending on whether it deems the applicant to hold such license and whether it considers the proposed location suitable. Each applicant may only be issued fifty-two (52) special event licenses within one (1) calendar year. (SDCL 35-4-124) 
(a)  Special Malt Beverage Retailers License. A special malt beverage retailers license may be issued in conjunction with a special event within the municipality to any civic, charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans organization or any licensee licensed pursuant to SDCL 35-4-2(4) on-sale liquor or sixteen (16) malt beverage retailers being both package off-sale dealers and on-sale dealers, in addition to any other licenses held by the special events license applicant. 
(b)  Special On-Sale Wine Retailers License. A special on-sale wine retailers license may be issued in conjunction with a special event within the municipality to any civic, charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans organization or any licensee licensed pursuant to SDCL 35-4-2(4) on sale liquor, twelve (12) wine retailers being both package dealers and on-sale dealers, or SDCL 35-12 South Dakota Farm Wineries, in addition to any other licenses held by the special events license applicant. 
(c)  Special On-Sale License. A special on-sale license may be issued in conjunction with a special event within the municipality to any civic, charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans organization or any licensee licensed pursuant to SDCL 35-4-2(4) on sale liquor in addition to any other licenses held by the special events license applicant. 
(d)  Special Off-Sale Package South Dakota Farm Wine Dealers License. A special off-sale package South Dakota Farm Wine dealers license may be issued in conjunction with a special event within the municipality to any civic, charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans organization or any licensee licensed pursuant to SDCL 35-4-2(3) off-sale liquor, five (5) municipal off-sale liquor, twelve (12) wine retailers being both package dealers and on-sale dealers, (17A) off-sale malt beverage and South Dakota Farm Wine dealers, nineteen (19) off-sale package wine dealers in table wines, sparkling wines, sacramental wines, or SDCL 35-12 South Dakota Farm Wineries, in addition to any other licenses held by the special events license applicant. A special off-sale package wine dealers licensee may only sell wine manufactured by a farm winery that is licensed pursuant to SDCL 35-12 (South Dakota Farm Wineries). 
(e)  Special On-Sale Public Property License. Notwithstanding Section 5.46.020 (SDCL 35-1-5.3), the governing body may allow the sale of alcoholic beverages on public property or property owned by a nonprofit corporation during a special event. Any license issued pursuant to this section shall be issued to the person and the location specified on the application. 
(Ord. No. 2077, 5-24-2010; Ord. No. 2098, 6-6-2011; Ord. No. 2170-5-124, 2-8-2016) 
5.46.020 - Special permit for alcoholic beverage consumption on public property. 
(a)  The governing body may permit the consumption, but not the sale, of any alcoholic beverage on property owned by the public or by a nonprofit corporation within its jurisdiction. The permit period may not exceed twenty-four (24) hours and the hours of authorized consumption may not exceed those permitted for on-sale licensees. However, the governing body may permit the sale of alcoholic beverages on publicly owned property or property owned by a nonprofit corporation if it is during a special event for which a temporary license has been issued pursuant to Subsection 5.46.010 (3)(e). 
(b)  A special permit issued pursuant to this subsection may only be issued to the person(s) or organization, location and date specified for on the application. 
(c)  An application fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall be submitted with the application for the special permit. 
(d)  If the location for the public consumption request is for a city-owned park, the applicant must submit an application permit to the parks and recreation board not less than forty-five (45) days prior to the scheduled event in order to allow sufficient time for the board and city commission to consider the request. 
(e)  It is a violation of municipal ordinance for any person to consume distilled spirits in any public place other that upon the premises of an on-sale dealer that is licensed to sell distilled spirits or upon the location set forth in a permit granted by this subsection. For purposes of this section the term, public place, means any place, whether in or out of a building commonly and customarily open to or used by the general public, and any street or highway. It is also a violation of municipal ordinance for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage upon the premises of a licensed on-sale dealer if the alcoholic beverage was not purchased from the on-sale dealer. 
(Ord. No. 2077, 5-24-2010; Ord. No. 2098, 6-6-2011) 
5.46.025 - Beer gardens. 
(1)  Definition. A beer garden is defined as an open air, roofed or unroofed area on a licensed premises and where alcoholic beverages are served or consumed. Section 5.46.025 shall not apply to golf courses or property owned by the State of South Dakota. 
(2)  Permit required. 
(a)  A permanent permit is required prior to any licensed alcohol on-sale retailer is authorized to operate a beer garden twelve (12) days or more one calendar year. Applications for a beer garden permit shall be filed with the building inspector on a form provided by the building and inspections department. Upon receipt of a beer garden application the building inspector shall conduct an on-site inspection of the beer garden. If the beer garden is in compliance with all applicable ordinances then the application will be submitted, with recommendations from the building inspector and chief of police, to the city commission for consideration. If approved the building inspector will issue a permit to the applicant and notify the police department of the issuance of the permit. Issuance of a permanent beer garden permit shall be valid unless revoked pursuant to Section 5.46.025(7) or at the annual public hearing held subsequent to the licensee's application for renewal of licensee's alcohol license. 
(b)  A temporary permit is required prior to any licensed alcohol on-sale retailer is authorized to operate a beer garden for less than twelve days within one calendar year. Applications for a beer garden permit shall be filed with the building inspector on a form provided by the building and inspections department. A temporary permit application shall identify the dates, not to exceed twelve (12) total dates within one calendar year and the total dates identified within multiple temporary beer garden applications submitted for the same licensed location within one calendar year shall not exceed twelve total days. Upon receipt of a beer garden application the building inspector shall conduct an on-site inspection of the beer garden. If the beer garden is in compliance with all applicable ordinances then the application will be submitted, with recommendations from the building inspector and chief of police, to the city commission for consideration. If approved the building inspector will issue a permit to the applicant and notify the police department of the issuance of the permit. A temporary beer garden permit may be suspended by the commissioner of public safety for good cause, including but not limited to excessive noise or loud and inappropriate language coming from the beer garden, and disorderly conduct on the premises, or the commissioner of public safety may recommend revocation of the temporary beer garden permit consistent with Section 5.46.25(7). 
(c)  No on-sale licensee shall sell or allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverage on their premises outside of the licensee's fully-enclosed and permanent structure unless the alcoholic beverage is sold or consumed inside the beer garden and the licensee has been issued a beer garden permit pursuant to Section 5.46.025 (2)(a) or (2)(b). 
(d)  Upon an application prior to March 31, 2011, and approval by the city commission for a permanent beer garden permit, a licensee may enclose a permanent beer garden until April 30, 2011, by a snow fence or other physical barrier in lieu of the extruded vinyl, chain link, wood, iron or concrete fence. Section 5.45.025(2)(d) shall be effective until April 30, 2011. 
(3)  Fee. The fee for a permanent beer garden permit issued pursuant to Section 5.46.025(2)(a) shall be a one-time fee. The fee for a temporary beer garden permit issued pursuant to Section 5.46.025(2)(b) shall be required with each temporary beer garden application. Fees for permanent and temporary beer garden permits shall be established by resolution of the Huron City Commission. The fee for a permanent beer garden permit shall be waived for any alcohol licensee having a beer garden on the premises prior to July 1, 2010, enclosed by an extruded vinyl, chain link, wood, iron or concrete fence. 
(4)  Hours. The hours when the licensee may be open to the public pursuant to municipal ordinances ([Sections] 5.52.060 and 5.54.022) shall be applicable to beer gardens. 
(5)  Regulations. No beer garden shall be permitted, maintained, or operated except in conformity with the following regulations: 
(a)  (i)  Beer gardens operated twelve or more days within one calendar year shall be enclosed by a permanent physical barrier constructed of extruded vinyl, chain link, wood, iron or concrete fence not less than forty-two inches high surrounding the beer garden area. There shall be at least one fire exit in the fence. Any alcohol licensee having a beer garden on the premises prior to July 1, 2010, enclosed by a chain link, wood, iron or concrete fence less than forty-two inches high is not required to install a fence at least forty-two inches high until such time as any modification to the fence is made. 
(ii)  A beer garden operated pursuant to temporary permit may utilize a snow fence or other physical barrier in lieu of the extruded vinyl, chain link, wood, iron or concrete fence. 
(b)  All combustible rubbish shall be stored in noncombustible covered containers. 
(c)  The licensee must comply with all applicable building codes. 
(d)  The maximum number of persons within a beer garden shall be limited to the maximum number of persons which may be in a building having the same floor dimensions as the beer garden. 
(e)  Any noise emanating from the beer garden shall not violate the regulations of municipal ordinance and no person within the beer garden shall make any loud noise or profane language so as to unreasonably disturb the peace of the city, or any neighborhood, family, lawful assembly of persons or any person. 
(f)  No underage consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed on the premises. 
(g)  The alcohol licensee and licensee's agents and employees shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that persons in the beer garden do not violate municipal ordinance [Section] 9.56.010 (disorderly conduct) or any other municipal ordinance or state law and shall report perceived violations to the Huron Police Department. 
(6)  The licensee and/or the licensee's agent and/or licensee's employees shall be responsible for violations of Section 5.46.025 if the licensee, licensee's agent or licensee's employee does not take immediate steps to stop the violations, with such steps including but not limited to timely reporting of violations to the Huron Police Department. Individual patrons within the beer garden may also be held responsible for violations of Sections 5.46.025(5)(e) and (f). Individual patrons within the beer garden may also be held responsible for violations of Sections 5.46.025(5)(g) and (h). 
(7)  Revocation of permit. In addition to the penalties provided for in Section 5.46.060, upon seven days prior written notice from the City of Huron a beer garden permit issued pursuant to Section 5.46.025(2) may be revoked by the city commission for a licensee's violation of Section 5.46.025(5). A licensee who has had its beer garden permit revoked due to a violation of Section 5.46.025(5)(c) may apply for a new beer garden permit upon coming into compliance with the Huron Municipal Building Code. A licensee whose beer garden permit has been revoked for reasons other than a violation of Section 5.46.025(5)(c) may not apply for a new beer garden permit in less than three (3) months from the date of revocation. Issuance of a new beer garden permit following a revocation shall require submission of a new beer garden permit application, application fee, and satisfactory re-inspection of the beer garden before a new beer garden permit shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 2087, 10-4-2010) 
5.46.030 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any organization, licensee or person violating any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty days or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 2077, 5-24-2010) 
Chapter 5.48 - LIQUOR-OFF-SALE[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Powers of municipalities to control alcoholic beverages are specifically granted by SDC 5.0108. 
Cross reference- General license provisions-See Ch. 5.04 of this code; Alcoholic beverages-See Ch. 9.04 of this code; Prior ordinance history: Ordinances 483, 804, 873, 893, 946, 980, 1034, 1106, 1297, 1321 and 1341. 

5.48.010 - Definition. 
    The terms used in this title, unless the context otherwise plainly requires, shall mean the same as is defined in SDCL, Chapter 35-1. 
(Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.020 - License required. 
    No person shall sell, exchange, barter, distribute or keep for sale any alcoholic beverages, as herein defined, without having obtained a license therefor, pursuant to the provisions of Title 35 of the South Dakota Codified Laws. 
(Ord. 1572 (part), 1988: Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.030 - Classes of licenses. 
    All classes of licenses shall be as set out in Title 35 of the South Dakota Codified Laws, except where otherwise indicated. 
(Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.040 - Application for "off-sale" license. 
    Any person desiring to enter into the "off-sale" alcoholic beverage business in the city shall make an application for an "off-sale" license under the provisions of Title 35 of the South Dakota Codified Laws. The application shall be presented with a surety bond to the city finance officer, together with a certified check in the amount of five hundred dollars to pay the license fee for the license. 
(Ord. 1572 (part), 1988: Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.050 - Place of business. 
    The governing body shall not approve any application for "off-sale" licenses to sell alcoholic beverages other than malt beverages in the city in any place of business unless the same faces upon the streets hereinafter mentioned or is located within the following area: 
    Unless the place of business faces upon Dakota Avenue South and is located on that part thereof which is south of the south line of Market Street South and north of the south line of Fourth Street South; or is located upon that part of Dakota Avenue South, and faces east on the same and is between the south line of Fourth Street Southwest, and the south line of a parcel of property described as the north forty feet of Lots Seven, Eight, Nine, Ten, Eleven, Twelve, Thirteen and the east five feet of the north forty feet of Lot Fourteen, all in Block Fifteen, Second Railway Addition to Huron; or unless the place of business faces west on Wisconsin Avenue Southwest between the north line of Fourth Street Southwest, and the south line of Third Street Southwest and faces east or west on Wisconsin Avenue Southwest between the north line of Third Street Southwest and the south line of Second Street Southwest; or unless the place of business is located on the south fifty feet of the north eighty feet of Lot Seven, Block One, First Ashland Park Addition in the city of Huron, South Dakota; or unless the place of business is located on Outlot Two of Outlot One of the SE1/4; of SE1/4; of 12-110-62 in the city of Huron, or unless the place of business is located on Lot One of the Replat of City Tract "A" in the NE1/4; of 6-110-61 in the city of Huron, South Dakota; or unless located on Christen-Osborn Field Estates, Fourth Addition, as replatted, city of Huron, Beadle County, South Dakota or unless the property is located on Lot 12, Block 2, First North Huron Addition, or unless located on Outlot Four and Five of SE1/4; of SE1/4; of SE1/4; of 12-110-62, in the city of Huron, South Dakota; or unless located on Lots Twenty-Four, Twenty-Five, Twenty-Six and Twenty-Seven, Block Three, Prospect Park Addition in the city of Huron, South Dakota; or unless located on Super Tract A and Part of Block B, Blocks 83-124, Sixth Railway Addition and Resurvey Lots. 
    Any person, partnership, firm, corporation or agency seeking an off-sale alcoholic beverage license, other than a malt beverage license, whose application reveals that the proposed location of the business is outside of the established off-sale alcoholic beverage license zone shall deposit with the city finance officer the sum of fifty dollars as reimbursement to the city for expenses incurred in the process of amending the off-sale alcoholic beverage license zone or place of business as requested in the original application for the liquor license. 
(Ord. 1756, 1995: Ord. 1585, 1989: Ord. 1572 (part), 1988: Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.060 - Hours of sale. 
    No person shall sell "off-sale" alcoholic beverages within the city between two a.m. and seven a.m., nor shall they sell "off-sale" alcoholic beverages on Christmas Day. 
(Ord. 1572 (part), 1988: Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
(Ord. No. 2065, 9-28-2009; Ord. No. 2068, 10-26-2009; Ord. No. 2077, 5-24-2010; Ord. No. 2163-5-123, 8-31-2015) 
5.48.070 - No sale without license. 
    No person shall sell within the city any alcoholic beverages in the original package unless he holds the appropriate license under Title 35 of the South Dakota Codified Laws. 
(Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.080 - Unlawful to refill containers. 
    It shall be unlawful to refill any container of alcoholic beverage except beer and the beer container may be refilled only by a manufacturer or distributor as defined by Title 35 of the South Dakota Codified Laws. 
(Ord. 1572 (part), 1988: Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.090 - No delivery-Purchase only from licensed dealers. 
    No package dealer or off-sale dealer as defined by this chapter shall permit or shall make any deliveries of alcoholic beverages outside his place of business. No person shall buy any alcoholic beverages in package except from a package dealer, holding a valid license. 
(Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.100 - Unsealed package. 
    No person shall have an unsealed package or any receptacle containing an alcoholic beverage in his possession in a public place within the city, except as may be allowed by Title 35 of the South Dakota Codified Laws. 
(Ord. 1849, 1999: Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.110 - Sale to certain persons prohibited. 
    No off-sale licensee may sell any alcoholic beverages: 
(1)  To any person under the age of twenty-one years; 
(2)  To any person who is obviously intoxicated at the time, or who is known to the seller to be a habitual drunkard. 
(Ord. 1572 (part), 1988: Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.120 - Intoxicated persons prohibited on premises. 
    No licensee shall permit any intoxicated persons to enter his premises, nor shall he permit any person to become intoxicated thereon or therein. No person shall give or sell any alcoholic beverage to any person who is intoxicated. 
(Ord. 1572 (part), 1988: Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.130 - Revocation of license. 
    Any off-sale license issued within the city may be revoked for any violation of this chapter or the laws of the state of South Dakota relative to the sale of alcoholic beverages or to the conduct of the business of the licensee after hearing in the manner as provided by Title 35 of the South Dakota Codified Laws. 
(Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
5.48.140 - Sale of other commodities. 
1)  Any person, corporation, or business entity that is issued a new license under SDCL 35-4-2(3) off-sale liquor in a municipality of the first class after June 30, 2008, and derives more than fifty percent of the licensee's annual gross receipts from the sale of food, prepared food, and food ingredients at the location where the license is held, shall display its alcoholic beverages, other than malt beverages and wine, in one area which is separated by a physical barrier from the rest of the establishment. For the purposes of this section, a physical barrier includes a wall or fence erected for the sole purpose of separating the area in which the alcoholic beverages are displayed from the rest of the establishment. 
State Law reference- SDCL 35-4-121 
2)  Any person, corporation, or business entity that is issued a new retail license under subdivision [SDCL] 35-4-2(3) off-sale liquor after June 30, 2009, and derives less than fifty percent of the licensee's annual gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages at the location where the license is held shall display its alcoholic beverages, other than malt beverages and wine, in one area which is separated by a physical barrier from the rest of the establishment. For the purposes of this section, a physical barrier includes a wall or fence erected for the sole purpose of separating the area in which the alcoholic beverages are displayed from the rest of the establishment. 
State Law reference- SDCL 35-4-122 
(Ord. 1766, 1995: Ord. 1572 (part), 1988: Ord. 1536 (part), 1986). 
(Ord. No. 2077, 5-24-2010) 
5.48.150 - Off-sale liquor server-Minimum age. 
    No off-sale licensee may permit any person less than twenty-one years old to sell, serve or dispense alcoholic beverages on or from the licensed premises. However, an off-sale licensee may permit persons eighteen years old or older to sell alcoholic beverages if less than fifty percent of the gross business transacted by that establishment is from the sale of alcoholic beverages and the licensee or an employee that is at least twenty-one years of age is on the premises when the alcoholic beverage is sold, served or dispensed. 
(Ord. 1572 (part), 1988). 
(Ord. No. 2077, 5-24-2010) 
State Law reference- SDCL 35-4-79.1 
Chapter 5.52 - LIQUOR-ON-SALE[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Powers of municipalities to control alcoholic beverages are specifically granted by SDC 5.0108. 
Cross reference- General license provisions - See Ch. 5.04 of this code; Alcoholic beverages - See Ch. 9.04 of this code. 

5.52.010 - Definition. 
    The terms used in this title, unless the context otherwise plainly requires, shall mean the same as is defined in SDCL, Chapter 35-1. 
(Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 483 7.1302, 1950). 
5.52.020 - License required. 
    No person shall sell, exchange, barter, distribute or keep for sale as an on-sale dealer any alcoholic beverage, as hereinafter defined, without having obtained a license therefor as required by state law. 
(Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 483 7.1301, 1950). 
5.52.021 - On-sale dealer fees. 
    The following classifications and fees are established for on-sale dealers in distilled spirits: 
(1)  On-Sale Dealer. Any person who sells or keeps for sale any alcoholic beverages other than pursuant to another license hereunder, for consumption on the premises where sold. License fee is one thousand five hundred dollars. License fee for nonprofit organizations operating less than sixty days per year is three hundred dollars. Airport license fee is two hundred fifty dollars. 
(2)  Sunday Retail Dealer. Any on-sale dealer licensed under subsection (1) above, which licensee has the facilities for the serving of prepared meals from a fixed restaurant. The term "restaurant" as used herein shall mean only a room, having a seating capacity for at least fifty guests, regularly and in a bona fide manner used and kept open for the serving of meals to guests for compensation, and having a kitchen connected therewith containing fixtures and appliances sufficient to provide meals in a bona fide manner for at least fifty guests at one and the same time. A Sunday retail dealer licensed in accordance with this section shall also obtain a "Food Service Establishment" license as required by SDCL 34-18-10 and amendments thereto. 
(Ord. 1866, 2000; Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 1537 (part), 1986). 
(Ord. No. 2062, 8-3-2009; Ord. No. 2065, 9-28-2009) 
5.52.022 - Inspection required. 
    All initial applications for retail on-sale licenses and all applicants for transfer of retail on-sale licenses to another location shall be accompanied by a certification that the premises have been inspected and approved by a State Electrical Inspector. Applications for new or transfer of on-sale liquor licenses to another location shall be referred to the building inspector and chief of fire department who shall inspect the building or premises described in the application to determine whether the same complies with the regulations, ordinances and laws applicable thereto. Such officers shall furnish to the governing body the information obtained in such investigation, accompanied by a recommendation as to whether a license should be granted or refused. No license shall be extended or renewed without the inspection and report and recommendation of the officers named herein, as above provided. 
(Ord. 1459, 1982). 
(Ord. No. 2081, 8-2-2010) 
5.52.030 - Place of business or area in which alcoholic beverages other than malt beverages "on-sale" may be sold. 
    The governing body shall not approve any application for "on-sale" licenses to sell alcoholic beverages other than malt beverages in the city in any place or business unless the same faces upon the streets hereinafter mentioned or is located within the following areas: 
    Unless the place of business faces on Dakota Avenue South between the south property line of Second Street and the north property line of Fifth Street; or unless the place of business fronts on Third Street Southwest, between the west property line of Dakota Avenue South and the east property line of Illinois Avenue Southwest; or unless the place of business fronts on Wisconsin Avenue Southwest, between the north property line of Second Street Southwest and the south property line of Fourth Street Southwest; or unless the place of business fronts on Fourth Street Northeast and located in and upon real property described as City Tract "A" in the northwest quarter of the northeast quarter (NW1/4 NE1/4) of Section Six, Township One Hundred Ten, Range Sixty-one, west of the 5th P.M.; or unless the place of business is located on Lots No. 5 and 6, Block 2, H.P. Browns Addition to the city of Huron; or unless the place of business is located at Twenty-first Street Southeast and Frank Avenue Southeast in and on real property described as Lot 9, Block 2, of Sutter's Subdivision of the city of Huron; or unless the place of business is located on Third Street Southwest in and on real property described as Outlot 2 of SW 1/4 of NE 1/4 of Outlot B of 2-110-62 to the city of Huron; or unless the place of business is located on Christen-Osborn Field Estates, Fourth Addition, as replatted; or unless business is located on Lots 1 and 2, Huron Center Addition; or unless the place of business is located on Lot 18, Block 4, Bloodgood's Addition to the city of Huron. 
    Any person, partnership, firm, corporation or agency seeking an on-sale alcoholic beverages other than malt beverages license whose application reveals that the proposed location of the business lies outside of the established on-sale alcoholic beverages other than malt beverages license zone shall deposit with the city finance officer the sum of fifty dollars as reimbursement to the city for expenses incurred in the process of amending the on-sale alcoholic beverages other than malt beverages license zone or place of business as requested in the original application for the liquor license. 
(Ord. 1898, 2000: Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 1542, 1986: Ord. 1326, 1978: Ord. 1320, 1978: Ord. 1296, 1977: Ord. 1076 (part), 1973: Ord. 1015, 1971: Ord. 944, 1967: Ord. 694 § 1, 1958: Ord. 483 § 7.1314, 1950). 
5.52.040 - Requirements of premises. 
    No "on-sale" licensee shall be permitted to serve alcoholic beverages except on the premises authorized by the state Department of Revenue issued license, and no alcoholic beverages shall be served in any booth wherein all of the occupants therein are not in full view of every other occupant in the room and observable from any and all points in the room.
