No "on-sale" licensee shall allow any game of skill or chance or athletic contest on the premises, or permit any slot machine or other like gambling device, in or about the licensed premises. 
(Ord. 996 (part), 1971: Ord. 483 § 7.1304, 1950). 
5.52.050 - Minors prohibited on premises. 
(1)  No "on-sale" licensee shall permit any person less than twenty-one years old to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages on such premises where the business under the license is authorized. 
(2)  No "on-sale" licensee shall permit any person under the age of twenty-one years to loiter or to consume alcoholic beverages on such premises where the business under the license is authorized, unless such person under the age of twenty-one years is in the immediate presence of a parent or guardian or spouse over twenty-one years of age. 
(Ord. 1152, 1974; Ord. 996 (part), 1971: Ord. 483 § 7.1305, 1950). 
5.52.060 - Sale prohibited at designated times. 
    No "on-sale" liquor licensee, shall sell, serve, or allow to be consumed on the premises covered by the license, alcoholic beverages between two a.m. and seven a.m. of the following day, or at anytime on Christmas Day except as provided hereinafter under Section 5.52.070. On business days when Daylight Saving Time goes into effect (second Sunday in March at two a.m.), businesses subject to this chapter must close at two a.m. On business days when Daylight Saving Time terminates (first Sunday in November at two a.m. when two a.m. becomes one a.m.), businesses subject to this chapter are entitled to remain open and sell "on-sale" liquor for one additional hour (until what would otherwise have been three a.m. had not there been termination of Daylight Saving Time). 
(Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 1076 (part), 1973: Ord. 1073, 1973; Ord. 996 (part), 1971: Ord. 823 (part), 1963: Ord. 555 § 1, 1953: Ord. 483 § 7.1306, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2065, 9-28-2009; Ord. No. 2163-5-123, 8-31-2015) 
5.52.070 - Procedure and hours of business. 
(1)  Every "on-sale" licensee shall flash the lights on his place of business at one forty-five a.m. each day as a warning that within fifteen minutes, his place of business will close. At the closing hour every "on-sale" dealer shall clear his premises of customers and patrons and shall lock all doors to the premises and shall turn out all lights therein, except such an interior night light for security purposes, as approved by the chief of police. Such night light shall burn from two a.m. until the business reopens. Except as provided in this section, the "on-sale licensee" and his employees shall leave the place of business or premises within thirty minutes after the closing hour and every "on-sale" licensee, after closing his place of business or premises at the authorized closing hour on every morning shall keep the premises closed and locked until seven a.m. the following morning. 
(2)  On business days when Daylight Saving Time goes into effect (second Sunday in March at two a.m.), businesses subject to this chapter must close at two a.m. On business days when Daylight Saving Time terminates (first Sunday in November at two a.m. when two a.m. becomes one a.m.), businesses subject to this chapter are entitled to remain open and sell "on-sale" liquor for one additional hour (until what would otherwise have been three a.m. had not there been termination of Daylight Saving Time). 
(Ord. 2022, 2006; Ord. 1994, 2005; Ord. 1899, 2000; Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 1185, 1975: Ord. 1076 (part), 1973; Ord. 1073, 1973; Ord. 996 (part), 1971: Ord. 823 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 7.1307, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2065, 9-28-2009; Ord. No. 2163-5-123, 8-31-2015) 
5.52.080 - Sanitation. 
    Every on-sale dealer shall maintain upon his licensed premises, toilets properly connected with the city sewer system, and he shall maintain thereon separate toilet facilities for men and women; in each toilet room, there shall be maintained a suitable oval wash bowl and there shall be maintained in each of the toilets running water and towels for use by the users of such facilities. Every on-sale licensee shall have his bar equipped with, and use, drainboards and sinks for the washing of glasses and bar equipment; the same shall be constructed of copper or monel metal; the sink shall be oval in shape; the sink and drain board shall be connected with the city sewer system; and there shall be installed and maintained in each sink running water for use therein; all glassware and other containers used in serving liquor shall be rinsed in a disinfectant solution; and same shall then be thoroughly washed, rinsed, and dried before being reused. 
(Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 483 § 7.1308, 1950). 
5.52.090 - Tax stamps. 
    No person shall have in his possession within the city any alcoholic beverage on which the state tax has not been paid and without having same in a container upon which the state tax has not been paid and without having same in a container upon which a stamp evidencing payment of the tax as provided by the laws of the state of South Dakota is securely affixed and cancelled, provided this shall not apply to alcoholic beverage in the possession of a distributor. 
(Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 1537 (part), 1986). 
5.52.100 - Sale to certain persons prohibited. 
    No licensee may sell alcoholic beverages: 
(1)  To any person under the age of twenty-one years; 
(2)  To any person who is obviously intoxicated at the time, or who is known to the seller to be a habitual drunkard. 
(Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 1537 (part), 1986). 
5.52.110 - Intoxicated persons prohibited on premises. 
    No licensee shall permit any intoxicated person to enter his premises, nor shall he permit any person to become intoxicated thereon or therein. No person shall give or sell alcoholic beverages to any person who is intoxicated. 
(Ord. 1573 (part), 1988: Ord. 483 § 7.1311, 1950). 
5.52.120 - On-sale liquor server-Minimum age. 
    No on-sale licensee may permit any person less than twenty-one years of age to sell, serve or dispense alcoholic beverage upon the licensed premises. However, an on-sale licensee may permit persons eighteen years old or older to sell and serve or dispense alcoholic beverages if less than fifty percent of the gross business transacted by that establishment is from the sale of alcoholic beverages and the licensee or an employee that is at least twenty-one years of age is on the premises when the alcoholic beverage is sold or dispensed. For the purposes of this section, the term to sell and serve alcoholic beverages means to take orders for alcoholic beverages and to deliver alcoholic beverages to customers as a normal adjunct of waiting tables. The term does not include tending bar or mixing alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. 1573 (part), 1988). 
(Ord. No. 2077, 5-24-2010) 
State Law reference- SDCL 35-4-79 
Chapter 5.53 - FULL-SERVICE ON-SALE RESTAURANT LICENSES 

5.53.010 - Definitions of terms. 
(1)  "Bar," any permanently installed counter within the restaurant area from which alcoholic beverages are regularly served to customers by a person who is tending bar or drawing or mixing alcoholic beverages; 
(2)  "Full-service restaurant," any restaurant at which a waiter or waitress delivers food and drink offered from a printed food menu to patrons at tables, booths, or the bar. Any restaurant that only serves fry orders or food such as sandwiches, hamburgers, or salads is not a full-service restaurant; 
(3)  "Restaurant," any area in a building maintained, advertised, and held out to the public as a place where individually priced meals are prepared and served primarily for consumption in such area and where not more than forty percent of the gross revenue of the restaurant is derived from the sale of alcohol or alcoholic beverages. The restaurant shall have a dining room or rooms, a kitchen, and the number and kinds of employees necessary for the preparing, cooking, and serving of meals. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
5.53.020 - License application requirements. 
    Documentation: An applicant for a full-service restaurant on-sale license shall provide sufficient documentation to the municipality with an application form provided by the municipality to prove that the primary source of revenue from the operation of the restaurant will be derived from the sale of prepared food and nonalcoholic beverages and not from the sale of alcoholic beverages. The supporting documentation concerning the primary source of revenue submitted pursuant to this section is confidential. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
5.53.030 - Annual reports. 
    The full-service restaurant on-sale licensee shall submit an annual report and supporting documentation to the City on forms provided by the City of the annual sales of the full-service restaurant, which includes an oath verifying the validity of the information provided in the report. The report and the supporting documentation submitted pursuant to this section are confidential. The report shall contain the annual gross sales of the licensee for the following two categories: 
(1)  Food and nonalcoholic beverage sales; and 
(2)  Alcoholic beverages sales. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
5.53.040 - License renewals. 
    When renewing a full-service restaurant on-sale license, the City shall condition the license renewal upon receiving documentation that not more than forty percent of gross sales from the preceding twelve months operation of the full-service restaurant is derived from the sale of alcohol or alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
5.53.050 - Only retail, on-sale service permitted. 
    A full-service restaurant on-sale licensee may only serve alcoholic beverages for on-premise consumption in the bar and dining room area of the restaurant. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
5.53.060 - Smoking prohibited. 
    No licensee that has a full-service restaurant on-sale license may allow smoking on the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
5.53.070 - Full-service restaurant license fees. 
(1)  As required by State law, the license fee charged for a full-service restaurant on-sale license shall be at or above the current fair market value for such license as determined herein. However, any fair market value so established shall be a minimum of one dollar for each person residing within the City as measured by the last preceding decennial federal census. 
(2)  The license fee shall be initially established by Resolution within ninety (90) days of the initial adoption of this chapter. Subsequent changes in the license fee shall not be made for a period of ten (10) years from the effective date of adoption of this chapter unless a population growth reported by the Federal decennial census requires an increase in the fee. 
(3)  Fair Market Value for full-service restaurant license shall be established as follows: 
(a)  Within 90 days of the effective date of this chapter and as required by State statute, each licensee within the City who owns an on-sale license issued pursuant to SDCL 35-4-2 (4) or (6) as of January 1, 2008, and who purchased the license or had the license transferred to such licensee at any time between January 1, 2003, and January 1, 2008, shall report the amount originally paid for the on-sale license to the City of Huron Finance Department on forms provided by the City. Any form submitted pursuant to this provision shall be signed under oath and shall include the documents establishing the amount originally paid for the on-sale license. If the transaction for the purchase of the on-sale license included real or personal property, the full market value of the real or personal property on the date of the original sale shall be deducted from the total transaction price to determine the amount paid by the licensee for the on-sale license. The burden of establishing the amount paid for the license shall be on the licensee. Any licensee contesting the fair market value of the real or personal property may appeal the valuation adopted by the City to circuit court. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the term, "Current Fair Market Value" means the documented price of the on-sale license most recently sold between January 1, 2003, and January 1, 2008, through an arm's length transaction, less the value of any real or personal property included within the transaction. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
5.53.080 - Registry of full-service restaurant on-sale licensees. 
    The City shall maintain a registry of each full-service on-sale restaurant license that is being offered for sale and the City shall furnish a copy of the registry to anyone who requests a new-full service restaurant on-sale license. The existing full-service restaurant on-sale licensee is responsible for registering with the City that the full-service restaurant on-sale license is for sale. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
5.53.090 - Issuance of new full-service restaurant licenses restricted. 
    The City may only issue a new license pursuant to this chapter if no on-sale license is on the registry or a person desiring to purchase an on-sale license listed on the registry provides documentation showing that the person is unable to purchase the on-sale license at the price established in section 5.53.070 of this chapter and on terms satisfactory to both the potential buyer and seller. The price of any on-sale license registered as "for sale" with the City shall be sold at the current fair market price set by the City pursuant to a Resolution adopted in accordance with subsection 5.53.070 (2) of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
5.53.100 - Conflicts repealed. 
    Any or all ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 2180-5-127, 12-19-2016) 
Chapter 5.54. - MALT BEVERAGE AND SOUTH DAKOTA FARM WINE LICENSE[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2193-5-128, adopted May 14, 2017, amended Ch. 5.54 title to read as herein set out. The former Ch. 5.54 title pertained to malt beverage and malt beverage/South Dakota farm wine licenses. 

5.54.010 - Definitions. 
    The term used in this chapter unless the context otherwise plainly requires shall mean as follows: 
(a)  "Malt beverage" means an alcoholic beverage as defined by Title 35 of South Dakota Codified Laws. 
(b)  "On-sale" means the sale of malt beverage for the consumption upon the premises where sold. 
(c)  "Off-sale" means the sale of malt beverage for consumption off the premises where sold. 
(d)  "Dealer" means any holder of a malt beverage retailer license, being both package dealers and on-sale dealers. 
(e)  "South Dakota Farm Wine" means an alcoholic beverage as defined by SDCL 35-12-1. 
(Ord. 2026 (part), 2007). 
(Ord. No. 2098, 6-6-2011) 
5.54.012 - Classification and fees. 
    This license allows the business to sell any type of malt beverage and also sell South Dakota Farm Winery wines. No other type of wine may be sold. The licensing period runs from July 1 through June 30. The annual license fee is $300.00. The fee to transfer a license is $150.00. 
(Ord. 2047 (part), 2008; Ord. 2026 (part), 2007). 
(Ord. No. 2061, 7-20-2009; Ord. No. 2098, 6-6-2011; Ord. No. 2193-5-128, 5-14-2017) 
5.54.014 - Application review procedures. 
    License applications are available at the city finance office. All applications must be completed with fees collected prior to being submitted to the city commission for consideration. Notice of the application must be published in the local newspaper with a public hearing being held not less than seven (7) days after official publication. The governing board shall have discretion to approve or disapprove the application depending on whether it deems the applicant a suitable person to hold such license and whether it considers the proposed location suitable. 
(Ord. 2026 (part), 2007). 
(Ord. No. 2098, 6-6-2011) 
5.54.020 - Age restriction. 
    No dealer may sell any alcoholic beverages to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. No dealer may permit any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to loiter on such premises where the business under the license is authorized, unless such person under the age of twenty-one (21) years is in the immediate presence of a parent or guardian or spouse over twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(Ord. 2047 (part), 2008; Ord. 2026 (part), 2007). 
(Ord. No. 2098, 6-6-2011; Ord. No. 2193-5-128, 5-14-2017) 
5.54.022 - Procedures and hours of business. 
(a)  Opening and closing hours shall be between the hours of seven a.m. through two a.m. every day, including Sunday. On business days when Daylight Saving Time goes into effect (second Sunday in March at two a.m.), businesses subject to this chapter must close at two a.m. On business days when Daylight Saving Time terminates (first Sunday in November at two a.m. when two a.m. becomes one a.m.), businesses subject to this chapter are entitled to remain open and sell malt beverages for one additional hour (until what would otherwise have been three a.m. had not there been termination of Daylight Saving Time). 
(b)  Any on-sale or off-sale licensee may permit persons eighteen years old or older to sell or serve alcoholic beverages if less than fifty percent of the gross business transacted by the establishment is from the sale of alcoholic beverages, or the licensee or an employee that is at least twenty-one years of age is on the premises when the alcoholic beverage is sold or served. For the purposes of this section, the term to sell or serve alcoholic beverages does not include tending bar or drawing, pouring, or mixing alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  Every on-sale licensee shall flash the lights of his place of business at one forty-five a.m. each day as a warning that within fifteen minutes the place of business will close. By two a.m. every on-sale dealer shall clear his premises of customers and patrons and shall lock all doors to the premises and shall turn out all lights therein, except such a night light as approved by the police department. Such night light shall burn from two a.m. until daylight of the following day. The on-sale licensee and the employees shall leave the place of business or premises within thirty minutes or earlier after the closing hour. It is the intent of this section that the premises be wholly vacant during that designated time period. 
(Ord. 2047 (part), 2008; Ord. 2026 (part), 2007). 
(Ord. No. 2065, 9-28-2009; Ord. No. 2193-5-128, 5-14-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2193-5-128, adopted May 14, 2017, amended the title of § 5.54.022 to read as herein set out. The former § 5.54.022 title pertained to retail on-sale malt beverage dealers procedures and hours of business. 
5.54.024 - Inspection required. 
    All initial applications for retail on-sale licenses and all applicants for transfer of retail on-sale licenses to another location shall be accompanied by a certification that the premises have been inspected and approved by a State Electrical Inspector. Applications for new or transfer of on-sale licenses to another location shall be referred to the building inspector and chief of fire department who shall inspect the building or premises described in the application to determine whether the same complies with the regulations, ordinances and laws applicable thereto. Such officers shall furnish to the governing body the information obtained in such investigation, accompanied by a recommendation as to whether a license should be granted or refused. No license shall be extended or renewed without the inspection and report and recommendation of the officers named herein, as above provided. 
(Ord. No. 2081, 8-2-2010; Ord. No. 2193-5-128, 5-14-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2193-5-128, adopted May 14, 2017, repealed the former §§ 5.54.024-5.54.027, and renumbered the former §§ 5.54.028, 5.54.030 as §§ 5.54.024, 5.54.026 as herein set out. The historical notations have been retained with the amended provisions. The former §§ 5.54.024-5.54.027 pertained to package off-sale malt beverage dealers procedures and hours of business; package off-sale malt beverage and SD farm winery license; and retail off-sale malt beverage and South Dakota Farm Wine License, and derived from Ord. 2047(part), adopted 2008; Ord. 2026(part), adopted 2007; Ord. No. 2065, adopted September 28, 2009; Ord. No. 2077, adopted May 24, 2010; and Ord. No. 2098, adopted June 6, 2011. 
5.54.026 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any dealer or his employee violating any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a class two misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty days or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 2026 (part), 2007). 
(Ord. No. 2193-5-128, 5-14-2017) 
Editor's note- See the editor's note to § 5.54.024. 
Chapter 5.55 - ON-OFF SALE WINE DEALERS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2065, adopted Sept. 28, 2009, amended Ch. 5.55 title as herein set out. Former Ch. 5.55 title pertained to wine dealers. Prior history: Ords. No. 2047 and 2027. 

5.55.010 - Definitions. 
    The term used in this chapter unless the context otherwise plainly requires shall mean as follows: 
(a)  "Wine" means an alcoholic beverage as defined by Title 35 of South Dakota Codified Laws. 
(b)  "On-sale" means the sale of wine for the consumption only upon the premises where sold. 
(c)  "Off-sale" means the sale of wine for consumption off the premises where sold. 
(d)  "Dealer" means any person who sells, or keeps for sale, any alcoholic beverage for consumption on or off the premises where sold. 
(Ord. 2047 (part), 2008; Ord. 2027 (part), 2007). 
5.55.012 - Classification and fees. 
    The licensing period for wine licenses runs from January 1 through December 31. The following classifications and fees are established: 
License Type Fees Retail 
(On-Off Sale) 
Wine License $500.00/year Transfer Fee 150.00  
(Ord. 2047 (part), 2008; Ord. 2027 (part), 2007). 
5.55.014 - Application review procedures. 
    Wine license applications are available at the city finance office. All applications must be completed with fees collected prior to being submitted to the city commission for consideration. Notice of the application must be published in the local newspaper with a public hearing being held not less than seven days after official publication. The governing board shall have discretion to approve or disapprove the application depending on whether it deems the applicant a suitable person to hold such license and whether it considers the proposed location suitable. (Ord. 2047 (part), 2008; Ord. 2027 (part), 2007). 
5.55.016 - Inspection required. 
    All initial applications for retail on-sale licenses and all applicants for transfer of retail on-sale licenses to another location shall be accompanied by a certification that the premises have been inspected and approved by a state electrical inspector. Applications for new or transfer of on-sale licenses to another location shall be referred to the building inspector and chief of fire department who shall inspect the building or premises described in the application to determine whether the same complies with the regulations, ordinances and laws applicable thereto. Such officers shall furnish to the governing body the information obtained in such investigation, accompanied by a recommendation as to whether a license should be granted or refused. No license shall be extended or renewed without the inspection and report and recommendation of the officers named herein, as above provided. 
(Ord. No. 2081, 8-2-2010) 
5.55.028 - Procedures and hours of business. 
(a)  Retail On-Off Sale Wine License. Opening and closing hours for retail on-off sale wine dealers shall be between the hours of seven a.m. and two a.m. each day of the week, including Sunday. On business days when daylight saving time goes into effect (second Sunday in March at two a.m.), businesses subject to this chapter must close at two a.m. On business days when daylight saving time terminates (first Sunday in November at two a.m. when two a.m. becomes one a.m.), businesses subject to this chapter are entitled to remain open and sell wine for one additional hour (until what would otherwise have been three a.m. had not there been termination of daylight saving time). 
(b)  The licensing period runs from January 1 through December 31. 
(c)  No on-sale licensee may permit any person less than twenty-one years old to loiter on the licensed premises or to sell, serve, dispense, or consume alcoholic beverages on such premises. However, an on-sale licensee licensed pursuant to subdivision SDCL 35-4-2(12) wine retailers being both package off-sale dealers and on-sale dealers, may permit persons eighteen years old or older to sell and serve or dispense alcoholic beverages if less than fifty percent of the gross business transacted by that establishment is from the sale of alcoholic beverages and the licensee or an employee that is at least twenty-one years of age is on the premises when the alcoholic beverage is sold or dispensed. For the purposes of this section, the term, to sell and serve alcoholic beverages, means to take orders for alcoholic beverages and to deliver alcoholic beverages to customers as a normal adjunct of waiting tables. The term does not include tending bar or drawing or mixing alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. 2047 (part), 2008; Ord. 2027 (part), 2007). 
(Ord. No. 2065, 9-28-2009; Ord. No. 2077, 5-24-2010) 
State Law reference- SDCL 35-4-79 
5.55.030 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any dealer or his employee violating any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty days or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 2027 (part), 2007). 
Chapter 5.56 - JUNK DEALERS AND YARDS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference- General license provisions - See Ch. 5.04 of this code; Purchases, sales and records of sales, pawnbrokers, secondhand and junk dealers - See Ch. 9.28 of this code; Junked vehicles and equipment - See Ch. 9.56 of this code. 

5.56.010 - Junk dealer defined. 
    "Junk dealer," as used in this chapter, means any person or persons, firm or corporation who is engaged in business as a dealer and/or trader in junk, old meals, rags, waste paper, old automobiles or other articles or things, the worn condition of which renders them useless for the purpose for which they were originally made, and who operates a junkyard or shop. 
(Ord. 836 § 1, 1963). 
5.56.020 - License required. 
    Every person or persons, firm or corporation who is engaged in the business or junk dealing shall before engaging in such business, obtain a license so to do as provided for in Section 5.04.020 of this code. 
(Ord. 836 § 2, 1963). 
5.56.030 - Application for license. 
    Any person, persons, association, firm or corporation desiring to procure a license as herein provided shall file with the city auditor a written application upon a blank form prepared and furnished by the city. It shall also state the following: 
(a)  The length of time the applicant or applicants has or have resided in the city, their places of previous employment, whether married or single, whether he or they or any of them have been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, and if so, what offense, when and in what court. 
(b)  The premises where the business is to be located on carried on. Such description shall be given by street number in case of a building and in case such business is carried on wholly or in part on a vacant lot or lots, the lot and block number shall be given, together with the exact dimensions of the space to be occupied in any manner in the conduct of such business. 
(c)  Such other information as may be required by the governing body. 
(d)  Such application shall contain the consent and agreement by the applicant that any license granted such applicant may be revoked by the governing body at any time without notice or hearing upon violation by the holder of said license of any of the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance of the City of Huron or statute of the State of South Dakota. 
(Ord. 836 § 3; September 16, 1963). 
5.56.040 - License fees. 
    Every junk dealer, as defined in Section 5.56.010 of this chapter, shall pay an annual license fee of fifty dollars for each established place of business. All license fees shall accompany the application for license and in case of the refusal of such license by the governing body, the license fee shall be returned to the applicant. All licenses shall be issued as of May first of each year and shall continue in force until April thirtieth next succeeding the date of issuance thereof unless sooner revoked by the governing body. 
(Ord. 836 § 4; September 16, 1963). 
5.56.050 - Issuance of license-Effect of refusal. 
    Upon filing of the application, together with the necessary license fee, as provided in the preceding section, the governing body, if they deem such applicant a fit person to engage in such business, shall by majority vote grant such license and thereupon such license shall be issued by the city auditor in the manner as provided for the issuance of other licenses in the City of Huron by Chapter 5.04 of this title, and no applicant to whom a license has been refused shall make further application until a period of at least twelve months shall have elapsed since the last previous rejection, unless he can show that the reason for his rejection no longer exists. 
(Ord. 836 § 5; September 16, 1963). 
5.56.060 - Revocation of license. 
    The governing body may at any time, for such cause, if it upon investigation deems sufficient, revoke any license granted under the provisions of this chapter without any hearing or notice to the holder of such license and whenever such license shall be revoked, no refund of any unearned portion of the license fee shall be made. Notice of such revocation and the reasons shall be served by the governing body upon such person or persons, firm, association or corporation named in the application either by personal service or by mailing the same to the address given in the application and filing a copy of such with the auditor of the City of Huron. 
(Ord. 836 § 6; September 16, 1963). 
5.56.070 - Record of purchases. 
    Every junk dealer shall keep in such form as the chief of police shall prescribe, and written in ink or indelible pencil, a daily record of all articles purchased, the name, residence, age and occupation of the person from whom each article was purchased and the name of the employer of such person, also, the day and hour of such purchase and the price paid. The records shall at all reasonable times be open to inspection of the chief of police or any police officer, or any person duly authorized in writing by the chief of police. No entry in such records shall be changed, erased, obliterated or defaced. 
(Ord. 836 § 7; September 16, 1963). 
Cross reference- Purchases from minors-See Section 9.28.010 of this code. 
5.56.080 - Reports to police department. 
    Every junk dealer, upon being served with written notice so to do by a member of the police department, shall report to the chief of police a description of all goods, articles or things purchased or received by him in the course of business of a junk merchant at such time and during such period of time specified in the notice, stating the amount paid for and the name, residence and general description of the person from whom such goods, articles or things were received. 
(Ord. 836 § 8; September 16, 1963). 
5.56.090 - Unlawful acts-Enclosures. 
1.  The handling, storing and keeping of old bones of any description whatsoever by any person within the City of Huron is hereby prohibited, and handling, storing and keeping such bones is hereby declared to be a nuisance and the violation of this section by the holder of any license granted under the provisions of this chapter, shall be sufficient cause for the revocation of this license in addition to the penalties hereinafter prescribed to the terms of this chapter. 
2.  No junk dealer shall carry on the business at or from any other place than the premises designated and described in the application and license and all junk of all kinds and description shall be kept wholly within the boundaries of such premises. 
3.  It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to burn old cars or other refuse on the premises covered by said license or at any other place within the City of Huron without the proper and approved facilities for burning operations. 
4.  The wrecking and dismantling of old cars for the purpose of junking the bodies and securing old parts, shall be done wholly inside the buildings occupied by said junk dealer or within the enclosure hereinafter provided for and shall not in any event be done upon the highways or streets of the city or outside the premises described in the application and license. 
5.  In all cases where the business of a junk dealer is to be conducted on a vacant lot or lots, or in a partially enclosed structure, said lots or structures shall be enclosed by a tight board fence, eight feet in height, or by an eight-foot Cyclone wire fence or other wire fence of like construction. Said fence shall be properly maintained and kept in regular repair by the licensee and shall be constructed with a gate or gates to prevent unauthorized entry to said premises, and all junk of all kinds and description shall be kept wholly within the boundaries of such enclosure and shall not in any event be deposited on the highways, streets, sidewalks, or boulevards of the city. 
    Licenses shall be allowed until the first day of July, 1964, to comply with the provisions of this section for the erection of enclosures as herein provided and failure so to do prior to such time shall be sufficient cause for the revocation of any license issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 836 § 9, 1963). 
Chapter 5.60 - CATV SYSTEM[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ords. 931, 1241, 1376 and 1514. 

5.60.002 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2117-5-118, adopted Aug. 20, 2012, repealed § 5.60.002, which pertained to purpose and derived from Ord. No. 1803 (part), adopted 1997. 
5.60.004 - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Huron Cable Television Franchise Ordinance." 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.006 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter and any cable TV franchise granted pursuant thereto, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein and as found in 47 U.S.C. § 522. When not inconsistent with the context, words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. The word "may" is directory and discretionary and not mandatory. 
(1)  "Activated channels" means those channels engineered at the headend of a cable system for the provision of services generally available to residential subscribers of the cable system, regardless of whether such services actually are provided, including any channel designated for public, educational, or governmental use. 
(2)  "Affiliate", when used in relation to any person, means another person who owns or controls, is owned or controlled by, or is under common ownership or control with, such person. 
(3)  "Basic cable service" means any service tier which includes the retransmission of local television broadcast signals. 
(4)  "Cable channel" or "channel" means a portion of the electromagnetic frequency spectrum which is used in a cable system and which is capable of delivering a television channel (as television channel is defined by the Commission by regulation). 
(5)  "Cable operator" means any person or group of persons: 
(A)  Who provides cable service over a cable system and directly or through one or more affiliates owns a significant interest in such cable system, or 
(B)  Who otherwise controls or is responsible for, through any arrangement, the management and operation of such a cable system. 
(6)  "Cable service" means: 
(A)  The one-way transmission to subscribers of: 
(i)  Video programming, or 
(ii)  Other programming service, and 
(B)  Subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection or use of such video programming or other programming service. 
(7)  "Cable system" means a facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such term does not include: 
(A)  A facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of 1 or more television broadcast stations; 
(B)  A facility that serves subscribers without using any public right-of-way; 
(C)  A facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of subchapter II of this chapter, except that such facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of 47 U.S.C. § 541(c) to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers, unless the extent of such use is solely to provide interactive on-demand services; 
(D)  An open video system that complies with 47 U.S.C. § 573; or 
(E)  Any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility system; 
(8)  "City Commission" or Commission" means the Huron, South Dakota City Commission. 
(9)  "Franchise" means an initial authorization, or renewal thereof (including a renewal of an authorization which has been granted), issued by the City of Huron, whether such authorization is designated as a franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, agreement, or otherwise, which authorizes the construction or operation of a cable system. 
(10)  "Franchising authority" means the Huron City Commission. 
(11)  "Franchise area" means the area within the legal boundaries of the City of Huron. 
(12)  "Grade B contour" means the field strength of a television broadcast station computed in accordance with regulations promulgated by the Commission. 
(13)  "Grantee" is the entity which is granted a Franchise in City pursuant to this chapter, its agents and employees, lawful successors, transferees or assignees. 
(14)  "Grantor" is the City of Huron. 
(15)  "Gross subscriber revenue" means all revenue derived by the Grantee from the provision of cable service by the Grantee within the City from the operation of its cable system including, but not limited to, monthly fees charged to subscribers for basic cable service; monthly fees charged to subscribers for any optional cable service; pay cable; digital service; high definition services; digital video record; video on-demand; monthly fees charged to subscribers for any tier of service other than basic cable service; installation, disconnection and reconnection fees; payments or other consideration received by the Grantee from programmers for carriage of programming on the cable system and accounted for as revenue under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP); converter rentals or sales; and fees for cable Internet service (if such service is deemed to be a cable service). There shall be no deductions from gross revenues except for uncollected amounts as set forth in a. below. Gross Revenues shall not include: 
a.  To the extent consistent with GAAP, bad debt; provided, however, that all or part of any such bad debt that is written off but subsequently collected shall be included in gross revenues in the period collected; 
b.  Any capital contribution required by the franchise in support of PEG Access; 
c.  Revenue from advertising, home shopping service payment or other consideration; or 
d.  Any taxes or franchise fee on services furnished by the Grantee, which are imposed directly on any subscriber or user by the state, city, or other governmental authority and which are collected by the Grantee on behalf of said governmental authority. 
(16)  "Interactive on-demand services" means a service providing video programming to subscribers over switched networks on an on-demand, point-to-point basis, but does not include services providing video programming prescheduled by the programming provider. 
(17)  "Multichannel video programming distributor" means a person such as, but not limited to, a cable operator, a multichannel multipoint distribution service, a direct broadcast satellite service, or a television receive-only satellite program distributor, who makes available for purchase, by subscribers or customers, multiple channels of video programming. 
(18)  "Other programming service" means information that a cable operator makes available to all subscribers generally. 
(19)  "Person" means an individual, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust, corporation, or governmental entity. 
(20)  "Public, educational, or governmental access facilities" means: 
(A)  Channel capacity designated for public, educational, or governmental use, and 
(B)  Facilities and equipment for the use of such channel capacity. 
(21)  "Service tier" means a category of cable service or other services provided by a cable operator and for which a separate rate is charged by the cable operator. 
(22)  "State" means any State, or political subdivision, or agency thereof. 
(23)  "Street" means the surface of, and the space above and below, any public street, road, highway, freeway, lane, alley, path, court, sidewalk, parkway, or drive, or any easement or right-of-way now or hereafter held by Grantor. 
(24)  "Subscriber" means any Person who lawfully receives Cable Service. 
(25)  "Usable activated channels" means activated channels of a cable system, except those channels whose use for the distribution of broadcast signals would conflict with technical and safety regulations as determined by the Commission. 
(26)  "Video programming" means programming provided by, or generally considered comparable to programming provided by, a television broadcast station. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.0075 - Franchise required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any Person to construct, operate or maintain a Cable System without being granted by the City of Huron a nonexclusive franchise authorizing the same, unless applicable federal or State law prohibits the Grantor's enforcement of such a requirement. Each nonexclusive franchise that is granted in City shall be subject to the terms and conditions contained within this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.0076 - Grant of nonexclusive franchise. 
(1)  A Grantee shall have the right and privilege to construct, erect, operate, and maintain, in, upon, along, across, above, over and under the streets, public ways and public places now laid out or dedicated and all extensions thereof, and additions thereto in Franchise Area, poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes, and other television conductors and fixtures necessary for the maintenance and operation in franchise area of a cable system. 
(2)  A franchise shall be nonexclusive, and Grantor reserves the right to grant a similar use of said streets to any cable operator any time, provided, however, that all franchises shall contain the same terms and conditions as this chapter in order that one cable operator does not have competitive advantage over another. 
(3)  Every franchise shall apply to the entire service area of the Grantor, as it exists now or may later be configured. A franchise shall be granted for the corporate boundaries of Grantor, as it exists from time to time. In the event of annexation by Grantor, or as development occurs, any new territory shall become part of the area covered, provided, however, that Grantee(s) shall not be required to extend service beyond its present system boundaries unless there is a minimum of twenty-five (25) homes per cable mile as measured from the last fiber node or terminating amplifier. 
(4)  Written Notice. All notices, reports, or demands required to be given in writing under this chapter shall be deemed to be given when received by any officer of Grantee or Grantor's Administrator of this chapter as specified in a franchise. 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.0077 - Application for new or renewed franchise. 
(1)  An application for an initial or renewed franchise to shall be in writing on a form provided by the City which shall contain where applicable. 
(2)  Applicant name and business address of applicant. 
(3)  A statement as to the proposed franchise area, and whether applicant holds an existing authorization to access the rights-of-way in the City and a map of the areas where such authorization exists if for an area other than the entire City. 
(4)  Resume of prior history of applicant, including the legal, technical, and financial expertise of applicant in the cable service field. 
(5)  List of officers, directors, and managing employees of applicant. 
(6)  A proposed construction and schedule to provide Cable Service to Subscribers. 
(7)  A certificate of insurance consistent with the requirements of this chapter. 
(8)  A description of the cable system the applicant intends to utilize, including its capacity, the types of equipment proposed for use and the cable services which will be offered. 
(9)  A description of the financial qualifications of the applicant to construct and operate the system including a balance sheet, income statement sources and uses of funds statement and pro forma projections for at least three (3) years of operation subsequent to system completion. 
(10)  The initial franchise application may be evaluated according to the following criteria, and approved within one hundred eighty (180) days after City deems the application is complete. In the event applicant is already authorized to occupy the rights-of-way, the time for review and approval will be ninety (90) days. 
(a)  The evidence of legal, technical and financial ability required in the applicant's proposal will be such as to assure the ability to complete the entire System within a reasonable time from the date the Franchise is granted. The City will also consider the applicant's ability to operate the system and provide the necessary cable services in compliance with the terms of this chapter. 
(b)  The City Planner shall prepare a report and make his or her recommendations respecting such application to the City Commission. 
(c)  Within thirty (30) days after the receipt of the report by the City Commission, the Commission shall make a decision whether or not the Franchise should be granted, and, if granted subject to what conditions, if any. 
(d)  The City Commission may consider any additional information that it deems applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.008 - Franchise term. 
    A franchise may be granted pursuant to this chapter for ten (10) years from the effective date of the Commission's formal approval of the franchise application, subject to one five-year renewal period on the same terms and conditions as contained in this chapter, or on such different or additional terms and conditions as may be lawfully specified by the governing body and as are consistent with the rules and regulations of the FCC. The company's application for franchise renewal may be granted provided company shows that its service during the preceding franchise period has reflected a good faith effort to serve the needs and interests of its service area and company has not demonstrated a callous disregard of the law and all pertinent regulations. Pending final completion of renewal proceedings, the then current franchise agreement shall remain in effect on a six (6) month basis even if the original term has expired. If the then current franchise is not renewed, or it is revoked for cause by the city, the transfer of company's system shall be governed by Section 627 of the Cable Communication Policy Act of 1984, as amended. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.010 - Payments to the city. 
(1)  The Grantee shall, during the Franchise Agreement period, pay to the city the per cent established by resolution of the governing board, gross subscriber revenues as defined in Section 5.60.006(15), received by the Grantee. The franchise fee shall be payable monthly, together with a brief report showing the basis for the computation, a certified statement showing the gross subscriber revenues. It shall be the duty of Grantee to pay the city within fifteen days after the time for filing such statement the amount due for the preceding month covered by such statement. 
(2)  Such payments by the Grantee to city shall be in lieu of any occupational tax, license tax, or similar levy. Nothing contained in this section, however, shall in any way relieve the Grantee or its assigns or successors from the obligation of paying property taxes to the city or any other taxes lawfully levied by the state of South Dakota or any governmental subdivision of the State of South Dakota in the operation of the company. 
(3)  Grantee shall file with the city within sixty days after the expiration of the Grantee's operating year during the term of the rights granted under this chapter, a certified statement showing the gross subscriber revenues as defined in Section 5.60.006(15). 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.012 - Rates. 
(1)  Company shall at all times maintain on file with the city finance officer a schedule setting forth all rates and charges to be made to subscribers for all tiers of service, including installation charges. 
(2)  During the term hereof, company shall comply with the rate regulation rules of the Federal Communications Commission. 
(3)  The company shall not discriminate in rates between customers of the same category except to the extent permitted by the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended, The Telecommunications Act of 1996, and FCC regulations. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.014 - Complaints. 
    During the term of this franchise, and any renewal thereof, complaints regarding the quality of service, equipment malfunctions, and similar matters shall be directed to the company. Any complaints from subscribers shall be investigated and acted upon as soon as possible, but at least within three business days of their receipt. The company shall keep a maintenance service log which will indicate the nature of each service complaint, the date and time it was received, the disposition of such complaint and the time and date thereof. This log shall be made available for periodic inspection by the City. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.016 - Notice of complaint procedure. 
    The company shall, by appropriate means, such as a card or brochure as subscribers are connected or reconnected to the system, furnish information concerning the procedure for making inquiries and/or complaints, including the name, address and local telephone number of the employee or employees or agent to whom such inquiries or complaints are to be addressed. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.018 - Indemnification by company. 
    The Grantee shall indemnify, protect and save harmless the city from and against losses and physical damage to property and bodily injury or death to persons, including payments made under any worker's compensation law which may arise out of or be caused by the erection, maintenance, presence, use or removal of attachments or poles within the city, or by any action of Grantee, its agents or employees. Grantee shall also carry insurance in amounts stated in Section 5.60.020 to protect the parties to this franchise from and against all claims, demands, actions, judgments, costs, expenses and liabilities which arise or result, directly or indirectly, from or by reason of such loss, injury or damage. Grantee shall also carry such insurance as it deems necessary to protect it from all claims under the worker's compensation laws in effect that may be applicable to company. All insurance required shall be and remain in full force and effect for the entire life of the rights granted under this chapter. Insurance certificates evidencing such insurance coverage shall be approved by the governing body of the city, or its designated official, and then be deposited with and kept on file by the City. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.020 - Insurance by company. 
    Grantee shall, at all times, keep in effect the following types of insurance coverage: 
(1)  Worker's compensation upon its employees engaged in any manner in the installation or servicing of its plant and equipment within the City. 
(2)  Property damage liability insurance in the amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for property damage to any one person and one million dollars ($1,000,000) for property damage resulting from any one act or occurrence, and personal injury liability insurance in the amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) as to one person and one million dollars ($1,000,000) for personal injury or death of two or more persons in any one occurrence. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.022 - Revocation of franchise. 
    Grantor has the right to revoke a Grantee's franchise should Grantee fail in any of its obligations as set forth in this Chapter or the franchise document signed by Grantor after approval of the franchise application. The franchise document shall be consistent with the Grantee's obligations as set forth in this Chapter. Revocation may occur only upon Grantor having given Grantee written notice of violation and Grantee being given an opportunity to appear before the Commission and give such reason as Grantee may have as to why the franchise should not be revoked. A revocation of Grantee's license by the Federal or State government shall result in immediate revocation of Grantee's franchise and no hearing before the Commission shall be required. Notwithstanding a revocation, Grantee remains responsible for payment of all funds pursuant to Section 5.60.010(1) owed to City up to the date of revocation. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2117-5-118, adopted Aug. 20, 2012, amended § 5.60.022 title to read as herein set out. Former § 5.60.022 title pertained to copyright infringement. 
5.60.024 - System construction, maintenance and procedures. 
(1)  Upon grant of a franchise to construct and maintain a cable television system in the city, the Grantee may enter into contracts with light, gas, and water divisions of the city, and public utility companies or any other owner or lessee of any poles located within or without the city to whatever extent such contract or contracts may be expedient and of advantage to the company for use of poles and posts necessary for proper installation of the system; obtain right-of-way permits from appropriate state, county and federal officials necessary to cross highways or roads under their respective jurisdictions to supply main trunk lines from the Grantee's receiving antennas; obtain permission from the Federal Aviation Authority to erect and maintain antennas suitable to the needs of the system and its subscribers; and obtain whatever other permits a city, county, state or federal agency may require. In the construction, installation and maintenance of its system, the Grantee will use steel, cable and electronic devices, all of specialized and advanced design and type; in the operation of its system, the company will employ personnel with training, skill and experience in electronics and communications. 
(2)  The Grantee's system, poles, wires, and appurtenances shall be located, erected and maintained so that none of its facilities shall endanger or interfere with the lives of persons or interfere with any improvements the city may deem proper to make, or unnecessarily hinder or obstruct the free use of the streets, alleys, bridges, easements, or public property. 
(3)  In the event that the city annexes further territory as authorized by law, the Grantee shall extend energized trunk cable to the remaining portions of the city so annexed within one year thereafter, unless additional time is granted by the governing body upon request of the company for good cause shown. Extension of service shall not be required into an area which does not meet the requirements set forth in Section 5.60.0076(3) of this chapter. 
(4)  All transmission and distribution structures, lines and equipment erected by the company within the city shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, alleys and other public ways and places and to cause minimum interference with the rights or reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of the streets or other public ways and places. 
(5)  In case of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalk, driveway, or other surfacing, the company shall, at its cost and expense and in a manner approved by the city, replace and restore all paving, sidewalk, driveway or surface of any street or alley disturbed, in as good condition as before such work was commenced. 
(6)  In the event that at any time during the period of this franchise the city lawfully elects to alter or change the grade of any street, alley or other public way, the company, upon reasonable notice by the city, shall remove, relay and relocate its poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes, and other fixtures at its own expense. 
(7)  The company shall not place poles or other fixtures where the same will interfere with any gas, electric or telephone fixture, water hydrant or main, and all such poles or other fixtures placed in any street shall be placed at the outer edge of the sidewalk and inside the curb line, and those placed in alleys shall be placed close to the line of the lot abutting on such alley, and in such a manner as not to interfere with the usual travel on such streets, alleys and public ways. 
(8)  A Grantee shall obtain all required permits from Grantor before commencing any construction upgrade or extension of the System. 
(9)  If at any time during the period of a franchise Grantor shall elect to alter, or change the grade or location of any street, alley or other public way, a Grantee shall, at its own expense, upon reasonable notice by Grantor, remove and relocate its poles, wires, cables, conduits, manholes and other fixtures of the System. If Grantor reimburses other owners of similar equipment for such removal and relocation, Grantee shall be likewise reimbursed. 
(10)  A Grantee shall, on request of any person holding a moving permit issued by Grantor, temporarily move its wires or fixtures to permit the moving of buildings with the expense of such temporary removal to be paid to Grantee by the person requesting the same, and a Grantee shall be given not less than ten (10) calendar days advance notice to arrange for such temporary changes. 
(11)  Upon written request by Grantee and written approval being given by Grantor, Grantee shall have the right to trim any trees upon and overhanging the streets, alleys, sidewalks, or public easements of Grantor so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires and cables of the Grantee. 
(12)  In areas where all other utility lines are placed underground, Grantee shall construct and install its cables, wires and other facilities underground. In any area where one or more public utilities are aerial, Grantee may construct and install its cables, wires and other facilities from the same pole with the consent of the owner of the pole. 
(13)  A Grantee shall at all times construct and operate its System in accordance with applicable FCC Technical specifications. 
(14)  In the event that a new franchise is granted but Grantee does not take substantial action toward commencing the cable service within two (2) years of the franchise being granted, or if the use of any part of the system is discontinued for any reason for a continuous period of twelve (12) months, or in the event such systems or property has been installed in any street or public place without complying with the requirements of this Chapter, or the rights granted hereunder have been terminated, cancelled or have expired, Grantee shall, subject to the rights of the City to acquire the system as specified in Section 5.60.024(13) herein, promptly remove from the streets, or public places all such property and poles of such system other than any which the City may permit to be abandoned in place. In the event of such removal, Grantee shall promptly restore the street or other area from which such property has been removed to a condition satisfactory to the City. 
(15)  Any property of Grantee to be abandoned in place shall be abandoned in such a manner as the City may prescribe. Upon permanent abandonment of the property of Grantee in place, it shall submit to the City an instrument to be approved by the City, transferring to the City the ownership of such property. 
(16)  All cable and passive equipment for cable television reception service installed by Grantee at a subscriber's location shall remain the property of Grantee and Grantee shall have the right to remove said cable and equipment. Upon termination of service to any subscriber, the Grantee shall promptly remove all its above ground facilities and equipment from the premises of such subscriber upon his request. 
(17)  No poles or other wire-holding structures shall be erected by the Grantee without prior approval of the designated representative of the City Commission with regard to locations, height, type or any other pertinent aspect, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. However, no locations of any pole or wire-holding structure of the Grantee shall be a vested interest of Grantee and such poles or structures shall be removed or modified by the Grantee at its own expense whenever the City Commission or its designated representative determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. 
(18)  Where poles or other wire-holding structures already existing in use in serving the City are available for use by Grantee, Grantor may require the Grantee to use such poles and structures if it determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby and the terms of the use available to the Grantee are just and reasonable. 
(19)  Where the City or a public utility serving the City desires to make use of poles or other wire-holding structures of the Grantee but agreement therefore with the Grantee cannot be reached, the Grantor may require the Grantee to permit such use for such consideration as is just and reasonable and upon such terms as the Grantor determines the use would enhance the public convenience and would not unduly interfere with the Grantee's operations. 
(20)  Grantee shall at all times maintain on file with the City Finance Officer a schedule setting forth all rates and charges to be made to subscribers for basic cable service, including installation charges. 
(21)  During the term hereof, the City may regulate rates only if authorized to do so by Federal Communications Commission regulations and the State of South Dakota and then such regulation shall only be in accordance with the provisions of such federal and state regulations. 
(22)  Grantee is subject to all requirements of the city ordinances, rules, regulations and specifications of the city, including, but not limited to, those concerning street work, street excavation, use, removal and relocation of property within a street, and other street work. Provided, however, that company shall not be required to pay a fee for street openings nor shall company be required to post any excavation bond. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.026 - Service to schools and city. 
(1)  Grantee shall provide basic cable service at no cost to public and parochial elementary and secondary schools within the city, at one terminal junction, for educational purposes upon request of the school system. An additional second channel for digital PEG programming shall be provided to Grantor by Grantee, Grantee's location of the channel being subject to Grantor's approval, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(2)  Grantee shall, subject to the line extension provisions of Section 5.60.034, also provide to the city without charge, up to ten (10) city-owned buildings to be selected by the Grantor, and shall also furnish to such buildings, basic cable service to all sets connected within such building to the terminal junction. 
(3)  Public, Educational and Government (PEG) Channels: The Grantee shall allocate one channel to the City as a public, educational or governmental access channel. The city shall have complete control as to content, scheduling, administration and all other aspects of said PEG access channel, and may delegate certain or all of such functions to an appropriate designee. Said channel shall be viewable in the lowest tier of service on the grantee's system and in other locations as designated within the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.028 - Grantee's compliance with the municipal code, federal and state laws. 
    Grantee is subject to all requirements of the federal and state governments and the city ordinances, rules, regulations and specifications of the city, including, but not limited to, those concerning street work, street excavation, use, removal and relocation of property within a street, and other street work. Provided, however, that company shall not be required to pay a fee for street openings nor shall company be required to post any excavation bond. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2117-5-118, adopted Aug. 20, 2012, amended § 5.60.028 title to read as herein set out. Former § 5.60.028 title pertained to company's compliance with the municipal code. 
5.60.029 - Cities waiver of nonsolicitation ordinance. 
    The city waives any and all city ordinances, regulations, covenants, restrictions or decrees regulating "door to door" sales within the jurisdiction of the city for all employees of grantee. Grantee shall comply with any applicable state law(s) regulating "door to door" sales. Any complaint received by a resident of the city pertaining to "door to door" sales shall be handled under the customer complaint procedures set forth in this franchise. 
(Ord. 1998, 2005). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.030 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2117-5-118, adopted Aug. 20, 2012, repealed § 5.60.030, which pertained to abandonment of equipment and removal thereof and derived from Ord. No. 1803 (part), adopted 1997. 
5.60.032 - Company's failure to complete project. 
    Upon failure of company to complete any work required by law or by the provisions of this chapter to be done in any street, within the time prescribed, and to the satisfaction of the city, the city may cause such work to be done and company shall pay the city the cost thereof in the itemized amount reported to company within thirty days after receipt of such itemized report. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.034 - Line extensions. 
(1)  It shall be the obligation of the Grantee to serve all residents of the city except to the extent that density of homes, adverse terrain or other factors render providing service impractical, technically infeasible or economically noncompensatory. For purposes of determining compliance with the provisions of this section, and to provide for a reasonable and nondiscriminatory policy governing extensions of cable service within the city, which policy was subject to public notice and public review in the proceeding leading to the award of this franchise, company shall extend service to new subscribers, at normal installation charge and monthly service rate for customers of that classification where there is an average of seventy-five homes per each linear mile of new cable construction. 
(2)  In the event the requirements of subsection (1) of this section are not met, extensions of service shall be required only on a basis which is reasonable and compensatory. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.036 - Compliance with standards. 
    All facilities and equipment of company shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the requirements and specifications of the National Electrical Safety Code prepared by the National Bureau of Standards, the National Electrical Code of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, and such applicable ordinances and regulations set forth by the city and/or any other local, state or federal agencies. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012) 
5.60.038 - Grantee rules and regulations. 
    The Grantee shall have the authority to promulgate such rules and regulations, terms and conditions governing the conduct of its business as shall be reasonably necessary to enable the Grantee to exercise its rights and perform its obligations under this franchise, and to assure an uninterrupted service to each and all of its customers; provided however, that such rules, regulations, terms and conditions shall not be in conflict with the provisions of this chapter or of federal, state and local laws. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012)

    Notwithstanding any ordinance in Chapter 5.60 or provision within a Franchise Agreement to the contrary, the City of Huron shall have the right during a franchise agreement period to amend Chapter 5.60 should the Huron City Commission determine it is the interests of the City of Huron to amend Chapter 5.60. 
(Ord. 1803 (part, 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012)

5.60.042 - Assignment. 
    The Grantee shall not assign this franchise to another person without prior approval of the city council, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997).

5.60.044 - Compliance with FCC rules and regulations. 
    The Grantee shall, at all times, comply with the rules and regulations of the FCC. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012)

    The Grantee shall assume the costs of the publication of this Chapter or portion thereof as such publication is required by law. A bill for publication costs shall be presented to the Grantee by the appropriate city officials upon the company's filing of its acceptance of this franchise and the publication costs shall be paid at that time by the company. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997).

5.60.048 - Grantee not to interfere with television reception or utilities. 
    The Grantee shall not allow its cable or other operations to interfere with television reception of persons not served by the company, nor shall the system interfere with, obstruct or hinder in any manner, the operation of the various utilities serving the residents of the city. 
(Ord. 1803 (part), 1997). 
(Ord. No. 2117-5-118, 8-20-2012)
