Chapter 6.04 - CITY HEALTH OFFICER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Authority for municipality to appoint city health officer-See SDC 45.1103; Municipalities empowered to do what may be necessary or expedient for the promotion of health or the suppression of disease-See SDC 45.0201(35). 

6.04.010 - Appointment. 
    There is hereby created and established in and for the City of Huron, South Dakota, a city health officer, who shall also be the city physician, who shall be appointed by the governing body, and have and exercise all the powers necessary for the preservation of the public health. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0101; April 24, 1950). 
6.04.020 - Powers. 
    The city health officer subject to the supervision of the state board of health, shall have general supervision over the health of the city. He may examine into all nuisances, sources of filth and cause of sickness and have power to take all action and make all regulations necessary to promote the general cleanliness and healthfulness of the city and its inhabitants and every person who shall violate any order or regulation made by him and duly published, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0102; April 24, 1950). 
6.04.030 - Physicians to report dangerous diseases. 
    Whenever any physician shall know that any person whom he is called to visit or who is brought to him for examination is infected with any disease dangerous to the public health, he shall immediately give notice thereof to the city physician, and to the householder, hotel-keeper, keeper of any boarding house or tenant within whose house or rooms the sick person may be. The notices to the city physician shall state the name of the disease, the name, age and sex of the person sick, also the name of the physician giving the notice, and shall by street and number or otherwise sufficiently designate the house or room in which the sick person may be; every physician and person acting as physician who shall refuse or neglect immediately to give such notice shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0103; April 24, 1950). 
6.04.040 - Removal of infected persons to separate house. 
    When any person coming from abroad or residing in this city is or has lately been infected with any contagious disease dangerous to the public health, the city physician may immediately cause such person to be removed to a separate house if it can be done without danger to his or her health. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0104; April 24, 1950). 
6.04.050 - Health measures where infected persons cannot be moved. 
    If such infected person cannot be removed without danger to his or her health, the city physician shall make provision for such person in the house where he may be, and in such cases he may cause the persons in the neighborhood to be removed and may take such other measures as he may deem necessary for the safety of the public. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0105; April 24, 1950). 
6.04.060 - Pest house. 
    When a disease, dangerous to the public health, breaks out in said city, the city physician shall immediately provide such hospital or place of reception for the infected as he judges best for their accommodation and the safety of the inhabitants, which place shall be subject to the regulations of the city physician, and he may cause any sick and infected person to be removed thereto unless his or her condition will not permit such removal without danger to his or her health, in which case the house or place where said sick or infected person shall be, shall be considered as a hospital and with all its inmates be subject to the regulations of the city physician. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0106; April 24, 1950). 
6.04.070 - Removal of filth. 
    Whenever any nuisance, filth or source of sickness is found on private property, the city physician shall order the owner or occupant thereof, at his own expense, to remove the same within twenty-four hours, and if the owner or occupant neglects so to do, he shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor; and the city physician shall cause the said nuisance, filth or source of sickness to be removed and all expenses incurred thereby shall be paid by the said owner or occupant, or by the person who caused or permitted such nuisance, filth or cause of sickness to be on said premises. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0107; April 24, 1950). 
6.04.080 - Police to assist. 
    Whenever the city physician deems it necessary, for the preservation of the health of the inhabitants of the city, to enter any building in the city for the purpose of examining into the cause or nature of any sickness, or to cause the removal of any filth or nuisance and shall be refused such entry, he may make complaint to the chief of police, and accompanied by the city physician between the hours of sunrise and sunset, the said chief of police shall repair to the place where such nuisance, filth or cause of sickness complained of may be, and destroy and remove the same under the direction of the city physician. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0108; April 24, 1950). 
Chapter 6.12 - RATPROOFING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Municipalities empowered to do what may be necessary or expedient for the promotion of health or the suppression of disease - See SDC 45.0201(35). 

6.12.010 - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise plainly requires, shall have the following meanings: 
(A)  BUSINESS BUILDING: Any structure, either public or private, that is adapted for occupancy for transaction of business, for rendering of professional service, for amusement, for the display, sale or storage of goods, wares or merchandise, or for the performance of work or labor, including - but not being limited to its application to - hotels, rooming houses, office buildings, public buildings, stores, theatres, markets, restaurants, grain elevators, abattoirs, warehouses, work shops, factories, and all out buildings, sheds, barns, and other structures on premises used for business purposes. 
(B)  RAT-PROOFING: A form of rat-proofing to prevent the ingress into business buildings, from the exterior or from one business building to another. It consists essentially of the closing, with material impervious to rat gnawing, of all openings in the exterior walls, ground or first floors, basements, and foundations, that may be reached by rats from the ground by climbing or by burrowing. 
(C)  RAT HARBORAGE: Any condition which provides shelter or protection for rats, thus favoring their multiplication and continuous existence in, under, or outside of a structure of any kind. 
(D)  HEALTH OFFICER: The city health officer, or city physician, or inspector, of the City of Huron or his duly authorized representative. 
(E)  OWNER: The actual owner of the business building, either individual, partnership or corporation, the agent of the owner in charge of said building, the person having custody of said building, and the person to whom any rental upon said building is paid. In the case of business buildings leased under agreement that the lessee is responsible for maintenance and repairs, the lessee will in such cases also be considered as the "owner" for the purpose of this chapter. 
(F)  OCCUPANT: The individual or partnership who, or the corporation that, has the use of or occupies any business building, or a part or portion thereof, whether the actual owner, tenant or sub-tenant. In the case of vacant buildings, or any vacant portion of the business building, the owner, agent or other person having custody of said building, shall have the responsibility of an "occupant" of said building. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0301; April 24, 1950). 
6.12.020 - Buildings to be rat-proofed. 
    It is hereby provided and required that all business buildings in the City of Huron shall be rat-proofed, freed of rats, and maintained in a rat-proof and rat-free condition, under the direction and supervision of the health officer. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0302; April 24, 1950). 
6.12.030 - Notification to rat-proof. 
    Upon receipt of written notice and/or order from the health officer, the owner of any building specified in said notice or order shall take immediate steps for rat-proofing said building, and unless said work and improvements required for such rat-proofing have been completed by the owner of said building in the time specified in said written notice or order, or within the time to which a written extension may have been granted by the health officer, then the owner shall be deemed to have violated this chapter. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0303; April 24, 1950). 
6.12.040 - Occupant required to rat-proof. 
    Whenever the health officer notifies the occupant of a business building that there is evidence of rat-infestation of said building, said occupant shall immediately institute appropriate steps for freeing the premises of all rats, and unless suitable measures for freeing said building of rats are instituted within ten days after receipt of such notice, and unless continuously maintained in a reasonable manner until said building is free from rats, the health officer is hereby authorized and directed to free said building of rats and to levy a charge against the occupant to cover the charge for labor, materials and equipment necessary for the eradication measures carried out. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0304; April 24, 1950). 
6.12.050 - Maintain rat-proof condition. 
    The occupants of all rat-proofed business buildings are required to maintain the premises in a rat-proof condition and to repair all breaks and leaks that may occur in the rat-proofing. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0305; April 24, 1950). 
6.12.060 - Inspection. 
    The health officer is empowered to make unannounced inspections of both the interior and exterior of business buildings within the City of Huron as in his opinion may be necessary to determine whether there has been a full compliance with this chapter, and to require a full compliance with this chapter. If at the time of any such inspection, the health officer finds evidence of rat-infestation, and/or the existence of breaks or leaks in the rat-proofing, or new openings through which rats may again enter said building, the health officer shall serve upon the owner or occupant of said building a notice and/or order to abate the condition so found. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0306; April 24, 1950). 
6.12.070 - May require replacement of floors. 
    Whenever conditions inside or under business buildings provide such extensive harborage for rats that the health officer deems it necessary to eliminate such harborage he may require the owner to install suitable cement floors in the basement or to replace wooden first floors or ground floors or require the owner to correct such other interior rat harborage as may be necessary in order to facilitate the eradication of rats in a reasonable length of time. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0307; April 24, 1950). 
6.12.080 - Unlawful to remove rat-proofing. 
    It shall be unlawful for the occupant, owner, contractor, public utility company, plumber, or any other person to remove the rat-proofing from any business building for any purpose and fail to promptly restore the same in a satisfactory condition; and, in like manner, it shall be unlawful for any such person to make any new openings that are not sealed or closed against the entrance of rats. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0308; April 24, 1950). 
6.12.090 - Storing food and feed. 
    All food and feed kept within the city for feeding poultry, cattle, swine, horses, or other animals, shall be kept and stored in rat-free and ratproof containers, compartments or rooms, unless kept in a rat-proof building. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0308, 1950). 
6.12.130 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars, or imprisonment in the city or county jail for not more than thirty days or by both such fine or imprisonment. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0313, 1950). 
Chapter 6.16 - RESTAURANTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities empowered to do what may be necessary or expedient for the promotion of health or the suppression of disease - See SDC 45.0201(35). 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ordinances 483 and 877. 

6.16.010 - Regulations adopted. 
    The definitions; the inspection of food-service establishments; the issuance, suspension and revocation of permits to operate food-service establishments, the prohibiting of the sale of adulterated or mislabeled food or drink; and the enforcement of this chapter shall be regulated in accordance with Chapters 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10 and Appendixes A, B, C, D and E of the 1976 Edition of the Food and Drug Administration "Food Service Sanitation Ordinance," three certified copies of which shall be on file in the office of the city finance officer of the city; provided, that the words "municipality of _______" in said ordinance form shall be understood to refer to the city of Huron, South Dakota. 
(Ord. 1538 (part), 1986). 
6.16.020 - Interpretation of conflicts. 
    In case of conflict between the provisions of said Food and Drug Administration Food Service Sanitation Ordinance Regulating Eating and Drinking Establishments and this code the provisions of this code shall prevail. 
(Ord. 1538 (part), 1986). 
6.16.030 - Itinerant restaurants. 
    Operators of itinerant restaurants shall be required to secure a permit in accordance with the requirements of Sections 10-101 and 10-102 of the 1976 Edition of the Food and Drug Administration Food Service Sanitation Manual. 
(Ord. 1538 (part), 1986). 
6.16.040 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereto, shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or less than fifteen dollars at the discretion of the court. In addition thereto, such persons may be enjoined from continuing such violations. Each day upon which such a violation occurs constitutes a separate violation. 
(Ord. 1538 (part), 1986). 
6.16.050 - Amendments. 
    Sections 1-104 and 10-601 are deleted from the 1976 Edition of the Food and Drug Administration Food Service Sanitation Manual. 
(Ord. 1538 (part), 1986). 
Chapter 6.20 - MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2130-6-41, adopted April 29, 2013, amended Ch. 6.20 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 6.20, §§ 6.20.010-6.20.240, pertained to garbage, and derived from Ordinance Numbers 815; 914; 926; 973; 1022; 1149; 1243; 1256; 1257; 1313; 1325; 1334; 1371; 1412; 1416; 1438; 1457; 1516; 1623; 1656; 1671; 1682; 1714; 1731; 1762; 1787; 1795; 1801; 1808; 1835 and 2072. 
State Law reference- Municipalities empowered to do what may be necessary or expedient for the promotion of health or the suppression of disease - See SDC 45.0201(35); Municipal authority to lease or own real property within or without the corporate limits for all purposes authorized by law or necessary to power granted - See SDC 45.0201(13); Municipal authority to make regulations as may be proper and necessary and to provide for the punishment of violations thereof - See SDC 45.0201(19); Specific additional power of municipality to collect and dispose of and to regulate manner of handling garbage and other waste material granted by SDC '60 Supp. 45.0201(21). 

6.20.010 - Definitions. 
A.  Commissioner shall mean the city commissioner as appointed by the governing body having supervisory responsibility of the Solid Waste Department. 
B.  Compost shall mean a mixture of decaying organic matter, as from grass clippings, leaves and manure, used to improve soil structure and provide nutrients. 
C.  Container shall mean a city issued automated city collection container used specifically for household garbage, yard waste, or recyclables. 
D.  Municipal solid waste means: 
1.  Household garbage and waste material, including but not limited to kitchen and table refuse and every accumulation of waste, animal and vegetable matter that attends the preparation, cooking and eating of food, or any substance that is in the process of decay, which gives off an odor offensive to the senses; 
2.  Yard waste; 
3.  Recyclable materials, 
which are required to be disposed of in a Solid Waste Department approved container or at the transfer site. 
E.  Recyclables are those items designated through ordinance enacted by the governing board as suitable for inclusion in the city's curbside recycling program. Those items are flat and corrugated cardboard, newspaper, office paper, paperback books, junk mail, magazines, catalogues, rinsed plastic bottles and jugs with recycling symbol, and metals, including rinsed aluminum and tin cans. Glass bottles and jars are not recyclable items. 
F.  Rubble shall mean furniture, carpet, pad, mattresses, heavy plastics, dirt, fiberglass, gravel, hoses, large glass items, porcelain, rock, sand, doors (metal with wood cores), sheet rock, asphalt shingles, tar paper, concrete, brick, cinderblock, dry paint cans. 
G.  Soil amendment means material added to soil to improve plant growth and health. 
H.  Solid Waste Superintendent shall mean the person who is employed by the City of Huron who is charged with the operation and enforcement of the rules and regulations pertaining to collection and disposal of municipal solid waste. 
I.  Transfer station shall mean the municipally owned facility located at 1901 9th St. SE, Huron, SD, for disposal of municipal solid waste. 
J.  Yard waste shall mean grass, leaves, branches less than three (3) inches in diameter, animal waste, or organic material authorized by the Department of Agriculture to be processed for use as a soil amendment. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.020 - Solid waste collection. 
A.  All municipal solid waste listed in Sections 6.20.010 D. 1, 3 and 4 from domestic dwelling units, as defined in Section 6.20.070 A., shall be collected by the Solid Waste Department as set forth in Chapter 6.20, unless the city has entered into a contract with a commercial solid waste collector pursuant to Section 6.20.230 to provide collection service. 
B.  No person or entity shall engage in the business of collecting solid waste from multiple dwelling units or businesses within the city without first having been granted authorization from the city to collect municipal solid waste. 
C.  Nothing within this provision removes the right granted residents pursuant to Section 6.20.160 to dispose of municipal solid waste at the transfer station. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.030 - Reserved. 
6.20.040 - Reserved. 
6.20.050 - Reserved. 
6.20.060 - Reserved. 
6.20.070 - Domestic dwelling, multiple dwelling and business classification. 
A.  Domestic dwelling unit. Domestic dwelling unit is defined to mean single-family residences (a dwelling structure forming a single habitable unit with facilities used or intended to be used by a single-family for living, sleeping, cooking and eating purposes). Each single-family residence within a duplex or within a single-family dwelling with one or two apartments also shall constitute a domestic dwelling unit. 
B.  Multiple dwelling unit. Multiple dwelling unit classification means all apartment houses with three or more single-family residences which are rented. 
C.  Business unit classification. The business unit classification shall mean all Solid Waste Department collection locations, except for the transfer station, which are not included in the first two above classifications. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.080 - Containers provided. 
A.  Only city provided automated collection containers shall be used by the Solid Waste Department as garbage, yard waste and recyclables containers. 
B.  For each domestic dwelling unit as defined in Section 6.20.070 A., the Solid Waste Department shall provide one automated collection container for collection of garbage and, upon request shall provide one automated collection container for recyclables provided the use of a collection container for recyclables has not been suspended pursuant to Section 6.20.215 J. 
C.  The Solid Waste Department will collect yard waste provided the yard waste containers are purchased from the Solid Waste Department by the owner or tenant of the domestic dwelling unit who request yard waste collection by the Solid Waste Department. The cost for the yard waste container shall be set by resolution of the governing board. 
D.  The fee for additional household garbage containers and yard waste containers shall be set by resolution of the governing board. 
E.  The owner of each domestic dwelling unit or multiple dwelling unit shall furnish and maintain for the use of the residents therein a sufficient number of containers to hold all household garbage that accumulates upon such premises in the course of a week. The place where the containers are located shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times and accessible by collection trucks at time of collection. 
F.  All commercial establishments, such as hotels, boarding houses, restaurants, lunchrooms, bars, drugstores, trailer courts, tourist courts, grocery stores and all other commercial and business establishments shall provide an adequate number of containers or a dumpster as determined by the Solid Waste Superintendent. The containers or dumpster shall be located in a proper manner at the rear of the building or property using the same, unless otherwise approved by the Solid Waste Superintendent, as to be easily accessible by collection trucks. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.090 - Use of municipal household garbage containers, yard waste containers and recycling containers. 
A.  The occupant of every domestic dwelling unit, multiple dwelling unit, and the operator of every place of business in the city, is hereby required to deposit and keep the municipal solid waste that accumulates each day upon his premises in a solid waste container and keep the yard waste that accumulates upon his premises in a yard waste container, provided that grass, leaves, or other material to be used as soil amendment may be kept in a pit or closed container, until such time as it may be used. 
B.  Residents of the city are responsible for picking up the contents from their tipped containers. 
C.  No person shall place at the designated collection location on the scheduled collection day a container that contains items which are hazardous to the health of the public or constitute a fire hazard, including but not limited to hot ashes, lithium batteries, chemicals, fireworks, liquid paint, and medical sharps (a hypodermic needle, pen needle, intravenous needle, lancet and other device that is used to penetrate the skin for the delivery of medications). 
D.  No person shall place rubble, including but not limited to furniture, carpet, sheet rock, asphalt singles, in the containers or next to the containers which are at the designated collection location. See definition of rubble, Section 6.20.010 F. 
E.  All household garbage shall be thoroughly drained and wrapped in paper or enclosed by plastic or other material so as to prevent as nearly as possible moisture from the garbage from coming in contact with and freezing to the sides and bottom of the household garbage container. 
F.  Materials placed in the household garbage containers, yard waste containers, or recyclable containers in violation of Chapter 6.20 will result in a sorting charge being assessed upon the person or business responsible. The sorting charge shall be established by resolution of the governing board. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.100 - Reserved. 
6.20.110 - Container collection. 
    Unless otherwise designated by the Solid Waste Department, on collection day, containers shall be located on the premises adjacent to an alley bordering on said premises so as to be accessible from the alley adjoining the premises. Where there is no through alley available, containers shall be placed on the boulevard adjoining the premises on the day of collection. Containers shall be so placed that collectors of household garbage, yard waste and recyclables do not have to exit the truck in order to position the container to be picked up by the automated arm. Containers are not to be placed farther than six feet from street or alley and are not to be placed within three feet from any obstacles. No Solid Waste Department truck shall be required to use any private driveway in collection of municipal solid waste under the provisions of this chapter. All containers shall be removed from the parkway or boulevard by the homeowner or tenant within twenty-four hours after being emptied by the solid waste department. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.120 - Reserved. 
6.20.130 - Reserved. 
6.20.140 - Collection rates for domestic dwellings classification. 
A.  The Solid Waste Department collection rate for the collection of municipal solid waste, including recyclable materials, from all domestic dwellings units and multiple dwellings units, shall be set by resolution of the governing board and shall be billed in conjunction with the city utility service billing. 
B.  Suspension of collection fee: 
1.  The collection rate fee applicable to a rented domestic dwelling unit shall be suspended during the period of time when water services to the premises are shut off; 
2.  Should the residents of the domestic dwelling unit not be residing in the domestic dwelling unit for at least sixty consecutive days, if the collection containers stay at the domestic dwelling unit the collection rate fee applicable to the domestic dwelling unit shall be reduced by fifty per cent, provided the residents notify the Solid Waste Department prior to the time of absence; 
3.  Should the residents of the domestic dwelling unit not be residing in the domestic dwelling unit for at least sixty consecutive days, if the collection containers are removed from the domestic dwelling unit the collection rate fee applicable to the domestic dwelling unit shall be suspended, provided the residents notify the Solid Waste Department prior to the time of absence and upon payment of container pick-up, delivery and cleaning fees, if applicable. 
C.  All accounts for municipal solid waste collection fees shall be billed in the same manner as specified in Section 21.12.030 to the owner or occupant of any premises or structure so served. Such billings shall be subject to penalties as provided by Section 21.12.030. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.150 - Collection rates for business establishments served by Solid Waste Department. 
A.  When municipal solid waste is deposited in containers or three or four cubic yard dumpsters containers as herein provided under the business classification, the charge for collection by the city shall be set by resolution of the governing board. The collection fee shall be established by the weight category of the type of solid waste generated and the volume of solid waste collected from the business. The weight category, based on the type of solid waste generated, and volume of municipal solid waste produced by the business shall be periodically reviewed by the Solid Waste Department to determine whether or not the existing municipal solid waste service fee is representative of the weight category and volume of municipal solid waste being produced by the business establishment. 
B.  Calls for special municipal solid waste service pickups which are exclusive of the routine and scheduled municipal solid waste route pickups shall be at a rate for each individual call. The rate charge for special pickups shall be established by resolution of the governing board. 
C.  All accounts for municipal solid waste collection fees shall be billed in the same manner, as specified in Section 21.12.030 to the owner or occupant of any premises or structure so served. Such billings shall be subject to penalties as provided by Section 21.12.030. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.160 - Hauling solid waste to transfer station. 
A.  Any person, persons, firm, association or corporation hauling municipal solid waste, wood and tree waste, construction/demolition material, rubble, metal, or any other materials to the city solid waste disposal site, for the purpose of depositing such waste materials at the transfer station or other city designated disposal site, shall be charged a fee therefore based on the weight of waste materials. The fee shall be established by resolution of the governing body. 
B.  Municipal solid waste, wood and tree waste, construction/demolition material, rubble, metal, or any other materials brought to the city solid waste disposal site pursuant to this provision shall be deposited at designated locations as directed by the Solid Waste Superintendent or his/her designee. 
C.  Materials delivered to the city's transfer station or other city designated solid waste disposal site not sorted and deposited as directed by the Solid Waste Department will result in a maintenance/sorting charge as set by resolution of the governing board being assessed upon the person or business having delivered the same. 
D.  Car bodies, machinery, and large pieces of scrap metal shall not be deposited or permitted at the transfer station at any time unless authorized by the Solid Waste Superintendent, or in his/her absence, by the commissioner or his/her designee and the Solid Waste Superintendent's designee. 
E.  No vehicle or trailer loaded with garbage, cans, bottles, wastepaper, ashes, refuse, trash, or rubbish, or any other nauseous or offensive matter, or anything being transported to a solid waste disposal site for disposal, shall be driven or pulled to the disposal site unless the load is totally covered or secured in a manner which will prevent the load or any part of the load from dragging, spilling or falling from the vehicle. Loads of waste being hauled to the garbage collection site that are not totally covered or secured in a manner which will prevent the load or any part of the load from dragging, spilling or falling from the vehicle will be assessed a maintenance charge as set by resolution of the governing board. Trucks hauling waste to the landfill will use end-gates to prevent waste from spilling out. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.170 - Reserved. 
6.20.180 - Burning solid waste prohibited. 
    No municipal solid waste, rubble or yard waste shall be burned in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.190 - Reserved. 
6.20.200 - Reserved. 
6.20.210 - Reserved. 
6.20.215 - Recycling. 
A.  Recyclable items are the following products: flat and corrugated cardboard, newspaper, office paper, paperback books, junk mail, magazines, catalogues, rinsed plastic bottles and jugs with recycling symbol, and metals, including rinsed aluminum and tin cans. Glass bottles and jars are not recyclable items. 
B.  Participation by residents of the city in the recycling program is voluntary. Participating residents shall separate recyclable materials from the municipal solid waste stream and place the recycling container at the curb or alley on the designated collection day to be collected by the city. The recycling container must be at least one-third full when placed at the curb or alley on the designated collection day. 
C.  Every owner of a multiple dwelling unit, as defined in Section 6.20.070 B., shall provide an adequate number of containers for recyclable material for each multiple dwelling unit building in order to facilitate resident recycling. Containers shall be placed on the premises in a location that is convenient for the deposit and collection of recyclables. Unless use of the recycling container has been suspended pursuant to Section 6.20.215 J., on approval by the unit owner or operator, the City of Huron will provide recycling collection service for all multiple dwelling units being provided solid waste collection service by the Solid Waste Department. 
D.  Businesses being provided solid waste collection services by the City Solid Waste Department may submit a request to contract with the Solid Waste Department for the collection of recyclable items. Businesses entering into a contract with the Solid Waste Department shall comply with all rules, regulations, policies and ordinances to the extent such rules, regulations, policies and ordinances are applicable to businesses. 
E.  Residential recycling collection fee. 
1.  Each domestic dwelling unit as defined in Section 6.20.070 A. and as identified on municipal wastewater billing records shall pay a monthly fee for residential recycling in an amount established by resolution of the governing board to help defray the costs and expenses of the recycling program. The domestic dwelling recycling fee shall be included in and collected with the municipal solid waste fee on the municipal utility billing. 
2.  The owner of a multiple dwelling unit as defined in Section 6.20.070 B. shall be assessed a residential recycling fee in an amount established by resolution of the governing board. The fee shall be based upon the number of separate residential dwelling units within the multiple dwelling unit. 
3.  The owner of multiple dwelling units which do not have municipal solid waste collection service by Solid Waste Department shall be responsible for the disposal of the recyclable materials from the multiple dwelling unit; however, upon written authorization from the owner of the multiple dwelling unit, or its agent, and its solid waste collection contractor, and subject to the approval of the Solid Waste Department, the Solid Waste Department may provide recycling service for apartments not otherwise receiving municipal solid waste collection services by the Department. 
4.  The owner of a multiple dwelling unit receiving recycling services from the Solid Waste Department pursuant to Section 6.20.215 E.3. shall comply with all rules, regulations, policies and ordinances to the extent such rules, regulations, policies and ordinances are applicable, in the determination of the Solid Waste Department, and failure by such owner to adhere to the rules, regulations, policies and ordinances may result in the suspension or termination of recycling services by the Solid Waste Department. 
F.  The City of Huron will provide curbside recycling collection for all domestic dwelling units as defined in Section 6.20.070 A. and will provide recycling collection for the multiple dwelling units as defined in Section 6.20.070 B. being provided solid waste collection service by the Solid Waste Department. 
G.  Recycling containers. Unless use of the recycling container has been suspended pursuant to Section 6.20.215 J., the city will provide to each domestic dwelling unit a recycling container having a molded recycling decal. The city shall determine if it is necessary to replace a container. Should it be necessary to replace a container the city shall notify the owner or resident and direct the owner or resident to leave the container at the curb. 
H.  Use of recycling containers: 
1.  Only those items designated by the city as being recyclable shall be placed in the recycling containers, and should items not designated as recyclable items be placed in the container and collected by the Solid Waste Department, the person(s) responsible for contamination identified shall be sent a miscellaneous billing for sorting fee as established by resolution of the governing board, plus the cost of any damage to equipment, any costs incurred by city due to city's recycling vendor rejecting the load, and constitute a violation of Chapter 6.20. 
2.  Items not separated as directed or ineligible to be recycled by the city may be left at the curb by the Solid Waste Department. 
3.  Before recycling containers are placed at the collection locations, the recycling container must be at least one-third full of recyclable items. 
4.  Except for shredded paper and plastic bags, all recyclables shall be placed loose in the automated recycling container provided. Shredded paper and plastic bags shall be tied inside a transparent plastic grocery bag. Cardboard boxes shall be flattened and completely empty of all contents. 
5.  Recycling containers shall be securely covered and protected from the elements to the greatest extent possible so that the wind cannot blow out and scatter the contents over street, alleys and property within the city. 
6.  Residents of the city are responsible for picking up items from their tipped containers. 
7.  Every container shall, to the extent possible, be maintained by the owner in a sanitary condition and it shall be the responsibility of the owner to periodically clean bins by washing, scalding or other methods as deemed necessary. 
8.  Residences or businesses placing items in recycling containers which are hazardous to the health of the public or constitute a fire hazard will have the recycling container removed by the Solid Waste Department and will not be provided recycling collection service until the city has approved the residence or business method for disposal of the items which are hazardous to the health of the public or constitute a fire hazard. 
9.  All recyclable materials placed at the curb become the sole property of the city or its designated agent. It will be considered a violation of this chapter for any unauthorized individual(s) to salvage, remove, or carry off any of the recyclable materials. Containers placed in the public way and displaying the city recycling decal on the regularly scheduled collection day shall be presumed intended for collection, and as such shall be collected by the Solid Waste Department or solid waste collection business authorized by the city. 
I.  Collection procedures. 
1.  The city will provide, on a regularly scheduled day, weekly curbside collection of recyclable materials for all domestic dwelling units as defined in Section 6.20.070 A. and on a regularly scheduled day will provide collection of recyclable materials for multiple dwelling units being provided solid waste collection service by the Solid Waste Department. 
2.  The city reserves the right to change the pickup schedule with reasonable notice provided. 
3.  Recyclable materials containers shall be placed at the curb/alley, or as otherwise directed by the city, and at least three feet away from the household garbage and yard waste containers. 
4.  On the designated day of recycling pickup, all recycling materials must be set out for collection in the manner and within the time frame as established by the Municipal Solid Waste Department. Recycling containers shall be removed from the designated location on the same day as collection. 
J.  In addition to the penalties set forth in Section 1.04.130, the Solid Waste Superintendent may suspend the use of recycling containers for a domestic dwelling unit or a multiple dwelling unit due to repeated violations of Sections 6.20.215 H. and I., for such length of time as may be determined by the Solid Waste Superintendent 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.220 - Operation and enforcement of regulations. 
    The operation and enforcement of this chapter shall be vested in the commissioner of solid waste, solid waste superintendent, and city attorney. The superintendent and commissioner of solid waste shall have the right to promulgate rules and regulations for carrying out the intents and purposes of this chapter, subject to the approval of the governing body. Any such rules and regulations so adopted shall be filed with the city finance officer prior to the effective date thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.230 - Contracted services. 
A.  The city, at its discretion and upon approval of the governing board, may enter into contracts to collect municipal solid waste, including recyclable materials, from additional users, including but not be limited to businesses and multiple dwelling units not being provided collection service by the Solid Waste Department, 
B.  The city, at its discretion and upon approval by the governing board, may enter into contracts with commercial solid waste collectors to provide some or all municipal solid waste collection service for the city. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.240 - Penalty for violations. 
    In additional to the use of recycling containers being suspended as set forth is Section 6.20.215 J., any person, persons, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter or violating any policy, regulation or resolution approved by the governing body and duly published, shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1.04.130. Each day that a violation of this chapter, or any policy, regulation or resolution promulgated there under shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
6.20.250 - Effective date. 
    The amendments to Chapter 6.20 as outlined in Ordinance Number 2130-6-41 shall be effective July 1, 2013. 
(Ord. No. 2130-6-41, 4-29-2013) 
Chapter 6.28 - STOCKYARDS AND SLAUGHTERHOUSES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Municipalities empowered to control location and regulate management of slaughterhouses, etc. - See SDC 45.0201(39). 
Cross reference- Handling, keeping or storing bones prohibited - See Section 5.56.090 of this code. 

6.28.010 - Storage of hides and carcasses. 
    It is unlawful for any person, partnership or corporation to engage in the business of buying or selling or storing, or having in their possession for sale or storage for any other purpose any hides, pelts, or skins, or any carcasses or parts of carcasses of any animals or any furs or wool, unless the same is kept in a building with a cement or concrete basement and floor and the basement must have a sewer and water connection and drainage so that such storage room can be drained and washed out and kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.1401, 1950). 
6.28.020 - Place of business to be kept in sanitary condition. 
    Any person, partnership, or corporation, or firm engaging in the business referred to in Section 6.28.010 hereof shall at all times keep his place of business in a clean and sanitary condition and in such a condition that no offensive odors or smell arise therefrom to the injury or annoyance of any person. 
(Ord. 483 § 7.1402, 1950). 
6.28.030 - Rendering of fats and grease. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to keep or collect within the limits of this city any stale, putrid or unsound fat, grease, meat, carcass, entrails or other matter, to render and fry out the same unless it is done in such a manner that no offensive smell or odor or unhealthy fumes shall arise therefrom. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0503, 1950). 
6.28.040 - Location of stockyards, slaughterhouses, etc. 
    It is unlawful for any person, persons, corporation or company to conduct or maintain any slaughterhouse, stockyard, hide house, tannery, soap or glue factory within one hundred fifty yards of any dwelling house, school building or church within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 6.0603, 1950). 
Title 8 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes:
