Chapter 8.04 - ANIMALS 

8.04.010 - Definitions. 
(1)  "Adequate shelter" means protection from the elements generally considered to be standard and accepted for an animal's health and well-being consistent with the species, breed, physical condition, and type of animal. 
(2)  "Animal" includes any mammal, bird, reptile, amphibian or fish, except humans. 
(3)  "Animal containment area" means any area wherein an animal is restrained, contained, or restricted to or any enclosure or shelter wherein an animal lives. 
(4)  "Animal control officer" means a law enforcement officer or any person employed, contracted, or appointed by the Beadle County Humane Society. 
(5)  "At large" means to be off the premises of the owner and not under the control of the owner or owner's designee. An animal within an automobile of its owner shall be deemed upon its owner's property. 
(6)  "Impoundment" means taking physical control and custody of an animal. 
(7)  "Kennel" means any person engaged in keeping four or more dogs or cats of any species who are more than six months of age, for pleasure, profit, breeding, exhibiting, or for commercial business of boarding or trading for a fee on the premises. 
(8)  "Leash" means a cord, thong, or chain by which an animal is controlled by the person accompanying it. 
(9)  "Neutered dog/cat" means any male dog/cat which has undergone surgery to prevent reproduction, whose owner can provide proof of surgery. 
(10)  "Owner" includes any person harboring or keeping an animal or the owner or manager in charge of the establishment or premises at which an animal remains or returns to. 
(11)  "Spayed dog/cat" means any female dog/cat which has undergone surgery to prevent conception, whose owners can provide suitable proof of such surgery. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.015 - Designated animal care and control agency. 
    The Beadle County Humane Society is designated pursuant to SDCL Chapter 40-2 as the animal care and control agency for the City of Huron and may enforce the provisions of this title, SDCL Ch. 40-1 and Chapter 40-2. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.020 - Animal running at large prohibited. 
    The owner of an animal shall not permit such animal to run at large within the city. Any animal found at large may be impounded as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.030 - Dog and cat registration required. 
(1)  All dogs and cats over the age of six months kept, harbored or maintained by their owners in the city shall be licensed and registered annually before the first day of February each year. Each license shall then be effective for a twelve-month period. Dog and cat licenses shall be issued by the Beadle County Humane Society. The license fee to be paid upon the registration and licensing of each dog and cat shall determined by resolution of the governing board. 
(2)  Before any dog or cat is licensed or registered, the owner shall be required to furnish the certificate of current vaccination issued by a licensed veterinarian certifying that the dog or cat for which the license is being issued is vaccinated for rabies. 
(3)  Upon payment of the registration fee, the Beadle County Humane Society shall register all dogs and cats, such record to show the owner's name and street address, the dog's or cat's name, breed and color, and the year for which the registration is paid. 
(4)  After the payment of the registration fee, the Beadle County Humane Society shall give to the owner of such dog or cat a metallic tag for each dog or cat so registered, upon which tag shall be stamped or engraved the registered number of the dog or cat and the year when registered, and it shall be the duty of the owner of the dog or cat to place a collar around the neck of such dog or cat so owned by him on which collar shall be securely fastened the metallic tag furnished by the Beadle County Humane Society and which tag shall be worn by the dog or cat at all times; provided that in case of the loss of any registration tag so issued, the Beadle County Humane Society is authorized to issue a duplicate thereof upon payment by the owner of the sum as determined by resolution of the governing board. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.040 - Vaccination required. 
    Any owner acquiring a dog, cat or other animal by purchase, gift, birth or otherwise, shall have such animal vaccinated against rabies within one month following acquisition or when the animal reaches the age of six months. An animal shall be considered unvaccinated after the expiration of the date of its latest rabies vaccination. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.050 - Impounding of animals. 
(1)  An animal control officer is authorized to impound any animal running at large. The owner thereof may at any time within three days after the same has been impounded, reclaim the same by paying the Beadle County Humane Society the impoundment fees as set by resolution of the governing body for the keeping of such animal. If any animal so impounded has not been reclaimed within three days, the governing body is authorized to destroy, sell or otherwise dispose of the same. 
(2)  All animals captured, conveyed and impounded as provided by this chapter shall be kept with humane treatment and supplied with sufficient food and water for a period of at least three days, unless sooner reclaimed by the owner or keeper of the animal. The owner or keeper of any animal which has been impounded shall be responsible for payment of the impoundment fee, plus any veterinarian costs, if any, and licensing fee, if any, before the animal is released to the owner or keeper of the animal. 
(3)  If the owner or keeper of any animal impounded shall fail to reclaim such animal within three consecutive days after such impounding, excluding Sundays and holidays, any other person may, upon complying with the provisions of this chapter, adopt such animal from the pet shelter and be the lawful owner thereof. It shall be unlawful for any person, for the purpose of returning the animal to its prior owner, to fraudulently adopt an otherwise unclaimed animal for the purpose of avoiding the payment of fees otherwise chargeable against the owner of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.060 - Kennel license required. 
    Any person operating a kennel as defined in this chapter shall pay an annual license fee as determined by resolution of the governing board. Licenses will be issued by Beadle County Humane Society. The location and use of a kennel must be in compliance with the city zoning ordinances and animal control ordinances. Any property for which a kennel license has been issued may be inspected by an animal control officer to make sure it meets the requirements of all city ordinances, state statutes, and is being operated in a humane manner. No kennel shall be established within fifty feet of any dwelling house unless the owner (and lessee, if the dwelling house is rented) of all dwelling houses within fifty feet of the kennel consent in advance in writing to the kennel. Persons operating such kennels are not required to license individual animals as provided in this chapter. Persons operating kennels are required to obtain a kennel license annually before the first day of February each year. Each license shall then be effective for a twelve-month period. Hospitals, clinics, pet shops, Humane Society or other premises operated by a licensed veterinarian for the care and treatment of animals are exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.070 - Rabies control-Procedure upon notification of dog bite by unvaccinated animal. 
(1)  When any person owning or harboring a dog, cat or other animal which is not currently vaccinated for rabies, or for which the owner cannot produce a current certificate of vaccination issued by a licensed veterinarian, has been notified that said animal has bitten any person, the animal shall be impounded at the Beadle County Humane Society facility for the period of ten days, under the observation of a licensed veterinarian, with the expense of such impoundment and observation to be borne by the owner of the animal. 
(2)  If it is determined by the licensed veterinarian at the end of the ten day impoundment period that the animal is not rabid, and provided the animal is not determined to be a dangerous dog, the animal will be returned to its owner, subject to the owner: (a) paying impound charges and all other expenses incident to the observation of the dog; (b) agreeing to comply with all requirements imposed by an animal control officer in respect to the vicious animal provisions of this chapter; (c) the animal is properly vaccinated for rabies; and (d) any other provisions or requirements of law, including licensing, are fully complied with; otherwise the animal shall be disposed of. 
(3)  Any animal impounded or placed for observation, showing active signs of rabies, suspected of having rabies or known to have been exposed to rabies, shall be subject to the control and direction, including disposition as necessary, of the licensed veterinarian conducting the observation and impoundment. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.080 - Disturbance of peace by dogs. 
    It is declared that the persistent or constant barking, howling, whining, snarling or growling or any such sound by a dog constitutes a public nuisance by disturbing the peace and quiet of a neighborhood. 
    No owner of a dog and no person keeping, harboring or having a dog on property occupied by that person, whether the person is a resident or not of the property, shall allow the dog to persistently and constantly bark, howl, whine, snarl, growl or make other such sound. For purposes of this provision "persistent or constant" shall mean the barking, howling, whining, snarling, growling or any such sound continually for at least three minutes and with only brief or no interruptions within the three-minute period, or the barking, howling, whining, snarling, growling or any such sound continually within a thirty minute period with periodic or short intervals between the barking, howling, whining, snarling, growling or any such sound. 
    An owner of a dog and a person keeping, harboring or having a dog on property during the time that the dog is a public nuisance by disturbing the peace and quiet of a neighborhood may be issued a citation or a summons to appear in court. A citation issued by an animal control officer shall identify the amount of the fine and command the person to appear in court unless the fine is paid prior to the court date. 
    The penalty for violating the ordinance codified in this section shall be a fine as set by resolution of the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011; Ord. No. 2139-8-23, 1-13-2014) 
8.04.090 - Animal feces. 
    No person owning, harboring, keeping or in charge of any animal shall cause, suffer or allow such animal to soil, defecate on or commit any nuisance on any common thoroughfare, sidewalk, play area, park or any place where people congregate or walk, or upon any public property whatsoever, or upon any private property without the permission of the owner of said property. Any person in charge of an animal shall immediately remove all fecal deposits by an animal in their charge by wrapping said deposits in a sanitary manner and depositing them in a garbage container, or in such other sanitary manner. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.110 - Animal shelter and containment areas. 
    Every person owning, harboring, keeping or in charge of any animal shall provide the animal with adequate shelter from the elements generally considered to be standard and accepted for an animal's health and well-being consistent with the species, breed, physical condition, and type of animal. Animal containment areas shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and not permitted to become stagnant, noxious or a nuisance. Every person owning, harboring, keeping or in charge of any animal shall clean such containment area within twenty-four hours of receiving written notice from an animal control officer that such cleaning is required. The animal control officer is authorized to impound, without notice, animals in unsafe, unsanitary, unsecured, neglected or otherwise inhumane conditions that warrant immediate attention. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.04.120 - Penalty for violations. 
    Except as may be modified with this chapter, any person found violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
Chapter 8.06 - DANGEROUS ANIMALS AND VICIOUS DOGS 

8.06.010 - Definitions. 
    Whenever used in this chapter, the following terms shall be defined as follows: 
(1)  "Dangerous animal" means any animal that, by itself or by environmental circumstances, at the determination of an animal control officer, is a threat to the physical well-being of other owned animals or humans. 
(2)  "Owner" means any person possessing, harboring, keeping, having an interest in, or having control or custody of a dog. 
(3)  "Unprovoked" means that the dog was not being teased, tormented, abused or assaulted. 
(4)  "Vicious dog" is (a) any dog which, when unprovoked, in a vicious or terrorizing manner approaches in apparent attitude of attack, or bites, inflicts injury, assaults, or otherwise attacks a human being who is on the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or places, or (b) any dog which, on private property, when unprovoked, in a vicious or terrifying manner approaches in apparent attitude of attack, or bites, or inflicts injury, or otherwise attacks a mailman, meter reader, serviceman, journeyman, delivery man, or other employed person who is on private property by reason of permission of the owner or occupant of such property or who is on private property by reason of a course of dealing with the owner of such private property. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.06.020 - Enforcement. 
    Animal control officers shall be empowered to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.06.030 - Dangerous animal a nuisance. 
    Any dangerous animal found within the city is declared to be a public nuisance. An animal control officer may order the owner of a dangerous animal to remove the dangerous animal from the jurisdictional limits of the city, or in the alternative, to deliver the dangerous animal to the impound facility. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.06.040 - Determination of a dangerous animal-Appeal. 
    An animal control officer shall have the authority to make a determination that an animal is dangerous, as defined in this chapter. The animal control officer shall make such determination after a reasonable investigation of the physical and behavioral characteristics including breed characteristics, that the animal is dangerous. Upon a determination that the animal is dangerous, the animal control officer may order the owner to either remove the dangerous animal from the jurisdictional limits of the city, or in the alternative, deliver the dangerous animal to the city impound facility. The owner shall be responsible for all impound costs. The owner of the animal determined to be dangerous by the animal control officer may request the magistrate court to review the determination, and in such case, the magistrate court shall review the determination and consider any additional information or evidence the owner may offer in respect to the issue of whether the animal in question is a dangerous animal. Nothing in this section shall excuse the owner from complying with any terms or conditions relating to vicious dogs. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.06.050 - Acquisition of a dangerous animal prohibited. 
(1)  No person shall own or harbor any animal for the purpose of dog fighting, or train, torment, badger, bait or use any animal for the purpose of causing or encouraging said animal to attack or menace human beings or domestic animals when not provoked. 
(2)  No person shall sell, offer for sale, breed, buy or attempt to buy any dangerous animal within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.06.060 - Vicious dog a nuisance. 
    Any vicious dog within the city is declared to be a public nuisance. An animal control officer may order the owner of a vicious dog to comply with registration and confinement requirements set forth in Section 8.06.090, to remove the dog from the jurisdictional limits of the city, or deliver the vicious dog to the impound facility. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.06.070 - Determination of a vicious dog. 
(1)  An animal control officer shall have the authority to make a determination that a dog is vicious, as defined in this chapter. The animal control officer shall make such determination that the dog is vicious after a reasonable investigation of the physical and behavioral characteristics including breed characteristics, that the dog, while on private or public property, approached any person who is on a public street, sidewalk or other public ground, in a vicious or terrorizing manner and in an apparent attitude of attack, or bit, inflicted injury, assaulted, or otherwise attacked the person. Upon a determination that the dog is vicious, the animal control officer may order the owner to either remove the vicious dog from the jurisdictional limits of the city, or in the alternative, deliver the dangerous dog to the city impound facility. The owner shall be responsible for all impound costs. 
(2)  No dog may be declared vicious if an injury or damage is sustained to any person who was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon premises occupied by the owner or keeper of the dog, or who was teasing, tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.06.080 - Determination of a vicious dog-Appeal. 
    Within fourteen days of an animal control officer notifying the owner of the dog that the dog has been determined to be a vicious dog, the owner of the dog determined to be vicious by the animal control officer may request the magistrate court to review the determination, and in such case, the magistrate court shall review the determination and consider any additional information or evidence the owner may offer in respect to the issue of whether the dog in question is vicious. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.06.090 - Vicious dog regulations. 
    The owner of a vicious dog may be ordered by an animal control officer to comply with the following regulations as a condition of maintaining such animal within the jurisdictional limits of the city: 
(1)  Registration. The owner of a vicious dog must register such dog with the Beadle County Humane Society. The application for such registration shall contain the name and address of the owner, the breed, age, sex, color and any other identifying marks of the dog, the location where the dog is to be kept if not at the address of the owner and any other information which the Beadle County Humane Society may require. The application for registration pursuant to this section shall be accompanied by a registration fee as set by resolution of the governing board. A vicious dog registered pursuant hereto shall be assigned an official registration number by the Beadle County Humane Society which shall be inscribed on a metal tag which shall be attached to the collar of the such dog at all times. The tag and a certificate of registration shall be of such form and design and shall contain such information as the Beadle County Humane Society shall prescribe and shall be issued to the owner upon payment of the registration fee and compliance with all orders of the Beadle County Humane Society or animal control officer with respect to the vicious dog. 
(2)  Confinement. The animal control officer may order the owner of a vicious dog to confine the dog, at all times, indoors or in a proper enclosure which shall consist of a securely enclosed and locked pen or structure, suitable to prevent the entry of young children, or a part of their bodies or other foreign objects, and designed to prevent the animal from escaping; such pen or structure shall have secure sides and prevent the dog from digging his way out through the bottom or under the sides. The pen or structure shall also provide the animal or dog with adequate shelter from the elements. The animal control officer may further require the owner to conspicuously display a sign designed with a warning symbol approved by the animal control officer which indicates to both children and adults the presence of a vicious dog or animal, on the pen or structure and on or near the entrance to the residence where the dog is kept. At any time the dog is not confined as required herein, the dog shall be muzzled in such a manner as to prevent it from biting or injuring any person, and kept on a leash no longer than six feet with the owner or some other responsible person attending such dog. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.06.100 - Violations and penalties. 
    Failure by the owner of the dog determined to be vicious to comply with an animal control officer requirement related to registration or confinement of the vicious dog, to remove the dog from the jurisdictional limits of the city if ordered by an animal control officer, to deliver the dog to the impound facility, or appeal the determination to magistrate court, shall subject the owner to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
Chapter 8.08 - CRUELTY, ABUSE AND INJURY TO ANIMALS 

8.08.010 - Definitions. 
(1)  Mistreatment, torture, or cruelty of animals means any act or omission whereby unnecessary, unjustifiable, or unreasonable physical pain or suffering is caused, permitted, or allowed to continue, including acts of mutilation, upon an animal. 
(2)  Neglect of an animal is the failure to provide food, water, protection from the elements, adequate sanitation, adequate facilities, or care generally considered to be standard and accepted for an animal's health and well-being consistent with the species, breed, physical condition, and type of animal. 
(3)  Inhumane treatment of an animal is any act of mistreatment, torture, cruelty, neglect, abandonment, mutilation, or inhumane slaughter of an animal that is not consistent with generally accepted training, use and husbandry procedures for the species, breed, physical condition, and type of animal. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.08.020 - Mistreatment, torture, cruelty, neglect, inhumane treatment of animals prohibited. 
    No person shall mistreat, torture, neglect or commit any act or omission of cruelty any animal owned by or under the care of the person responsible for the welfare of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.08.030 - Right of entry. 
    Any animal control officer finding an animal inhumanely treated, shall, pursuant to a warrant or court order, cause the animal to be impounded or otherwise properly cared for, and the expenses of such impoundment or care shall be a lien on the animal to be paid before the animal may be lawfully recovered. However, a warrant or court order is not necessary if the animal is severely injured, severely diseased, or suffering and any delay in impounding the animal would continue to cause the animal extreme suffering or if other exigent circumstances exist. If any animal is impounded or subjected to other action under this section without a warrant or court order, the officer or agent shall subsequently show cause for the impoundment or other action to the court, and the court shall issue an order ratifying the impoundment or action; or, if sufficient cause for the impoundment or action is not shown, the court shall order the return of the animal to the owner or other appropriate remedy. The owner or caretaker of an animal impounded or cared for pursuant to this provision is liable for the expense of services rendered. The payment shall be on vouchers. Expenses may be recovered in a civil action against the owner unless the expenses are paid within thirty days after notice and demand. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.08.040 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person convicted for violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
Chapter 8.16 - KEEPING IN CITY 

8.16.010 - Keeping animals within city limits. 
    It is unlawful for any person, partnership, association or corporation to keep or harbor any horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats, swine or birds such as ducks, geese, turkeys, pheasants or chickens, within the city of Huron, except that public auction rings, livestock commission houses, veterinary clinic and treatment facilities, locker plants and hatcheries may temporarily keep and hold any such animals or fowl for the purpose of sale, slaughter or treatment; and in addition the state of South Dakota fairgrounds shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
8.16.012 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person convicted for violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. No. 2105-8-22, 12-12-2011) 
Title 9 - PUBLIC SAFETY AND MORALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Cruelty to animals - See Ch. 8.08 of this code; Park regulations - See Ch. 11.12 of this code; Traffic laws and regulations - See Title 16 of this code. 

Chapter 9.02 - 911 EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SERVICE 

9.02.010 - Enhanced 911 system established. 
    An enhanced 911 emergency telephone reporting system as the same is defined in SDCL 34-45 et seq., is authorized and established. Management and control of said system shall be vested in the city of Huron, South Dakota, a municipal corporation. 
(Ord. 1677 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2147-9-52, 7-28-2014) 
9.02.020 - Jurisdictional service area. 
    The 911 system established by this chapter shall cover the service area including all of the area within the legal boundaries of the limits of the city of Huron. The governing bodies of other counties or cities within the reasonable service area of the city who have adopted ordinances substantially similar to this chapter may, subject to the agreement of the city commission, enter intergovernmental agreements between the city and such other cities and counties, as authorized by SDCL 34-45-3, for the administration of the 911 system through this system established by the city. 
(Ord. 1677 (part), 1992). 
9.02.030 - Installation, operation and surcharge. 
    The city, pursuant to the intergovernmental agreement between this county and said city, shall be responsible for the installation, operation and maintenance of the 911 system, and all costs incurred in respect thereto. In order to pay for the costs incurred, both recurring and nonrecurring, the said city may collect, from all system users within Beadle County, a user surcharge for each local access service line within Beadle County, South Dakota. The surcharge rate shall be the current State 911 reimbursement rate per month for each local access line. All surcharge sums collected by any local exchange access company, from users of local exchange access lines within Beadle County, shall be remitted directly to the city finance officer of the city. 
(Ord. 1677 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2147-9-52, 7-28-2014) 
9.02.040 - Surcharge use and procedure. 
(a)  The proceeds of the surcharge shall be utilized to pay for nonrecurring and recurring costs of the 911 related service, as the same are defined by statute. The surcharge shall be imposed upon every local exchange access line within Beadle County, South Dakota; except that such charge may not be imposed upon more than one hundred local exchange access lines or the equivalent service, per customer account billed, per month. All rate review procedures and rate charges shall be in conformance with the provisions of SDCL 34-45 et seq. 
(b)  All funds collected from the surcharge shall be credited to a special fund, apart from the general fund of the city, for payment of nonrecurring and recurring costs and for the general operational expense of the 911 related service, including but not limited to the personnel costs. Said funds shall be administered in accordance with the statutes in such case made and provided. 
(Ord. 1677 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2147-9-52, 7-28-2014) 
9.02.050 - Severability and saving clause. 
    If any provision of this chapter shall be held invalid, it shall not affect any other provision of this chapter that can be given effect without the invalid provision, and for the saving purpose, the provisions of the chapter are hereby declared. 
(Ord. 1677 (part), 1992). 
Chapter 9.12 - PROSTITUTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities empowered to restrain and punish prostitutes and to suppress bawdy or disorderly houses or houses of ill fame-See SDC 45.0201 (26), (28). 

9.12.010 - Keeping house of prostitution. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, company or corporation to keep a house of ill-fame, or other place resorted to for the purpose of prostitution or lewdness within the jurisdiction of the city of Huron. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0301; April 24, 1950). 
9.12.020 - Practicing prostitution. 
    It shall be unlawful for any woman to be a prostitute, practice prostitution or to be an inmate of any bawdy house, house of ill-fame, or assignation, to entice, solicit or procure any person to commit an act of prostitution with her, or to endeavor by word, sign or action to ply the vocation of a prostitute within the city of Huron. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0302; April 24, 1950). 
9.12.030 - Renting premises for purpose of prostitution. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, company or corporation to let or rent any building or portion of any building, knowing that it is intended to be used as a house of ill-fame or place resorted to for the purpose of prostitution or lewdness or in any manner to permit any building to be so used within the jurisdiction of the city of Huron. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0303; April 24, 1950). 
9.12.040 - Soliciting for prostitute. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city of Huron to entice, solicit, or procure, or attempt to solicit, entice or procure, another to commit an act of prostitution, or to designate, indicate or lead the way to any house, room or place where prostitution is practiced, or to point out or to indicate to another any person with whom he or she believes an act of prostitution may be committed. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0304; April 24, 1950). 
9.12.050 - Disorderly house defined. 
    Every house or resort by which the peace, comfort and decency of the community is annoyed or disturbed, or in which house any unlawful act is done or performed, is a disorderly house. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0305; April 24, 1950). 
9.12.060 - Unlawful to keep or maintain disorderly house. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons within the city of Huron to keep, maintain, manage or run any disorderly house, or any room or rooms in a disorderly house, or to aid, assist or in any manner contribute to the control or management thereof. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0306; April 24, 1950). 
9.12.070 - Inmates of disorderly house. 
    Any person or persons found in a disorderly house shall, upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0307; April 24, 1950). 
Chapter 9.16 - FIREWORKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities empowered to regulate or prohibit the sale or use of fireworks-See SDC 45.0202 (30). 
Cross reference- Fire prevention generally-See Title 19 of this code. 

9.16.010 - Unlawful to sell fireworks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, deliver, or give away to any person any firecrackers, blank cartridges, Roman candles, rockets or other fireworks or explosives or other material, or explosives from which firecrackers, blank cartridges or other fireworks may be manufactured, except caps for toy cap pistols, at any place within the city of Huron, or within one mile of the corporate limits of the city of Huron. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0401, as amended by Ord. 571; May 10, 1954). 
9.16.020 - Discharging or shooting fireworks prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot, discharge or explode, or cause to be shot, discharged or exploded any firecrackers, sky rockets, blank cartridges, fireworks or other explosives used for fireworks or fire display in the city of Huron, except caps for toy cap pistols. It shall also be unlawful for any person to have any of such fireworks in his possession in a public place in the city of Huron except that contained in a sealed original package in the condition it was shipped or transported and the wrapping and seal of said package unbroken. The having in possession by any person in a public place of any such package with the wrapping or seal broken shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0402, as amended by Ord. 571; May 10, 1954). 
Chapter 9.20 - MINORS' CURFEW[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Minors in pool rooms and bowling alleys-See Ch. 5.16 of this code; Minors in roller skating rinks-See Ch. 5.20 of this code; Minors at dances-See Ch. 5.24 of this code; Sale of liquor to minors-See Chs. 5.48, 5.52 of this code; Minimum driving age-See Ch. 16.12 of this code; Bicycle riding curfew-See Ch. 16.48 of this code. 

9.20.010 - Unlawful for parents to permit child on streets during curfew hours. 
    It is unlawful for any parent, guardian, or other person having the legal care or custody of any person under sixteen years of age to allow or permit any such child, ward or other person under such age, while in such legal care, custody or control, to go or be in or upon any of the streets, avenues, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds or places, places of amusement or entertainment, and places of business, or vacant lots in said city of Huron between the hours of ten p.m. and six a.m. of the following day, unless accompanied by parent or guardian or other adult person having the care or custody of such child, unless there exists a reasonable necessity therefor. The fact that said child unaccompanied by parent or guardian or other adult person having its care or custody is found in or upon any of said places after the hour of ten p.m. or before the hour of six a.m. shall be prima facie evidence that said child is there unlawfully and that no reasonable excuse does exist therefor. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0501; April 24, 1950). 
9.20.020 - Unlawful for child to be on street during curfew hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any minor under the age of sixteen years to be on or present upon any streets, avenues, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public ground or places, places of amusement or entertainment, and places of business, or vacant lots in said city of Huron, between the hours of ten p.m. and six a.m. of the following day unless there exists a reasonable necessity therefor, or unless such child is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian or other adult person having the care or custody of said minor child. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0502; April 24, 1950). 
9.20.030 - Unlawful to permit minors in place of amusement premises during curfew hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, manager, or person in charge of any show or other place of amusement and business to permit any minor under the age of sixteen years to enter or remain in said show or other place of amusement and business after ten p.m. and until six a.m. of the following day, unless said minor shall be accompanied by his or her parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of said minor child. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0503; April 24, 1950). 
9.20.032 - Daylight saving time provisions. 
    In the event that the state of South Dakota and/or the city of Huron operates on Central Daylight Saving Time, the ten p.m. Central Standard Time curfew provisions of this chapter shall be interpreted to mean and to be enforced as an eleven p.m. Central Daylight Saving Time curfew from June 1st through September 1st of the calendar year. 
(Ord. 939; July 10, 1967). 
9.20.040 - Arrest-Penalty for violation by child. 
    Each member of the police force is authorized to arrest with or without a warrant any person or persons violating the provisions of Sections 9.20.010, 9.20.020 or 9.20.030; and any child unaccompanied by parent, guardian or other adult person having care or custody of said child may be sent home or taken home or proceeded against in court. Upon conviction the minor child shall be punished by a fine pursuant to the general penalty provision in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. 1694 (part), 1993: Ord. 483 § 8.0504; April 24, 1950). 
9.20.050 - Each violation as separate offense. 
    Each violation of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0505; April 24, 1950). 
9.20.060 - Interpretation. 
    This chapter shall not be construed as permitting the presence at any time of any person under the age of sixteen years of age in any place where his presence is now prohibited by any existing law or ordinance. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0506; April 24, 1950). 
9.20.070 - Penalty for violation by adult. 
    Any parent, guardian or any other adult person or persons having care or custody of any such minor child violating Section 9.20.010 and any owner, manager or person in charge of any show, or other places of amusement and business violating Section 9.20.030 shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provision in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. 1694 (part), 1993: Ord. 1232 (part), 1976; Ord. 483 § 8.0507, 1950). 
Chapter 9.28 - SECONDHAND STORES, PAWNBROKERS AND JUNK DEALERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities empowered to regulate secondhand and junk stores and forbid purchase from minors without a written consent of parents or guardians - See SDC 45.0201(63). 
Cross reference- License provisions - See Ch. 5.56 of this code. 

9.28.010 - Purchasing junk from minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, firm or corporation, to purchase or receive from any person under the age of eighteen years, any article, goods, or things commonly known and classed as junk, any bottle, pipe or pipe fittings, lead, iron or brass, tools or implements, or any goods or wares of a secondhand character, or any rubber, overshoes, boots, or rubber goods of any nature, either secondhand or new without the written consent of such minor's parents or guardian, which writing shall be kept by such person or persons, firm or corporation and be subject to the inspection of any police officer of the City of Huron or any other law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. 836 § 10, 1963). 
9.28.020 - Sale of junk by minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen years to sell or offer for sale within the City of Huron any of the goods mentioned in Section 9.28.010 without the written consent of such minor's parent or guardian. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0603, 1950). 
9.28.030 - Secondhand stores and pawnbrokers must keep records. 
    All pawnbrokers, keepers of secondhand stores and dealers in secondhand goods, within the City of Huron are hereby required to keep a book in a form to be approved by the police commissioner, open to the inspection of the public in which shall be entered by such pawnbroker or dealer in secondhand goods, the name and address of each and every person of whom any article is purchased or pawned and the price paid for the same or the amount loaned on the same, a brief description of the goods purchased or pawned and the date of such transaction. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0601, 1950). 
Cross reference- Junk dealers required to keep records - See Section 5.56.070 of this code. 
Chapter 9.32 - STATIC[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities specifically authorized to control installation and operation of radio interference producing devices - See SDC 45.0201(50). 
Cross reference- ;Interference with radio and television reception from electric signs - See Ch. 18.32 of this code. 

9.32.010 - Unlawful to cause static. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate or cause to be operated in the City of Huron any machine, device, apparatus or instrument of any kind whatsoever causing preventable or avoidable interference with television or radio broadcast receiving apparatus between the hours of seven o'clock a.m. and eleven o'clock p.m. of any day; provided, however, that x-ray pictures, examinations or treatments may be made at any time if the machines or apparatus used therefor are properly equipped to avoid all unnecessary or reasonably preventable interference with television or radio reception and are not negligently operated. 
    This chapter shall not be held or construed to embrace or cover the regulation of any transmitting, broadcasting or receiving instrument, apparatus or device used or useful in interstate commerce or the operation of which instrument, apparatus, or device is licensed or authorized by or under the provisions of any act of Congress of the United States. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0631, as amended by Ord. 830, 1963). 
9.32.020 - Inspection. 
    The city electrical inspector or his duly authorized deputy, shall have the right to enter upon any premises at all reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting the installation and working of all apparatus coming within the terms of this chapter, and it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to interfere with the electrical inspector or his duly authorized deputy, in making said inspection or to refuse to permit the city electrical inspector or his deputy to enter the premises for such purposes. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0632, 1950). 
9.32.030 - Notice of violation. 
    When an inspection and test shall have been made by the electrical inspector or his duly authorized deputy and it is found that equipment or apparatus coming within the terms of this chapter is being operated in violation of this chapter the person or persons responsible for the operation shall be notified in writing to discontinue the use of such machine or to make additions, repairs or modifications thereof in order that the same may be operated in a manner which complies with the provisions of this chapter. The mailing of a registered letter addressed to the owner or operator of the machine at the premises where the machine or apparatus is located shall constitute a sufficient notice for the purpose of this chapter. In the event that the owner or operator of such machine or apparatus does not within seven days after the receipt of notice to repair or discontinue the use of such machine, either entirely discontinue the use of such machine during the hours the use of such machine is prohibited by this chapter, or repair the same so that it complies with the provisions of this chapter, such owner shall be deemed to be operating such machine or apparatus in violation of the provisions of this chapter and such person shall be subject to the penalties provided in Section 1.04.130 of this code. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0633, 1950). 
Chapter 9.36 - WEAPONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities may provide for keeping and preserving the peace and quiet-See SDC 45.0201 (25). 
Cross reference- Pistols - See Ch. 5.44 of this code. 

9.36.010 - Drawing a deadly weapon. 
    No person except an officer of the law in the execution of his duty of a person in self-defense shall in the city draw a pistol, gun, revolver, knife or any other deadly or dangerous weapon upon another person. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0606, 1950). 
9.36.020 - Carrying concealed weapon. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to carry concealed about his person any pistol or other firearm, slingshot, brass knuckle, or knuckles of other metal or material, or any sandbag, dagger, bowie knife, dirk knife or other dangerous or deadly weapon or any instrument or device which when used is likely to produce death or great bodily harm; provided, that this section shall not be construed to prohibit any peace officer from wearing or carrying such weapons as may be necessary and proper for the discharge of his official duties. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0607, 1950). 
9.36.030 - Slingshots. 
    No person shall throw any projectile from any sling within the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0613, 1950). 
9.36.040 - Discharging firearms and weapons. 
A.  No person shall discharge or shoot off any gun, pistol, air gun, rocket, missile or other firearm or shoot any bow and arrow within the limits of the city. No person shall discharge or shoot off any gun, pistol, air gun, rocket, missile or other firearm or shoot any bow and arrow on city property located outside city limits without the prior approval of the city commission. 
B.  For land located in Sections 2, 3, 4, 9, 10 and 11, in Township 110N, Range 61W (Custer Township) that is also located east of Custer Avenue and south of the railroad right-of-way, there shall be no discharge of a shot shell shotgun or shooting arrows from a bow outside of city limits that is within six hundred sixty feet of a building within city limits, no discharge of a slug shotgun or muzzleloader outside of city limits that is within one-quarter mile of a building within city limits, and no discharge of a rifle outside of city limits that is within one mile of a building within city limits. 
C.  For all land adjacent to city limits and not identified in [subsection] B., above: 
1.  Discharging of shot shells from a shotgun and shooting arrows from a bow shall not be permitted within six hundred sixty feet of city limits; 
2.  Discharging of shotguns shooting slugs or muzzleloaders shall not be permitted within one-quarter mile of city limits; 
3.  Discharging of rifles, pistols, air guns, rockets, missiles or any other type of firearm shall not be permitted within one mile of city limits. 
D.  Section 9.36.040 shall not apply to shooting ranges or archery ranges (1) within city limits, (2) within one mile of city limits, or (3) on city property located outside city limits, provided the city commission has given prior authorization for the shooting range or archery range. Section 9.36.040 shall also not apply to any duly appointed animal control officer or his designee authorized by the governing board to eradicate any wild animal causing injury to trees, shrubs, vegetable gardens, flower gardens or other vegetation. 
(Ord. 1816, 1998: Ord. 1780, 1996: Ord. 483 § 8.0630, as amended by Ord. 686, 1958). 
(Ord. No. 2064, 9-14-2009; Ord. No. 2198-9-53, 12-10-2018) 
9.36.050 - Trapping of animals. 
    No person without permission of the city health department or chief of police shall set, allow to be set, or use any trap for the purpose of catching any animal, which trap could injure or kill any animal, except rodent traps in the interior of a building, and except by persons employed by, or agents of the city health department or city park and recreation department for purposes of the city's health and welfare. 
(Ord. 1515, 1984). 
Chapter 9.40 - INDECENT CONDUCT-OBSCENE LITERATURE[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- This chapter supplements SDC 13.1722; Municipalities specifically empowered to prohibit sale or exhibition of obscene literature as here defined - See SDCL 9-29-9; Municipalities authorized to declare what shall constitute a nuisance and to prevent, abate and remove the same - See SDCL 9-29-13. 

9.40.010 - Nudity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in any public place in this city in a state of nudity or in an indecent or lewd dress. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0620, 1950). 
9.40.020 - Indecent exposure. 
    No person shall, in the city, wilfully and lewdly expose his or her person, or the private parts thereof in any public place where there are present other persons to be offended or annoyed thereby. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0616, 1950). 
9.40.030 - Obscene literature defined. 
    The term "obscene literature" wherever used in this chapter shall be construed to include all obscene, lewd, or lascivious books, pamphlets, papers, magazines, writings, advertising, circulars, cards, prints, letters, pictures, drawings, films or other representations or publications upon paper or any other material, of an immoral, lewd or indecent nature and character and shall be construed to include all publications and printed and written matter declared by the United States Government to be nonmailable matter and which may not be conveyed or delivered in the mails. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0617, 1950). 
9.40.040 - Selling or offering for sale of obscene literature prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, either by himself, clerk, servant, employee or agent to exhibit, publish, pass, sell or offer for sale or have in his possession with such intent, any obscene literature as defined in this chapter. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0618, 1950). 
9.40.050 - Destruction of obscene literature. 
    All such obscene literature as defined in this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance and any police officer is authorized to seize any such literature found in the possession of any person arrested for a violation of this chapter, and upon trial of any accused person or persons, if he or they shall be convicted of a violation of the provisions of this chapter, the court shall order as a part of the judgment in addition to any other penalty or penalties, that the officer having custody of such obscene literature shall destroy the same. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0619; April 24, 1950). 
Chapter 9.44 - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC OFFICER[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities empowered to provide for keeping and preserving the peace-See SDC 45.0201(25). 

9.44.010 - Resisting an officer. 
    No person or persons shall rescue or take from the custody of any police officer, policeman or watchman, nor prevent the arrest of any person, nor resist, oppose, obstruct or impede any member of the police in the discharge of his duty in the City of Huron. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0608; April 24, 1950). 
9.44.020 - Refusing to assist an officer. 
    No person shall refuse to assist any policeman in making any arrest when lawfully required by the chief of police or any policeman. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0609; April 24, 1950). 
9.44.030 - Refusing to obey the command of an officer. 
    No person shall refuse to obey the command and direction of any police officer or policeman who may be doing duty for the purpose of preserving order and enforcing the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0604; April 24, 1950). 
9.44.040 - Impersonating officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not duly authorized to exercise the duties conferred by law upon policemen of this city, to wear a policeman's badge or represent himself as being a policeman or peace officer, or attempt to exercise the duties of a policeman or peace officer in the City of Huron. 
(Ord. 483 § 8.0605; April 24, 1950).

9.48.020 - Bathhouse at water intake.

9.48.030 - Gas pumps and signs.

(Ord. 1695 (part), 1993).
