Chapter 9.56 - MISCELLANEOUS UNLAWFUL CONDUCT[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to provide for keeping and preserving the peace and quiet and prevent disorderly conduct and to restrain and punish vagrants - See SDC 45.0201(25), (26). 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ords. 483, 830, 834 and 1232. 

9.56.010 - Disorderly conduct. 
    No person shall disturb the good order and peace of this city by fighting, by threatening to fight, by tumultuous threatenings, by offensive carriage, by using obscene or profane language, by making any loud or unusual noise so as to disturb the peace of the city, or any neighborhood, family, lawful assembly of persons or any person, or by using any word or words or committing any act or acts which tends to corrupt the public morals or outrages public decency. 
(Ord. 1697 (part), 1993). 
9.56.030 - Unlawful lodging. 
    No person shall, within the city, occupy, for lodging or other purpose, any barn, shed, shop or place other than such kept for that purpose, without consent of the owner, or party entitled to the possession thereof. 
(Ord. 1697 (part), 1993). 
9.56.040 - Unlawful assemblage. 
(a)  It is unlawful for three or more persons to assemble together with intent to do an unlawful act, separately or in concert, with force or violence against any property of the city, or against any person or his private property; to act in such a manner as to cause fear or terror to any person, to make any movement, preparation or demonstration against the peace of the city or against the peace or property of any citizen thereof; for any person present at any such meeting or assembly, by his presence or otherwise, to aid, abet, assist, encourage or countenance the commission of any unlawful act, movement, preparation or demonstration. 
(b)  No person shall aid, countenance or assist in making any noise, disturbance or improper diversion in or about any street, alley, avenue or public place or grounds; nor shall any person remain with, abet, encourage or countenance any unlawful assembly or crowd of persons collected together to the annoyance of any person, or to the obstruction of the passage over any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks, public places or grounds within the city. 
(Ord. 1697 (part), 1993). 
9.56.050 - Failure to appear in court. 
    Any person arrested for a violation of a municipal ordinance and who is released from custody after giving a written promise to appear in court at a time and place specified, and who violates his written promise to appear, shall be punished, and upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. 1697 (part), 1993). 
9.56.060 - Penalty for violation. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided, any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this title shall be punished, and upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. 1697 (part), 1993). 
Chapter 9.58 - NUISANCES[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ords. 965 and 1453. 

9.58.010 - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to provide a just, equitable and practicable method, to be cumulative with and in addition to any other remedy provided by city ordinances or otherwise available at law, whereby a public nuisance located on any premises or public property which from any cause endangers the life, limb, health, morals, property, safety or welfare of the general public or which tends to lower the value of adjacent real property because of its unsightliness may be required to be repaired, removed or abated. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter certain terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall be construed as specified in either this chapter, the municipal code or as specified in the ICC codes as adopted in ordinance 18.12.010. Where terms are not defined, they shall have their ordinary accepted meanings, within the context with which they are used. Words in the singular include the plural and the plural the singular. Words used in the masculine gender include the feminine and the feminine the masculine. Where the definitions imposed by any provision of this chapter are more restrictive than comparable definitions imposed by any other law, ordinance, statute, resolution, or regulation of any kind, the definitions that are more restrictive or impose a higher standard or requirements shall prevail. 
(1)  "Appliance" means any household or office device operated by gas or electrical current which would include but not limited to stoves, refrigerators, washing machines and dryers. 
(2)  "Board of appeal" means, the board of commissioners of the city of Huron, South Dakota. 
(3)  "Building official" as used in this article shall be construed to mean the city health inspector, the fire inspector, the building inspector, their respective authorized representatives, or any other city official authorized by the legislative body of this jurisdiction with the enforcement of this code. 
(4)  "Litter" as used in this chapter means any discarded, used or contaminated substance or waste. "Litter" may include, but is not limited to, any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish, grass clippings or other lawn or garden waste, newspapers, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper containers or other packaging construction material, abandoned motor vehicles, motor vehicle parts, tires, salvage materials, furniture, oil, carcasses of dead animals, any nauseous or offensive matter of any kind, any object likely to injure any person or create a traffic hazard, dead trees, dead tree branches, construction materials, or anything else of any unsightly or unsanitary nature, which has been discarded, abandoned or otherwise disposed of improperly. 
(5)  "Premises" is a lot or parcel of land, improved or unimproved, parking areas thereon, walkways, sidewalks. 
(Ord. 1830, 1998; Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
(Ord. No. 2057, 3-16-2009) 
9.58.030 - Nuisance defined. 
    A nuisance consists in unlawfully doing an act, or omitting to perform a duty, which act or omission either: 
(1)  Annoys, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; 
(2)  Offends decency; 
(3)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs, or tends to obstruct, or renders dangerous for passage, any lake or navigable river, bay, stream, canal or basin, or any public park, square, street or highway; 
(4)  In any way renders other persons insecure in life, or in the use of property. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.040 - Enumeration of conditions constituting nuisance. 
(a)  It is declared that one or more of the following conditions either alone or in combination with others, which at the same time affects an entire community or neighborhood, or a considerable number of persons, although the extent of annoyance or damage inflicted upon the individuals may be unequal, constitutes a public nuisance, however this enumeration shall be deemed exclusive: 
(1)  The keeping of premises at variance with the zoning laws applicable to the premises; 
(2)  The interference, obstructing or rendering dangerous for passage, any lake, or navigable river, bay, stream, public park, street, alley, city parking lot or highway; 
(3)  The abandonment, leaving or placing on any street, alley or public place any property of any kind; 
(4)  Broken windows, doors, attic vents and underfloor vents; 
(5)  Allowing the exterior building coverings to deteriorate as to encourage decay, dry rot, warping and cracking; 
(6)  Any malfunctioning, leaking, unclean or filthy sink, water closet, urinal or other plumbing fixture in any building open for public use; 
(7)  Any sign or sign structure that is dismantled, partially dismantled, defective, broken, deteriorated, in disrepair, or defaced; 
(8)  The accumulation of dead animals, animal matter or waste of any kind, dead, decayed, diseased trees, and other vegetation; 
(9)  Failure to store in a covered metal container or throwing or letting fall on or permit to remain on any street, alley or public ground any manure, garbage, rubbish, filth, fuel, small dead animals, wood or like material; 
(10)  Allowing the movement by natural elements, or the accumulation, or discarding, or throwing of litter, which would include but not be limited to: trash, refuse, debris, newspapers, magazines, glass, plastic containers, or styrofoam containers; 
(11)  Depositing, maintaining or permitting to be maintained or be accumulated upon any public or private property any combustible refuse matter such as papers, sweepings, rags, grass, tree branches, wood shavings, wood, magazines, cardboard, etc.; 
(12)  The accumulation of junk and/or litter maintained upon any premises; 
(13)  Undressed hides kept longer than twenty-four hours, except at the place where they are to be manufactured, or in a storeroom or basement whose construction is approved by the health department; 
(14)  To place, leave, dump or permit the accumulation of manure, garbage or anything whatever which harbors or favors the multiplication of flies, insects or rodents; 
(15)  Abandoned, discarded or unused furniture, appliances, sinks, toilets, cabinets or other household fixtures or equipment; 
(16)  Any unused refrigerator, ice box, or refrigerating unit, without the doors thereof removed; 
(17)  Parking or permitting a livestock truck or trailer to remain on any street, area or public ground in a residential district when such truck or trailer gives off an offensive odor or is contaminated with manure or other filth; 
(18)  The accumulation of lumber, boxes, barrels, bricks, stones or any other material unless placed on open racks that are elevated not less than eight inches above ground, and evenly piled or stacked so that such material will not afford harborage for rodents; 
(19)  Accumulation of junk, old iron, or parts of motor vehicles, campers, trailers, tractors or other like property; 
(20)  Any excavation or depression in which stagnant water is permitted to collect or allow for the multiplication of insects; 
(21)  Maintaining upon such premises or upon the sidewalk abutting or adjoining such lot, parcel, tract or piece of land, loose earth, mounds of soil, fill material, asphalt, concrete rubble or waste material of any kind (all such materials shall hereinafter be referred to as "waste materials"), except for waste materials used for construction or landscaping upon premises in which case it shall be the duty of the owner, lessee, occupant or persons in possession of premises wherein waste materials exist, to maintain weed control during construction and to level or remove waste materials after construction is completed, or in any event, within eight months from time of placement of waste materials upon premises. 
(b)  For sites where filling, grading or excavation activities have or will span more than one year, it shall be the duty of the owner, lessees, occupant or person in possession of said premises to level or remove the waste materials from said premises at least once each year during the months of either June, July or August for the purpose of maintaining weed and rodent control. 
(Ord. 1991, 2005; Ord. 1783, 1996: Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.050 - Maintenance of conditions constituting nuisance. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation owning, leasing, occupying, or having charge or possession of or part of any premises in the city to create, keep, maintain or permit a public nuisance. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to create, keep, or maintain a public nuisance upon any public property or body of water within the city limits. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.060 - Littering prohibited. 
    No person shall dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard, leave, cause or permit dumping, depositing, throwing, discarding or leaving of litter upon any public or private property in the city or upon any body of water in the city unless: 
(1)  The property has been designated by the city or state for the disposal of litter; or 
(2)  The litter is placed in a receptacle or other container intended by the owner or tenant in lawful possession of that property for the deposit of litter. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.061 - Unauthorized deposit of litter in receptacle. 
    No person shall deposit, dump, drop, discard or leave any litter in any receptacle or other container intended for the deposit of litter, wherever located, without the consent of the owner or person in lawful possession of that receptacle container. 
(Ord. 1773, 1996). 
9.58.070 - Right of entry. 
    Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this chapter, or whenever the building official or her or his authorized representative has reasonable cause to believe that there exists upon any premises any condition which is prohibited under this chapter, the building official or her or his authorized representative may enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon the building official by this chapter; provided that if such premises be occupied, she or he shall first present proper credentials and request entry; and if such building or premises be unoccupied, he or she shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of the premises and request entry. If such entry is refused, the building official or his or her authorized representative shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry including but not limited to the securing of a search warrant. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.080 - Remedies against nuisances. 
    The city has the following remedies against nuisances: 
(1)  Civil action, abatement, or issue a uniform citation/notice to abate and summons for violation of municipal ordinance; 
(2)  The costs of which may be assessed as prescribed by this chapter or state law. 
(Ord. 2004 (part), 2005: Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.090 - Notice to abate-Issuance. 
(a)  Whenever the building inspector or code enforcement officer becomes aware of and upon inspection thereof that any condition or conditions prohibited in this chapter has been created or exist on any premises located within the city, the building inspector or the code enforcement officer may give or cause to be given a uniform citation/notice to abate and summons to the occupant, person in charge or owner of the property requiring the person to abate the unlawful condition or conditions existing on the premises within a specified time frame and commanding the person to be in magistrate court for violation of the nuisance ordinance, if the nuisance is not abated within the time specified. 
(b)  Service of such notice may be accomplished by personally delivering the notice upon either the occupant, person in charge or owner of any lot. 
(c)  If the building official has determined that a condition or conditions have been created or exist in violation of city code, the building inspector or code enforcement officer shall require that all permits be secured, therefor and the work physically commenced within such time and completed within such time as the building inspector or code enforcement officer shall determine is reasonable under all of the circumstances. 
(Ord. 2004 (part), 2005: Ord. 1913, 2001; Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.100 - When notice waived. 
    Whenever the person responsible for the creation of, or the owner occupant or agent of, any premises in or upon which any nuisance may be found is unknown or cannot be found, the building official may proceed to abate the nuisance without notice. In either case, the expense of such abatement shall be collected from the person who may have created, caused or suffered such nuisance to exist. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.110 - Abatement by city. 
(a)  In the event a person shall fail to abate any nuisance created, permitted or maintained by him following written notice to him to do so, the building official may cause such nuisance to be abated. The cost may be charged against the owner of the personal property abated or the owner of the real estate upon which the nuisance was located. 
(b)  The building official may prepare a statement of the expense incurred in the razing, demolishing, removing, reconstruction or other affirmative act necessary to abate the unlawful condition(s) and shall file such statement with the city finance officer. Such statement shall refer to the particular premises including any improvements, structures or buildings thereon, upon which the actions taken to abate the unlawful conditions occurred. With regard to the premises or each piece of property therein referred to, the statement shall show the number of the lot and block and the name of the addition in which the lot lies or upon which the structures, improvements or buildings were located at the time that the actions to abate the unlawful conditions were taken or shall describe such premises in any other way that they may be easily identified. 
(c)  "Expense incurred" shall be defined as the actual expense incurred to abate the unlawful condition(s) plus a graduated noncompliance fee calculated over the calendar year as follows: 
    First violation abated: fifty-dollar noncompliance fee; 
    Second violation abated: one hundred-dollar noncompliance fee; 
    Third violation abated: one hundred fifty-dollar noncompliance fee; 
    Fourth violation abated: two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee. 
(d)  Any subsequent violations abated by the city within the current calendar year, to be defined for the purposes of this chapter as the twelve-month period starting January 1st and ending December 31st, shall be billed at the two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee rate. The graduated noncompliance fee rate schedule shall apply to any and all violations abated by the city of Huron as allowed in Chapters 9.58, 9.62, 9.64, 11.16 and 15.24 of this code; and all shall be cumulative in calculation of the noncompliance fee. This graduated fee schedule shall become effective on January 1, 2005; shall apply to an individual address, lot, or parcel of real property; and shall be calculated by calendar year except in the case of transfer of ownership. However, the cumulative calculation of the noncompliance fee shall continue in the case of transfers of ownership between immediate family members. ("Immediate family" is defined for the purposes of this chapter as: spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandparent, grandchild, in-law, ward/guardian or cohabiting adult.) 
(Ord. 1981 (part), 2004: Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.120 - Right of appeal from building official's determination. 
    The owner or any person affected shall have the right of appeal to the board of appeals for investigation and review of the building official's determination. Such appeal shall be in writing, shall state the objections of the person filing the same, shall be filed with the municipal finance officer within the ten days after the date of posting, publishing, serving or mailing of notice to abate, and shall be presented to the board of appeals by the building official at its next regular meeting. The board of appeals shall determine by resolution whether the building official shall proceed in accordance with the abatement notice, or as modified by the board, or not at all, and its decision thereon shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.130 - Notice to property owner of costs. 
    Within thirty days after the filing of the statement referred to in Section 9.58.110, the city finance officer shall cause a statement of the costs of the abatement to be served upon the owner, agent of the owner, lessee, occupant or person in possession of the parcel of land on which the nuisance was abated. Such notice may be given personally or by first class mail addressed to the last known address of the owner as shown on the director of equalization's records. Notice shall be further given that if the costs are not paid upon receipt of the statement the city may levy the costs as a special assessment against the property. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.140 - Recovery of expense-Special assessment. 
    The city may recover the expenses incurred by the building official in abating a public nuisance by taxing the cost thereof by special assessment against the real property on which the nuisance occurred, as authorized by state law. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.150 - Preparation of assessment roll-Public hearing. 
(a)  On a quarterly basis the finance officer shall prepare an assessment roll containing all costs of abating nuisances, that the city elects to recover through the special assessment process. Upon completion of the assessment roll, the finance officer shall file such assessment roll with the governing board. After approval by the governing board, they shall set a public hearing date on the assessment roll. The public hearing date shall be no sooner than twenty days from the date of the meeting at which the public hearing date was set. 
(b)  Thereupon the finance officer shall cause a notice of the time and place of hearing to be published in the official newspaper for two successive weeks prior to the date set for such hearing, which notice shall in general terms describe the purpose for which the special assessment is levied, the day of the filing of the assessment roll, the time and place of the hearing thereon, and that the assessment roll will be open for public inspection at the office of the finance officer. 
(c)  In addition to the publication of such notice of public hearing, the finance officer shall mail a copy of the notice, by first class certified mail addressed to the owner or owners of any property to be assessed for abatement costs at his or her address as shown by the records of the director of equalization and that such mailing shall be at least one week prior to the date set for such hearing. 
(d)  At the time and place fixed for such hearing, the governing board shall meet to consider the assessment roll and hear any objections thereto. Upon such hearing it may approve, amend, or reject the same. 
(Ord. 1949, 2002; Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.160 - Recovery of expense-Civil suit. 
    The city may recover the expenses incurred by the building official in abating any nuisance under the provisions of this chapter from the person creating, permitting or maintaining the same, or the person owning the real estate in a civil suit instituted for such purpose. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.170 - Keeping of articles or property which have been declared to be a public nuisance. 
    The building official or the police department may take possession of any article or property for reasons of abating a public nuisance. If the same is believed to have any value, he shall keep it and make an attempt to find the owner thereof, and retain any such article heretofore so taken up by it. It shall be the duty of said departments to maintain a place for the keeping of any such article until the same shall be claimed or otherwise disposed of and the city shall have a lien thereon for the reasonable expenses incurred and value or cost of the time and effort necessary in taking, removing and storing such article, and for the value of the storage in keeping thereof, and may retain possession until any and all such liens are discharged. 
(Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.180 - Destruction or sale of property declared a public nuisance. 
    Any article or property taken severally, or in congregate, by the city for reasons of abating a public nuisance may be destroyed or sold pursuant to law as city surplus property, as determined by the city commission, if the owner thereof does not fully pay the city for its aggregate lien expenses incurred for the removal and storage of said article(s) and property(ies) before the expiration of thirty days from the taking of same. 
(Ord. 1837, 1999: Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
9.58.190 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130, and each and every day that the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1698, 1993: Ord. 1576 (part), 1988). 
Chapter 9.60 - RESERVED 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2073, adopted March 29, 2010, deleted Ch. 9.60, §§ 9.60.010-9.60.060, which pertained to shoplifting and derived from Ord. No. 1109 (part), adopted 1974; Ord. No. 1354, adopted 1979 and Ord. No. 1699, adopted 1993. 
Chapter 9.62 - ABANDONED, WRECKED, DISMANTLED OR INOPERATIVE MOTOR VEHICLES[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ords. 1195, 1232, 1571 and 1577. 

9.62.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein: 
(1)  "Abandoned motor vehicle" means any motor vehicle, as defined in this section, which is left unattended on any public street, alley, public place or parking lot within the city for a longer period than twenty-four hours without notifying the chief of police and making arrangements for the parking of such motor vehicle. 
(2)  "Antique/collectible vehicle" means any motor vehicle having special value because of its age or characteristics and does not meet the junked motor vehicle definition. 
(3)  "City" means the city of Huron. 
(4)  "Inoperable vehicle" means any motor vehicle, as herein defined, which has not physically moved twenty-five feet in a seven-month period or which is not in operating condition due to damage or removal or inoperability of one or more tires and wheels, damage or removal or inoperability of the engine or other essential parts required for the operation of the vehicle, or which does not have lawfully affixed thereto a valid state license plate or which constitutes an immediate health, safety, fire or traffic hazard. 
(5)  "Junked motor vehicle" means any motor vehicle which does not have lawfully affixed thereto a valid state license plate or plates, or the condition of which is wrecked, dismantled, partially dismantled, inoperable or discarded. 
(6)  "Motor vehicle" means any vehicle which is designed to travel along, or on the ground or water and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses, motorbikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golfcarts, campers, trailers, boats and farm equipment. 
(7)  "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(8)  "Private property" means any real property within the city which is privately owned and which is not public property as defined in this section. 
(9)  "Public property" means any street, alley or highway, or boulevard which shall include the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained for the purposes of vehicular travel, and also means any other publicly owned property or facility. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.020 - Storing, parking or leaving abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked or partially dismantled motor vehicles declared nuisance-Exceptions. 
    The presence of an abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked or partially dismantled motor vehicle or parts thereof on private or public property is a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. This section shall not apply to any motor vehicle fully enclosed within a building on private property or to any motor vehicle held in connection with a business enterprise, lawfully licensed by the city and properly operated in the appropriate business zone, pursuant to the zoning laws of the city. A motor vehicle in operable condition, although not legally licensed, specifically adopted or designed for operation on drag strips or raceways, may be kept on private property if kept in a fully enclosed structure during nonracing seasons. 
(Ord. 1841 (part), 1999: Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.030 - Storing, parking or leaving dismantled or other such motor vehicles on public property prohibited. 
    No person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked or partially dismantled motor vehicle of any kind, whether attended or not, upon any public property or right-of-way within the city. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.040 - Removal. 
    Whenever any police officer finds an abandoned motor vehicle or an unattended motor vehicle which is in a wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked or partially dismantled condition on public property within the city, he is authorized to provide for the removal of such motor vehicle to a garage or place of safety. A motor vehicle which causes an obstruction and hazard to traffic may be removed at any time under the direction of the police department. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.050 - Notice to owner. 
    It is the duty of the police department to notify, by certified mail, the registered owner, if known and if encumbered, the lien holder, of the removal and storage of any motor vehicle under the provisions of this chapter and where such motor vehicle has been stored. If the owner or his or her address is unknown, a notice of removal and storage shall be given by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county. If the owner, for whatever reason, is not contacted after reasonable efforts have been made to contact him or her, a notice of removal and storage shall be given by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county. 
(Ord. 2039 (part), 2007: Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.060 - Sale of unclaimed motor vehicle. 
    If, after thirty days from the initial date of mailing or publishing the notice of removal and storage provided for by this chapter, the motor vehicle shall remain unclaimed, such motor vehicle may be sold by the police department at public auction upon notice to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county not less than once a week for two consecutive weeks. 
(Ord. 2039 (part), 2007: Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.070 - Notice of sale. 
    The notice of sale provided for by this chapter shall contain a description of the removed and stored motor vehicle, including the year, make, model, serial number, color, license number, if any; a statement that the motor vehicle was found abandoned, the date thereof; and the place, date and time at which such motor vehicle shall be sold, which date shall not be sooner than one week following the date of the last publication of notice. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.080 - Lien for costs. 
(a)  The police department shall have a possessory lien upon any motor vehicle removed under the provisions of this chapter for the costs in taking custody of and storing such motor vehicle plus a graduated noncompliance fee calculated over the calendar year as follows: 
First violation abated: fifty-dollar noncompliance fee; 
Second violation abated: one hundred-dollar noncompliance fee; 
Third violation abated: one hundred fifty-dollar noncompliance fee; 
Fourth violation abated: two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee. 
(b)  The city will abate nuisance vehicles singly or in groups if the vehicles are located on a lot or adjacent lots under single ownership. The compliance fee shall be paid each time that the city must abate a single vehicle or a group of vehicles if the group can be dealt with as a single entity. Each successive time that the city must return to the property to abate a single vehicle or group of vehicles, during the current calendar year, the graduated noncompliance fee schedule shall apply. 
(c)  Any subsequent violations abated by the city within the current calendar year, to be defined for the purposes of this chapter as the twelve-month period starting January 1st and ending December 31st, shall be billed at the two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee rate. The graduated noncompliance fee rate schedule shall apply to any and all violations abated by the city of Huron as allowed in Chapters 9.58, 9.62, 9.64, 11.16 and 15.24 of this code; and all shall be cumulative in calculation of the noncompliance fee. This graduated fee schedule shall become effective on January 1, 2005; shall apply to an individual address, lot, or parcel of real property; and shall be calculated by calendar year except in the case of transfer of ownership. However, the cumulative calculation of the noncompliance fee shall continue in the case of transfers of ownership between immediate family members. ("Immediate family" is defined for the purposes of this chapter as: spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandparent, grandchild, in-law, ward/guardian or cohabiting adult.) 
(d)  Right to appeal from building official's determination shall be available as specified in Section 9.58.120 of this code. 
(Ord. 1981 (part), 2004: Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.090 - Title may vest in the city-When. 
    If, after thirty days from the initial date of mailing or publishing the notice of removal and storage provided for by this chapter, the motor vehicle shall remain unclaimed, the title to such motor vehicle shall be vested in the city and such motor vehicle may be utilized or disposed of in any manner as may be provided by the city commission. The proceeds of any such disposal shall first be applied to the costs incurred in the enforcement of this chapter with the balance to be deposited to the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. 2039 (part), 2007: Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.100 - Duty of private property owners. 
    No person owning, in charge of or in control of any real property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, shall allow any abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked or partially dismantled motor vehicle of any kind to remain on such property longer than ten days. 
(Ord. 1841 (part), 1999: Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.110 - Notice to remove. 
    Whenever it comes to the attention of the police department that any person has an abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked or partially dismantled motor vehicle on his property, a notice in writing shall be served upon such person requesting the removal of such motor vehicle in the time specified in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.120 - Responsibility for removal. 
    Upon proper notice, the owner of the abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked or partially dismantled motor vehicle and the owner or occupant of the private property on which the same is located, either or all of them, shall be responsible for its removal. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.130 - Notice procedure. 
    The police department shall give notice of removal to the owner or occupant of the private property where it is located. It shall constitute sufficient notice when a copy of same is sent by certified mail or personally delivered to the owner or occupant of the private property at his last known address. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.140 - Content of notice. 
    The notice shall contain the request for removal within fourteen days after the mailing of such notice, and the notice shall advise that failure to comply with the notice to remove shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.150 - Alternative abatement procedure, recovery of expenses and storage. 
    The public nuisance defined in Section 9.62.020 may be abated and costs charged and or assessed as prescribed in Chapter 9.58 of the municipal code. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
9.62.155 - Destruction or sale of motor vehicle declared a public nuisance. 
    Any motor vehicle taken by the city for reasons of abating a public nuisance may be destroyed or sold pursuant to law as city surplus property, as determined by the city commission, if the owner thereof does not fully pay the city for its aggregate expenses incurred for the removal, towing and storage of said motor vehicle before the expiration of thirty days from its taking. 
(Ord. 1838, 1999). 
9.62.160 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a municipal ordinance violation punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars or by imprisonment not to exceed thirty days or by both such fine and imprisonment, and each and every day that the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1686 (part), 1993). 
Chapter 9.64 - NUISANCE VEGETATION 

9.64.010 - Certain weeds and plants declared nuisances. 
    The following named weeds and plants shall be deemed dangerous and unhealthy and are declared to be nuisances: ragweed, pusley, pigweed, nettle, thistle of any kind, sunflower, goldenrod, tumbleweed, burdock, cocklebur, sandbur, wild oats, sticktight, milkweed, mustard and any and all other variety of weeds and vegetation deemed to be noxious, obnoxious, dangerous and unhealthy or deemed to be a nuisance by the building official and all other weeds and grasses growing upon any lot or parcel of land in the city to a greater height than eight inches or which have gone or are about to go to seed. 
(Ord. 2053, 2008: Ord. 1784 (part), 1996). 
9.64.020 - Duty to correct. 
    It shall be the duty of the occupant, person in charge, or owner of any lot or parcel of land in the city to keep such lot, to include any abutting city right-of-way, commonly known as the city boulevard, free of such nuisance vegetation by cutting, spraying or removal, as may be appropriate. 
(Ord. 1784 (part), 1996). 
9.64.030 - Public notice to correct. 
(a)  The building official or his authorized representative during the month of May shall by general public notice require all nuisance vegetation to be cut, removed or sprayed as required by this chapter. 
(b)  Such public notice shall be given generally by publication in the official newspaper once a week for two consecutive weeks. 
(c)  The notice shall provide that during the growing season every occupant, person in charge or owner of any lot who fails to cut, remove or spray nuisance vegetation is in violation of this chapter, and shall further provide that in case of failure to cut or destroy such vegetation the city will cause the same to be cut and assess the costs thereof including the costs of levying such special assessment against the property benefitted. 
(Ord. 1784 (part), 1996). 
9.64.040 - Personal notice to correct. 
(a)  Any occupant, person in charge or owner of any lot in violation of this chapter shall receive written notice from the building official or his authorized representative of such violation. 
(b)  The occupant, person in charge or owner shall within forty-eight hours after service of such notice cut, remove or spray as required all nuisance vegetation. 
(c)  The notice shall provide that the occupant, person in charge or owner of any lot shall cut, remove or spray the nuisance vegetation within forty-eight hours after service of such notice, and shall further provide that in case of failure to cut or destroy such nuisance vegetation the city will cause the same to be cut and assess the costs thereof including the costs of levying such special assessment against the property benefitted. 
(d)  Service of such notice may be accomplished by personally delivering the notice upon either the occupant, person in charge or owner of any lot. Personal service upon any one occupant, person in charge or owner of any lot shall constitute service upon all. Service of such notice may also be accomplished by securely posting the notice in a conspicuous place on the affected premises. 
(Ord. 1784 (part), 1996). 
9.64.050 - Abatement by city. 
(a)  In the event the occupant, person in charge, or owner of any lot or parcel of land fails to correct any such vegetation nuisance as required, the building official or his respective representative shall cause such nuisance vegetation to be cut, sprayed or destroyed and for such purpose may enter upon any such lot or parcel of land. 
(b)  The city may contract with private persons or concerns to accomplish the removal of the nuisance vegetation as required by this chapter. 
(c)  It is a public offense for any person to intentionally interfere or attempt to interfere with the cutting, spraying or removal of such nuisance vegetation by physical force, violence, threat of violence or physical intimidation. 
(d)  The building official or his respective representative may prepare a statement of costs incurred against each lot or parcel of land for the abatement of such nuisance vegetation and shall file such statement with the city finance officer on or before November 1st of each year. "Cost incurred" shall be defined as the actual expenses incurred for abatement of the vegetation nuisance plus a graduated noncompliance fee calculated over the calendar year as follows: 
First violation abated: fifty dollar-noncompliance fee; 
Second violation abated: one hundred-dollar noncompliance fee; 
Third violation abated: one hundred fifty-dollar noncompliance fee; 
Fourth violation abated: two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee. 
(e)  Any subsequent violations abated by the city within the current calendar year, to be defined for the purposes of this chapter as the twelve-month period starting January 1st and ending December 31st, shall be billed at the two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee rate. The graduated noncompliance fee rate schedule shall apply to any and all violations abated by the city of Huron as allowed in Chapters 9.58, 9.62, 9.64, 11.16 and 15.24 of this code; and all shall be cumulative in calculation of the noncompliance fee. This graduated fee schedule shall become effective on January 1, 2005; shall apply to an individual address, lot, or parcel of real property; and shall be calculated by calendar year except in the case of transfer of ownership. However, the cumulative calculation of the noncompliance fee shall continue in the case of transfers of ownership between immediate family members. ("Immediate family" is defined for the purposes of this chapter as: spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandparent, grandchild, in-law, ward/guardian or cohabiting adult.) 
(f)  Right to appeal from building official's determination shall be available as specified in Section 9.58.120 of this code. 
(Ord. 1981 (part), 2004: Ord. 1912, 2001; Ord. 1784 (part), 1996). 
9.64.060 - Notice to property owner of costs. 
    Within thirty days after the filing of the statement referred to in Section 9.64.050(d), the city finance officer shall cause a statement of the costs of the abatement to be served upon the owner, agent of the owner, lessee, occupant or person in possession of the parcel of land on which the nuisance vegetation was abated. Such notice may be given personally or by the first class mail addressed to the last known address of the owner as shown on the director of equalization's records. Notice shall be further given that if the costs are not paid upon receipt of the statement the city may levy the costs as a special assessment against the property. 
(Ord. 1784 (part), 1996). 
9.64.070 - Recovery of costs-Special assessment. 
    The city may recover the costs incurred by the building official in abating nuisance vegetation by taxing the cost thereof by special assessment against the real property on which the nuisance occurred, as authorized by state law. 
(Ord. 1784 (part), 1996). 
9.64.080 - Preparation of assessment roll-Public hearing. 
(a)  Annually the finance officer shall prepare an assessment roll containing all costs of abating nuisance vegetation, that the city elects to recover through the special assessment process. Upon completion of the assessment roll the finance officer shall file the assessment roll with the governing board. After approval by the governing board they shall set a public hearing date on the assessment roll. The public hearing date shall be no sooner than twenty days from the date of the meeting at which the public hearing date was set. 
(b)  Thereupon the finance officer shall cause a notice of the time and place of hearing to be published in the official newspaper for two successive weeks prior to the date set for the hearing, which notice shall in general terms describe the purpose for which the special assessment is levied, the day of the filing of the assessment roll, the time and place of the hearing thereon, and that the assessment roll will be open for public inspection at the office of the finance officer. 
(c)  In addition to the publication of such notice of public hearing, the finance officer shall mail a copy of the notice, by first class certified mail addressed to the owner or owners of any property to be assessed for abatement costs at his or her address as shown by the records of the director of equalization and that such mailing shall be at least one week prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(d)  At the time and place fixed for such hearing, the governing board shall meet to consider the assessment roll and hear any objections thereto. Upon such hearing it may approve, amend or reject the same. 
(Ord. 1784 (part), 1996). 
9.64.090 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day that the violation continues, and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130, except for purposes of this chapter any such fine imposed thereunder shall not be less than one hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 1904, 2001: Ord. 1784 (part), 1996). 
Chapter 9.66 - NON-NUISANCE MOTOR VEHICLES ON RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY 

9.66.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter the following terms shall have the following definitions: 
A.  "Driveway" means the area on a residential property designed or used for moving or parking of vehicles. 
B.  "Residential property" means: 
1.  Any parcel zoned residential; 
2.  Any parcel primarily used as residential; 
3.  Any vacant parcel located directly adjacent to a residential parcel, as defined in subsections 1 and 2 above. 
C.  [Reserved.] 
D.  "Vehicle" means any device which is designed to travel along, or on the ground or water and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses, motorbikes, vans, motorhomes, pick-up trucks, motorcycles, motor scooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts, campers, trailers, boats and farm equipment. 
E.  "Vehicle unit" means as determined by the inspections department representative. 
1.  A single vehicle (examples, but are not limited to a: car, pick-up truck, van, trailer, etc.). 
2.  Combinations of units parked in such a manner as to take no more space and create no more of a visual impact than a single vehicle (examples, but not limited to: a loaded trailer or four motorcycles or three quads, etc.). 
F.  "Yard" means a required open space on a lot, which is unoccupied and unobstructed by a building from its lowest ground level to the sky except as expressly permitted in this title. A yard shall extend along a lot line and at right angles to such lot line to a depth or width specified in the yard regulations for the district in which such lot is located. A yard shall be measured from the lot line to the vertical wall of the principal structure of structures. 
1.  Yard - Front. "Front yard" means a yard extending along the full width of the front lot line between side lot lines and extending from abutting front street right-of-way line to a depth at its shallowest required in the yard regulations for the district in which such lot is located. 
2.  Yard - Rear. "Rear yard" means a yard extending along the full width of the rear lot line between the side lot lines and extending toward the front lot line for a depth as specified in the yard regulations for the district in which such lot is located. 
3.  Yard - Side. "Side yard" means a yard extending along the side lot line between the front and rear yards, having a width as specified in the yard regulations for the district in which such lot is located. 
(Ord. 2042 (part), 2008). 
9.66.020 - Vehicle parking on private residential property. 
    A maximum number of eight vehicle units may be parked on any residential property parcel, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter or required by code. 
(Ord. 2042 (part), 2008). 
9.66.030 - Vehicle parking limits-Exceptions. 
    Certain vehicles shall not be included in determining the maximum number of vehicle units parked on residential property parcels. 
A.  Vehicles stored inside of a fully enclosed structure such as a garage or shed. The enclosing structure must comply with all applicable building and zoning regulations. 
B.  Excess vehicle units as specified on an approved special parking permit. 
C.  Vehicle units parked on property within six blocks of the State Fairground during South Dakota State Fair. 
D.  Excess vehicles temporarily present on property as a result of a limited duration special occasion. In example, but not limited to: family reunions, weddings, funerals, holiday gatherings, anniversary celebrations, birthday celebrations, etc. 
(Ord. 2042 (part), 2008). 
9.66.040 - Vehicle parking on private residential property-Location. 
    Permitted parking of vehicles on private residential property shall be as follows: 
A.  DRIVEWAY. Parking on an established driveway on private property shall be permitted as long as no part to the vehicle extends over or otherwise interferes with the public use of the sidewalk. 
B.  REAR YARD. To the maximum extent possible, all other vehicle parking shall be confined to the rear yard (as defined in this chapter). 
C.  SIDE YARD. When there is no access to the rear yard or there is inadequate area available in the rear yard (an applicant's fence shall never be considered as denying access), exposed vehicle parking may be located on side yards. 
D.  FRONT YARD. Where access or area limitations preclude rear yard or side yard parking, a maximum of thirty percent of the front yard including driveway may be used for parking or a total of three vehicle units may be parked in the front yard whichever is greater. 
(Ord. 2042 (part), 2008). 
9.66.050 - Prohibited parking. 
    No vehicles shall be parked or stored in such a manner or location as to: 
A.  Present a potential fire hazard as determined by the Huron fire department chief administrator or his authorized representative. 
B.  Hinder police, fire, emergency services, municipal service providers, etc. in the performance of their authorized duties. 
C.  Violate any law or ordinance, including allowing a nuisance to exist on the property. 
(Ord. 2042 (part), 2008). 
9.66.060 - Special parking permit. 
    An owner or tenant of residential property may apply for a special parking permit authorizing the owner or tenant to park vehicles totaling more than eight vehicle units on their specific residential property parcel. Special parking permits shall remain in effect until revoked. 
A.  All applications for special parking permit shall be filed in the building inspections office on forms provided by the city. 
B.  Public notice shall be given of the request. A sign indicating that an application for a special parking permit has been filed shall be posted at the address listed on the application at least ten days prior decision date. 
C.  Requests for up to two excess units, require payment of a twenty-dollar-fee at the time of filing: 
1.  Request may be approved or denied by the building inspector or his or her designated official upon completion of an application and a ten-day public comment period. 
2.  The building inspector or his or her designated official may place conditions on the approval of any application. 
3.  Any person adversely affected by the decision of the building inspector shall have the right of appeal to the city commission. Such appeal shall be in writing, shall state the objections of the person filing the same, shall be filed with the municipal finance officer within the ten days after the date of the building inspector's decision. The city commission shall determine whether the building inspector's decision shall be upheld, modified or reversed. 
D.  Requests for three or more excess units, require payment of a fifty-dollar-fee at the time of filing: 
1.  Notices shall be sent by regular mail to owners of property within one hundred fifty feet of the address listed on the application; 
2.  Request must be approved or denied by the city commission following the ten-day public comment period; public comment may also be presented at the city commission meeting; 
3.  The building inspections office may recommend conditions on the approval or recommend denial of any application along with its submission to the city commission; 
4.  The city commission may place conditions on the approval of any application and shall decide regarding approval or denial. 
(Ord. 2042 (part), 2008). 
9.66.070 - Revocation of special parking permit-Cause. 
    Any special parking permit may be revoked for cause. Permits may, at any time, be revoked by the building inspections officer based on complaints of neighboring property owners, a report of noncompliance by the code enforcement officer or police department. Upon receipt of a public complaint the code enforcement officer shall investigate and determine the validity of the complaint and if there exists grounds for revocation, and if such grounds exist he or she shall provide that information to the building inspections officer who may revoke the permit. Grounds for revocation include the following: 
A.  Violation of any condition of approval; 
B.  Violation of any law or ordinance in connection with the parking permit; 
C.  Creation of any nuisance to the neighborhood; 
D.  The residential property is transferred to a new owner; 
E.  Receipt of a valid complaint through the city inspections department. 
(Ord. 2042 (part), 2008). 
9.66.080 - Effective date and enforcement. 
A.  The effective date of this chapter shall be May 1, 2008. 
B.  Upon receipt of a complaint from an affected neighboring property occupant/owner (within one hundred fifty feet excluding alley and street right-of-ways), the enforcement process shall proceed: 
1.  The property in question shall be inspected to determine the validity of the complaint; 
2.  If the complaint is valid, notice shall be given to the occupant (if occupied) or owner (if vacant) in the form of an order to correct or a citation; 
3.  A minimum fourteen-day grace period shall be allowed for correction; 
4.  After the specified grace period, formal action may be taken and the owner and/or tenant is subject to the penalties as set forth in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. 2042 (part), 2008). 
Title 10 - GOLF COURSES 
Chapter 10.02 - GOLF DEPARTMENT, COURSES and GOLF COURSE ADVISORY BOARD[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2121-10-6, adopted Jan. 7, 2013, amended Ch. 10.02 title to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 10.02 title pertained to golf course commission. 

10.02.010 - Municipal golf courses-Authorized. 
    The City of Huron shall establish, maintain and operate public golf courses as set forth in this Chapter. The City of Huron Golf Department shall have the responsibility of maintaining and operating all aspects of municipal public golf courses within the City of Huron. Operation of municipal golf courses means, but is not limited to, the maintenance of the golf courses, including driving range, and the maintenance of facilities such as club house/pro-shop and other buildings located at the golf courses, the sale of concessions, cart, club and related rentals, determination of membership fees and green fees, and all activities held at the golf courses. 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
10.02.015 - Municipal golf courses-Management. 
(a)  The Huron City Commission shall have ultimately supervisory authority and responsibility for the Golf Department and the establishment, maintenance and operation of public golf courses within the City of Huron. 
(b)  The Golf Department shall be under the direct supervision of the City Commissioner as designated by the City Commission. The City Commissioner designated as the Golf Commissioner, or the Golf Commissioner's designee, shall be the City's representative whenever the City has entered into a contract with an independent contractor directly related to the maintenance or operation of the municipal golf courses. 
(c)  The Golf Course Superintendent is responsible for the planning, directing and coordinating of activities concerned with the construction, maintenance, and operation of the City's golf courses and supervises and directs all activities of the City's golf courses. 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
10.02.020 - Golf course advisory board-Creation-Purpose. 
    There is hereby created a golf course advisory board for the purpose of assisting the Golf Department, Golf Course Superintendent, and Golf Department Commissioner in the operations of public golf courses of the city. 
(Ord. 1660 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2121-10-6, adopted Jan. 7, 2013, amended § 10.02.020 title to read as herein set out. Former § 10.02.020 title pertained to golf course commission-creation-purpose. 
10.02.040 - Golf course advisory board-Appointment-Terms. 
(a)  The board of city commissioners shall appoint five members to the golf course advisory board. 
(b)  At the first regular meeting of the city commission in May of each year, members shall be appointed or reappointed by the mayor and approved by the city commission for a term of three years, to succeed the retiring members. The members comprising the golf course advisory board shall not hold any elective office in the municipal government. 
(Ord. 1660 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2121-10-6, adopted Jan. 7, 2013, amended § 10.02.040 title to read as herein set out. Former § 10.02.0420 title pertained to golf course commission-appointment-terms. 
10.02.060 - Board compensation. 
    All members appointed to serve on the golf course advisory board shall serve without compensation except for expenses accrued due to authorized travel outside the city in fulfilling the obligations of their appointed duties. Allowances for travel expenses shall be at rates established by resolution of the city commission as provided by Section 3.02.018. 
(Ord. 1660 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
10.02.080 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2121-10-6, adopted Jan. 7, 2013, repealed § 10.02.080, which pertained to performance bond-oath and derived from Ord. No. 1660 (part), adopted 1992. 
10.02.100 - Election of golf course advisory board officers. 
    The golf course advisory board shall elect from its number a president, a vice-president and a secretary, each of whom shall serve for a term of one year or until his successor is elected and qualified. The vice-president shall act in the absence or disability of the president. In case of death or retirement of an officer, a successor shall be elected immediately. 
(Ord. 1660 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013)

10.02.120 - Golf course advisory board-Responsibilities and powers. 
    The golf course advisory board shall make recommendations related to golf course facility, golf course improvements and operation of golf courses within the City of Huron. The recommendations shall be given to the City Commissioner having supervision responsibilities over the municipal golf courses within the City of Huron. 
(Ord. 1660 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2121-10-6, adopted Jan. 7, 2013, amended § 10.02.120 title to read as herein set out. Former § 10.02.120 title pertained to golf course commission-responsibilities and powers. 
10.02.140 - Establishment of golf course operating fund. 
    There is hereby created an enterprise fund known as the golf course enterprise fund. This fund shall be operated as an enterprise fund of the purpose of meeting operational, maintenance and capital outlay expenses of the municipal golf courses. Revenue sources for the fund shall consist of: 
(a)  All income from user fees, and except as may be received by a vendor pursuant to a contract between the City and a vendor or an independent contractor, all other income resulting from golf course operations and activities; 
(b)  Such other sums of money provided by the city commission. 
(Ord. 1660 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
10.02.160 - Golf course superintendent to submit annual budget. 
    The golf course superintendent, with the assistance of the golf advisory board, shall prepare and submit the Golf Department's proposed annual budget for the ensuing fiscal year. The proposed budget shall show the estimated revenues in detail necessary to finance the proposed expenditure budget. The expenditure budget shall be detailed to show expenditures by function, activity and object as provided in the S.D. Municipal Accounting Manual. Such revenue and expenditure budgets shall be certified to the city finance office on or before the fifteenth day of June of each year. 
(Ord. 1660 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2121-10-6, adopted Jan. 7, 2013, amended § 10.02.160 title to read as herein set out. Former § 10.02.160 title pertained to golf course commission to submit annual budget. 
10.02.180 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2121-10-6, adopted Jan. 7, 2013, repealed § 10.02.180, which pertained to documents and requisition signed by golf course commission president or vice-president-countersigning of requisitions and derived from Ord. No. 1660 (part), adopted 1992. 
10.02.200 - Meetings of golf course advisory board-Quorum. 
    The golf course advisory board shall hold regular meetings at least once a month and as many special meetings as it may deem proper. Three members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. City Hall is designated as the principal place of business of the golf advisory board. 
(Ord. 1660 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013)

10.02.210 - Five-year plan. 
    The golf course superintendent, with the assistance of the golf course advisory board shall annually file an updated five-year business plan which provides for the total costs of operation of the municipal golf course facilities after initial development. 
(Ord. 1660 (part), 1992). 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2121-10-6, adopted Jan. 7, 2013, amended § 10.02.210 title to read as herein set out. Former § 10.02.210 title pertained to golf course commission reports to city commission-records subject to inspection. 
10.02.220 - Contracts and employees. 
    Except as may be limited by a contract between the City and an independent contractor or otherwise authorized pursuant to SDCL 9-1-5, the City Commission shall have the sole authority and responsibility for approving, executing and enforcing all golf department contracts and related documents. The City Commission shall be responsible for the hiring of golf department employees, and the Golf Superintendent shall be responsible for the scheduling and supervision of golf department employees. 
(Ord. No. 2121-10-6, 1-7-2013) 
Title 11 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Appointment of officers-See Ch. 2.08 of this code. 

Chapter 11.06 - CITY PARK AND RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ords. 987, 1161 and 1856. 

11.06.010 - Establishment of combined board. 
    There is created a combined city park and recreation board for the city to be known as the Huron park and recreation board, to establish, improve, care for, regulate and manage a system of public parks, parkways, and boulevards, and to operate a system of public recreation, playgrounds and parks in and for the city. For the purpose of this section, "recreation" shall mean all recreation activities except for golf courses. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.020 - Appointment of board members. 
    Term of Office. Upon the final adoption and publication of the ordinance codified herein, the mayor with the approval of the governing body shall forthwith appoint seven members to the city park and recreation board. One such member shall be appointed for the year, one for two years, one for three years, one for four years, one for five years, and there after each appointment shall be for five years. Such appointees are to hold office until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
(Ord. No. 2161-11-15, 6-1-2015) 
11.06.030 - Annual appointments. 
    At the first regular meeting of the board of commissioners in June of each year, one member shall be appointed or reappointed by the mayor and approved by the governing body for a term of five years. The members comprising the park and recreation board shall not hold any elective office in the municipal government. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.040 - Board compensation. 
    All members appointed to serve on the city park and recreation board shall serve without compensation except for expenses accrued due to authorized travel outside the city in fulfilling the obligations of their appointed duties, said expenses shall be reimbursed on the basis of actual proof of personal expenses accrued due to and during such travel authorized by the parks and recreation board. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.050 - Oath. 
    Each member of the board shall take oath of office required for appointive officers of the city. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.060 - Board vacancies. 
    Any vacancy on the city park and recreation board shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member vacating such board for any reason or purpose in the same manner as is required for a regular appointment and shall also qualify as provided in Section 11.06.030. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.070 - Election of officers. 
    At the first regular meeting of the park and recreation park board after the final adoption and publication of the ordinance codified herein, the board shall elect from its number a president, a vice president, and a secretary, each of whom shall serve until the first meeting of the board in June of each year. Thereafter, the board shall hold an annual election of officers at the first meeting in June of each year. The vice president shall act in the absence or disability of the president. In case of death, resignation or retirement of an officer, a successor shall be elected immediately. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.080 - Official meeting-Quorum. 
    The board shall hold regular meetings at least one each month and as many special meeting as it deems proper and necessary to conduct the official business affairs of the park and recreation department. Meetings of the parks and recreation board are subject to SDCL 1-25. Three members constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. An affirmative vote of at least three members shall be necessary to authorize any official action of the board. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.090 - Official records and reports. 
    The secretary of the board shall keep a record of its proceedings and make such reports as may be required by the board. In his absence, or inability to act, the board may appoint a secretary pro tem to perform his duties. The records of such board, kept by its secretary or copies of any such records when duly certified by the secretary shall be competent evidence of the proceedings of the board. Copies of any and all such records and/or reports shall be filed with the city finance officer. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.100 - Board rules and regulations. 
    The city park and recreation board, subject to the approval of the governing body, may establish bylaws, rules and regulations for the orderly transaction and conduct of its business and operation of the park and recreation department facilities. Any amendment to Title 11 desired by the board shall be requested by the resolution as outlined in Section 11.06.130. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.110 - Board authority and duties. 
(a)  The president, and in his absence or disability the vice-president, shall have authority to sign, execute and acknowledge in the name of the park and recreation board all contracts or documents as authorized by the park and recreation board and to carry out the normal business and functions of the city park and recreation department, and to sign requisitions upon the city finance officer for warrants and for funds under control of and to be expended by the park and recreation board. All such requisitions shall be countersigned by the secretary and, in his absence or disability, by some member of the board other than the president or vice president. All such warrants shall be drawn by the city finance office and signed by the mayor and city finance officer. Any warrants so drawn shall be recorded in the official financial ledgers of the city and drawn on the park and recreation cash funds. 
(b)  Except for contracts subject to public contracts awarded on competitive bids and subject to the approval of the city commission, the park and recreation board may authorize the director of the park and recreation department to enter into a contract on behalf of the municipality and to execute the contract and any other instrument necessary or convenient for the performance of the contract. 
(c)  The board shall establish, improve, care for, regulate, and manage a system of public parks, parkways, and boulevards and with the approval of the governing body acquire land therefor; regulate the planting and trimming of trees and shrubbery in parkings and park places upon any public street or boulevard; establish the channel of any stream or watercourse forming a part of the park system and improve the banks thereof; establish, maintain, and conduct with or without charge or to grant concessions for places of public amusement, recreation, or refreshment within or in connection with such parks; provided no lease or grant may be made for longer than three years and no professional shows or exhibitions for which an admission price is charged may be given in such parks; to park and boulevard the streets and to maintain the same and regulate the care thereof. However, a lease or grant to a concession may be made by the board for a period up to but not to exceed fifteen years if the concession requires a realty improvement investment of at least fifty thousand dollars or for a period up to but not to exceed fifty years if the concession requires a realty improvement investment of at least one hundred thousand dollars. The board may cause the cost of parking and boulevarding the streets and the maintenance thereof to be assessed against the abutting property as provided in SDCL 9-38-49 to 9-38-53, inclusive. 
(d)  The board may recommend to the governing board to have any road, parkway, boulevard, or street or part thereof, under its control and management, graded, regraded, paved, repaved, curbed, recurbed, guttered, reguttered, or otherwise improved, repaired, and maintained, including the construction, repair, and maintenance of bridges, retaining walls, viaducts, and sidewalks, and the planting of trees and shrubbery, in a manner and at such times and with such material as the board may determine and may pay for the work or improvements or any part thereof out of the funds not otherwise appropriated belonging to the park district in which the work or improvement is done or made. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.120 - Powers, limitations and immunities. 
    Except as may be limited within this chapter, the city park and recreation board shall have all of those powers and be subject to the limitations and enjoy those privileges and immunities all as provided for by Chapter 9-38 of the South Dakota Compiled Laws as now and hereafter amended. Whenever the prior approval of the governing board is required before the city park and recreation board can act, such prior approval shall be first obtained. Otherwise, the board shall be charged with the supervision and management of all city park and recreation facilities and functions. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.130 - Board regulations. 
    Any recommendation by the city park and recreation board to the governing body related to a proposed ordinance or amendment to an existing ordinance shall be by resolution of the park and recreation board. When any ordinance of the governing body is passed upon the recommendation of the park and recreation board, it is not necessary for such ordinance to recite at length the resolution of the park and recreation board recommending the same, but it is sufficient to recite the fact of such recommendation by such recreation board, which recital shall be conclusive of the making and regularity of such resolution in all proceedings thereafter. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.140 - Records open to inspection. 
    The park and recreation board shall make an annual report to the governing body of its acts and all its expenditures, showing the condition of all affairs under its control. The governing body may require a report from the park and recreation board at any time, and the records, books, papers, and accounts of the board, shall at all times be subject to inspection by the mayor, auditor, or any committee appointed by the governing body for that purpose or by any citizen. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.150 - Department employees. 
    The park and recreation board may recommend to the city commission the appointment of a director of the park and recreation department, who shall be the chief executive officer under the board and city commission of the park and recreation department and who shall not be an employee under civil service. He or she shall hold office at the pleasure of the city commission and receive such salary as the city commission may determine and shall on behalf of the city commission and board have charge, supervision, and direction of all activities and of all park and recreation department employees. Upon recommendation of the park and recreation board the city commission may appoint and employ other employees as it may deem necessary and shall prescribe and fix their duties and compensate in accordance with the provisions of Title 3 of the Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.160 - Bond for employees. 
    The park and recreation board may recommend to the city commission that park and recreation department director, recreation specialist and administrative assistant give bond for the faithful performance of their duties in such sum as shall be fixed by the city commission, which bonds shall be filed with the city finance officer. The city shall pay any premium for the bonds required to be given by members of the board or its officers or employees. All official bonds required under the provisions of this chapter shall be approved by the governing body. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.170 - City attorney's duties. 
    The city attorney as a part of his duties shall conduct all court proceedings under this chapter and shall be the legal adviser of the board. When in its judgment the interests of the city demand, the board may employ special counsel to assist the city attorney at the city attorney's request. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.180 - City finance officer duties. 
    The city finance officer shall keep in separate accounts all money received for the use of the park and recreation board and shall pay the same upon requisition by the president and secretary of the board and warrant drawn and executed as hereinbefore provided. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.190 - Acquisition of land. 
    Upon recommendation of the park and recreation board the governing body may purchase, condemn, or otherwise acquire land within or without the city limits as authorized by Chapter 9-38 of the South Dakota Compiled Laws for public parks, parkways, and boulevards, and establish the same. 
    Payment for any such land so selected and acquired may be made by cash, by purchase by installment payments with or without a mortgage, by entering into lease-purchase agreements, or by lease with option to purchase, out of the general fund, park fund, or by the issue and sale of bonds of the first or second class municipality after authorization as and in the manner provided by this title. No mortgage given hereunder shall provide as security property other than the specific land acquired pursuant to the provisions hereof. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.200 - Gifts, bequests and devises. 
    Real or personal property or the income thereof may be granted, bequeathed, devised or conveyed to the city for park or recreational purposes authorized by Chapter 9-38 of the South Dakota Compiled Laws and upon such conditions as may be prescribed by the grantors, donors, or devisors thereof and agreed to by the governing body and the park and recreation board. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.210 - Contracts. 
    Contracts subject to the bid laws pursuant to SDCL 5-18 incidental to the operation of a system of public parks, recreation and playgrounds for which special assessments are not to be levied shall be let by and awarded the park and recreation board subject to the provisions set forth in SDCL 5-18, provided that the funds for the project or acquisition are a specified line item within the department's budget as approved by the governing board and provided that the approval of the governing board is not required by state or federal grants or other requirements. All construction and improvement work shall be done under the control of the park and recreation board with engineering assistance and supervision from the city engineer. The park and recreation board shall inform the governing board at regularly scheduled commission meetings as to anticipated bid letting, the awarding of bids and progress on all bid projects. Nothing herein prohibits the park and recreation board from letting and awarding bids or obtaining quotes for materials, supplies, equipment and improvement when the cost thereof is less than the amount required for letting bids pursuant to SDCL 5-18. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.220 - Annual budget. 
    The park and recreation board on or before the fifteenth day of July of each year shall make an estimate of the moneys necessary for the operation of the city's system of public parks, recreation and necessary for the operation of the city's system of public parks, recreation and playgrounds and as authorized by Chapter 9-38 of the South Dakota Compiled Laws.
