Such estimate shall be certified by the secretary of the park and recreation board to the city finance officer on or before the first day of August of each year. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.230 - Appropriations and expenditures. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided, all sums used for the purpose of acquiring, equipping and maintaining land, buildings, parks or recreational facilities as authorized by Chapter 9-38 of the South Dakota Compiled Laws shall be paid out of the moneys received for the use of the park and recreation board and such moneys shall be appropriated from the general fund for the use of the park and recreation board and such moneys shall be appropriated and expended in the same manner as other money is appropriated and expended by the governing body. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
11.06.240 - Designation of park and recreation areas. 
    The maintenance and improvement of any land acquired by the park and recreation board for public parks and recreation and playground purposes shall be the responsibility of the board; and, when possible, public parks or designated areas thereof, in the city shall also be used for the operation of a system of public recreation and playgrounds. The designation of the use of any public park, or designated area thereof, for recreational purposes shall be designated by the park and recreation board, subject to review and approval by the governing body in the event of disagreement as to such use by any other factions. In order to facilitate the carrying out of the authorized purposes of the park and recreation board, it is required that the appointed director of the park and recreation department attend all regular and special meetings of the park and recreation board. 
(Ord. 2031 (part), 2007). 
Chapter 11.12 - PARK REGULATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities have jurisdiction for all authorized purposes over any public park belonging to the municipality-See SDC 45.0201(24). 
Cross reference- Health regulations generally-See Ch. 6.04 of this code; Traffic-See Title 16 of this code; Sign regulations generally-See Ch. 18.32 of this code; Boats and docks on James River-See Sec. 21.16.100 of this code. 

11.12.010 - Trespassing. 
    No person shall go on foot or otherwise on the grass or curb of any park or parkway when any prohibitory sign is posted. 
(Ord. 483 § 10.0201, 1950). 
11.12.020 - Destruction of park property prohibited. 
    No person shall injure or destroy any plant, shrub, or tree in any park or parkway in the city of Huron. 
(Ord. 483 § 10.0202, 1950). 
11.12.030 - Signs prohibited. 
    No person shall post, paste, paint or fix any placards, bills, notices, or signs upon any structure or thing within any park, or upon any part of any park or parkway. 
(Ord. 483 § 10.0203, 1950). 
11.12.040 - Exhibitions prohibited. 
    No entertainment, exhibition, or public speaking shall be given in any park or parkway, except those given under the direction and authority of the park board. 
(Ord. 483 § 10.0204, 1950). 
11.12.050 - Defacing property. 
    No person shall injure or deface any building or structure within any city park. 
(Ord. 483 § 10.0205, 1950). 
11.12.060 - Cleaning up litter and refuse after use of facilities. 
    Any person, or group of persons, using any picnic areas, playground centers, or recreational facility and equipment belonging to and located upon park premises, shall be responsible for cleaning up all litter and refuse caused by their occupancy before leaving the area. 
(Ord. 483 § 10.0206, 1950). 
11.12.080 - Metal containers, glass bottles, glass containers or glassware prohibited in swimming pool areas of public parks. 
    No metal containers, glass bottles, glass containers or glassware of any kind shall be taken by any person to any area of any public park that shall be designated by the park board as a swimming pool area. 
(Ord. 632, 1956: Ord. 483 § 10.0212, 1950). 
11.12.085 - Glass beverage containers prohibited from park and recreation areas. 
    No person shall have in his possession or control any glass beverage container in the following public areas in the city: Kunhart Field, Memorial Park, Memorial Ball Diamond, Ravine Lake Park, Riverside Park, Prospect Park, Crown Park, West Tower Park, Gibbs Park, Washington Field, Northside Memorial Playground, Winter Park and Campbell Park. 
(Ord. 1452, 1982). 
11.12.090 - Use of park waters. 
    No person shall bathe, wade or swim in any park in the city, except at such time and in such place as may be specifically designated by the park board. Notice of the time and place for the use of such waters shall be given by the park board by appropriate signs posted in one or more conspicuous places in the park or parks in which the waters are situated. The use of the waters situated in any park, except as permitted as to time and place by the park board, is hereby forbidden. Each and every violation of any of the provisions of this section shall be considered a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 483 § 10.0208, 1950). 
11.12.110 - Fishing season and catch limits. 
    The governing body shall in cooperation with the game and fish department of the state of South Dakota pass and publish resolutions from time to time fixing dates fishing shall be permitted in said lake and providing the number and kind of fish that may be caught, taken or killed by any person in any one day. 
(Ord. 483 § 10.0210, 1950). 
11.12.120 - Violation declared misdemeanor. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or any of the provisions of any resolution passed and published pursuant to this chapter, is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 483 § 10.021 1, 1950). 
11.12.130 - Park hours. 
    The park and recreation board may by resolution restrict the hours of public use of any park or parkway. Prohibitory signs shall be posted at any park or parkway for which public use hours are restricted. No person, other than a person with an overnight camping permit, shall go on foot or otherwise in any park or parkway other than those permitted by the park and recreation board resolution. 
(Ord. 1403, 1980). 
11.12.140 - Boating and recreational vehicles. 
    That part of Ravine Park Lake south of U.S. Highway 14 is closed to any and all fuel-driven motor boats and recreational vehicles. Exceptions to this section may be granted by the director of the parks and recreation department. 
(Ord. 1638, 1991). 
Chapter 11.16 - PLANTING IN BOULEVARDS AND PARKING STRIPS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Park boards have power to regulate the planting and trimming of trees and shrubbery in parkings and park places on any street or boulevard - See SDCL 9-38-24. 
Cross reference- Weeds-See Ch. 6.24 of this code; Streets and sidewalks-See Title 15 of this code. 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ord. 483 §§ 10.0301 - 10.0314, 15.0420; Ords. 485, 614 and 849. 

11.16.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following terms, phrases or words shall have the meaning given herein: 
(1)  "Parks and recreation director" means the director of parks and recreation of the city or a designated representative. 
(2)  "Parking strip" means the area along the public streets and avenues between the curbline and the sidewalk, or fifteen feet in from the curbline. 
(3)  "Public trees and shrubs" means all trees or shrubs planted or to be planted on any park, playground or other property owned or controlled by the city, or on any public street, alley, sidewalk, highway or parking strip, as defined in subsection (2) of this section, within the public right-of-way, but shall not include school sites. 
(4)  "Private property" means real property owned by any entity, except a municipal corporation, including parking strips. 
(5)  "Public property" means any real property owned by the city of Huron, South Dakota, a municipal corporation. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.020 - Purpose of control. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the city to regulate and control the planting, transplanting and protection of trees and shrubs in the city in order to eliminate and guard against dangerous conditions which may result in injury to persons using the streets, alleys, sidewalks or property of the city, to promote and enhance the beauty and general welfare of the city, to prevent damage to any public sewers, water main, street, sidewalk or other public property, and to protect trees and shrubs located in public areas from undesirable and unsafe planting, removal, treatment and maintenance practices. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.030 - Enforcement. 
    The parks and recreation board shall be responsible for the enforcement of this chapter, and it shall have the duty of carrying out all of the provisions of this chapter through the director of parks and recreation or other appointed employees designated for this purpose. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.040 - Interference prohibited. 
    No person shall prevent, delay or interfere with the parks and recreation board or its agents, employees or servants while they are engaged in carrying out any work or activities authorized by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.050 - General authority of board. 
    The parks and recreation board is directed and given the right to maintain any tree or shrub on any public property, boulevard or parking strip so as to preserve the function or beauty of such public property or parking strip in accordance with the art of good arboriculture. The board or its director shall have the authority to order any tree or shrub located on any property within the city to be cut, trimmed or removed by a property owner when in the opinion of the board or director, such order will alleviate any unsafe or illegal condition. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.060 - Authority to remove dead or diseased trees on private property-Order to correct. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall have the authority to order the owner of any private property to remove, at the expense of the property owner, any dead, diseased or insect infested tree, no less than ten days after personal service of an order to correct on the owner. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.070 - Tree branches to be trimmed and cut. 
    Except for streets identified in Section 11.16.075, no person, firm, corporation or any other owner of real property within the corporate limits of the city shall permit his tree limbs or branches to become a hazard and a nuisance to street maintenance and garbage disposal equipment by permitting tree branches to grow too close to the ground and/or overhang into the streets and alleys. Each owner, including the owner's property manager, and tenant shall be responsible for having tree limbs or branches of trees located upon his real property and upon the street and alley areas which are adjacent to his property, including the boulevard, trimmed to a minimum height of thirteen and one-half (131/2) feet above the street or alley level to allow ample space for the movement of city maintenance and garbage disposal equipment. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
(Ord. No. 2080, 6-7-2010; Ord. No. 2093, 2-14-2011) 
11.16.075 - State highways and truck routes. 
    The city shall trim all trees located on the boulevard/right of way of state highways and truck routes (i.e., Highway 37/Dakota Avenue, S.D. Highway 14, Lincoln Avenue from Hwy. 14 to 21st Street, 21st Street; West Park Avenue from Hwy. 14 to 3rd Street SE, and Custer Avenue) to a minimum height of fifteen feet over the adjacent street. It shall be the responsibility of the property owner, property manager or tenant to trim the balance of the tree to ensure compliance with Section 11.16.080. 
(Ord. No. 2080, 6-7-2010) 
11.16.080 - Clearance over sidewalks. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the property owner or persons occupying property adjacent to or on any parking strip, boulevard or sidewalk to keep all overhanging tree branches and limbs trimmed to a clearance of eight (8) feet above sidewalk level. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
(Ord. No. 2080, 6-7-2010; Ord. No. 2093, 2-14-2011) 
11.16.090 - Planting of trees-Widening of streets. 
    When trees are removed in preparation of widening of any established street, new trees can be planted providing that in the opinion of the director of parks and recreation there is adequate land in the parking strip to reasonably support tree growth. The director of parks and recreation shall determine the location of each tree to be planted, and the species and size. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.100 - Planting trees-New streets. 
    Following the installation of curbing and sidewalks or sidewalk locations, the director of parks and recreation will determine the species and size of stock to be used on the streets and decide on location of the trees. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.110 - Planting trees-Unimproved streets or other sites. 
    Should any owner of adjacent property desire to plant a tree on any parking strip or boulevard, a permit shall be obtained from the director of parks and recreation in which the species, size of the tree and location shall be designated, and that only trees and grass can be planted on the boulevard. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.120 - Permit and traffic control safety devices required. 
(a)  (1)  No person except an employee or agent of the city shall plant, transplant, or remove any tree or shrub located on the boulevard/right of way within the city without first obtaining from the director of parks and recreation a written permit for such work; 
(2)  Persons owning property adjacent to the boulevard/right of way or public utilities, or their respective agents, are not required to obtain the permit required pursuant to Section 11.16.120(a) to spray, brace, trim or prune any tree or shrub located on the boulevard/right of way. 
(b)  Any person planting, transplanting, moving, spraying, bracing, trimming, pruning, cutting above or below the ground, disturbing, altering or do surgery on any tree or shrub located on the boulevard/right of way and in a manner in which vehicular traffic may be impeded or endangered shall contact the traffic department prior to doing such work. The traffic department shall determine the date and time for such work and provide appropriate traffic control safety devices as may be necessary during the period of such work. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
(Ord. No. 2080, 6-7-2010) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2080, adopted June 7, 2010, amended § 11.16.120 title to read as herein set out. Former § 11.16.120 title pertained to permit required. 
11.16.130 - Issuance of permit. 
    If the director of parks and recreation determines that the proposed work or planting described in any application for a permit is necessary and in accord with the purposes of this chapter, taking into account the safety, health and welfare of the public location of utilities, public sidewalks, driveways and streetlights, general character of the area in which the tree or shrub is located or proposed to be located, type of soil, characteristics and physiological needs of the species or variety of tree or shrub, he shall issue a permit to the applicant. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.140 - Conditions of permit. 
    Work done under a permit issued under this chapter shall be performed in strict accordance with the terms of the permit and with the following regulations established for the planting, trimming and care of trees by permittee: 
(1)  Trees for planting must be the size designated by the director of parks and recreation; 
(2)  No tree or plant shall be planted or permitted to grow in the area formed by intersecting sidewalks nor shall any tree or plant be placed closer than fifteen feet from such intersecting sidewalks; 
(3)  In felling trees, the root stumps must also be removed; 
(4)  All cuts must be made flush with the tree and those of one inch or over in diameter must be treated with a proper tree wound dressing; 
(5)  Trees shall be planted a set distance apart determined by the director of parks and recreation considering the ultimate size of the variety of tree involved; 
(6)  No tree shall be planted where the clear space between the curb and sidewalk is less than four feet; 
(7)  No tree shall be planted nearer than two feet from the curbline or outer line of the sidewalk except where otherwise permitted by the director of parks and recreation, and shall be planted either midway in the boulevard or in line with existing trees; 
(8)  The expense for cutting, trimming, preservation, removal or replacement of any tree or shrub located upon a boulevard or parking strip shall be the responsibility of the property owner; 
(9)  No tree shall be planted on any parking strip except of the variety designated for that street by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.150 - Permit form. 
    Every permit shall be issued by the office of the parks and recreation department on permit forms prepared for this purpose, and shall include a description of the work to be done and shall specify the species or variety, size, nursery grade and location of trees or shrubs to be planted, if any. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.160 - Compliance with permit. 
    Any work done under a permit issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be performed in strict accordance with the terms of the permit and the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.170 - Duration of permit. 
    Permits issued under this chapter shall expire six months after the date of issuance. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.180 - Inspection of permitted work. 
    All work performed under a permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be inspected by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.190 - Replacement of removed trees. 
    As a condition to granting any permit to remove a public tree or shrub, the director of parks and recreation may require that the permittee plant one or more trees or shrubs in place of the one removed, and no permittee under such a conditional permit shall fail, refuse or neglect to plant trees or shrubs of the type, size and in the location specified in this permit. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.200 - Regulation of public utilities. 
    The parks and recreation board annually or as often as it deems necessary shall meet with a representative designated by public utilities engaged in tree trimming or removal in this city to discuss clearance practices and particularly any practices the board finds not in the best interests of the city. Permission shall be granted in writing by the parks and recreation board to each utility to cover any clearance work done. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.210 - Order to preserve or remove trees-Authority. 
    The director of parks and recreation shall have the authority to order the trimming, preservation and removal of trees upon private property when determined such action is necessary for public safety or to prevent the spread of disease or insects to public trees and places. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.220 - Order to preserve or remove trees-Procedure. 
    When the director of parks and recreation determines that any tree upon private property is in violation of this chapter, he shall serve upon the owner a written order to correct the violation. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.230 - Order to preserve or remove trees-Time for compliance. 
    The order to preserve, trim or remove trees shall set forth a time limit for compliance, dependent upon the hazard and danger created by the violation, but in no event shall it be less than ten days. In cases of extreme danger to persons or public property, the director of parks and recreation shall have the authority to require compliance immediately upon service of the order. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.240 - Written notice of order to correct. 
(a)  Any owner of private property with trees in violation of this chapter shall be served with a written order to correct from the director of parks and recreation, or a designated representative. 
(b)  The order shall provide that the owner of the affected premises shall trim, cut or remove the trees designated within the time and manner specified; and shall further provide that in case of failure to timely cut, trim or remove such trees, the city will cause the same to be trimmed, cut or removed and assess the costs thereof against the affected premises; and shall further advise that the order to correct may be appealed by the owner to the city commission. 
(c)  Service of such order to correct shall be accomplished by personally serving the owner of the affected premises; or service of such order may also be accomplished by securely posting the order in a conspicuous place on the affected premises and such posting shall constitute personal service. Personal service upon one owner shall constitute service upon all owners of the affected premises. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.250 - Order to preserve or remove trees-Appeal. 
    A person to whom an order to preserve and trim or remove trees as directed shall have the right within ten days of the service of such order, to file a written appeal with the city commission, who shall forthwith set a day for hearing thereon and give notice thereof to the person appealing. Upon such hearing and review, the commission may affirm, modify or revoke the order of the director of parks and recreation. Unless the order is revoked or modified, it shall remain in full force and be obeyed by the person to whom directed. No person to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply with such order within ten days after an appeal has been determined. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.260 - Order to preserve or remove trees-Failure to comply. 
(a)  When a person to whom an order is directed to preserve, trim or remove trees fails to comply within the specified time, the director or parks and recreation shall remedy the condition or contract with others for such purposes, and charge the cost thereof to the owner of the affected premises. The person remedying a condition under a contract made hereunder shall be authorized to enter premises for that purpose. 
(b)  "Cost therefore" shall be defined as the actual expenses incurred for remedying the condition plus a graduated noncompliance fee calculated over the calendar year as follows: 
First violation abated: fifty-dollar noncompliance fee; 
Second violation abated: one hundred-dollar noncompliance fee; 
Third violation abated: one hundred fifty-dollar noncompliance fee; 
Fourth violation abated: two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee. 
(c)  The city will abate nuisance trees singly or in groups if the trees are located on a lot or adjacent lots under single ownership. The compliance fee shall be paid each time that the city must abate a single tree or a group of trees if the group can be dealt with as a single entity. Each successive time that the city must return to the property to abate a single tree or group of trees, during the current calendar year, the graduated noncompliance fee schedule shall apply. 
(d)  Any subsequent violations abated by the city within the current calendar year, to be defined for the purposes of this chapter as the twelve-month period starting January 1st and ending December 31st, shall be billed at the two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee rate. The graduated noncompliance fee rate schedule shall apply to any and all violations abated by the city of Huron as allowed in Chapters 9.58, 9.62, 9.64, 11.16 and 15.24 of this code; and all shall be cumulative in calculation of the noncompliance fee. This graduated fee schedule shall become effective on January 1, 2005; shall apply to an individual address, lot, or parcel of real property; and shall be calculated by calendar year except in the case of transfer of ownership. However, the cumulative calculation of the noncompliance fee shall continue in the case of transfers of ownership between immediate family members. ("Immediate family" is defined for the purposes of this chapter as: spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandparent, grandchild, in-law, ward/guardian or cohabiting adult.) 
(e)  Right to appeal from building official's determination shall be available as specified in Section 9.58.120 of this code. 
(Ord. 1981 (part), 2004: Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.270 - Order to preserve or remove trees-Special assessment. 
    If the cost of remedying a condition for which an order to preserve, trim or remove trees was issued is not paid within thirty days after receipt of a statement therefor from the city finance office, such cost may be levied against the property benefitted or upon which such condition existed as a special assessment. The levying of such special assessment shall not affect the liability of the person to whom the order is directed to fine and imprisonment for the violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.280 - Street tree-Permitted types. 
    Trees used for street tree planting shall be hard or soft maple, American linden or basswood, hackberry, ash, honey locust and other types as may be approved by the parks and recreation board. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.290 - Height of hedges. 
    All existing hedges and shrubs on the boulevard or parking strips shall be trimmed to a height of thirty inches or not to exceed thirty inches, as measured from the gutter level of the street. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.300 - Injury to trees by moving-Trimming or replacement. 
    No person whether licensed or not shall move any building or other structure along any street, avenue, public place or alley in such manner as to interfere with or injure any tree in any public area except as hereinafter provided. If in moving any building or structure, it is necessary to trim or move any tree, all such work shall be done under the supervision and control of the parks and recreation department and at the expense of the person moving such building or structure. Such person shall, upon the direction of the parks and recreation department, replace the tree at his own expense. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.310 - Injury to tree by moving-Supervision of work. 
    If in moving any building or structure, it is necessary to trim or remove any tree along any street, avenue, public place or alley within the city, all such work shall be done under the supervision and control of the parks and recreation department at the expense of the person moving such building or structure, and following the pruning standards as set forth pursuant to Section 11.16.140 by the parks and recreation department. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.320 - Abuse or mutilation of trees. 
    Regarding public trees or shrubs no person shall: 
(1)  Damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or plant or injure the bark; 
(2)  Pick the flowers or seeds of any tree or plant; 
(3)  Attach any rope, wire or other contrivance to any tree or plant; 
(4)  Dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any area; 
(5)  Cause or permit any wire charged with electricity to come in contact with any tree or plant, or allow any gaseous, liquid or solid substance which is harmful to such trees or plants to come in contact with them. 
(Ord. 1820 (part), 1998: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.16.330 - Waiver of costs. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter regarding the charging of costs and the levying of a special assessment against a property owner, the city commission may waive the charging of costs or levy of special assessment against an affected property owner when attempted compliance with this chapter would likely present substantial and imminent danger to persons or vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. 1833, 1999). 
11.16.340 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day that the violation continues, and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provision in Section 1.04.130, except for purposes of this chapter any such fine imposed thereunder shall not be less than one hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 1915, 2001). 
Chapter 11.20 - DUTCH ELM DISEASE 

11.20.010 - Declaration of policy. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of Title 11, the city commission has determined that the health of the elm trees within the municipal limits is threatened by a fatal disease known as Dutch elm disease. It has further determined that the loss of elm trees growing upon public and private property would substantially depreciate the value of property within the city and impair the safety, good order, general welfare and convenience of the public. It is the intention of the city commission to control and prevent the spread of this disease and this chapter is enacted for that purpose. 
(Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.020 - Public nuisances defined. 
    The city commission declares the following to be public nuisances: 
(1)  Any living or standing elm tree or part thereof infected with the Dutch elm disease fungus, Ceratocystis ulmi, or which harbors the European elm bark beetle, Scolytus jultistriatus (Eichb.) and/or the American elm bark beetle, Hylurgopinus rufipes (Marsh.); 
(2)  Any dead elm tree or part thereof including logs, branches, stumps, firewood or other elm material from which the bark has not been removed and burned, or sprayed with an effective insecticide for destroying elm bark beetles. 
(Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.030 - Nuisances prohibited. 
    No person shall permit any public nuisance as defined in this chapter to remain on the premises owned or controlled by him within the city. 
(Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.040 - Abatement of nuisances. 
    If the city parks and recreation director in person or by some qualified person acting for him, determines upon inspection or examination that any public nuisance as defined in Section 11.20.020 exists in or upon any public street, alley, park or other public place, including the terrace strip between a curb and a lot line within the city, he may cause it to be removed and burned, or otherwise abate the same. 
(Ord. 1404 (part), 1980: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.050 - Notice to abate. 
    If the city parks and recreation director in person or by some qualified person acting for him, upon inspection or examination, determines with reasonable certainty that any public nuisance as defined in Section 11.20.020 exists in or upon private premises within the city, he may immediately serve or cause to be served, either personally or by U.S. registered mail, upon the owner of such property, if he can be found, or upon the occupant thereof, a written notice to abate such nuisance within twenty days of service of the notice. 
(Ord. 1404 (part), 1980: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.060 - Determination of disease. 
    If the city parks and recreation director is unable to determine with reasonable certainty whether or not a tree in or upon private premises is infected with Dutch elm disease, he is authorized to remove or cut specimens from such tree, may forward such specimens for diagnosis and report to the plant pathology department of South Dakota State University, and may proceed as provided in this chapter upon receipt of a positive report from the department. 
(Ord. 1414 (part), 1980: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.070 - Abatement by city. 
    If the owner or occupant of the property upon which any nuisance exists in violation of this chapter fails to abate such nuisance within the time specified in the notice to do so, the city park and recreation director may cause the nuisance to be removed and burned, or otherwise abated. 
(Ord. 1414 (part), 1980: Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.080 - Effect of abatement. 
    All abatements made under the provisions of this chapter shall be made in such manner as to destroy or prevent as fully as possible the spread of Dutch elm disease or the insect pests or vectors known to carry such disease fungus. 
(Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.090 - Assessment of abatement cost. 
    The cost of abating any public nuisance as defined in this chapter shall be borne as follows: 
(1)  The entire cost of any abatement of a public nuisance as defined in this chapter on trees on any public street, alley, park or other public place, including the terrace strip between a curb and a lot line, shall be borne by the city. 
(2)  The cost of any abatement of a public nuisance as defined in this chapter on any private property shall be borne by the owner or owners of such property and shall be assessed against such property as provided in this chapter. If any part of a tree constituting a nuisance hereunder is located on a property line, the owners of property on either side of such line shall share equally in the cost of abatement. 
(Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.100 - Reporting of costs. 
    The city parks and recreation director shall keep strict account of the costs of work done under this article for which assessments are to be made, stating and certifying the description of the land, lots, parts of lots or parcels of land, and the amounts chargeable to each. The city parks and recreation director shall include in his report to the city commission the aggregate amounts chargeable to each lot or parcel as recorded by him, and such amounts shall be levied and assessed against such parcels or lots in the same manner as provided in Section 11.16.260. 
(Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.110 - Financing. 
    The cost of pruning, spraying and/or removing elm trees, or otherwise abating any public nuisance as set forth by this chapter, on any street, alley, avenue, boulevard or park, or the initial cost for the removal of trees on private property harboring the Dutch elm disease fungus may be financed from a special fund as authorized by state law, from general revenue or other special funds, or from any combination of these sources. 
(Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
11.20.120 - Transporting of elm wood controlled. 
    It is unlawful for any person to transport within the city any bark-bearing elm wood without first obtaining approval from the park and recreation department. 
(Ord. 1209 (part), 1976). 
Title 12 - CEMETERIES 
Chapter 12.04 - ADDITIONAL CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to establish, regulate, and maintain cemeteries within or without the municipality and to prohibit their establishment within the city or within one mile of the corporate limits-See SDC 45.0201(40). 
Cross reference- Zoning-See Title 23 of this code. 

12.04.010 - Declaration of purpose. 
    For the purpose of exercising the power delegated to it by Chapter 198 Session Laws 1949 of the State of South Dakota and pursuant to the action and recommendation of the plan commission as part of the master plan of the City of Huron, the governing body has determined and does hereby determine that good cause and reason exists for regulating and prohibiting the establishment of additional cemeteries within the following described areas: 
(1)  Within the corporate limits of the City of Huron, South Dakota, and within one mile of the said corporate limits. 
(2)  Within that area included within the master plan of the City of Huron, South Dakota, but outside of the area included in subsection (1) above. 
(Ord. 556 § 1; December 7, 1953: Ord. 563 § 1; February 1, 1954). 
12.04.020 - Additional cemeteries prohibited in described areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association to establish and/or maintain a cemetery, or cemeteries, within the following described areas: 
(1)  Within the corporate limits of the City of Huron, South Dakota, and within one mile of the said corporate limits; 
(2)  Within that area included in the master plan of the City of Huron, South Dakota, and more particularly described and designated in Map 1 filed in Plat Book 4, Page 16, in the office of the Register of Deeds of Beadle County, South Dakota. 
(Ord. 556 § 2; December 7, 1953: Ord. 563 § 1; February 1, 1954). 
12.04.030 - Existing cemeteries exempted. 
    The prohibition herein contained shall not apply to any person, firm, corporation or association that has heretofore established and is now maintaining a cemetery within the areas described in Section 12.04.020. 
(Ord. 556 § 3; December 7, 1953: Ord. 563 § 4; February 1, 1954). 
12.04.040 - Penalty. 
    Any person or persons, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter or failing to comply with any of the provisions thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in Section 1.04.130 of the Huron Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 556 § 4; December 7, 1953). 
Title 13 - MUNICIPAL AIRPORT 
Chapter 13.04 - AIRPORT BOARD[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ords. 483, 988, 1839 and 1908. 

13.04.010 - Establishment of board. 
    There is created an airport board for the city, to be known as the airport board, to operate, improve, care for, regulate and manage the municipal airport facilities and affairs for the purpose of providing airport facilities and services to general and commercial aviation in and for the city. All rules, regulations and policies of the airport board shall be subject to the approval of the city commission. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.020 - Appointment of board members-Terms of office. 
    There shall not be less than five members on the airport board. The mayor, with the approval of the governing body, shall appoint the members to the airport board. Each appointment shall be for five years. Such appointees are to hold office until their successors are appointed and qualified. Such successors need not be residents or freeholders of the city. 
(Ord. 2032 (part), 2007: Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.030 - Annual appointments. 
    At the first regular meeting of the city commission in May of each year, and subject to the approval of the governing board, the mayor shall appoint to a term of five years such board members as may be necessary to have a full complement of board members. Appointments shall commence on June 1st and expire on May 31st. The members comprising the airport board shall not hold any other elective or appointive office in the municipal government. 
(Ord. 2032 (part), 2007: Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.040 - Board compensation. 
    All members appointed to service on the airport board shall serve without compensation, except for expenses accrued due to authorized travel outside the city in fulfilling the obligations of their appointed duties, such expenses shall be reimbursed on the basis of actual proof of personal expenses accrued due to and during such travel authorized by the airport board at a regular board meeting. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.050 - Performance bond and oath. 
    Each member of the board, before entering upon his official duties, shall give bond to the city in the amount of five hundred dollars for the faithful performance of his duties and shall take and file with the finance officer the bond and the usual oath of office required from appointive officers of the city. The city shall pay any premium for the bonds required to be given by members of the board. All official bonds required under the provisions of this chapter shall be approved by the governing body. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.060 - Board vacancies. 
    Any vacancy on the airport board shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member vacating the board for any reason or purpose in the same manner as is required for a regular appointment and shall also qualify as provided in Section 13.04.030 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.070 - Election of officers. 
    At the first regular meeting of the airport board, the board shall elect from its number a president, vice president and a secretary, each of whom shall serve until the first meeting of June the following year. The vice president shall act in the absence or disability of the president. In case of death or retirement of an officer, a successor shall be elected from the remaining board members at the next official meeting subsequent thereto. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.080 - Official meetings-Quorum. 
    The board shall hold regular meetings at least once each month and as many special meetings as it deems proper and necessary to conduct the official business affairs of the municipal airport department. Meetings of the airport board are subject to SDCL 1-25. Three members shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of transacting any official business or authorizing the expenditures of any municipal airport funds, however, an affirmative vote of three or more board members shall be required for all official action of the airport board. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.090 - Official records and reports. 
    The secretary of the board shall keep a record of its proceedings and make such reports as may be required by the board. In his absence, or inability to act, the board may appoint a secretary pro tem to perform his duties. The records of the board, kept by its secretary or copies of any such records when duly certified by the secretary shall be competent evidence of the proceedings of the board. Copies of any or all such records and/or reports shall be filed with the finance officer for city record purposes. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.100 - Board rules and regulations. 
    The airport board, subject to the approval of the governing body, may establish bylaws, rules and regulations for the orderly transaction of business and operation of the municipal airport department and its facilities. Any amendment to this chapter as desired by the board shall be requested by resolution as outlined in Section 13.04.130 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.110 - Board authority and duties. 
    The president, and in his absence or disability the vice-president, shall have the authority to sign, execute and acknowledge in the name of the airport board all contracts or documents as authorized by the airport board and to carry out the normal business and functions of the municipal airport department, and to sign requisitions upon the city finance for warrants and for funds to be expended by the airport board. All such warrants shall be drawn by the city finance office and be signed by the mayor and city finance officer. Any warrants drawn shall be recorded in the official financial ledgers of the city and drawn on the municipal airport department cash funds. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.120 - Powers, limitations and immunities. 
    The airport board shall have all of those powers and be subject to the limitations and enjoy those privileges and immunities as all provided for by this chapter and by Chapters 50-6, 50-7 and 50-8 of the South Dakota Codified Laws as now or hereafter amended. Whenever the prior approval of the governing body is required before the airport board can act, such prior approval shall be first obtained. Otherwise, the board shall be charged with the supervision and management of all municipal airport facilities and functions. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.130 - Board regulations. 
    Any recommendation by the airport board to the governing body shall be by resolution and submitted in writing to the city commission for consideration. When any ordinance of the governing body is passed upon the recommendation of the airport board, it is not necessary for such ordinance to recite at length the resolution of the airport board recommending the same, but it is sufficient to recite the fact of such recommendation by the airport board, which recital shall be conclusive of the making and regularity of such resolution in all proceedings thereafter. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.140 - Department tax levy. 
    The airport board's annual tax levy as may be authorized by the city commission shall be governed by the provisions of Chapters 9-21 and 50-6 of the South Dakota Codified Laws as now or hereafter amended. Each tax levy as authorized by state statutes for specific purposes shall not be exceeded by the combination of such levies at any time or for any purpose and as approved by the governing body of the city. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.150 - Records open to inspection. 
    The airport board shall make an annual report to the governing body of its acts and all its expenditures, showing the condition of all affairs under its control. The governing body may require a report from the airport board at any time, and the records, books, papers, and accounts of the board, shall at all times be subject to inspection by the mayor, finance officer, or any committee appointed by the governing body for that purpose or by any citizen. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.160 - Airport manager-Employees. 
    The airport board may recommend to the city commission the appointment of an airport manager of the municipal airport, who shall be the chief executive officer under the airport board and shall not be an employee under civil service. He/she shall hold office at the pleasure of the city commission and receive such salary and benefits as the city commission may determine. The airport manager shall, on behalf of the city commission and airport board, have charge, supervision, and direction of all activities and of all airport department employees under the jurisdiction of the airport board and the city commission. Upon the recommendation of the airport board, the city commission may appoint and employ other officers and employees as it may deem necessary and may prescribe and fix their duties and compensation in accordance with the provisions of Title 3 of the Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.170 - Bond for employees. 
    The airport board may recommend to the city commission that airport department officers and employees give bond for the faithful performance of their duties in such sum as shall be fixed by it, which bonds shall be filed with the city finance officer. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.180 - Collection of fees and rents. 
    The airport manager shall collect for the municipal airport department from all persons desiring and who use the facilities of the airport, all fees aside from such fees as are otherwise regularly remitted to the city finance officer. All collections shall be transmitted to the city finance officer monthly. All money received by the airport manager shall be acknowledged by him/her upon triplicate receipt, each bearing his/her signature. The original of such triplicate shall be delivered to the persons making the payment, the duplicate delivered to the city finance officer when the collection is transmitted, and the triplicate shall be retained for the records of the municipal airport department. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.190 - Airport revenue fund. 
    The city finance officer shall credit to and keep in a separate municipal airport account all money derived from the tax levy provided for by Chapters 9-21 and 50-6 of the South Dakota Codified Laws and any other revenues received for the use of the municipal airport facilities and shall pay the same upon requisition by the president and secretary of the board and warrant drawn and executed hereinbefore provided. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.200 - Annual budget. 
    The airport board on or before July 15th shall make an estimate of the moneys necessary for the operation of the airport department and as authorized by Chapter 50-6 of the South Dakota Codified Laws. Such estimate shall be certified by the secretary of the airport board to the city finance officer on or before 1st day of August each year. The proposed airport budget shall be considered by the city commission during its normal budget process and the proposed budget submitted by the airport board may be approved, with or without modification, as deemed appropriate by the city commission. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.210 - Department expenditures. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided, all sums used for the purpose of acquiring land, constructing, equipping, maintaining buildings and other airport facilities as authorized by Chapters 50-6, 50-7 and 50-8 of the South Dakota Codified Laws shall be paid out of the moneys derived from the annual tax levy and other general revenues of the municipal airport department credited for the use of the airport and such moneys shall be appropriated by ordinance in the same manner as other money is appropriated by the governing body of the city. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.220 - Acquisition of land. 
    Upon recommendation of the airport board, the governing body may provide by ordinance for the purchase, condemnation, or otherwise acquisition of land within or without the city limits as authorized by Chapters 9-21 and 50-6 of the South Dakota Codified Laws. Payment for any such land selected and acquired may be made out of the money derived from the tax levy provided by Chapters 9-21 and 50-6 of the South Dakota Codified Laws or any other money received for the use of the airport board or by the issue and sale of bonds of the city after authorization as provided by law. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.230 - Contracts for construction and improvements. 
    Pursuant to state law, contracts for any construction or improvements incidental to the operation of the municipal airport for which special assessments are not to be levied shall be let by the airport board to the lowest responsible bidder, in the same manner and subject to the same provisions as similar work not under control of the airport board with engineering assistance and supervision from a registered or qualified engineer. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.240 - Fees for water and sewer permits. 
    Fees for water and sewer permits at the municipal airport shall be the same as for other such permits within the city limits, which shall be issued by the city and credited to the proper city funds designated for such purposes. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.250 - Airport zoning ordinance. 
    The governing body shall establish an airport zoning ordinance in conformity with federal and state laws and be approved by the Federal Aviation Administration and the State Aeronautics Commission prior to adoption. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.260 - Airport building permits. 
    Building permits in the airport area must conform to the current master airport layout plan as established by the governing body. All building permits shall conform to the provisions of the airport zoning ordinance and city building codes, unless granted exceptions by the governing body. Building permits shall be issued by and through the city building inspector's office at the request of the airport board. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.270 - City attorney's duties. 
    The city attorney as a part of his duties shall conduct all court proceedings under this chapter and shall be the legal advisor of the board. When in its judgment the interests of the city demand, the city commission may employ special counsel to assist the city attorney at the city attorney's request. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.280 - General regulations, ground rules, etc. 
    The airport manager shall enforce a schedule of general regulations, ground rules, etc., not inconsistent with the civil aeronautics air regulations, which shall be approved by the airport board. When approved, a set of such rules shall be filed in the office of the city engineer, city finance officer and office of the airport manager. The airport board reserves the right by a majority vote of the airport board to revoke, cancel or change any or all rules or parts thereof. In any contingencies not specifically covered by these rules, the airport board shall be the arbitrators. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
13.04.290 - Violations-Penalties. 
    All federal, state and local laws and ordinances pertaining to intoxicating liquors and narcotics, will be respected by all persons connected with the municipal airport operations, under penalty of arrest, revocation of license and withdrawal of privileges granted under the provisions of Section 13.04.270 of this chapter and the Huron Municipal Code. The airport manager and/or police officers of the city will have authority to enforce all rules and regulations established by ordinance and the airport board. Any person violating these rules or refusing to comply therewith, will be subject to the penalties provided by law. 
    The air traffic rules of the Federal Aviation Administration and future amendments thereto are made a part of this chapter and incorporated herein. Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter or the rules and regulations adopted by the duly appointed airport board or city commission, or failing to comply with any of the provisions thereof, is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 1999 (part), 2005). 
Chapter 13.08 - AIRPORT ZONING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Model airport zoning law adopted-See SDC 2.05 '60 Supp.; Municipalities empowered to adopt, administer, and enforce airport zoning; regulations-See SDC 2.0504, et seq. 
Cross reference- Zoning provisions generally-See Title 23 of this code; Building permits-See Ch. 18.08 of this code. 

13.08.010 - Name and citation of chapter. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Huron Airport Zoning Ordinance. 
(Ord. 493, 1951: Ord. 483 § 2.010900, 1950). 
13.08.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires: 
(1)  AIRPORT means the W. W. Howes Municipal Airport. 
(2)  AIRPORT HAZARD means any structure or tree or use of land which obstructs the airspace required for the flight of aircraft in landing or taking off at the airport or is otherwise hazardous to such landing or taking off of aircraft. 
(3)  NONCONFORMING USE means any structure or tree or use of land which does not conform to a regulation prescribed in this chapter or an amendment thereto, as of the effective date of such regulation. 
(4)  PERSON means any individual, firm, copartnership, corporation, company, association, joint stock association or body politic, and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee, or other similar representative thereof. 
(5)  STRUCTURE means any object constructed or installed by man, including, but without limitation, buildings, towers, smokestacks, and over-head transmission lines. 
(6)  TREE means any object of natural growth. 
(7)  BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT means the governing body of the City of Huron, or the Board of Adjustment as provided for in section 23.01.030. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010901, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
(Ord. No. 2165-13-6, 8-31-2015) 
13.08.030 - Zones and maps. 
(1)  For the purpose of this chapter all of the land lying within the outer boundary of the zoned area of the airport is divided into the following zones and areas: 
(a)  Inner zone 
1.  Landing area. 
2.  Inner areas of approach zones. 
3.  Transition zones. 
(b)  Outer zone: 
1.  Outer areas of approach zones. 
2.  Turning zones. 
(2)  The boundaries of these zones and areas are hereby established as shown on the Airport Approach Plan and Zoning Map No. 1, prepared by the South Dakota Aeronautics Commission, which is made a part of this chapter and may be amended and supplemented. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010902, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.040 - Height limits. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, allowed to grow or maintained in any part of the inner or outer zones created by this chapter to a height in excess of the height limits hereby established for such zones. 
(2)  The height limits for each of the zones and areas herein created are hereby established as shown and noted on the Airport Approach Plan and Zoning Map No. 1. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010903, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.050 - Use restrictions. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it shall be unlawful to put any land located within any zone hereby created to any of the following prohibited uses: 
(1)  Transformer stations. 
(2)  High power transmission lines. 
(3)  Manufacturing establishments or other uses which produce smoke interfering with the safe use of the airport. 
(4)  All plants and businesses of every kind which emit or discharge gases and odors that would interfere with the health or safety of the public in the use of the airport. 
(5)  Businesses or structures of any kind that may be detrimental or injurious to the health, safety, and general welfare of the public in the use of the airport. 
(6)  Any other use which would create electrical interference with radio communications between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between airport lights and others, result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport, or otherwise endanger the landing, taking-off, or the maneuvering of aircraft. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010904, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.060 - Spacing requirements of adjacent airports. 
(1)  Within a radius of eight miles from the center of the W. W. Howes Municipal Airport no airport of Class 1 or greater, as hereinafter defined, shall be established unless permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted, in accordance with the provision of this chapter. 
(2)  Except as otherwise provided, the minimum distance between the W. W. Howes Municipal Airport and any other airport hereafter established, measured from center to center, shall be not less than provided in the following schedule: 
Class of

Other AirportDistance From

W. W. Howes 

Municipal 

AirportClass I ..... 4 miles Class II ..... 5 miles Class III ..... 6 miles Class IV or larger ..... 7 miles  
(3)  Airport classification for the purpose of this chapter shall be in accord with the following schedule: 
Length longest landing strip and class of airport. 
Under 2700 feet plus 1/4 Elev. above sea level-I; 
2700 to 3700 feet plus 1/4 Elev. above sea level-II; 
3700 to 4700 feet plus 1/4 Elev. above sea level-III; 
Over 4700 feet plus 1/4 Elev. above sea level-IV or larger. 
(4)  Exceptions to the spacing requirements hereinbefore provided in this section may be granted by the board of adjustment, which is hereby authorized to allow lesser distances between the W. W. Howes Municipal Airport and any other airport proposed to be established, but only after public hearing duly held in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, and where, owing to special conditions, the board of adjustment duly finds that a literal enforcement of these provisions would result in unnecessary hardship and such variance would not be contrary to the public interest. 
    Prior to the granting of any such exception or variance, the board of adjustment shall, for the purpose of study and recommendation, refer the matter to the South Dakota Aeronautics Commission and to any local aviation commission, airport zoning commission, and any local planning body having jurisdiction within the area affected. 
    If any of the aforementioned bodies to whom the matter shall have been referred does not within forty-five days transmit a report to the board of adjustment, then it shall be deemed to have approved the proposal, provided, however, that upon request of any said bodies the board of adjustment shall grant a reasonable extension of such time. 
    In granting such exception or variance the board of adjustment shall impose special conditions which will ensure that the public interest is maintained. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010905, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.070 - Existing nonconforming uses. 
(1)  REGULATIONS NOT RETROACTIVE. The regulations prescribed by this chapter shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering, or other change or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming to the regulations as of March 12, 1951, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of any nonconforming use. Nothing herein contained shall require any change in the construction, alteration, or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which has begun prior to March 12, 1951, and is diligently prosecuted and completed within two years thereof. 
(2)  MARKING AND LIGHTING. Notwithstanding the preceding provisions of this section, the owner of any nonconforming structure or tree is hereby required to permit the installation, operation, and maintenance thereof of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the city engineer or building inspector to indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport, the presence of such airport hazards. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated, and maintained at the expense of the City of Huron. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010906, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.080 - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer or the building inspector to administer and enforce the regulations prescribed herein. Applications for permits and variances shall be made to the city engineer or the building inspector. Applications which are by this chapter to be decided by the city engineer or the building inspector shall be promptly considered and granted, or denied by them. Applications for action by the governing body of the City of Huron shall be forthwith transmitted by the city auditor to the board for hearing and decision. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010907; as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.090 - Permits. 
(1)  FUTURE USES. No material change shall be made in the use of land, and no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, planted, or otherwise established, which would violate the provisions of this chapter, in any zone hereby created, unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted. Each such application shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient particularity to permit it to be determined whether the resulting use, structure, or tree would conform to the regulations herein prescribed. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. 
(2)  EXISTING USES. Before any existing use, structure, or tree may be replaced, substantially altered or repaired, rebuilt, allowed to grow higher or replanted in violation to the provisions of this chapter, within any zone hereby created, a permit must be secured authorizing such replacement, change, or repair. No such permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an airport hazard or permit a nonconforming use, structure, or tree to be made or become higher, or become a greater hazard to air navigation, than it was on March 12, 1951 or the effective date of any amendment, or than it is when the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for such permits shall be granted. 
(3)  NONCONFORMING USES ABANDONED OR DESTROYED. Whenever the city engineer or the building inspector determines that a nonconforming structure or tree has been abandoned or more than eighty per cent torn down, physically deteriorated or decayed, (a) no permit shall be granted that would allow such structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning regulations, and (b) whether application is made for a permit under this paragraph or not, the city engineer or the building inspector may by appropriate action compel the owner of the nonconforming structure or tree, at his own expense, to lower, remove, reconstruct, or equip such object as may be necessary to conform to the regulations or, if the owner of the nonconforming structure or tree shall neglect or refuse to comply with such an order after ten days notice thereof, the city engineer or building inspector may proceed to have the object so lowered, removed, or equipped, and assess the cost and expense thereof upon the object or the land wherein it is or was located. Unless such an assessment is paid within ninety days from the service of notice thereof on the agent or owner of such object or land, the sum shall bear interest at the rate of six per cent per annum until paid, and shall be collected in the same manner as are general taxes. Except as indicated herein, all applications for permits for replacement, change, or repair of non-conforming uses shall be granted. 
(4)  VARIANCES. Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use his property, not in accordance with the regulations prescribed in this chapter, may apply to the governing body of the City of Huron for a variance from such regulations. Such variance shall be allowed where it is duly found that a literal application or enforcement of the regulations would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and the relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest but do substantial justice and be in accordance with the spirit of this chapter. 
(5)  HAZARD MARKING AND LIGHTING. Any permit or variance granted may, if such action is deemed advisable, effectuates the purpose of this chapter, and is reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or tree in question to permit the City of Huron, at its own expense, to install, operate, and maintain thereon such markers and lights as may be necessary to indicate to flyers the presence of an airport hazard. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010908, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.100 - Appeals. 
(1)  Any person aggrieved, or taxpayer affected, by any decision of the city engineer or the building inspector made in their administration of this chapter, or any governing body of a political subdivision, (or any joint airport zoning board), if of the opinion that a decision of the city engineer or the building inspector is an improper application of these regulations of concern to such governing body (or board), may appeal to the board of adjustment. 
(2)  All appeals hereunder must be taken within a reasonable time, as provided by the rules of the board of adjustment, by filing with the city auditor for the city engineer or the building inspector and with the board, a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The city engineer or building inspector shall forthwith transmit to the board all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(3)  An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the city engineer or building inspector certifies to the board, after the notice of appeal has been filed with it, that by reason of the facts stated in certificate a stay would, in their opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by order of the board and on due cause shown. 
(4)  The board shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give public notice and due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(5)  The board may, in conformity with the provisions of this chapter, reverse or affirm, wholly or in part, or modify, the order, requirement, decision, or determination appealed from and may make such order, requirement, decision, or determination as ought to be made, and to that end shall have the powers of the city engineer or building inspector. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010909, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.110 - Board of adjustment. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the governing body to act as the board of adjustment and have and exercise the following powers: 
(a)  To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the city engineer or building inspector in the enforcement of this chapter. 
(b)  To hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this chapter upon which such board may be required to pass under such regulations. 
(c)  To hear and decide specific variances under Section 13.08.090. 
(2)  The board shall adopt rules for its governance and procedure in harmony with the provisions of this chapter. Meetings of the board shall be held at the call of the mayor, and at such other times as the board may determine. The chairman, or in his absence the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All hearings of the board shall be public. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall immediately be filed in the office of the city auditor, and shall be a public record. The office of the city auditor shall be the office of the board. 
(3)  The board shall make written findings of fact and conclusions of law giving the facts upon which it acted and its legal conclusions from such facts in reversing, or affirming, or modifying any order, requirement, decision, or determination which comes before it under the provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  The concurring vote of a majority of the members of the board shall be sufficient to reverse any order, requirement, decision, or determination of the city engineer or building inspector, or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which it is required to pass under this chapter, or to effect any variation in this chapter. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010910, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.120 - Judicial review. 
(1)  Any person aggrieved, or taxpayer affected, by any decision of the board of adjustment, or any governing body of a political subdivision (or any joint airport zoning board) which is of the opinion that a decision of the board of adjustment is illegal, may present to the district court a verified petition setting forth that the decision is illegal, in whole or in part, and specifying the grounds of illegality. Such petition shall be presented to the court within thirty days after the decision is filed in the office of the board. 
(2)  Upon presentation of such petition the court may allow a writ of certiorari directed to the board of adjustment to review such decision of the board. The allowance of the writ shall not stay proceedings upon the decision appealed from but the court may, on application, on notice to the board and on due cause shown, grant a restraining order. 
(3)  The board of adjustment shall not be required to return the original papers acted upon by it, but it shall be sufficient to return certified or sworn copies thereof or of such portions thereof as may be called for by the writ. The return shall concisely set forth such other facts as may be pertinent and material to show the grounds of the decision appealed from and shall be verified. 
(4)  The court shall have exclusive jurisdiction to affirm, modify or set aside the decision brought up for review, in whole or in part, and, if need be, to order further proceedings by the board of adjustment. The findings of fact of the board, if supported by substantial evidence, shall be accepted by the court as conclusive, and no objection to a decision of the board shall be considered by the court unless such objection shall have been urged before the board or, if it was not so urged, unless there were reasonable grounds for failing to do so. 
(5)  Costs shall not be allowed against the board, unless it appears to the court that it acted with gross negligence, in bad faith, or with malice, in making the decision appealed from. 
(6)  In any case where these regulations, although generally reasonable, are held by a court to interfere with the use or enjoyment of a particular structure or parcel of land to such an extent, or to be onerous in their application to such a structure or parcel of land, as to constitute a taking or deprivation of that property in violation of the constitution of this state or the constitution of the United States, such holding shall not affect the application of such regulations to other structures and parcels of land. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010911, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.130 - Conflicting regulations. 
    Where this chapter imposes a greater or more stringent restriction upon the use of land than is imposed or required by any other ordinance or regulation, the provision of this chapter shall govern. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010913, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951). 
13.08.140 - Penalties. 
    Each violation of this chapter or of any regulation, order, or ruling promulgated hereunder shall constitute a misdemeanor and be punishable as provided in Section 1.04.130 of the Huron Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 483 § 2.010912, as amended by Ord. 493; March 12, 1951).

Chapter 15.04 - NAMING STREETS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to name and change the name of any street, avenue, alley, or other public place - See SDC 45.0201(96). 
Cross reference- Platting new streets - See Ch. 24.16 of this code. 

15.04.010 - Avenues designated. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, all those roadways which traverse the city of Huron due north and south are designated as avenues. All such avenues have individual names. 
(Ord. 453 § 15.0101; April 24, 1950). 
15.04.020 - Streets designated. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter all those roadways which traverse the city of Huron due east and west are designated as streets. All such streets are named as they are numbered, except as provided in Section 15.04.070. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0102; April 24, 1950). 
15.04.030 - City divided into four districts. 
    For the purpose of ready designation, the city of Huron is divided into four districts, namely, South East, North East, North West and South West. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0201; April 24, 1950). 
15.04.040 - Dividing lines of districts. 
    Such districts are determined in the following manner: Center Street is the line dividing the city north from south; Dakota Avenue is the line dividing the city east and west. The lines of these two roadways are the innermost boundaries of such districts. 
(1)  NORTH EAST. 
The portions of the streets and avenues lying east of Dakota Avenue and north of Center Street are designated North East. 
(2)  SOUTH EAST. 
The portions of the streets and avenue lying south of Center Street and east of Dakota Avenue are designated South East. 
(3)  SOUTH WEST. 
The portions of the streets and avenues lying west of Dakota Avenue and south of Center Street are designated South West. 
(4)  NORTH WEST. 
The portion of the streets and avenues lying west of Dakota Avenue and north of Center Street are designated North West. 
(5)  DAKOTA AVENUE NORTH AND SOUTH. 
The portion of Dakota Avenue lying north of Center Street is designated as Dakota Avenue North, and the portion of Dakota Avenue lying south of Center Street is designated as Dakota Avenue South. 
(6)  CENTER STREET EAST AND WEST. 
The portion of Center Street lying east of Dakota Avenue is designated as Center Street East, and the portion of Center Street lying west of Dakota Avenue is designated as Center Street West. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0202, April 24, 1950). 
15.04.050 - Names of avenues west of Dakota Avenue. 
(1)  DAKOTA AVENUE: That portion of that certain state roadway, known as the section line which divides the townships between Range No. 61 and Range No. 62, which passes through the city of Huron, is designated as Dakota Avenue. 
(2)  CALIFORNIA AVENUE: The roadway running parallel to and between Dakota Avenue and Wisconsin Avenue, from Fifth Street S.W. to and Seventh Street S.W. is designated as California Avenue. 
(3)  WISCONSIN AVENUE: The first roadway west of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue is designated as Illinois Avenue. 
(4)  ILLINOIS AVENUE: The second roadway west of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue is designated as Illinois Avenue. 
(5)  OHIO AVENUE AND HAWAII AVENUE: The third roadway west of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue is designated as Ohio Avenue provided that the avenue running parallel to and between Illinois Avenue and Ohio Avenue S.W. extended and commencing at 22nd Street S.W. and lying west of Dakota Avenue S. shall be designated Hawaii Avenue. 
(6)  UNION AVENUE N.W./S.W.: That roadway running north and south located midway between Rushmore Avenue N.W./N.E. and West Park Avenue N.E./N.W. with the north end of the street at Old Highway 14 N.E. and the south end at 3rd Street S.W. 
(7)  NEBRASKA AVENUE: The fourth roadway west of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue is designated as Nebraska Avenue. 
(8)  COLORADO AVENUE: The fifth roadway west of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue is designated as Colorado Avenue. 
(9)  MONTANA AVENUE: The sixth roadway west of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue is designated as Montana Avenue. 
(10)  WYOMING AVENUE: The seventh roadway west of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue is designated as Wyoming Avenue.
