(23)  McCLELLAN DRIVE: The roadway which extends from the intersection of 13th Street S.W. and Ohio Avenue S.W. in an arc to 14th Street S.W. and thence produced due south to 20th Street S.W. and running parallel to Dakota Avenue South and running south from 22nd Street S.W. to 24th Street S.W. is designated as McClellan Drive. 
(24)  CAMPBELL DRIVE: The roadway which extends from the intersection of 12th Street S.W. and Nebraska Avenue S.W. and produced south to 14th Street S.W. and running south and west from 22nd Street S.W. to the N-S quarter line in Section 13, T110N, R62W is designated as Campbell Drive. 
(25)  McDONALD DRIVE: The roadway which extends from the intersection of 12th Street S.W. and Colorado Avenue S.W. and produced south to 20th Street S.W. and running south from Campbell Drive S.W. to 24th Street S.W. where Campbell Drive is located south of 22nd Street S.W. is designated as McDonald Drive. 
(26)  WASHINGTON DRIVE: The roadway which extends from 14th Street S.W., between McDonald Drive S.W. and Nevada Avenue S.W. west of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue South, is designated as Washington Drive. 
(27)  SUNSET DRIVE: The roadway which extends from 14th Street S.W., between Nevada Avenue S.W. and Arizona Avenue S.W. west of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue South is designated as Sunset Drive.

(Ord. No. 2191-15-22, 3-26-2018)

(17)  RIVERVIEW DRIVE: The tenth roadway east of and running parallel to Dakota Avenue South and south of Third Street Southeast is designated as Riverview Drive. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.104; September 22, 1953; Subsection (14) added by Ord. 602; May 16, 1955: Subsection (15), (16) added by Ord. 752; September 12, 1960: Subsections (10), (11), amended by Subsection (17), added by Ord. 908-15-3; November 8, 1965: Subsection (16) amended by Ord. 958; October 21, 1968). 
(Ord. No. 2109-15-18, 3-26-2012) 
15.04.070 - Names of streets and drives. 
(1)  CENTER STREET: A line running due east and west, intersecting Dakota Avenue at right angles at a point fifty-six feet north of the main line of the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad is designated as Center Street. 
    Center Street is partly a true roadway and a partly hypothetical roadway, established as part of a systematic method of numbering the buildings and houses of the city. It is a true roadway from its intersection with Montana Avenue to Nevada Avenue, from its intersection with Lincoln Avenue to the western city limit line; a hypothetical roadway from its intersection with Dakota Avenue produced due east to the city limit line. 
(2)  COMMERCIAL STREET: That roadway adjoining the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad Company's right-of-way on the north, Dakota Avenue on the east and running westerly and parallel to the right-of-way to Nebraska Avenue is designated as Commercial Street. 
(3)  MARKET STREET: That roadway adjoining the right-of-way of the C. & N. W. R. R. Co. on the south and running parallel to the right-of-way through the city is designated as Market Street. 
(4)  FIRST STREET SOUTH: That first roadway south of and running on a true parallel with Center Street is designated as First Street South. 
    That part of First Street South, which is west of Dakota Avenue, has its origin as a roadway of Illinois Avenue and is the first roadway south of Market Street at that point. 
    That part of First Street South, which is east of Dakota Avenue, has its origin as a roadway at Frank Avenue and is the first roadway south of and running parallel to Center Street. 
(5)  FIRST STREET NORTH: That roadway first north of Center Street running parallel to the Center Street is designated as First Street North. 
(6)  US HWY 14: That roadway which is dedicated as U.S. Highway No. 14 which extends from the east city limit line produced westerly to the west city limit line and running parallel to and between the 4th Street N.E. and N.W. service roads and intersects S.D. Highway No. 37 at the intersection of Dakota Avenue North and 4th Street North. 
(7)  SUNRISE DRIVE: The roadway running parallel to and one block south of 19th Street S.W. running due east and west between Illinois Avenue and Ohio Avenue S.W. and lying west of Dakota Avenue S. is designated as Sunrise Drive. 
(8)  VAN HALL DRIVE: The roadway running parallel to Illinois Avenue S.W. extended and west of Dakota Avenue So. and commencing at a point midway between 22nd Street and 24th Street S.W. and Wisconsin Ave. S.W. is designated as Van Hall Drive. 
(9)  SOUTH TERRACE DRIVE: The roadway running parallel to Wisconsin Avenue S.W. between 24th Street S.W. and 27th Street S.W. and located west of Highway No. 37 So. and east of Wisconsin Avenue S.W. with entrance and exit on Wisconsin Avenue S.W. and located within the South Terrace Addition is designated as South Terrace Drive. 
(10)  PROSPECT PARK DRIVE: The roadway which extends from Dakota Avenue South to Prospect Park oval proceeding east and midway between 15th Street S.E. and 18th Street S.E. and running parallel to Center Street East is designated as Prospect Park Drive. 
(11)  JEFFERSON BOULEVARD: The roadway which extends from Utah Avenue S.E. and Frank Avenue S.E. between 14th Street S.E. and 15th Street S.E. and running parallel to Center Street East is designated as Jefferson Boulevard. 
(12)  MADISON BOULEVARD: The roadway which extends from Idaho Avenue S.E. to Lawn Ridge Avenue S.E. between 15th Street S.E. and 18th Street S.E. and running parallel to Center Street East is designated as Madison Boulevard. 
(13)  EASY STREET: That roadway, which extends from Jersey Avenue N.E. and located one block north of Center Street and proceeding due west to the east shoreline of Ravine Lake is designated as Easy Street. 
(14)  10TH STREET NE: That roadway adjoining the Great Northern Railroad Company's right-of-way on the south, Dakota Avenue on the west and running easterly and parallel to the railroad right-of-way to the east corporate limits of the city is designated as 10th Street NE. 
(15)  NORTH FRONTIER DRIVE: The roadway running parallel to and one-half block north of 26th Street S.W. and running due east and west through Frontier Acres Addition, and lying west of Lincoln Avenue S.W. 
(16)  SOUTH FRONTIER DRIVE: The roadway running parallel to and one-half block south of 26th Street S.W. and running due east and west through Frontier Acres Addition, and lying west of Lincoln Avenue S.W. 
(17)  PARKSIDE DRIVE: The roadway running parallel to and approximately one-half block south of 29th Street S.W. running east and west between Parkside Addition and Gibbs Park and lying east of Lincoln Avenue S.W. 
(18)  ARROWBEE COURT: The roadway running parallel to and approximately one block north of 21st St. S.E., extending east from Riverview Drive between Lot A and Lot B in Valley View Estates.

(36)  PRAIRIE EAGLE CIRCLE WEST: The west half of the "U" shaped roadway that extends south of 24th Street S.W. from McDonald Drive S.W. for about two and one-half blocks where it intersects with the south end of Prairie Green Drive S.W.

(Ord. 2007 (part), 2005; Ord. 1758, 1995; Ord. 1749, 1995; Ord. 1748, 1995; Ord. 1712, 1993; Ord. 1398, 1980; Ord. 1049, 1972; Ord. 958 (part), 1968: Ord. 867, 1964: Ord. 848 (part), 1964: Ord. 819, 1963: Ord. 798 (part), 1962: Ord. 787, 1962: Ord. 483 § 15.0105, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2109-15-18, 3-26-2012; Ord. No. 2188-15-21, 12-29-2017) 
15.04.080 - Registered plats incorporated by reference. 
    Those plats indicating the names of streets and avenues of the city now on file in the office of the register of deeds of Beadle County, and the office of the engineer of the city, incorporated as a part of this chapter. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0106, 1950). 
Chapter 15.08 - ADDRESS NUMBERING SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to regulate the numbering of houses and lots - See SDC 45.0201(97). 

15.08.010 - Numbering buildings. 
    All buildings fronting the streets and avenues of this city shall bear a distinctive number, posted in a conspicuous place on such buildings; each number to be ascertained in accordance with the plan set forth in the following sections of this chapter. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0301, 1950). 
15.08.020 - Buildings fronting on avenues. 
    Buildings fronting the avenues of this city shall be numbered from Center Street; such numbers shall be zero at Center Street and not to exceed the number 99 at the end of the first blocks either north or south of Center Street, 101 at the beginning and not to exceed the number 199 at the end of the second blocks either north or south of Center Street. Such system shall be followed in numbering buildings on all of the avenues through the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0302, 1950). 
15.08.030 - Buildings fronting on streets. 
    Buildings fronting the streets of this city shall be numbered from Dakota Avenue; such numbers shall be zero at Dakota Avenue and not to exceed the number 99 at the end of the first blocks either east or west from Dakota Avenue; 101 at the beginning and not to exceed the number 199 at the end of the second blocks either east or west of Dakota Avenue. Such system shall be followed in numbering buildings on all of the streets through the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0303, 1950). 
15.08.040 - Determining last numeral in number. 
    Buildings fronting the avenues from the east and fronting streets from the south shall bear even numbers in their last figure. 
    Buildings fronting avenues from the west and fronting streets from the north shall bear odd numbers in their last figure. 
    In blocks containing three hundred fifty feet the unit for determining the last figure of each number shall be eight and one-third feet, thus the first twenty-five feet from the numbering center shall be entitled to use the numbers 1, 3 and 5; on the opposite side of the street the first twenty-five feet shall be entitled to use the numbers 2, 4 and 6. 
    In blocks containing five hundred feet the unit for determining the final figure shall be twelve and one-half feet, thus the first twenty-five feet from the center of numbering shall be entitled to use the numbers 1 and 3, or on the opposite side of the street the numbers 2 and 4. 
    No deductions for alleys shall be used in figuring numbers. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0304, 1950). 
Chapter 15.12 - STREET WORK-GENERAL PROVISIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to exercise control over street work-See SDCL § 9-45-1. 

15.12.010 - Dedicated right-of-way width. 
    The dedicated right-of-way width for all streets, avenues, alleys and roadways that are dedicated for public use shall be provided for under the provisions of Section 24.20.020 of this code as a minimum standard for dedicated right-of-way widths in relation to the class of thoroughfare required in any given area of the city. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0401, 1950). 
15.12.020 - Public thoroughfare widths. 
    All public thoroughfares designated as streets, avenues, drives, parkways, alleys or roadways widths shall be established and designed in relation to the class of thoroughfare and volume of traffic to be carried on any of the thoroughfare classifications contained in the provisions of Section 24.20.020 of this code. The widths of the thoroughfares between curb lines for vehicular traffic on the various thoroughfares in the city heretofore established are fixed and established in accordance with the official record of the width of thoroughfares in the city and on file in the office of the city engineer, which record is incorporated herein by reference and is designated and adopted as the official record of the width of all improved thoroughfares in the city. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0402, 1950). 
15.12.030 - Street grades. 
    The grades of the streets in the city heretofore established in accordance with street profiles on file in the office of the engineer are established and designated as the grades of the streets of the city, which profiles are on file as aforesaid in the office of the engineer and the records thereof are incorporated herein by reference and adopted as the official record of the grades of streets in the city. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0403, 1950). 
15.12.040 - Paving, grading, and curbing. 
    The paving, grading and curbing of alleys, streets, avenues or public thoroughfares shall be done under the direct supervision and specifications of the engineer. Such public improvements shall be done strictly in accordance with the specifications therefor adopted by the governing body and are on file in the office of the engineer. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0404, 1950). 
15.12.050 - Interference with contractors. 
    No person shall interfere with or obstruct any person in carrying out in a lawful manner any lawful contract entered into with the city for paving, grading, or constructing sidewalks or curbs or any other public improvements or public works. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0405, 1950). 
15.12.060 - Hindering street improvements. 
    No person shall hinder or obstruct the street commissioner or any employees of the city in lawfully making any improvements in any street or on any public thoroughfare or ground nor shall any person without proper authority tear up, break or injure any pavement, crosswalk, sidewalk or other improvement in any street or public ground. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0406, 1950). 
15.12.070 - Duties of engineer. 
    The duties of the engineer shall include the preparing of all plans and specifications for and supervision over all contract work ordered by the governing body relating to sewerage, street and alley grading, paving, curb and sidewalk construction, sewer and water connections, and such other public improvement works as the governing body may designate. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0410, 1950). 
15.12.080 - Restoring pavements or street surfacing to former condition. 
    It shall be the duty of the engineer to keep on file all copies of permits issued hereunder and to inspect from time to time all pavement, or other street surfacing, disturbed pursuant to such permits. If such payments or surfacing are not restored as nearly as possible to the original condition by the permittee, notice thereof in writing by regular mail shall be given the permittee, who shall put the same in good condition within ten days. If the permittee fails after notice given to restore such pavement or the surface thereof, the commissioner of streets may make the necessary repairs and such permittee shall pay the cost thereof, and until he pays the same no other permit shall be issued to him or to any person in his behalf. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0411, 1950). 
15.12.090 - Liability policy or surety bond required to be furnished. 
    No person, firm, corporation, contractor, licensee or utility company, herein called contractor, other than the city, shall be granted any permit, license or contract or be permitted or authorized, except as otherwise provided herein, to grade, pave, surface, curb, excavate, make openings, break or cut any curb or pavement, install or work on sewer mains or sewer connections, install or work on water mains or water connections, erect or work on any telephone or telegraph lines or poles, install or work on any gas mains, construct, reconstruct or repair sidewalks, store building materials, erect or maintain barricades in connection with construction work, or perform any contract for a public improvement or do any public improvement work in, upon, under or over any street, avenue, alley, public way, park or other public place within the city without first securing and filing with the city auditor a policy or policies or certificate of standard form contractor's public liability and property damage insurance issued by an insurance company or companies duly authorized to do business in South Dakota covering such work and activities proposed to be done in such public places, which policy or policies shall protect such contractor and the city against liability to others for bodily injuries, including death, with limits of not less than twenty thousand dollars for one person and not less than forty thousand dollars for any one accident, and not less than five thousand dollars for property damage resulting from any one accident proximately caused or contributed to by the negligence or lack of care of such contractor or his employees in carrying on, safeguarding or properly completing such work, or resulting from the unsafe condition in the public streets and places caused by doing such work; or in lieu of such insurance the contractor may secure and file a surety bond covering such liability issued by a surety company duly authorized to do business in this state. The governing body may require such additional or further liability coverage as in its discretion seems necessary upon consideration of the nature and extent of the work to be performed. No such work shall be done by the contractor until such liability insurance policy or bond is so filed and is approved by the governing body. All requirements for the furnishing of performance bonds by such contractors shall remain in full force and effect but any other requirements for the furnishing of liability insurance or bonds by such contractors are superseded by the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0414, 1950). 
15.12.092 - Culverts under private driveways. 
(a)  The owner of any premises within the city where a new driveway is to be installed, which would restrict the flow of runoff in a ditch, shall be required to install a culvert under the driveway. The elevation and size of the culvert shall be established by the city engineer and the culvert shall be installed under the engineer's direction. 
(b)  Culverts under private drives, which are damaged or restricted to the point where they restrict the flow of runoff sufficiently to cause potential damage to roadways or property, shall be repaired or replaced by the owner. 
(c)  The city will furnish the culverts if the culverts were installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section and the restriction is due to the culvert being undersized. The city will only furnish the replacement culvert for these undersized culverts if approved by the city engineer prior to installation. The owner shall have the culvert replaced and pay for the cost of replacement. 
(d)  The city engineer, upon becoming aware of a damaged or restricted culvert and after inspection thereof, shall give written notice to owner to repair or replace the culvert. The owner shall be given ten days to correct the problem if there is an immediate threat to roadways or property. If the threat is not immediate the property owner shall be given thirty days to correct the problem. If the problem has not been corrected by the date given in the notice to the owner, the city shall have the problem corrected and the costs shall be filed with the finance officer. The costs shall be defined as the actual costs plus the sum of fifty dollars for administrative costs. 
(e)  The finance officer shall cause a statement of the costs of the abatement of the problem to be served upon the owner, agent of the owner, lessee, occupant or person in possession of the parcel of land for which the driveway and culvert are providing access. The notice may be given personally or by first class mail addressed to the last known address of the owner as shown on the director of equalization's records. Notice shall be given that if the costs are not paid upon receipt of the statement, the city may levy the costs as a special assessment against the property. 
(Ord. 1800, 1997). 
15.12.100 - Penalty for violations. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided, any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this title, or failing to comply with the provisions thereof, shall upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars nor more than one hundred dollars or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 1233 (part), 1976; Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0418, 1950). 
Chapter 15.16 - STREET EXCAVATIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to regulate the making of openings and connections in streets-See SDC 45.0201(79), (94). 
Cross reference- Sewer connections-See Ch. 2104 of this code. 

15.16.010 - Permit required. 
    No person shall make or cause to be made any excavation in or under any street, parking, sidewalk, alley, or public ground or remove any earth, soil, paving, gravel, or material therefrom, without first having obtained a permit therefor as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0801, added by Ord. 644; January 1, 1956). 
15.16.020 - Application and bonds. 
    Application for such permit shall be made to the city auditor, who shall secure the approval of the commissioner of streets and public property before issuing any such permit. Such application shall be accompanied by a fee of five dollars, which amount shall be considered compensation to the city for the granting of such permit and the necessary investigation prior thereto. In addition to the hereinbefore described fee, the applicant shall deposit with the city auditor not less than twenty-five dollars or such larger sum as deemed necessary by the commissioner of streets to insure the replacement and refilling of any such excavation. In lieu of such deposits, a bond for the same purpose in the amount of one thousand dollars to be approved by the governing body may be given covering all excavations for the year for which such bond is given. Before any such permit is issued, the person requiring the same shall state in his application therefor where such excavation is to be made, the extent thereof, in front of what lot or lots, for what purpose said excavation is to be made, and whether or not such person has a bond on file with the auditor for making such excavation. If such applicant has not filed such bond, then before a permit shall be issued, such applicant shall furnish a bond or make the deposit as above provided with the city auditor as a guaranty for the proper refilling of and guarding against such trenches and excavations while in the course of excavating or refilling and the maintenance of the same in good condition for one year thereafter. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0802, added by Ord. 644; January 1, 1956). 
15.16.030 - Deposit forfeited. 
    If at any time within one year after the issuance of the permit referred to in this chapter the city engineer shall find that the work for which the bond deposit was made does not stand a satisfactory test or has not been properly refilled, he shall notify the depositor in writing that the work must be put in satisfactory condition within three days, and if the depositor fails to comply with the terms of such notice, then the city engineer shall have authority to cause such work to be put in proper and satisfactory condition and charge the expense thereof to the sum deposited. The balance unexpended at the expiration of one year from date of such permit shall upon order of the city commission be returned by the treasurer to the depositor. 
    In cases where a deposit is put up for all work done by any person as provided in this chapter, the city engineer shall have power to cause the repairing or refilling of any excavations made by such person if he fails to do so upon three days written notice, and the expense thereof shall be charged to his deposit, and such depositor shall immediately replenish such deposit to the original amount. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0803, added by Ord. 644; January 1, 1956). 
15.16.040 - Supervision of excavations. 
    The city engineer under the general direction of the commissioner of streets shall supervise all excavations made for any purpose in the streets, alleys, or public grounds, and he shall require that all excavations be backfilled in the manner specified. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0804, added by Ord. 644; January 1, 1956). 
15.16.050 - Guarding excavations. 
    Any person receiving a permit to make excavations in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, public thoroughfare or grounds shall, during the progress and continuance of the work, erect and maintain around the same both day and night suitable guards, fences, lanterns and signals so as to prevent injury to persons, animals, or vehicles on account of such excavations. Such lanterns shall be kept lighted from sundown until sunrise. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0408, added by Ord. 831; August 26, 1963). 
15.16.060 - Interfering with barricades. 
    No person shall move, interfere with, break, destroy, or carry away any barricades or lanterns used by the city or any contractor in guarding unsafe or dangerous places in the maintenance or repair of streets or in any lawful work being carried on by the city or contractor. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0409, added by Ord. 831; August 26, 1963). 
15.16.070 - Refilling excavations. 
    Any person or firm making such excavations and having completed the purpose for which the excavation was made, shall notify the city engineer that the excavation is ready for refilling and when authorized by the city engineer to proceed with the refilling operation, the person or firm shall promptly and without delay refill the excavation under the provisions provided herein. 
    In refilling any excavation, the earth shall be compacted to a density equaling that of the undisturbed and original material adjacent to said excavation. The required degree of compaction shall be obtained by backfilling in accordance with that procedure of the two procedures listed hereinafter that is most adaptable to the material to be replaced in said excavation. 
    Procedure No. 1- The backfill material shall be inundated and when necessary to obtain proper compaction, mechanical vibration shall be used. 
    Procedure No. 2- The backfill material shall be placed in six inch layers each of which shall be individually mechanically tamped. The moisture content of the backfill material shall be adjusted when necessary. 
    The engineer shall specify which procedure is the most adaptable method for use in the placement of backfill material in each excavation. 
    Excavations shall be backfilled in such a manner that all the earth shall be replaced in the excavation, leaving the surface in its original condition, except where excavations have been made in the driving areas of any avenue, street, alley or driveway, the backfill shall be replaced with a minimum of eight inches in depth of compacted gravel from the original surface, and the original excess dirt shall be removed and disposed of by the excavator and the excavator will be responsible for keeping excavations full until the street department has available time and materials to finish these excavations with gravel, black top or cement. 
    In making connection to fire hydrants for flushing excavations, all rules and regulations of the water department relating thereto, shall be observed. 
    In all cases where excavations are made in the paved district, the earth and gravel shall be replaced in the manner above specified, and the pavement shall be replaced by the department of streets. 
(Ord. 1685, 1992: Ord. 981, 1970: Ord. 810, 1963: Ord. 723, 1959: Ord. 644, 1956: Ord. 483 § 15.0806, 1950). 
15.16.080 - Cutting pavements. 
    Where it is necessary to cut the street pavement in making any street excavation, there shall be deposited with the finance officer before permit is issued, an amount designated by resolution of the governing board, on a per square yard basis of pavement removed. The deposit shall be credited to the permanent street fund and be used by the department of streets in replacing the pavement. 
(Ord. 1123 (part), 1974: Ord. 981, 1970: Ord. 644, 1956; Ord. 483 § 15.0807, 1950). 
15.16.090 - Excavations near streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person, owner, or occupant of any lot to make or cause to be made any excavation on the lot adjacent to any street, alley, public thoroughfare or grounds, or travelled road, or roadway, except the same be securely guarded so as to prevent the injury of any person or animal passing upon or along the same. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0407, 1950). 
Chapter 15.20 - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities granted power to regulate use of land for trade, industry, residence, or other purposes for purpose of promoting public health, safety, morals, or the general welfare - See SDC 45.2601. 
Cross reference- Sidewalk construction may be required in subdivision - See Ch. 24.48 of this code. 

15.20.010 - Necessity of sidewalks. 
    All new dwellings constructed in the residential area and business structures in the business area of the city shall be required to install concrete sidewalks fronting and abutting the real property on which said structures are located within six months after completion of construction of the structure and in accordance with the provisions contained in the sections of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1757 (part), 1995: Ord. 790, 1962: Ord. 438 § 15.0601, 1950). 
15.20.012 - Waiving of necessity for sidewalks. 
    If due to surface drainage and street design it is not practical to install sidewalks, the city engineer may waive the requirement to install public sidewalks. At such time as street design and surface drainage change that makes the installation of sidewalks practical, the new sidewalk shall be installed within six months by the present owner of the property. 
(Ord. 1757 (part), 1995). 
15.20.020 - Location. 
    All sidewalks installed in the residential areas shall be located by the city engineer within the area which lies between the property lot line and five feet back from the established curb line. 
    No curb line sidewalk shall be constructed without special permission from the governing body. 
    All residential property plats, platted into blocks and/or lots must be accompanied by an instrument designating the proposed location of the sidewalks to be installed within the platted area with the submission of said plat to the Huron planning commission and the governing body for approval. 
(Ord. 1757 (part), 1995: Ord. 864-15-1, 1964: Ord. 790 (part), 1962; prior Ord. 483 § 15.0602). 
15.20.030 - Sidewalk and driveway construction and supervision. 
    The building and construction of all sidewalks and driveways within the streets shall be done under the direct supervision of the commissioner of streets and the city engineer. 
(Ord. 790 (part), 1962; Ord. 483 § 15.0603). 
15.20.040 - Construction specifications. 
    The construction of all sidewalks and driveways whether it be done by direct contract with the city or by contract with the owners of real property abutting said sidewalk or driveway, shall be done strictly in accordance with specifications for sidewalks and driveways as adopted by the governing body and on file in the office of the city engineer. The commissioner of streets and/or the city engineer shall have full power to condemn work and material not in accordance with the requirements of said specifications. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0604, as amended by Ord. 790; June 25, 1962). 
15.20.050 - Construction permit required. 
    Before any sidewalk or driveway is constructed within the City of Huron by any contractor or other person for the owners of real property fronting and abutting said sidewalk or driveway, said contractor or other person must first secure a permit therefor from the city engineer and must comply with all of the provisions of this chapter. The construction of all sidewalks and driveways shall be according to lines and grades furnished and established by the city engineer. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0605, as amended by Ord. 790; June 25, 1962). 
15.20.060 - Bond required of contractors and other persons. 
    Before any contractor or other person shall receive a permit for the construction or installation of more than one sidewalk and/or driveway for other parties or for private purposes within the streets of the City of Huron, he must first execute a guaranty bond in the sum of one thousand dollars covering all work to be done during the period of one year. Said bond shall be issued and signed by some surety company, approved by the governing body, and filed in the city auditor's office. All such bonds shall provide that the contractor or other persons constructing or installing such sidewalks or driveways shall replace sidewalks or driveways constructed by him at any time within a period of three years from time of completion of said sidewalks or driveways, which in the opinion of the city engineer was not laid in accordance with the required specifications on file in the city engineer's office at the time of said construction or installation. 
    If any person desires to install or construct a sidewalk or driveway within the streets and which is fronting and abutting their property owned or occupied by said person, application for a permit shall be made as provided in Section 15.20.050. Before issuance of such permit such person must first execute a guarantee agreement in such form as may be provided by the City of Huron, which guarantee agreement shall be in an amount equal to the city engineer's estimated standard construction cost of the sidewalk or driveway to be constructed. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0606, as amended by Ord. 790; June 25, 1962). 
15.20.070 - Width and thickness of sidewalks and driveways. 
A.  RESIDENCE DISTRICT. The width of all sidewalks in the residence district shall be established by the city engineer and none shall be less than four feet in width, and four inches thick, with cut joints every four feet, and expansion joints every twenty-five feet, such expansion joints to be composed of materials and thickness as approved by the city engineer. 
B.  BUSINESS DISTRICT. All sidewalks in the business district, and in front of all places of business, shall extend from the established property line or abutting business structure to the curb line unless otherwise approved by the city engineer and shall be four inches thick, cut into convenient sections at least two inches deep throughout, with expansion joints every twenty-five feet and adjoining brick or stone walls, such joints to be composed of such materials and thickness as approved by the city engineer. 
C.  CROSSING DRIVEWAY OR ALLEY. All sidewalks constructed or repaired in the residential or business district which cross or are a part of a driveway or alley, shall be constructed six inches thick, with expansion joints of a material and thickness approved by the city engineer, shall be installed at all abutting curbs, sidewalks, driveways and structures. 
D.  DRIVEWAYS. All driveways constructed or repaired within the streets of the City of Huron shall be no less than six inches thick or four inches thick reinforced with a minimum of six inch by six inch, number six gauge wire reinforcing mesh, and the width shall be as set forth in the latest driveway standards on file in the office of the city engineer. Expansion joints of a material and thickness as approved by the city engineer shall be installed at all abutting curbs, sidewalks or structures. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0607, as amended by Ord. 790; June 25, 1962). 
15.20.080 - Plans and specifications. 
    All material proportions, slope of forms, placing and finishing of materials, edging and jointing, subgrade preparation, etc., for all sidewalk and driveway construction in the street right-of-way of the City of Huron shall be done in conformance with the latest plans and specifications on file in the office of the city engineer. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0608, as amended by Ord. 790; June 25, 1962). 
15.20.090 - Inspection. 
(a)  The contractor or other person doing the work shall make the construction available for inspection by the city engineer or his authorized inspector at all times, and the city shall have the right to take whatever samples of material deemed necessary by the city engineer to determine the quality of the work. 
(b)  The contractor or other person doing the work shall call for an inspection by the city engineer or his authorized inspector at the time the forms are set but prior to pouring of the materials, to ascertain that the proper grades, slopes, widths, and thickness have been provided and established and request a final inspection after all work has been completed, and additional inspections shall be permitted at such times as ordered by the city engineer or his authorized inspector. Any workmanship or materials not in compliance with the provisions of this chapter or city engineer's specifications shall be corrected or replaced immediately as ordered by the city engineer. 
(Ord. 790 (part), 1962: Ord. 483 § 15.0609, 1950). 
15.20.100 - Imprinting contractor's name and date. 
    The contractor shall mark the surface of the walk with a suitable stamp bearing his name and the year of construction, when requested by the city engineer. Such stamp shall be placed at each end of the walk, and at intervals of not more than one hundred fifty feet. 
(Ord. 790 (part), 1962: Ord. 483 § 15.0610, 1950). 
15.20.110 - Curb and gutter construction. 
    All curbs and gutters hereafter constructed shall be built according to the plans and specifications on file in the office of the city engineer. 
(Ord. 790 (part), 1962: Ord. 483 § 15.0611, 1950). 
15.20.112 - Wheelchair ramp-Required. 
    All sidewalk, curb and gutter construction, improvement or replacement at all crosswalks in both business and residential areas shall include a ramp so as to make the movement from the street to the sidewalk easily negotiable for handicapped persons in wheelchairs. 
(Ord. 1226 (part), 1976). 
15.20.114 - Wheelchair ramp-Specifications. 
    All ramps mentioned in Section 15.20.112 shall be built according to plans and specifications on file in the office of the city engineer. 
(Ord. 1226 (part), 1976). 
15.20.120 - Repair, removal or defacing curbing. 
    It is unlawful for any person to remove, cut into, or deface in any manner, any portion of an existing curb, for the purpose of providing a drive-in or for any other reason, without first obtaining a written permission to proceed from the city engineer. Such construction shall be under the direction of the city engineer, and according to plans furnished by said city engineer. 
(Ord. 790 (part), 1962: Ord. 483 § 15.0612, 1950). 
15.20.130 - Duty and notice to improve defective sidewalk. 
    Any sidewalk, parkway, driveway or curb which has been deemed defective, unsafe or hazardous by the city engineer is declared a nuisance. It shall be the duty of the owner or the agent in charge, or the tenant of the property abutting on any street, avenue, public alley, place, square, section or part thereof along which a sidewalk, curb or driveway is ordered by the governing body to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired, to make all improvements stated in the notice within thirty days from the receipt of said notice from the governing body. 
(Ord. 790 (part), 1962: Ord. 483 § 15.0613, 1950). 
15.20.140 - Notice to owners to construct sidewalk-Work done by city. 
A.  NOTICE. Whenever the governing body shall deem it necessary to construct, rebuild or repair any sidewalk or driveway, it shall notify all owners of lots adjoining and abutting such sidewalk or driveway to construct, rebuild or repair the same at their own expense within the time designated. Such notice shall be in writing and either be served personally on each said owner, or by publication once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official newspaper of the City of Huron. It shall set forth the character of the work and the time within which it shall be done. Such notice may be general as to the owners, but must be specific as to the description of such lots, parts of lots or parcels of land. 
B.  RESOLUTION OF NECESSITY. The failure of any owner, or the agent of any owner, or the tenant to construct, reconstruct or repair any such sidewalk, or driveway ordered to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired by the governing body shall be deemed a misdemeanor and permit the governing body to proceed with a resolution of necessity for sidewalk improvements in accordance with S.D.C. - 1939 and supplements thereto, Chapter 45.1603. 
(Ord. 790 (part), 1962: Ord. 483 § 15.0614, 1950). 
Chapter 15.24 - STREET AND SIDEWALK USE REGULATIONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to regulate and prevent the placing of ashes, dirt, garbage, or any offensive matter in any street or public ground or in any stream or body of water within the municipality - See SDC 45.0201(38); Municipalities authorized to regulate and prohibit the use of streets, sidewalks, and public grounds for signs, sign posts, awnings, etc. - See SDC 45.0201(43); Municipalities authorized to regulate the use of sidewalks, streets, alleys, etc. to prevent injury and to regulate or prevent any practice having a tendency to annoy persons using the same - See SDC 45.0201(44); Municipalities empowered to require the owner of abutting property to remove snow and ice from sidewalks - See SDC 45.0201(45); Municipalities authorized to require railroad companies to make, keep open, repair and maintain crossings and ditches - See SDC 45.0201(93); Cities authorized to require railroad companies to keep flagmen and maintain lights at railroad crossing of streets - See SDC 45.0202(9).

15.24.010 - Ashes, dirt or waste materials on streets or in water. 
    No person shall place, throw, or deposit, or cause to be placed, thrown, or deposited any dirt, ashes, cinders, refuse, garbage, offal, leaves, branches or any offensive or waste material or matter in any street, alley, public thoroughfare or grounds or into any stream or body of water or upon the banks of any stream or body of water in such proximity that such substance may be washed into the stream or body of water within the city or under control of the city. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0412, 1950). 
15.24.020 - Vehicles or obstructions in streets. 
    No contractor, firm or person shall place, leave or keep on any street, road, alley, sidewalk, public thoroughfare or grounds any vehicle, except when the same shall be in actual use or parked as provided by the traffic ordinances, or any other article, substance, or material which may obstruct the free use of such street, road, alley, sidewalk, public thoroughfare or grounds. 
(Ord. 831 (part), 1963: Ord. 483 § 15.0413, 1950). 
15.24.030 - Obstructions and water discharge. 
    The streets, alleys and sidewalks shall be kept free and clean of all obstruction and encumbrances for the use of the public, and it is unlawful for any person, company or corporation to encumber, obstruct or cause to be encumbered or obstructed any street, alley, boulevard or sidewalk in the city by placing therein or thereon any building material or any article or thing whatsoever, or by discharging water upon or across any street, alley or sidewalk without first having obtained the permission of the commissioner of streets and public property or where otherwise authorized by this code. 
(Ord. 1507, 1984: Ord. 523, 1952: Ord. 483 § 15.0703, 1950). 
15.24.040 - Carts on sidewalks. 
    It is unlawful for the owner of any cart, wheelbarrow or other vehicle except baby carriages to push or draw them or cause them to be pushed or drawn upon any of the sidewalks of the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0704, 1950). 
15.24.050 - Removing snow from sidewalks. 
    Any owner, tenant or occupant of any property must remove all snow and ice from any sidewalk upon their property within 48 hours after any snowfall, snow or ice accumulation so that sidewalks are clean and safe for pedestrians for safe and convenient foot travel. Snow and ice must also be removed from that portion of the sidewalk which ends at an intersection or crosswalk, including the curb ramp. Any owner, tenant or occupant of property abutting sidewalks on two intersecting streets must remove all snow and ice from the sidewalks of both streets, regardless of the source of the snow accumulation. Snow and ice deposited on the sidewalk from the street snow removal process must also be removed within 48 hours of being deposited. Failure to remove snow and ice from a sidewalk in accordance with this section constitutes an ordinance violation. 
    In the event ice has so formed upon a sidewalk that it cannot be removed, then the owner, tenant or occupant must use sand, salt or other suitable substance in such manner as to prevent the ice from being dangerous until such time as it can be removed. Snow and ice which is removed from a sidewalk may be placed on the boulevard or yard. It is unlawful for any person to dispose of or move snow from a sidewalk or other private property onto a public street, alley or sidewalk. 
    Any owner, tenant or occupant of a building, lot or land bordering any street within the city where there is a curbside sidewalk outside of the core area, shall within forty-eight (48) hours after a snow accumulation event cause a path at least forty-eight (48) inches in width to be cleared and the path shall be located within five feet and parallel to the existing sidewalk on the yard side of the sidewalk. Said path shall be cleared to allow continuous pedestrian traffic across the lot. 
    Any owner, tenant, or occupant of a building, lot, or land bordering any street, within the core area of the city where there is a sidewalk shall comply with these provisions within twenty-four (24) hours after a snow accumulation event. Such snow may be deposited in the parking space(s) adjacent to the sidewalk within only first the twenty-four (24) hours following the snow accumulation event. 
    Any owner, tenants or occupants as aforesaid failing to comply with the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 1981 (part), 2004: Ord. 1909 (part), 2001: Ord. 483 § 15.0705, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2150-15-20, 11-10-2014) 
15.24.051 - Failure to remove snow-Removal by city. 
(1)  If the property owner, tenants or occupants of any building or lot shall neglect or refuse to comply with Section 15.24.050, the city may at once proceed to clear the sidewalk of snow by the employees of the city, by contract, or otherwise as it may select, and may assess the cost and expense thereof against each lot, lots or a fraction thereof lying along such sidewalk. 
(2)  The cost incurred by the city in removing snow under the provisions of this section shall be reported to the city commission and the same shall be levied as a cost against the abutting property, and shall become due and delinquent, bear the same rate of interest and be sold at the same time and in the same manner as provided for other special assessments. 
(3)  "Costs incurred" shall be defined as the actual expense incurred for abatement of such snow removal plus a graduated noncompliance fee calculated over the calendar year as follows: 
    First violation abated: fifty-dollar noncompliance fee; 
    Second violation abated: one hundred-dollar noncompliance fee; 
    Third violation abated: one hundred fifty-dollar noncompliance fee; 
    Fourth violation abated: two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee. 
(4)  Any subsequent violations abated by the city within the current calendar year, to be defined for the purposes of this chapter as the twelve-month period starting January 1st and ending December 31st, shall be billed at the two hundred-dollar noncompliance fee rate. The graduated noncompliance fee rate schedule shall apply to any and all violations abated by the city of Huron as allowed in Chapters 9.58, 9.62, 9.64, 11.16 and 15.24 of this code; and all shall be cumulative in calculation of the noncompliance fee. This graduated fee schedule shall become effective on January 1, 2005; shall apply to an individual address, lot, or parcel of real property; and shall be calculated by calendar year except in the case of transfer of ownership. However, the cumulative calculation of the noncompliance fee shall continue in the case of transfers of ownership between immediate family members. ("Immediate family" is defined for the purposes of this chapter as: spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandparent, grandchild, in-law, ward/guardian or cohabiting adult.) 
(5)  In lieu of spreading the costs of such snow removal by a special assessment against the property, in the discretion of the board of city commissioners, after the amount has been billed as a cost against the landowner and if not paid within thirty days, the amount may be recovered in a civil action against the owner or occupant of the property. 
(6)  Right to appeal from building official's determination shall be available as specified in Section 9.58.120 of this code. 
(Ord. 1981 (part), 2004: Ord. 1909 (part), 2001: Ord. 1446, 1982). 
15.24.055 - Disposal of snow. 
    It shall be the duty of the property owner, tenant or person in possession of any public or private driveway, parking lot or parking area outside the core area of the city, to dispose of accumulated snow upon its property in such manner that any snow when removed shall not be deposited upon a sidewalk, or within or upon any public street or alley. No snow within the city may be disposed of in any manner that will obstruct or interfere with the passage or vision of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(Ord. 1444, 1981). 
(Ord. No. 2150-15-20, 11-10-2014) 
15.24.060 - Obstruction by people. 
    It is unlawful for any group of people to collect or gather together on any sidewalk so as to obstruct the free passage thereof, and it shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of such premises and the officers of the city to disperse such gatherings. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0706, 1950). 
15.24.070 - Advertising matter. 
    It is unlawful to paint, draw or affix any posters, signs, advertising matter or devices upon or to any of the sidewalks, boulevards, pavements, telephone, telegraph and electric light poles or lamp posts, or upon any other public property or public buildings, or upon any private property without the consent of the owner of such property, or to place any handbills or other advertising matter in or upon any vehicle while such vehicle is standing or parked upon the public highways of the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0707, 1950). 
15.24.080 - Spitting on sidewalks. 
    It is unlawful for any person to spit or expectorate upon the public sidewalks, street or alley crossings or steps or entrances to buildings within the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0708, 1950). 
15.24.090 - Awnings over sidewalks, height of. 
    It is unlawful for any person to erect any awning over any sidewalk or public thoroughfare within the limits of the city unless such awnings be elevated at least seven feet at the lowest part thereof above the top of the sidewalk, and the awnings shall not project over the sidewalk to exceed three-fourths of the width thereof; they shall be supported without posts, by iron brackets or by iron framework or by an iron and wood framework attached firmly to the building, so as to leave the sidewalk wholly unobstructed thereby. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0709, 1950). 
15.24.100 - Signs, projection over sidewalks. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to place or cause to be placed, or to suspend from any house, shop, store, lot or place, any show bill, show board or sign of any description whatever so that the same shall project from the wall or front of the house, shop, lot or place, more than four feet toward or into the street or over the sidewalk, except electric light signs, which may so project not to exceed sixteen feet. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0710, 1950). 
15.24.110 - Stairways. 
    It is unlawful for owners of lots along Dakota Avenue South from the C. & N.W. right-of-way south to Fifth Street South, and on Third Street South from Iowa Avenue S.E., to Ohio Avenue S.W., and on Fourth Street South between Kansas Avenue S.E., and Illinois Avenue S.W., Second Street South between Kansas Avenue S.E., and Wisconsin Avenue S.W., Wisconsin Avenue S.W., between the C. & N. W. Railroad and Fifth Street South, Kansas Avenue S. E. from the C. & N. W. Railroad to Fifth Street South, in the City of Huron, to construct or to have constructed stairways, stairs or entrances to basement rooms through openings in the sidewalks uponsaid streets and avenues. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0711; April 24, 1950). 
15.24.120 - Stair railings guarding existing stairways. 
    It shall be the duty of all proprietors of property abutting upon Dakota Avenue and Third Street, between the points designated in Section 15.24.110 who have, before the passage and taking effect of the ordinance codified herein, constructed stairs and stairways to basement rooms through openings in the sidewalk upon Dakota Avenue and Third Street, to guard the openings thereof with a good substantial iron railing, and such railing shall not extend out more than three feet from the line of the said avenue or street. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0712; April 24, 1950). 
15.24.130 - Dragging things on streets. 
    No person shall drag over any of the streets and alleys of the city any branches of trees, automobile bodies or other material which shall come in contact with and drag upon such roadway. 
    This section shall not apply to machines used in maintaining said streets and alleys under the supervision of the superintendent of streets. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0715, added by Ord. 604; May 23, 1955). 
15.24.140 - Traction vehicles on paving. 
    No person shall drive, or move, or cause to be driven, or moved, whether by its own power or otherwise, any traction equipment, tractor, or vehicle unless such units are equipped with rubber tired wheels or treads, upon or across any of the paved thoroughfares or public grounds; except where such pavement is constructed of granite blocks, asphaltic pavement, or Portland cement concrete, such traction equipment, tractor or vehicle without rubber tired wheels or treads shall be driven or moved upon planks such as to completely protect the surface of pavement from injury and damage. 
    No person shall drive or move or cause to be driven or moved any such traction equipment, tractor, or vehicles upon or across any of the paved streets without first securing from the engineer a permit therefor, which permit shall designate the thoroughfares upon or across which such units are to be moved and the time when such thoroughfares may be used for such purpose. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0415, added by Ord. 831; August 26, 1963). 
15.24.150 - Railroads-Repair and maintenance of street crossings-Ditches and drains-Lighting and crossing alarms-Procedure to require such improvements-Civil penalty. 
    Any railroad company maintaining or operating any railroad onto or across any thoroughfare within the city shall construct thereat a crossing and shall keep open, maintain and repair all such crossings as required by the city. All such railroads shall make, keep open and repair ditches, drains, sewers, and culverts along and under their tracks, so that drainage of adjacent property shall not be impeded and the right of way shall be properly drained. In all cases where, in the opinion of the governing body, it is necessary for the safety and protection of the public that thoroughfare crossings over railway tracks be lighted or thoroughfare crossing alarms, signs or automatic signals installed to notify the public of approaching trains, the governing body may cause the railroad company over whose line such thoroughfare crosses to install lights, crossing alarms or automatic signals for the purpose of notifying the public of approaching trains in such manner and by such method, as, in the opinion of the governing body, will be most suitable for the protection of the public. 
    Whenever the governing body shall deem it necessary to order the construction, reconstruction or repair of any thoroughfare crossing or of ditches, drains and sewers or the installation of lights, crossing alarms or automatic signals at any crossing it shall declare in a proposed resolution the necessity of such construction, repair or improvement, describing therein the crossing ditch, drain or sewer to be improved and the nature of such improvement and the time and place at which it will meet to consider the adoption of such resolution. Such resolution shall be published once a week for three consecutive weeks prior to the time specified in such resolution for the consideration of the adoption of the same. A copy of such resolution shall also be served upon the railroad company involved at least fifteen days prior to the meeting in the manner provided by law for the service of a summons upon a railroad corporation. At the time of such meeting or hearing or at any adjournment thereof, the governing body shall investigate and consider the matter and shall hear the evidence and testimony of all parties appearing or interested therein. At the conclusion of such hearing, the governing body may reject or adopt such resolution with or without amendment as it shall deem proper. 
    Such resolution shall be published, take effect and be subject to referendum as other resolutions, and upon taking effect a copy of such resolution duly certified by the auditor shall be served upon the railroad company involved in the manner provided by law for the service of a summons upon a railroad corporation. Thereafter, and within twenty days or such longer time as may be granted by the governing body as set forth in such resolution, said railroad company shall do and perform all acts required by such resolution. Any railroad company neglecting to comply with the requirements of any resolution duly enacted in accordance with this section shall be liable to a penalty of twenty-five dollars for each day such neglect shall continue, to be recovered in a civil action in the name of the city and paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. 483 § 15.0416, added by Ord. 831; August 26, 1963). 
15.24.160 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day that the violation continues, and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provision in Section 1.04.130, except for purposes of this chapter any such fine imposed hereunder shall not be less than one hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 1916, 2001). 
Chapter 15.25 - STREET, ALLEY AND PUBLIC GROUND VACATIONS 

15.25.010 - Requirements for vacation. 
(1)  A street, alley, or public ground or any part thereof that is currently being used for public purposes may be considered for vacation by the city commission only after receiving a petition signed by the owners of all land adjacent to the street or alley; or 
(2)  Whenever a street or alley or any part thereof has not been used or traveled as a street or alley at any time during the preceding twenty years, the land may be vacated by the governing body upon application of the owner or owners of all the real property abutting upon both sides thereof. 
(Ord. 2033 (part), 2007). 
15.25.020 - Procedure for requesting vacation. 
(1)  Such petition shall set forth the facts and the reasons for such vacation and shall be accompanied by the existing plat of such street, alley, or public ground proposed to be vacated. Such petition shall be signed by all of the adjacent property owners and shall be verified by the affidavit of such owner or owners or his or their agent or attorney. The verified petition shall be filed at the city planning and inspections office with the filing fee in the amount as set by resolution of the governing board. 
(2)  Any street, alley or public ground that is vacated through this process may be dedicated, at the discretion of the city commission, in perpetuity by the owner(s) to the public as an easement for the installation of any publicly accepted utility(ies). The platting of the area as an easement shall occur at no cost to the city. The entire width and length of the area vacated shall be platted and dedicated as a public easement area. 
(3)  A hearing on the petition shall be held by the city planning commission if the street, alley or other public ground to be vacated is within city limits and shall be held by the joint planning commission if the street, alley or other public ground to be vacated is outside city limits but within the joint jurisdictional planning area. A sign providing notice of the meeting in front of the appropriate planning commission will be placed at each end of the street or alley or part thereof sought to be vacated and upon such other public ground sought to be vacated at such locations which provide reasonable notice of the hearing. The recommendation of the city planning commission will be forwarded to the city commission for consideration and the recommendation of the joint planning commission will be forwarded to the city commission and to the county commission for consideration. 
(4)  Notice of the proposed vacation shall be published once a week for two successive weeks prior to a public hearing being held on said petition by the city commission. The notice shall state that a petition has been filed, briefly state the object of the petition, and the date that the petition will be heard and considered by the governing body. The hearing shall be held not less than ten days from the last publication of the notice. At the public hearing, the city commission will take into consideration any testimony provided by the public, the recommendations of the planning commission and the recommendations of city departments that may have an interest in the proposed vacation. 
(5)  A resolution of vacation shall be published and is subject to referendum. Upon taking effect, a copy of the resolution certified by the city finance officer shall be filed in the office of the register of deeds. 
(6)  If the city commission approves the vacation, the applicant(s) shall have a plat of the vacated area be prepared at no cost to the city, said plat to show new property lines created as a result of said vacation and any utility or other easements upon the area vacated. The plat will be approved through the normal plat approval process and the applicant(s) submitting the petition for vacation shall pay the appropriate fee at the time that the plat is submitted for approval. The applicant(s) is/are required to have the plat recorded at the office of register of deeds, at applicant(s) sole expense, and shall provide the city a copy of the filed plat showing the date, book and page number where the plat may be found in the Beadle County office of the register of deeds. 
(7)  No petition for vacation of a street, alley or other public ground may be submitted and filed with the planning and inspections office less than six months following a denial by the city commission of an identical or substantially similar petition. 
(Ord. 2033 (part), 2007). 
(Ord. No. 2135-15-19, 1-6-2014) 
Chapter 15.28 - MOVING BUILDINGS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ords. 1233, 1160, 592, 578, 487 and Ord. 483 §§ 3.0301 - 3.0306. 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to regulate the use of streets to prevent and remove obstructions and encroachments upon the same, to prevent injury to the same - See SDC 45.0201(44). 
Cross reference- Street and sidewalk use regulations - See Ch. 15.24 of this code; Construction specifications for moved buildings - See Ch. 18.12 of this code; Building regulations - See Title 18 of this code. 

15.28.010 - Moving prohibited without permit. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to move into, along or over any of the streets, alleys or avenues of the city, any building without a permit having first been obtained. 
    Written application for a moving permit shall be made to the building inspector and shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The proposed location to which such building, or part thereof, may be moved; 
(2)  The present location of the building to be moved; 
(3)  At least two photographs of the building concerned, taken from different angles; 
(4)  Dimension of building, width, length and height, and type of construction, frame, masonry, steel, etc.; 
(5)  The moving route as designated by the city engineer; 
(6)  Signature of the applicant, date of application, and name of the bonded mover; 
(7)  That the bond or assurances required by Section 15.28.030 have been approved by the finance officer; 
(8)  A statement that the applicant will cause the building to conform to city building, plumbing and electrical codes and be compatible with other buildings in the proposed move-in area. Completion date for conformity to codes and area shall be no more than one hundred eighty days from date of issuance of the permits. 
(Ord. 1674 (part), 1992). 
15.28.020 - Notice and hearing by city commission. 
    If said building is to be moved to any location within the city, no permit shall be granted until after hearing on such application. Said hearing shall be at a regular meeting of the governing body and after five days notice of such hearing has been given by the building inspector, by posting of not less than one sign of at least nine square feet in area with a white background and black letters at least three inches high, containing notice of the hearing, in a conspicuous place on or near the property to which application is made to move said building. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the moving of a building where the building does not exceed eight feet in width and can be carried on a truck. 
(Ord. 1674 (part), 1992). 
15.28.030 - Bond for movers. 
(a)  Before issuing such permit, the person, firm or corporation who is to move the building shall file in the office of the finance officer a bond to be executed to the city with good and sufficient surety in the sum of not less than three thousand dollars and conditioned for the payment of any damage which said city may be made liable in consequence of the use of any street, alley or avenue for the removal of such building and for any damage which may occur to any street, alley or avenue on account of the removal of such building, and the payment of any penalty that may be incurred by such person, firm or corporation, his, their or its agents, for the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation in the business of moving buildings may file their bond in the sum of three thousand dollars for one year covering all buildings moved by them, subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  The city finance officer may accept cash security in lieu of the required bond. 
(Ord. 1674 (part), 1992). 
15.28.040 - Removing telephone wires, etc. 
    and planking streets. Any person, firm or corporation to whom a permit for moving buildings is granted, shall see that all telegraph, telephone or electric wires or poles are removed when necessary and replaced in good order, and shall be liable for the costs of the same; and necessary trimming of any trees or branches en route shall be done or supervised by the forestry department of the city, who shall be notified by the mover of such need; and such person, firm or corporation engaged in moving buildings shall plank all streets, alleys and avenues which are paved in such ways as to fully protect such paving or pavement from damage, and any damage to any sidewalk, pole or other city property, including the city roadways, caused by any person, firm or corporation moving the building, shall be repaired by the city, or his or their sureties, shall be liable for the same. 
(Ord. 1674 (part), 1992). 
15.28.050 - Building not to remain on streets. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to allow any building for which a removal permit shall be obtained, to remain upon, occupy or stand upon, any street, avenue, alley or sidewalk. 
(b)  Warning lights shall be displayed at night on buildings being moved while such buildings are standing upon the streets or alleys of the city. 
(Ord. 1674 (part), 1992). 
15.28.060 - City may move building. 
    Whenever the person, firm or corporation moving a building upon or along any street, avenue or alley shall wilfully or negligently permit such building, while in transit, to remain upon the street, avenue, alley or sidewalk, the street commissioner shall have the authority and is authorized to move said building from the street, avenue, alley or sidewalk to any point or place in the city where the same shall not obstruct travel or inconvenience the public, and he shall keep an account of the expense of such removal, and said person, firm or corporation and the sureties on the bond filed, as required by the provisions of this chapter, shall be liable to the city for such expense and the same shall be collected in any court having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 1674 (part), 1992). 
15.28.070 - Conforming to codes. 
    All moved buildings to be located within or relocated within the city limits shall be brought into compliance with the building code, housing code, plumbing code and electrical code in existence at the time the building or buildings are located or relocated. The foundation and/or basement on which the moved or relocated building will rest shall be complete and ready to accept the building prior to moving said building from the present location to the proposed location. A maximum of one hundred eighty days from date of issue of the moving permit, and other permits issued at the time of the moving permit, shall be allowed for complete compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. 1674 (part), 1992). 
15.28.080 - Fee for permit for moving building. 
    The fee for a permit to move a building into, along or over any of the streets, alleys or avenues of the city shall be ten dollars for sheds over one hundred twenty square feet and wider than eight feet, fifteen dollars for garages, and thirty dollars for houses and other buildings. 
(Ord. 1674 (part), 1992). 
15.28.090 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and each such person is guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter is committed, continued or permitted, and upon conviction of any such violation such person is punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or by imprisonment for not more than thirty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 1674 (part), 1992). 
Title 16 - TRAFFIC 
Chapter 16.04 - DEFINITIONS 

16.04.010 - Generally. 
    Terms used in this title unless the context otherwise plainly requires, shall have the meanings set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101 (part), 1950). 
16.04.020 - Business district. 
    The term "business district" means that area defined as business and industrial district in Title 23 of this code. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(a), 1950). 
16.04.030 - Private road or driveway. 
    The term "private road" or "driveway" means every road or driveway not open to the use of the public for vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(b), 1950). 
16.04.040 - Street. 
    The term "street" means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained by the municipality for purposes of vehicular travel, including but not limited to such areas designated as avenues or drives, when any part thereof is open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(Ord. 1379, 1979: Ord. 483 § 16.0101(c), 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2115-16-85, adopted June 25, 2012, amended § 16.04.040 title to read as herein set out. Former § 16.04.040 title pertained to street, roadway and highway. 
16.04.050 - Curb. 
    The word "curb" means the extreme edge or lateral boundary of a street, whether marked by curbing or not so marked. 
(Ord. 1381, 1979: Ord. 483 § 16.0101(d), 1950). 
16.04.060 - Intersection. 
    The word "intersection" means the area embraced within the prolongation of the lateral curblines or, if none, then of the lateral boundary lines of two or more streets or roadways which join one another at an angle, whether or not one such street or roadway crosses the other. 
(Ord. 1380, 1979: Ord. 483 § 16.0101(e) 1950). 
16.04.070 - Sidewalk. 
    The word "sidewalk" means a paved walkway on municipally owned property for pedestrian traffic. 
(Ord. 1910, 2001: Ord. 483 § 16.0101(f), 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.04.075 - Boulevard. 
    The street right-of way area owned by the municipality between the edge of the curb, or edge of the street if there is no curb, and the property line of the adjacent property. 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.04.080 - Crosswalk. 
    The word "crosswalk" means that portion of a street ordinarily included within the prolongation of curb and property lines at intersections, whether or not marked, or any other portion of a street clearly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(g), 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.04.090 - Vehicle. 
    The word "vehicle" means every device, motorized and nonmotorized in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public street, except devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks; for the purpose of this title, a bicycle or a ridden animal shall be deemed a vehicle. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(h), 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.04.100 - Motor vehicle. 
    The term "motor vehicle" means every vehicle which is self-propelled. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(i), 1950). 
16.04.110 - Pedestrian. 
    The word "pedestrian" means any person afoot. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(j), 1950). 
16.04.120 - Driver. 
    The word "driver" means every person who drives, or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(k), 1950). 
16.04.130 - Department. 
    The word "department" means the police department of the city unless clearly shown otherwise. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(1), 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.04.140 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2115-16-85, adopted June 25, 2012, repealed § 16.04.140, which pertained to right-of-way and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0101(m), adopted 1950. 
16.04.150 - Parking. 
    The word "parking" means the standing of a vehicle, whether attended or unattended otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading, or in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(n), 1950). 
16.04.160 - Double parking. 
    The term "double parking" means the standing of a vehicle upon a street at the rear of another vehicle which is parked diagonally at the curb, or along the side of another vehicle which is parked parallel at the curb. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(o), 1950). 
16.04.170 - Authorized emergency vehicle. 
    The term "authorized emergency vehicles" means vehicles of the fire department, police vehicles, ambulances and such emergency vehicles as are designated or authorized by the governing body. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0101(p), 1950). 
Chapter 16.08 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to regulate traffic upon the streets and sidewalks and in public places - See SDC 45.0201(42); Certain restrictions imposed upon control of motor vehicles by local authorities - See SDC 44.0334 and sections cited therein; Procedure for appearance upon arrest set out by statute - See SDC 44.05. 
Cross reference- Duty of police to enforce traffic laws - See Ch. 3.12 of this code; Officers and employees - See Ch. 2.08 of this code. 

16.08.010 - Obedience to traffic ordinances, signals and markings. 
    No person shall violate any rule, regulation, traffic direction, sign, or marking adopted, prescribed, or established in accordance with the provisions of this title, unless otherwise directed by a police officer or other person authorized by law to direct traffic. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0114, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2143-16-89, 5-5-2014) 
16.08.020 - Obedience to police. 
    No person shall refuse or fail to comply with any lawful order, signal, or direction of a police officer. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0115, 1950). 
16.08.030 - Police to direct traffic. 
    Police officers shall direct all traffic in conformance with traffic laws, ordinances and regulations provided that in the event of a fire or other emergency, or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police or fire department may direct traffic as conditions may require. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0117, 1950). 
16.08.040 - Construction and maintenance of crossing signal devices. 
    No one except the city shall construct, operate, or maintain upon or in any of the streets any crossing signal or device of any kind or character to regulate or direct motor vehicle traffic upon the streets except upon authority given by the city by resolution. All such signals or devices shall be so constructed that the base or standard supporting such signal or device shall be at the right side of such street and to one side of the paved, graveled or graded portion thereof, so as not to interfere in any manner with any traffic upon such highway. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0118, 1950). 
16.08.050 - Traffic control devices-Traffic engineering. 
(a)  The department shall place and maintain automatic traffic control devices or signals as required under the ordinances or as approved by resolution of the governing body. 
(b)  In order to make effective and carry out the provisions of the traffic ordinances and laws and to guide, warn, and regulate traffic, the department may maintain such additional traffic control devices, signs, and markings, not including automatic traffic control devices, as may be deemed necessary. 
(c)  The department shall determine the proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices, conduct engineering analyses of accidents, remedial measures, conduct engineering investigation of traffic conditions, and cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions. 
(d)  The city engineer shall have charge of installing automatic traffic control devices and shall cooperate with the department at all times in traffic regulation, in conducting engineering analyses of accidents and engineering investigation of traffic conditions. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0102, 1950). 
16.08.060 - Crosswalks, safety zones, and traffic lanes. 
(a)  The department may designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in its opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as it may deem necessary.
