(b)  The department may establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as it may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(c)  The department may mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as it may deem advisable consistent with the traffic ordinances. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0103, 1950). 
16.08.070 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.08.070 which pertained to markers indicating method of "U" turns and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0104, adopted in 1950. 
16.08.080 - Quiet zones. 
(a)  Fourth Street Southeast between Kansas Avenue and a point two hundred feet east of Iowa Avenue and Iowa Avenue Southeast between Fifty Street and a point two hundred feet north of Fourth Street are hereby designated quiet zones. The department shall designate such zones by placing a sign or marker at either end thereof. 
(b)  The department may temporarily establish a zone of quiet upon any street where a person is seriously ill, if requested so to do by the written statement of a registered physician certifying to its necessity. Such temporary zone of quiet shall embrace all territory within a radius of two hundred feet of the building occupied by the person named in the request of said physician. Such temporary zone of quiet and any other zone of quiet declared by any ordinance shall be designated by placing at a conspicuous place in the street a sign or marker bearing the words "Quiet Zone." 
(c)  In any "quiet zone," no person shall create any noise that can be heard for more than fifty (50) feet from the source. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0105, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2143-16-89, 5-5-2014) 
16.08.090 - No parking signs. 
(a)  The department may erect signs indicating no parking upon one or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property or public property when such parking would in its opinion interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(b)  The department may determine and designate by proper no parking signs located at either end of a block, or within a block, distances between which or places where the stopping or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(c)  When signs are erected as provided in paragraph (a) or (b) of this section, no person shall stop or park a vehicle at such designated places. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0106, 1950; Ord. 673, 1957). 
16.08.100 - Signs at through highways and at reduced speed intersections. 
(a)  The department shall place and maintain a stop sign on each and every street intersecting a designated through street. 
(b)  The department may designate intersections where particular hazard exists upon other than through streets and determine whether vehicles shall stop at one or more entrances to any such intersection, and shall erect a stop sign at every such place where a stop is required; or if the department determines that reduced speed rather than a stop is adequate for safe operation at such intersection it may erect a "slow" sign, or it may determine such safe speed and erect signs upon approaches to such intersection giving notice of such speed. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0107, 1950). 
16.08.110 - Signs for one-way traffic or parking restrictions. 
    Whenever by ordinance a one-way street is prescribed or any time limit parking or no parking limit is imposed, the department shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective until said signs are erected. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0108, 1950). 
16.08.112 - Action required at a stop sign-Place of stopping. 
    Except when directed to proceed by a police officer or traffic control signal, every driver of a vehicle approaching a stop intersection indicated by a stop sign, shall come to a full stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting street where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting street before entering the intersection. After having stopped, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle which has entered or is approaching the intersection from another street and shall not proceed into the intersection until certain that such intersecting street is free from oncoming traffic which may affect safe passage. 
(Ord. 1382, 1979). 
16.08.120 - Regulations to enforce traffic ordinances-Emergency and experimental regulations. 
(a)  The department may make and enforce regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the traffic ordinances, and to make and enforce temporary regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. 
(b)  The department may make temporary rules regulating traffic or test traffic control devices under actual conditions of traffic. No such experimental rule regulating traffic shall remain in effect for more than ninety days. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0109, 1950). 
16.08.140 - Manner of arrest. 
    Except when reasonably necessary to secure appearance, a person charged with violation of a traffic ordinance of the city by a police officer need not be arrested in the regular manner but may first be given an opportunity after notice to appear voluntarily to answer for such traffic violation. This procedure shall not apply to any person arrested and charged with an offense causing or contributing to an accident resulting in injury or death to any person, nor to any person charged with reckless driving nor to any person charged with driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotic drugs. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0401, 1950). 
16.08.150 - Notice to appear. 
    A person charged with violation of a traffic ordinance by notice shall be given a notice to appear before the court at the time stated in such notice, and stating that in the event of failure so to do, a warrant will be issued for his arrest. The notice shall state the time and nature of the offense and shall also describe the vehicle involved in the violation by trade name and by license number. The nature of the offense may be stated by marking an "X" in a blank opposite the word or words employed to designate the nature of the offense. The notice shall be signed or initialed by the police officer executing it, who shall also put thereon his identification number. The notice shall be made in duplicate, one copy to be given to the owner or driver charged with the offense or to be left in or upon the automobile involved in the violation and the other copy to be filed with the department. 
(Ord. 700 (part), 1993: Ord. 483 § 16.0402, 1950). 
16.08.160 - Appearance. 
    A person who has received a notice of traffic violation through the police shall, at the time specified in such notice, appear at the court to answer the charge set forth therein. 
(Ord. 1700 (part), 1993: Ord. 483 § 16.0403, 1950). 
16.08.170 - Arrest on failure to appear. 
    Upon failure of a person to appear in response to a notice of traffic violation as herein provided, he shall be subject to arrest in the manner otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0404, 1950). 
16.08.180 - Account for notices. 
    The department shall take a receipt for each set of blank notices of traffic violations issued to a police officer. The police officer to whom such blank notices are issued shall account for each set of notices issued to him by return thereof with copies in blank to the department, or by filing of a copy thereof with the department charging a person named therein with a traffic violation. For failure of a police officer to so account for each set of notices issued to him, he shall be subject to disciplinary action. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0405, 1950). 
16.08.190 - Penalty for violations. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided, any person violating any of the provisions of this Title, or failing to comply with any of the provisions thereof, shall upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. 1700 (part), 1993: Ord. 1234 (part), 1976; Ord. 833, 1963: Ord. 483 § 16.0176, 1950). 
Chapter 16.12 - MISCELLANEOUS DRIVING REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Minors' curfew - See Ch. 9.20 of this code. 

16.12.010 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.12.010 which pertained to age of drivers and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0119; and Ord. No. 833, adopted Aug. 26, 1963. 
16.12.020 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.12.020 which pertained to driving or operating a motor vehicle without a permit and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0180; and Ord. No. 561, adopted Jan. 12, 1954. 
16.12.030 - Signaling intention to turn, stop or decrease speed. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle upon a street before starting, stopping or turning from a direct line shall first see that such movement can be made in safety and if any pedestrian may be affected by such movement shall give a clearly audible signal by sounding the horn, and whenever the operation of any other vehicle may be affected by such movement shall give a signal plainly visible to the driver of such other vehicle of the intention to make such movement. 
(b)  Whenever the signal is given by means of the hand and arm, the driver shall indicate his intention by extending the hand and arm from the left side of the vehicle in the following manner; and such signals shall be indicated as follows: 
(1)  Left turn: hand and arm extended horizontally. 
(2)  Right turn: hand and arm extended upward. 
(3)  Stop or decrease of speed: hand and arm extended downward. 
(Ord. 1701 (part), 1993: Ord. 483 § 16.0120, as amended by Ord. 833; August 26, 1963). 
16.12.040 - Restricted left turns. 
    The driver or operator of any vehicle shall not make a left-hand turn at the intersection of one street with another when there is erected or placed at such intersection a signal or sign, or stationed at such intersection a police officer, indicating that no left-hand turn shall be made. The department may designate the intersections at which and the time during which left-hand turns shall not be made and cause to be erected or placed a signal or sign or station a police officer to indicate that no left-hand turn shall be made. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0121; April 24, 1950). 
16.12.050 - "U" turns and traveling on left side. 
    No vehicle shall cross over from the right side of the street to the left side of the street or make a complete turnaround or turn of one hundred eighty degrees upon any street except on the intersection of one street with another. No vehicle shall be permitted to make a complete turnaround or turn of one hundred eighty degrees at the intersection with other streets where official traffic signs indicate such is prohibited or traffic control signals are erected and placed or may hereafter be erected or placed. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0122; April 24, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2143-16-89, 5-5-2014) 
16.12.060 - Turning at intersections. 
    The driver of any vehicle, intending to turn to the right at an intersection shall approach the intersection in the lane for traffic nearest to the right hand side of the street, and in turning shall keep as closely as practicable to the right hand curb or edge of the street; and when intending to turn to the left shall approach the intersection in the lane for traffic to the right of and nearest to the center line of the street and in turning shall pass to the left of the center of the intersection passing as closely as practicable to the left thereof so as to complete the turn so that such vehicle shall pass into such cross street in the lane of traffic to the right of the center of the cross street at the intersection of such streets. For the purpose of this section, the center of the intersection shall mean the meeting point of the medial lines of the streets intersecting one another. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0123; April 24, 1950). 
16.12.070 - Keep to right. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall keep to the right of the center line of the street along which he is driving. The driver of a slowly moving vehicle shall keep as near the right hand curb as possible. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0124; April 24, 1950). 
16.12.080 - Overtaking and passing. 
    The operator of any vehicle overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the same direction shall pass at a safe distance to the left thereof, but only when such left side is clearly visible and is free from oncoming traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit such overtaking and passing to be made in safety and shall not cut in front of the overtaken vehicle until safely clear of same. 
    The driver of a vehicle within a business or residence district shall not deviate from his direct line of travel without ascertaining that such movement can be made with safety to other vehicles approaching from the rear. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not overtake and pass another vehicle upon the crest of a grade, upon a curve in the highway where the driver's view along the highway is obstructed for five hundred feet, upon any street in a "no passing" zone indicated either by regulatory signs adjacent to the street or by pavement markings with a yellow line to the right of the center line. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0125, as amended by Ord. 833; August 26, 1963). 
16.12.090 - Backing. 
    No vehicle shall be backed around a corner at an intersection, or into an intersection of public streets. No vehicle shall be backed without ample warning first having been given, and while backing, care must be exercised not to injure persons or vehicles or to block traffic. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0126; April 24, 1950). 
16.12.100 - Overtaken vehicle-Slow driving. 
    The operator of a vehicle upon a street, about to be overtaken and passed by another vehicle approaching from the rear, shall give way to the right in favor of the overtaking vehicle on suitable and audible signal being given by the driver of the overtaking vehicle and shall not increase the speed of his vehicle until completely passed by the overtaking vehicle. No person shall drive any vehicle at an unnecessarily slow rate of speed so as to hinder and retard the traffic. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0127; April 24, 1950). 
16.12.110 - Starting. 
    A standing vehicle about to start shall give moving vehicles the right of way and the driver thereof shall give ample warning before so starting. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0128; April 24, 1950). 
16.12.120 - Right of way. 
    When two vehicles approach or enter an intersection at approximately the same time, the driver of the vehicle on the left shall yield the right of way to the vehicle on the right except as otherwise provided herein. The driver of any vehicle traveling at an unlawful speed shall forfeit any right of way which he might otherwise have hereunder. 
    The driver of a vehicle approaching but not having entered the intersection shall yield the right of way to a vehicle within such intersection and turning therein to the left across the line of travel of such first mentioned vehicle, provided the driver of the vehicle turning left has given a plainly visible signal of intention to turn as required by law. 
    The driver of any vehicle upon a street within a business or residence district shall yield the right of way to a pedestrian crossing such street within any clearly marked crosswalk or any regular pedestrian crossing included in the prolongation of the lateral boundary lines of the adjacent sidewalk at the end of a block, except at intersections where the movement of traffic is being regulated by traffic officers or traffic direction devices. At intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic control signals or police officers, drivers of vehicles, including those making turns, shall yield the right of way to pedestrians crossing or those who have started to cross the roadway on a "Green" or "Go" signal, and in all other cases pedestrians shall yield the right of way to vehicles lawfully proceeding directly ahead on a "Green" or "Go" signal. Every pedestrian crossing a street within a business or residence district at any point other than a pedestrian crossing, crosswalk or intersection shall yield the right of way to vehicles upon the street. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0129; April 24, 1950). 
16.12.130 - Exceptions to right of way rule. 
    The driver of a vehicle entering a public street from an alley, private road or drive shall yield the right of way to all vehicles approaching on such public street. 
    The driver of a vehicle upon a street shall yield the right of way to ambulances, police and fire department vehicles when operated upon official business, and the drivers of any such vehicles sound audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle. The operator of every other vehicle shall immediately drive his vehicle as near as possible and parallel to the right hand curb of the street clear of any intersection, and shall stop and remain in such position until such emergency vehicle shall have passed, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
    These provisions shall not operate to relieve the driver of a police, fire department vehicle or ambulance from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the highway nor shall it protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequence of an arbitrary exercise of such right of way. 
    Street maintainers in the performance of their duties of maintaining the streets shall have the preference of right of way, and shall be permitted to drive upon the left hand side of the streets for the purpose of dumping materials, for repairing or smoothing the roadway, or for cleaning streets and removing snow. Such maintainers shall, at all times, display a red flag of such dimensions and in such manner as prescribed by the state highway commission to indicate his identity. Such maintainer shall not indiscriminately block traffic, but shall allow reasonable room on the traveled portion of the street for other vehicles to pass. Such maintainer shall not be bound by the rules herein provided to turn to the right when meeting other vehicles or allowing them to pass when his work requires him to remain on the other side of the traveled portion of the street. Such maintainer shall be subject to the rules of travel as provided by law, except when the performance of their maintenance work requires them to do otherwise. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0130; April 24, 1950). 
16.12.140 - Emerging from alley or driveway-Stop before entering. 
    The operator of a vehicle emerging from an alley, private driveway, or building into a street, or entering a through street shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a crosswalk or crosswalk area extending across such an approach. 
    Every vehicle driven from an alley into a street within the business district shall go straight across the street or shall turn to the right on coming out of such alley and go in the direction of traffic on such street. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0131; April 24, 1950). 
16.12.150 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.12.150 which pertained to "U" turns and traveling on the left side and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0122, April 24, 1950. 
16.12.160 - Yield signs. 
    The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall slow to a speed of not more than ten miles per hour and yield right-of-way to all vehicles approaching from the right or left on the intersecting street which are so close as to constitute an immediate hazard. If a driver is involved in a collision at an intersection or interferes with the movement of other vehicles after driving past a yield sign, such a collision or interference shall be deemed prima facie evidence of the driver's failure to yield right-of-way. 
(Ord. 629, 1956: Ord. 483 § 16.0181, 1950). 
16.12.170 - Railroad signals. 
    Whenever any person driving a vehicle approaches a highway or street railway crossing and a clearly visible and positive signal gives warning of the immediate approach of a railway train or car or locomotive, it is unlawful for the driver of the vehicle to fail to bring the vehicle to a complete stop before traversing such grade crossing and it shall be the duty of the driver of such vehicle to follow and obey the direction of said signal. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0174, 1950). 
16.12.180 - Crossing sidewalk. 
A.  MANNER OF CROSSING. A vehicle shall not be allowed to cross a sidewalk except where a driveway is provided, and in crossing a sidewalk to or from a alley, lot or building, no vehicle shall be driven without due caution for pedestrians. 
B.  WARNING BEFORE CROSSING SIDEWALKS. Every person driving any vehicle to or from an alley, lot or building, across any sidewalk shall give ample notice and warning of his approach. 
(Ord. 1701 (part), 1993: Ord. 483 § 16.0132, 1950). 
16.12.190 - Two and four lane traffic. 
    Vehicles shall not travel two or more abreast or pass a moving vehicle at an intersection on any two lane street or avenue. All streets and avenues in the city are designated for two lane traffic except that the following streets and avenues shall be designated for four lane traffic: 
Third Street South: Simmons Ave. S.E. to Lincoln Ave. S.W.; 
Sloan Parkway, U.S. Highway No. 14: East city limits line to west city limits line; 
Dakota Avenue North and South: From the intersection of U.S. Highway No. 14 and S.D. Highway No. 37 (4th Street North) to 27th Street South; 
Lincoln Avenue: From Sloan Parkway North to 9th Street S.W. 
(Ord. 1035 (part), 1972: Ord. 994, 1970: Ord. 955, 1968: Ord. 928, 1966: Ord. 795: Ord. 483 § 16.0133, 1950). 
16.12.200 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.12.200 which pertained to unnecessary driving adjacent to school property and derived from Ord. No. 833, adopted in 1963; and Ord. No. 483, § 16.0183, adopted in 1950. 
16.12.210 - Coasters, roller skates, skateboards, and similar devices. 
    No person on roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, skateboard, or toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street or crosswalk. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0155, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2143-16-89, 5-5-2014) 
16.12.220 - Clinging to moving vehicle. 
    No person traveling upon any bicycle, coaster, sled, skis, roller skates or any other toy vehicle shall cling to or attach himself or his vehicle to any other moving vehicle upon any street. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0156, 1950). 
16.12.230 - Riding on outside prohibited. 
    No person shall ride in or upon any motor vehicle by hanging onto the same, standing on the runningboard or otherwise, except by sitting in the seats provided for passengers in such vehicle. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0157, 1950). 
16.12.240 - Parades and processions. 
A.  PARADES-PERMIT REQUIRED. No parade or procession other than a funeral procession shall be held or participated in upon the streets except with the prior consent in writing from the city commission, obtained upon application filed with the department setting forth the time of, route of, approximate number of persons and vehicles to participate in, and name and character of the group or organization sponsoring such parade or procession. 
    The consent of the chief of police to the holding of such parades or procession shall be given unless it reasonably appears that the holding of the same as set out in the application would unreasonably obstruct and impede traffic or would be likely to disturb the peace and quiet of the city. 
B.  DRIVING THROUGH PROCESSION PROHIBITED. No driver of any vehicle shall drive through or otherwise interfere with any funeral or other authorized procession in any of the streets, and it shall be the duty of the driver of any vehicle to stop when reaching a street on which such a procession is passing and wait until the procession has entirely passed. 
(Ord. 1953, 2002; Ord. 483 § 16.0161, 1950). 
16.12.243 - Funeral processions-Identification. 
    A funeral composed of two or more vehicles shall be identified as such by the display of illuminated headlights upon each vehicle in the procession. 
(Ord. 833, 1963: Ord. 483 § 16.0184, 1950). 
16.12.245 - Funeral processions-Operation of vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle in or as part of any funeral procession without having the vehicle distinguished by illuminated headlights. The driver of every such vehicle shall keep as near the righthand edge of the roadway as practicable and following the vehicle ahead as closely as practicable and safe. 
(Ord. 833, 1963: Ord. 483 § 16.0185, 1950). 
16.12.247 - Funeral processions-Stops. 
    The operator of the vehicle in the lead of any funeral procession entering upon any street intersection where a stop is required by this title shall bring the vehicle to a full stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles on the intersected street, and where the other vehicles composing the procession are properly distinguished by illuminated headlights, they may follow the vehicle in the lead through the intersection without stopping, subject, however, to direction of any police officers stationed at the intersection. 
(Ord. 833, 1963: Ord. 483 § 16.0186, 1950). 
16.12.250 - Care in driving. 
    Every driver of any vehicle on any street shall drive in a careful manner and with due regard for the safety and convenience of pedestrians and other vehicles. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0164, 1950). 
16.12.280 - Exhibition driving. 
    Any person, firm or corporation driving and/or operating a vehicle within the city limits in such a manner that creates or causes unnecessary engine noise or tire squeal, skid or slide upon acceleration or stopping; or that simulates a temporary race; or that causes the vehicle to unnecessarily turn abruptly or sway shall be guilty of exhibition driving. 
(Ord. 942, 1967). 
16.12.285 - Use of dynamic air compression brake device prohibited. 
    The use or operation of a dynamic air compression braking device on unmuffled vehicles is prohibited within the City of Huron except to avoid an imminent threat to the safety of the driver or any other person; or to avoid an imminent threat to property, or except when used in conjunction with a special event provided that the use or operation of dynamic air compression braking devices at the special event has received prior approval of the police commissioner and chief of police. 
    A dynamic air compression braking device is a device used on vehicles that converts the engine from an internal combustion engine to an air compressor for the purpose of braking without the use of wheel brakes. These devices are commonly referred to as "air brakes," "engine brakes," "compression brakes," "Jacob's Brakes," or "Jake Brakes." 
    Violations of Section 16.12.285 shall be punishable by a fine as set by resolution of the governing board. If any ticket for a violation is not paid within seven days and a summons and complaint is filed in magistrate court based on such ticket, the magistrate court fine for the violation shall be as set by resolution of the governing board. In addition to establishing the fine, the resolution shall authorize the payment of the fine through power of attorney in lieu of a court appearance. 
(Ord. No. 2052, 2-1-2010; Ord. No. 2114-16-84, 6-4-2012) 
16.12.300 - Distracted driving. 
(a)  Definitions: 
(1)  "Distracted driving" means inattentive driving while operating a moving motor vehicle that results in the unsafe operation of the vehicle where such operation is caused by reading, writing, performing personal grooming, interacting with pets or unsecured cargo, using personal communications technologies, or engaging in any other activity which causes distractions. 
(2)  "Hands-free accessory" means an attachment, add-on, built-in feature, or addition to a mobile telephone, whether or not permanently installed in a motor vehicle, that when used allows the vehicle operator to maintain both hands on the steering wheel. 
(3)  "Mobile telephone" means a cellular, analog, wireless, or digital telephone capable of sending or receiving telephone messages without an access line for service. 
(4)  "Other electronic device" includes, but is not limited to, hand-held computers, pagers, and video games. 
(5)  "Text" or "texting" means using an electronic wireless communications device to compose or send a written message or image using a text-based communication system, including communications referred to as a text message, instant message, or electronic mail (e-mail). 
(6)  "Use" means talking, placing, texting, or receiving a call, or attempting to place, text, or receive a call, on a wireless communications device, including a mobile telephone. 
(b)  Distracted Driving Prohibited: 
(1)  No person while operating a moving motor vehicle on a public street shall use an electronic wireless communications device to compose or send a written message or image using a text-based communication system, including communications commonly referred to as a text message, instant message, or electronic mail (e-mail). 
(i)  Enforcement of municipal ordinance [Section] 16.12.300(b)(1) shall be a primary offense. 
(ii)  The penalty for violation of municipal ordinance [Section] 16.12.300(b)(1) shall be set by resolution of the governing board. 
(2)  No person having an instruction permit or a restricted minor's permit shall use any mobile telephone or other electronic device, including those with hands-free accessories, while operating a moving motor vehicle on a public street. 
(i)  Enforcement of municipal ordinance [Section] 16.12.300(b)(2) shall be a primary offense. 
(ii)  The penalty for violation of municipal ordinance [Section] 16.12.300(b)(2) shall be set by resolution of the governing board. 
(iii)  A person having an instruction permit or a restricted minor's permit and using a mobile telephone to call 911 to report an emergency shall not be deemed in violation of Section 16.12.0300(b)(2). 
(3)  No person shall use a mobile telephone or other electronic device, including those with hands-free accessories, while operating a moving school bus that is carrying passengers; provided, that this section shall not apply to a school bus driver who places an emergency call to school officials or to 911. 
(i)  Enforcement of municipal ordinance [Section] 16.12.300(b)(3) shall be a primary offense. 
(ii)  The penalty for violation of municipal ordinance [Section] 16.12.300(b)(3) shall be set by resolution of the governing board. 
(4)  Except as otherwise provided in Sections 16.12.300(b) (1), (2), and (3), distracted driving while operating a moving motor vehicle that results in the unsafe operation of the vehicle where such operation is caused by reading, writing, performing personal grooming, interacting with pets or unsecured cargo, using personal communications technologies, or engaging in any other activity which causes distractions, is prohibited. 
(i)  Enforcement of municipal ordinance [Section] 16.12.300(b)(4) shall be a secondary offense. 
(ii)  The penalty for violation of municipal ordinance [Section] 16.12.300(b)(4) shall be set by resolution of the governing board. 
(c)  Municipal ordinance [Section] 16.12.300 shall not apply to electronic wireless communication devices in police and fire department vehicles or ambulances used during the course of police, fire and ambulance related duties. 
(Ord. No. 2120-16-87, 12-3-2012) 
Chapter 16.14 - MOTORCYCLES 

16.14.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following word shall mean as follows: 
    "Motorcycle" includes motorcycles, motorbikes, bicycles with motor attached and all motor-operated vehicles of the bicycle or tricycle type, whether the motive power be a part thereof or attached thereto, and having a saddle or seat with the driver sitting astride or upon it, or a platform on which the driver stands, but excluding a tractor. 
(Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
16.14.020 - License required. 
    No person shall operate a motorcycle on the public streets or highways without a motor vehicle driver's license or permit upon which a state testing officer has certified that such person is qualified to operate such motorcycle. 
(Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
16.14.030 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.14.030 which pertained to height of handlebars and derived from Ord. No. 943 (part), adopted in 1967. 
16.14.040 - Helmet required. 
    It is unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen years to operate or ride upon a motorcycle on the public streets or highways of the city unless such person wears a protective helmet of a type approved by the South Dakota Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. The commissioner is authorized and empowered to adopt rules and regulations covering the types of helmets and the specifications therefor and to establish and maintain a list of approved helmets which meet the specifications established hereunder. 
(Ord. 1702 (part), 1993: Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
16.14.050 - Muffler. 
    Every motorcycle shall at all times be equipped with an adequate muffler in constant operation and properly maintained to prevent any excessive or unusual noise, and no muffler or exhaust system shall be complete with a cutout, bypass, or similar device. It is unlawful to make an alterations either by way of addition or modification of any original or stock muffler. 
(Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
16.14.060 - Additional riders. 
    It is unlawful for an operator or driver of a motorcycle while operating on the public streets or highways of the city to carry any other person thereon, except on a seat securely fastened to the machine to the rear of the driver provided with footrests or in a sidecar attached to the motorcycle and designed with the purpose of carrying a passenger. A passenger under the age of eighteen years shall wear all of the safety equipment which is required for the operator of the motorcycle. 
(Ord. 1702 (part), 1993: Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
16.14.070 - License required for rental. 
    No dealer or person renting or loaning motorcycles shall loan or rent a motorcycle unless a valid license or permit is shown such dealer by the renter or loanee and possesses the safety equipment required of the operator of such motorcycle. 
(Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
16.14.080 - Renter only to operate. 
    It is unlawful for a renter or loanee as provided in section 16.14.070 to permit any other person to operate such motorcycle. 
(Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
16.14.090 - Operation in parks. 
    It is unlawful to operate a motorcycle in any municipal park or recreation area except upon the normally traveled roads or roadways, or in specifically designated areas. 
(Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
16.14.100 - Nonapplicable when. 
    This chapter shall not apply to vehicles used for special occasions such as display, parade, exhibitions and similar uses. 
(Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
16.14.110 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation adjudged to be in violation of any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. 1702 (part), 1993: Ord. 943 (part), 1967). 
Chapter 16.15 - GOLF CARTS 

16.15.010 - Golf cart defined. 
    For the purposes of Chapter 16.15, golf cart means a four (4) wheeled vehicle originally and specifically designed and intended to transport one (1) or more individuals and golf clubs for the purpose of playing the game of golf on a golf course. 
(Ord. No. 2084, 11-1-2010) 
16.15.040 - Driver's license required. 
    Any person operating a golf cart on a public street within the City of Huron must hold a valid driver's license issued by the State of South Dakota or other recognized jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2084, 11-1-2010) 
16.15.050 - Insurance and permit required. 
(a)  Proof of financial responsibility, pursuant to SDCL Chapter 32-35, is required for all golf carts operated on public streets within the City of Huron. 
(b)  Pursuant to SDCL 32-14-14, the owner of the golf cart operated on public streets within the City of Huron must obtain a permit from the City of Huron or its designee prior to operating the golf cart on public streets within the City of Huron. The permit shall be valid during the period of time the person obtaining the permit owns the golf cart, and a subsequent owner of the golf cart must obtain a new permit prior to operating the golf cart on public streets within the City of Huron. The permit must be in the possession of the operator or passenger of the golf cart, or in or attached to the golf cart when the golf cart is being operated on public streets. The fee for the permit shall be established by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2084, 11-1-2010; Ord. No. 2112-16-83, 4-16-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2112-16-83, adopted April 16, 2012, amended § 16.15.050 title to read as herein set out. Former § 16.15.050 title pertained to insurance required. 
16.15.060 - Slow moving emblem required. 
    Unless a motor vehicle license issued by a governmental entity recognized by the State of South Dakota is mounted on the rear of the golf cart, the golf cart operated on a public street within the City of Huron shall display a slow-moving vehicle emblem mounted on the rear of the golf cart. 
(Ord. No. 2084, 11-1-2010) 
16.15.070 - Operation restrictions. 
(a)  No person may operate a golf cart on a state or county highway located within the City of Huron except for crossing from one (1) side of the highway to the other. A golf cart may cross the highway at a right angle but only after stopping and yielding the right-of-way to all approaching traffic and crossing as closely as possible to an intersection or approach. 
(b)  No person may operate a golf cart within the City of Huron on a public street during the time between one-half (1/2) hour after sunset and one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise unless the golf cart has the following equipment: rearview mirror, horn, headlights, tail lights, and brake lights. 
(c)  The operator of a golf cart shall comply with all municipal and state regulations related to operation of motor vehicles on public streets and highways. 
(Ord. No. 2084, 11-1-2010) 
Chapter 16.16 - SPEED LIMITS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Local authorities granted certain limited authority to limit speed of motor vehicles-See SDC 44.0334 and sections cited therein. 

16.16.010 - Speed limits designated. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle upon any street or alley within the city limits at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard to the traffic, surface and width of such street or alley, or of any other conditions then existing and no person shall drive any vehicle upon a street or alley in the city at such speed as to endanger the life, limb or property of any person. 
    Emergency vehicles-Fire regulations-See Ch. 16.40 of this code. 
(2)  Subject to the provisions of subsection (1) of this section, the driver of a motor vehicle to drive at the following speeds shall be lawful, but any speed in excess thereof is unlawful: 
(a)  On all street and roads which are not otherwise zoned or posted the maximum lawful speed shall be twenty (20) miles per hour; 
(b)  On all streets adjacent to a school, when a driver is passing a school during a period when children are present, the maximum lawful speed shall be fifteen miles per hour. 
For the purposes of this section, when children are present means when any person is on the sidewalk within the posted zone or if no sidewalk is present is on the street or within 20 feet of the street within the posted zone. 
(c)  In all alleys or driveways, other than streets or avenues, the maximum lawful speed shall be ten miles per hour; 
(d)  Within fifty feet and in traversing an intersection of streets when the driver's view is obstructed, the maximum lawful speed shall be fifteen miles per hour; 
(e)  The City Commission, by resolution, may establish limited speed zones, which speed limit shall constitute the maximum speed that any person may drive or operate any vehicle upon the zoned street or a portion thereof. The maximum speed permissible in the zone shall be posted by signs erected by the city. 
(Ord. 1653, 1991: Ord. 1207, 1976; Ord. 1037, 1972; Ord. 1035 (part), 1972; Ord. 1023, 1972; Ord. 955, 1968: Ord. 894: Ord. 841: Ord. 765, 1961: Ord. 483 § 16.0162, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2143-16-89, 5-5-2014) 
Chapter 16.20 - ONE-WAY TRAFFIC[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Note- Local authorities may prohibit other than one-way traffic upon certain highways. 

16.20.010 - Street and alleys designated. 
    The traffic on the first alley west of Dakota Avenue South, running north and south between Dakota Avenue South and Wisconsin Avenue Southwest, is limited to a northerly direction only between Second and Third Streets Southwest and is limited to a southerly direction between Third and Fourth Streets Southwest; and the traffic in the first alley east of Dakota Avenue South, between Dakota Avenue South and Kansas Avenue Southeast, is limited to a southerly direction only between Second and Fourth Streets Southeast in the city and the traffic in the alley east of Kansas Avenue Southeast, between Fourth and Fifth Streets Southeast, is limited to a westerly direction only from a point one hundred eighty-five feet east of Kansas Avenue Southeast, to Kansas Avenue Southeast. 
(Ord. 1977, 2004: Ord. 1428, 1981: Ord. 1196, 1975: Ord. 1155, 1974: Ord. 1085 (part), 1973: Ord. 699, 1958: Ord. 483 § 16.0182, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2186-16-92, 7-10-2017) 
Chapter 16.24 - THROUGH STREETS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Local authorities authorized to designate through highways - See SDC 44.0321. 

16.24.010 - City streets classified. 
    City streets are classified as follows: 
(a)  Principle Arterials: 
(1)  US Highway 14 within city limits; and 
(2)  SD Highway 37 within city limits. 
(b)  Major Collectors: 
(1)  Third Street SE and SW from West Park Avenue to the James River; 
(2)  Market Street SE and SW; and 
(3)  Old Highway 14. 
(c)  Minor Arterials: 
(1)  West Park Avenue from US Highway 14 to 21st Street SW; 
(2)  21st Street SE and SW from West Park Avenue to the James River; and 
(3)  Lincoln Avenue NW and SW from 7th Street NW to 21st Street SW. 
(d)  Minor Collectors: 
(1)  9th Street from West Park Avenue to Lawnridge Avenue SE; 
(2)  14th Street SW from McDonald Avenue to Dakota Avenue; 
(3)  15th Street SW from Lincoln Avenue to McDonald Avenue; 
(4)  McDonald Avenue from 15th Street to 14th Street; 
(5)  15th Street SE from Dakota Avenue to Riverview Drive; 
(6)  18th Street South from Lincoln Avenue to Riverview Drive; 
(7)  Arizona Avenue from 9th Street to 21st Street; 
(8)  Idaho Avenue from Market Street to 21st Street; 
(9)  Frank Avenue from Market Street to 21st Street; and 
(10)  Jersey Avenue. 
(e)  All other streets are local streets. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0141, as amended by Ord. 833, 1963). 
(Ord. No. 2145-16-90, 8-4-2014) 
16.24.020 - Through streets identified. 
(a)  The principle arterials are designed and intended to carry traffic through the city. The principle arterials serve high volumes of traffic traveling long distances at speeds generally equal to or greater than 40 mph. 
(b)  The minor arterials primarily serve through traffic with controlled access. The minor arterials serve moderate to high volumes of traffic with posted speeds equal to or greater than 35 mph. 
(c)  The major collectors serve moderate traffic volumes with a posted speed equal to or greater than 30 mph. 
(Ord. No. 2145-16-90, 8-4-2014) 
Chapter 16.28 - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to regulate the use of streets, to provide for cleaning the same, and to prevent and remove obstructions and encroachments on the same - See SDCL 9-30-2. 

16.28.010 - Where prohibited. 
    No vehicle shall be parked in any of the following places except when done in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign: 
(a)  Within an intersection; (SDCL 32-30-6.1(1)) 
(b)  On a crosswalk; (SDCL 32-30-6.1(4)) 
(c)  Outside the first line of cars parked next to the curb; (SDCL 32-30-6.1(1)) 
(d)  Within twenty feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
(e)  Within twenty feet of the driveway entrance to a fire station; (SDCL 32-30-6(5)) 
(f)  Within fifteen feet of a fire hydrant; (SDCL 32-30-6(2)) 
(g)  In front of a public or private driveway without the consent of the property owner; (SDCL 32-30-6-6(1)) 
(h)  On or across a sidewalk; (SDCL 32-30-6.1(2)) 
(i)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; (SDCL 32-30-6.1(6)) 
(j)  Upon private property without the prior consent of the person lawfully in possession of such premises; 
(k)  Upon a boulevard without the prior consent of the city or the person lawfully in possession or control of the real estate adjacent to such boulevard; 
(l)  Where curb has been painted yellow upon the direction of the department; 
(m)  In a designated fire line. (SDCL 32-30-6.1(9)) 
(Ord. 1563, 1988: Ord. 483 § 16.0142, as amended by Ord. 833, 1963). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012; Ord. No. 2143-16-89, 5-5-2014) 
16.28.015 - Time limit designated by sign. 
    The department is authorized to install parking signs or remove parking signs. No vehicle shall be parked on any street, avenue, alley or in a municipally owned public ground for a longer period in an area clearly marked by a parking sign and designated by the governing body as follows: 
(a)  Twelve minutes; 
(b)  One hour; 
(c)  Two hours; 
(d)  Three hours; 
(e)  Twenty-four hours; 
(f)  Seventy-two hours. 
(Ord. 1703 (part), 1993). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.28.020 - Vehicles standing or parking in alleys. 
    No vehicle shall be left standing, attended or unattended, in public alleys. 
    Trucks shall not stand or park in alleys except for the purpose of receiving or delivering property and shall not so stand or park for a longer period of time than is necessary to load or unload. Such trucks, when loading or unloading, shall stand or park on the side of the alley. When two or more trucks are thus standing on opposite sides of the same alley the truck last arriving shall be placed in such staggered position as to leave sufficient space between it and the first truck for the free passage of other vehicles. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0143, as amended by Ord. 754, 1960). 
16.28.030 - Police parking. 
    The police department may designate parking areas for police vehicles and mark such areas with appropriate signs, and when such areas are so designated and marked, no vehicles other than police vehicles shall be parked therein. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0144, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.28.040 - Temporary "no parking" areas. 
    The city may designate temporary no parking areas and mark the temporary no parking area with appropriate "no parking" signs and when so marked no vehicle shall be parked therein. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0145, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2115-16-85, adopted June 25, 2012 amended § 16.28.040 title to read as herein set out. Former § 16.28.040 title pertained to temporary "no parking" areas for street cleaning and snow removal. 
16.28.045 - Temporary parking allowed. 
    The city may designate temporary parking areas, and when so designated, parking is permitted as designated and notwithstanding any ordinance to the contrary. 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.28.050 - Parallel and diagonal parking. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on any street unless such vehicle is parked parallel to the curb headed in the direction of traffic with curbside wheels of the vehicle within twelve inches of the curb, and no closer than four feet to any other vehicle front or rear, except where otherwise marked and except upon those streets which have been designated or marked for diagonal parking. Where streets are so marked, vehicles must park within the space thus designated. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0146, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.28.060 - Size of vehicle. 
    No vehicle or equipment of more than eight feet six inches in width shall be parked on public streets within areas zoned residential. On public streets which separate areas zoned residential from areas zoned other than residential, no vehicle or equipment of more than eight feet six inches in width shall be parked on the side of the public street adjacent to the area zoned residential. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0147, as amended by Ord. 833, 1963). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.28.070 - Parking of trucks. 
    All freight, grain, stock and gas and oil transport trucks, and truck trailers, shall be parked only at such places and in such manner as have been marked and designated by the department for such parking. This section shall not apply to a light delivery truck delivering goods from house to house and place to place which requires a stop or parking of but a few minutes to receive or deliver merchandise. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0148, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.28.075 - Service zones. 
    The chief of police is authorized to issue a permit for "service parking" which term shall mean the use of parking spaces for vehicle parking exceeding the parking time limitation, materials and dumpsters while rendering service in cleaning, painting, adjusting or making minor repairs or replacement in or to buildings, or building equipment upon the following conditions: 
(1)  Application shall be made to the chief of police on such forms as the chief of police shall prescribe. The applicant shall set forth the applicant's business and the necessity for such permit. 
(2)  If it appears that a necessity exists, the chief of police may authorize the issuance of a service permit upon payment of the fee established by resolution of the governing board and on the conditions hereinafter prescribed. 
(3)  The service permits shall show the name of the permittee location and the purpose of the service permit, and the valid dates of the service permit. The applicant granted a service permit shall present the service permit upon request by law enforcement or by the building inspector. 
(4)  The chief of police may revoke any permit if the service zone is used for any purpose other than that authorized herein or for any violation of the terms and conditions of this chapter. Upon revocation, the permit shall be immediately returned to the department and all fees paid shall be forfeited. Police officers finding such zone in use shall investigate the use being made thereon and if it is found in violation of this chapter, shall report the facts to the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.28.076 - Loading zone designation. 
    It is unlawful to park a vehicle in an area marked "loading zone" except to load or unload either passengers or cargo. 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.28.080 - Removing and storing illegally parked vehicles; waiver of fees. 
    When any vehicle is illegally parked or parked in a location which creates a hazard, obstruction, nuisance or interference to or with the movement of traffic, snow removal operations, street sweeping or street maintenance, the police department may order such vehicle to be moved to a designated parking area or may have said vehicle moved to a city storage area as designated by the governing body, and under such circumstances the owner of the vehicle shall pay to the city the actual costs of the removal of the vehicle to the parking and storage area plus storage fees at the rate set by resolution of the governing board, and a fine set by resolution of the govern board, for each offense. If a vehicle has been removed from private property at the request of the property owner or other person having authority to order such removal, and the person requesting such removal subsequently informs the police department that the request for removal of the vehicle was in error, the person requesting such removal shall pay to the city the actual costs of the removal of the vehicle to the parking or storage area plus storage fees at the rate set by resolution of the governing board and a fine set by resolution of the governing board. Storage fees so incurred under this section may be waived in whole, or in part, if it is the determination of the chief of police that it is in the interest of the city to do so. 
(Ord. 1944, 2002: Ord. 1772, 1996: Ord. 964, 1969: prior Ord. § 16.0175, as amended by Ord. 533, 1953). 
(Ord. No. 2083, 8-2-2010) 
16.28.090 - Seventy-two hour limit. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on any street, avenue, alley or in a municipally owned public ground for a longer period than seventy-two hours at one location. Within the residential districts defined in Title 23 of this code, the above shall apply to the portion of the right-of-way between the curbline and property line (boulevard). Any vehicle which causes an obstruction or a hazard to traffic may be removed at any time under the direction of the police department. 
(Ord. 1508, 1984: Ord. 483 § 16.0179, added by Ord. 521, 1952). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2115-16-85, adopted June 25, 2012, amended § 16.28.090 title to read as herein set out. Former § 16.28.090 title pertained to twenty-four hour limit. 
16.28.110 - Leaving inoperable vehicle on public property. 
    No person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked or partially dismantled vehicle of any kind, whether attended or not, upon any public property or right-of-way within the city. Whenever any police officer finds an abandoned motor vehicle or an unattended vehicle which is in a wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked or partially dismantled condition on public property within the city, he is authorized to provide for the removal of such vehicle to a garage or place of safety. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0134, 1950). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2115-16-85, adopted June 25, 2012, amended § 16.28.110 title to read as herein set out. Former § 16.28.110 title pertained to leaving vehicle unattended with motor running. 
16.28.120 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2115-16-85, adopted June 25, 2012, repealed § 16.28.120, which pertained to delivery vehicle stickers authorized and derived from Ord. No. 860-16-1 (part), adopted 1964. 
16.28.130 - Core area delivery vehicle parking. 
    All drivers of delivery vehicles shall abide by the following rules and regulations if parking the delivery vehicle within the core area or on a designated snow emergency route as designated in Section 16.30.010(1), or in an alley: 
(a)  Whenever possible, delivery vehicles shall be parked at the rear entrance to buildings for loading and unloading merchandise; if no rear entrance is available, delivery vehicles shall be parked in marked parking spaces; should it not be possible to use the building rear entrance or marked parking spaces, for loading and unloading merchandise only, the delivery vehicle may be (1) parked in a municipal parking lot, (2) double parked, or (3) within the core area on Kansas Avenue, Wisconsin Avenue, Second Street and Fourth Street only, in the middle of the street. When double-parked or parked in the middle of the street, warning blinkers on the vehicle must be activated. Nothing within this provision restricts the right of a police officer to order the delivery vehicle be moved if in the opinion of the police officer the location of the parked vehicle constitutes an impermissible risk of motor vehicle accident. 
(b)  Delivery vehicle parking as set forth in this ordinance is applicable only to delivery vehicles in use at the time of parking for the loading and unloading merchandise. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision in ordinance, no delivery vehicle shall be parked next to fire hydrants or crosswalks. 
(d)  Delivery vehicles shall not be parked in a manner which block entrances. 
(e)  When two or more trucks are standing on opposite sides of and in the same alley, the truck last arriving shall be placed in a staggered position leaving sufficient space for clear passage of other vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2115-16-85, adopted June 25, 2012, repealed former § 16.28.130, and enacted a new § 16.28.130 as set out herein. Former § 16.28.130 pertained to delivery vehicle sticker regulations and derived from Ord. No. 860-16-1 (part), adopted 1964. 
16.28.140 - Handicap parking. 
    The owner of any vehicle not displaying a serially numbered certificate or special license plate parked in a parking space on public or private property designated as reserved for the physically handicapped commits a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 1703 (part), 1993). 
16.28.150 - Parking violation fines. 
    Violations of this chapter of the code shall be punishable by administrative fees as set by resolution of the governing board. If any ticket for a violation is not paid within seven days and a summons and complaint is issued based on such ticket for violating this chapter, the fine for the violations of any provision of this chapter shall be as set by resolution of the governing board. In addition to setting the fine, the resolution shall authorize the payment of the fine through power of attorney in lieu of a court appearance. 
(Ord. 1946, 2002: Ord. 1812, 1998). 
(Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
Chapter 16.30 - SNOW REMOVAL 

16.30.010 - Adoption of definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  "Core area of the city" means that area of the city enclosed within the boundaries of Market Street on the north and on the east by Iowa Avenue SE from Market Street to Third Street SE and Idaho Avenue from Third Street SE to Fifth Street SE and boundaried on the south by Fifth Street from Idaho Avenue SE to Wisconsin Avenue SW and Sixth Street SW from Wisconsin Avenue SW to Ohio Avenue SW and boundaried on the west by Ohio Avenue SW from Sixth Street SW to Market Street; to include the entire roadway of those designated streets and avenues. 
(2)  "Emergency routes" means the following streets: 
Fifteenth Street North from the Airport to Dakota Avenue; 
Seventh Street NW; 
Seventh Street Northeast from Dakota Avenue to Beach Avenue; 
Fourth Street North from the west city limits to the east city limits including that portion which is four-lane; 
Utah Avenue North from Seventh Street to Fourth Street; 
Old Highway 14 from the west city limits to Market Street; 
Market Street to Frank Avenue; 
Third Street South from the west city limits to the east city limits; 
Ninth Street South from Lincoln Avenue to Lawnridge Avenue; 
Fifteenth Street SW from Lincoln Avenue to Arizona Avenue; 
Fourteenth Street SW from Arizona Avenue to Dakota Avenue; 
Sixteenth Street SW from McDonald Drive to McClellan Drive; 
McClellan Drive from Sixteenth Street SW to Fourteenth Street SW; 
Fifteenth Street SE from Dakota Avenue to Riverview Drive; 
Eighteenth Street South from Lincoln Avenue to Riverview Drive; 
Lincoln Avenue from north city limits to Twenty-first Street South and Twenty-first Street/Centennial Road to east city limits; 
Arizona Avenue North from Seventh Street North to Fourth Street North; 
Arizona Avenue South from Ninth Street South to Twenty-first Street South; 
Nevada Avenue South from Market Street to Ninth Street South; 
Colorado Avenue/McDonald Drive from Market Street to Twentieth Street South and east to Campbell Drive and south to Twenty-first Street South; 
Dakota Avenue from north city limits to south city limits, except between the intersection of Dakota Avenue and Market Street to the intersection of Dakota Avenue and Fifth Street (which is in the designated core area of the city); 
Idaho Avenue South from Market Street to Twenty-first Street South; 
Frank Avenue from Market Street to Twenty-first Street South; 
Pennington Avenue from Third Street SW to Old Highway 14; 
Starting at 21st Street SW, South on Ohio to 22nd Street, West on 22nd Street to McClellan, South on McClellan to 24th Street then all of 24th Street from McDonald Avenue to Dakota Avenue. 
(3)  "Snow removal alert" means such times as the commissioner in charge of the street department or the mayor, or their designee declares that snow removal operations on the public streets will commence and that the provisions of this chapter in regard to parking on public streets during snow removal operations are effective and will be enforced. 
(4)  "Street" means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained by the municipality for purposes of vehicular travel, including but not limited to such areas designated as avenues or drives, when any part thereof is open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(5)  "Vehicle" means every device, motorized and nonmotorized, in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway. 
(Ord. 1823, 1998; Ord. 1580, 1988: Ord. 1545, 1987; Ord. 1541, 1986; Ord. 1533 (part), 1986). 
(Ord. No. 2103-16-82, 11-14-2011; Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012; Ord. No. 2134-16-88, 12-30-2013; Ord. No. 2190-16-93; 3-26-2018) 
16.30.020 - No parking on emergency routes in the city when snowfall exceeds two inches. 
    No person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any public street designated as an emergency route as defined by Section 16.30.010(2) when snowfall is greater than two inches until that street or portion has been plowed and cleared of snow accumulation, curb to curb, after which normal parking may be resumed until the next snow fall in excess of two inches. 
(Ord. No. 2103-16-82, 11-14-2011) 
16.30.030 - Declaration of snow removal alert. 
    When the commissioner in charge of the street department, or the mayor, or their designee determines that snow removal from the public streets will commence, the commissioner, mayor or designee will announce through local news media and whatever other sources are available that there has been declared a snow removal alert and that the provisions of this chapter will be effective and be enforced, designating a particular date and time when such alert will commence. The determination to declare a snow removal alert will be based on the then existing weather conditions, and the amount of snow then on the ground or expected according to weather forecasts from the National Weather Service. The declaration of a "snow removal alert" shall state the areas in which the alert is effective: 
(1)  Core area of the city; and/or 
(2)  All other streets not included in the core area or designated as a snow emergency route. 
(Ord. No. 2103-16-82, 11-14-2011; Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
Editor's note- Formally § 16.30.020; renumbered as § 16.30.030 via Ord. No. 2103-16-82. 
16.30.040 - Termination of snow removal alert. 
    After a snow removal alert has been declared, there will be no declaration of its termination, but such alert shall terminate and the provisions of Sections 16.30.040, 16.30.050 and 16.30.060 become not effective nor enforceable as to any particular street or portion of a street, as soon as that street or portion has been plowed and cleared of snow accumulation, curb to curb, after which normal parking may be resumed until the next declared snow removal alert. 
(Ord. No. 2103-16-82, 11-14-2011) 
Editor's note- Formally § 16.30.030; renumbered as § 16.30.040 via Ord. No. 2103-16-82. 
16.30.050 - No parking during snow removal alert in core area of city. 
    During a snow removal alert, no person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any public street within the core area of the city as that term is defined by Section 16.30.010(1) between the hours of twelve midnight and eight a.m. 
(Ord. No. 2103-16-82, 11-14-2011) 
Editor's note- Formally § 16.30.040; renumbered as § 16.30.050 via Ord. No. 2103-16-82. Former § 16.30.050 originating from Ord. No. 1533 (part), adopted 1986 and pertaining to no parking during snow removal alert on snow emergency routes in the city was repealed. 
16.30.060 - No parking on alternate days. 
    On public streets, not within the core area or designated as an emergency route as defined in this section, no person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle during a snow removal alert on any north-south streets or courts entering off a north-south street on an odd-numbered calendar day, and on any east-west street or court entering off an east-west street on an even numbered calendar day until such snow removal alert is terminated. 
(Ord. 1533 (part), 1986). 
(Ord. No. 2103-16-82, 11-14-2011) 
16.30.070 - Authorization to tow and impound vehicle and payment of costs. 
    No vehicle shall be parked in such a manner interfere with or obstruct the removal of snow from the streets in the city. The city of Huron police department is authorized to tow away any vehicle parked in violation of Section 16.30.020, 16.30.040, 16.30.050 or 16.30.060. For any vehicle towed, the owner shall be responsible for payment of towing costs and payment of all storage costs at rates approved by the city commission. No vehicle which has been towed and impounded for violating Section 16.30.020, 16.30.040, 16.30.050 or 16.30.060 shall be released from impound without the owner first having either paid the snow alert parking violation ticket or contested the ticket in the manner and within the time frame as prescribed by the governing body. 
(Ord. 2054 (part), 2009: Ord. 1533 (part), 1986). 
(Ord. No. 2103-16-82, 11-14-2011; Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
16.30.080 - Violations. 
    Any violation of Sections 16.30.020, 16.30.040, 16.30.050 and 16.30.060 of this code shall be punishable by a noncompliance fee in the amount set by resolution of the governing body. In addition to setting the noncompliance fee, the resolution shall: (1) Identify the time period within which the noncompliance fee must be paid, (2) Identify a late fee if the noncompliance fee is not paid within the prescribed time period, and (3) provide for an appeal process in which the vehicle owner may contest the ticket or late fee. Should the noncompliance fee and late fee not be paid within the time period as set forth in the resolution of the governing body, or at the conclusion of the appeal process if the noncompliance fee or late fee is not waived by the city, a summons and complaint for violation of Section 16.30.040, 16.30.050 or 16.30.060 and Section 16.30.080 shall be issued upon the owner of the vehicle commanding the owner to appear in magistrate court. If convicted in magistrate court the fine shall be in an amount set by resolution of the governing board, plus court costs. In addition to setting the fine, the resolution shall authorize the payment of the fine through power of attorney in lieu of a court appearance. 
(Ord. 2054 (part), 2009: Ord. 1704, 1993: Ord. 1559, 1987: Ord. 1533 (part), 1986). 
(Ord. No. 2103-16-82, 11-14-2011; Ord. No. 2115-16-85, 6-25-2012) 
Chapter 16.32 - RESERVED 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2116-16-86, adopted June 25, 2012, repealed Ch. 16.32, which pertained to parking meters. Please see the Table of Disposition of Ordinances and the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List for complete derivation of this chapter. 
Chapter 16.36 - VEHICLE STANDARDS AND EQUIPMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- License plates required - See SDC 44.01.; Brake efficiency specified - See SDC 44.0346; Horns and warning devices required - See SDC 44.0347; Mufflers required - See SDC 44.0350; Lighting equipment required - See SDC 44.0352; Maximum sizes and weights of vehicles and loads specified - See SDC 44.0336. 

16.36.010 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.36.010 which pertained to license plates and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0172, adopted in 1950. 
16.36.020 - Horns and warning devices. 
    Every motor vehicle when operated upon the city streets shall be equipped with a horn in good working order capable of emitting a sound audible under normal conditions from a distance of at least two hundred feet, and it is unlawful, except as otherwise provided in this section, for any vehicle to be equipped with or for any person to use upon any vehicle any siren, or any compression or spark plug whistle, or any exhaust horn or whistle which does not produce a harmonious sound, or for any person at any time to use a horn otherwise than as a reasonable warning, or to make any unnecessary or unreasonably loud or harsh sound by means of a horn or other warning device. 
    Every police and fire department patrol vehicle and every ambulance used for emergency calls shall be equipped with a bell, siren or exhaust whistle. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0172, 1950). 
16.36.030 - Muffler - Smoke. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle unless such motor vehicle is provided with a muffler, which at all times is kept closed so that the exhaust is effectively muffled. No person shall operate a motor vehicle in such a manner as to emit unnecessary or excessive smoke from the motor of such vehicles. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0135, 1950). 
16.36.040 - Brakes and signaling device. 
    Every motor vehicle shall be provided with adequate brakes in good working order and sufficient to control such motor vehicle at all times when the vehicle is in use and with an adequate bell or horn or other device for signaling. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0136, 1950). 
16.36.050 - Lights. 
    A motor vehicle in motion, during the period from half an hour after sunset to half an hour before sunrise, shall display at least two lighted lamps on the front and one on the rear of such motor vehicle, such lamps to conform to the state law; provided that a motorcycle or a motor bicycle shall be required to display but one lighted lamp in front and one in the rear. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0137, 1950). 
16.36.060 - Dimming headlights. 
    No person shall use headlights or side lights upon any vehicle on any street unless they are dimmed in such a way as to prevent the lights being dazzling or blinding to persons using the streets. Whenever a motor vehicle meets another vehicle on any street it shall be mandatory to tilt the beams of head lamps downward subject to requirement that the tilted lamps shall give sufficient illumination under normal atmospheric conditions and on a level road to render clearly discernable a person seventy-five feet ahead, but shall not project a glaring or dazzling light to persons in front of the vehicle. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0138, 1950). 
16.36.070 - Size and weight of vehicle and load. 
    No person shall drive or operate any vehicle upon any street the maximum width and length of which and the gross weight of which, including the load, does not comply with the requirements of the state law governing such vehicle. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0140, 1950). 
16.36.080 - Muffler cutouts and excessive noise regulated. 
    No person shall drive a motor vehicle on the streets of the city unless such motor vehicle is equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise. Further, it is unlawful to use a muffler "cutout" on any motor vehicle on the streets of the city. 
(Ord. 1012, 1971). 
Chapter 16.40 - EMERGENCY VEHICLES-FIRE REGULATIONS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Maximum speed limits not applicable to fire department vehicles, police vehicles, nor to ambulances when operated in an emergency - See SDC 44.0308. 
Cross reference- Fire department - See Ch. 3.16 of this code; Fire prevention generally - See Title 19 of this code; Police to enforce traffic laws - See Ch. 3.12 of this code. 

16.40.010 - Definition of authorized emergency vehicle. 
    An "authorized emergency vehicle," for purposes of this title, means police car, fire truck and ambulance. 
(Ord. 1706 (part), 1993). 
16.40.020 - Exemptions to authorized emergency vehicles. 
    The provisions of this title regulating the movement, parking and standing of vehicles shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles while the operator of such vehicle is operating the same in an emergency in the necessary performance of public duties. This exemption shall not, however, protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequence of a reckless disregard of the safety of others. 
(Ord. 1706 (part), 1993). 
16.40.030 - Emergency vehicle exceeding speed limit to give warning of approach. 
    The speed limit set out in this title shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles when responding to emergency calls, provided the driver thereof sounds an audible signal by siren or horn and the vehicle is equipped with lighted red or blue lights or a rotary red or blue flasher which are displayed to the front. This provision shall not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the street nor shall it protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequences of a reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Ord. 1706 (part), 1993). 
16.40.040 - Speed limit for private automobiles carrying firemen. 
    No driver of a private automobile driven by or carrying members of the fire department shall drive the car at a dangerous rate of speed or at a rate of speed to exceed five miles an hour over the posted speed limit. 
(Ord. 1706 (part), 1993). 
16.40.050 - Crossing fire hose. 
    No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected fire hose of the fire department when laid down on any street or private driveway to be used at any fire or alarm of fire without the consent of the fire department official in charge. 
(Ord. 1706 (part), 1993). 
16.40.060 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.40.060 which pertained to following fire apparatus and derived from Ord. No. 1706 (part), adopted in 1993. 
Chapter 16.44 - RAILROAD TRAINS AND BUSES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities empowered to regulate the speed of locomotives - See SDC 45.0201(41); Municipalities authorized to regulate the use of streets and to prevent and remove obstructions upon the same - See SDC 45.0201(44); Municipalities authorized to regulate the use of motor vehicles - See SDC 45.0201(32). 
Cross reference- Vehicles or obstructions in streets - See Ch. 15.24 of this code. 

16.44.010 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.44.010 which pertained to railroad trains obstructing streets and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0149, April 24, 1950. 
16.44.020 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.44.020 which pertained to uncoupling train obstructing streets and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0150, April 24, 1950. 
16.44.030 - "Flying switches" prohibited. 
    Whenever any railroad intersects any street, alley or avenue of the City of Huron, it shall be unlawful for any railroad company, engineer, conductor or other person to conduct, permit, allow or assist in any "flying switch." 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0151; April 24, 1950). 
16.44.040 - Speed of railroad trains. 
    The speed at which any railroad equipment may be operated within the city shall be reasonable under the existing conditions, with due regard to the safety of the public. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0152; April 24, 1950). 
16.44.050 - Operation of buses. 
    Buses operated upon the streets of the city, as public carriers shall not be operated so as to impede traffic or obstruct the streets, shall not be double parked, shall not be behind another such bus closer than fifty feet except when stopping for the purpose of taking on or letting off passengers or while passing another such bus, and when driven to the curb shall be kept parallel to the curb. No more than two such buses shall be parked within a block in the business district except at the beginning or end of the established route traveled. Such buses shall not be so loaded as to obstruct the view of the driver thereof. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0153; April 24, 1950). 
16.44.060 - Bus stops. 
    The governing body may establish bus stops in such places as it shall consider to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop shall be designated by appropriate signs. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle other than a bus to stand or park in any officially designated bus stop except that he may temporarily stop in such area for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any bus to stand or park upon any street in the business district at any place other than at a designated bus stop. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0154, 1950). 
Chapter 16.48 - BICYCLES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- General license provisions - See Ch. 5.04 of this code; Minors' curfew - See Ch. 9.20 of this code; Street and sidewalk use regulations - See Ch. 15.24 of this code. 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ord 483 §§ 16.0301 through 16.0307, as amended by Ord. 1116. 

16.48.010 - Registration. 
    Every owner of a bicycle may list and register with the finance office his name and address, the name of the manufacturer of his bicycle, its number, style and general description. 
(Ord. 1486 (part), 1983). 
16.48.030 - Tag and registration certificate. 
    The finance officer shall provide the police department copies of all registrations and shall furnish to the owner a suitable metallic or decal identification tag upon which shall be marked or stamped a distinguishing number for each bicycle registered. The owner shall affix and keep affixed to the bicycle for which the same is issued the original metallic or decal tag. 
(Ord. 1486 (part), 1983). 
16.48.040 - Registration fee. 
    The fee for such registration and identification tag shall be one dollar and shall be paid to the city finance officer. The issuance of the tag provided for in this chapter, and the record thereof as provided in this chapter, shall be the evidence of the registration of the bicycle and a written certificate thereof shall be issued. Upon change of ownership and surrender of the old tag and certificate such registration may be transferred and new tag issued in the manner provided in this chapter in the name of the new owner upon payment by him of a fee of one dollar payable at the office of the finance officer. 
(Ord. 1486 (part), 1983). 
16.48.050 - Tags and certificate nontransferable. 
    Tags shall not be transferred from one bicycle to another and no person shall attach to any bicycle a tag not issued for use thereon. 
(Ord. 1486 (part), 1983).
