16.48.060 - Unlawful to interfere with pedestrians. 
    No person shall ride or propel any bicycle upon any public street, highway or boulevard in such a manner as to interfere with any pedestrian thereon. 
(Ord. 1486 (part), 1983). 
16.48.070 - Care in riding. 
(1)  No person shall ride or propel a bicycle upon any public street, highway or boulevard except in a careful and prudent manner and unless such person shall be capable of efficient control and operation of such bicycle, nor shall any person propel or operate a bicycle upon a public street, highway or boulevard carrying or permitting to be carried any other person upon such bicycle. 
(2)  No bicycle shall be ridden faster than is reasonable and proper, but every bicycle shall be operated with reasonable regard to the safety of the operator and other persons upon the streets and highways of the city. 
(3)  Persons riding or propelling any bicycle shall observe all traffic signs and stop at all stop signs. 
(4)  No bicycle shall be permitted on any street, highway or boulevard of the city between thirty minutes after sunset and thirty minutes before sunrise without a headlight visible from the front thereof for not less than two hundred feet, indicating the approach or presence of the bicycle, which light shall be firmly attached to the bicycle, and properly lighted, nor without a red tail light or in lieu thereof a reflector attached to and visible from the rear of such bicycle for a distance of not less than two hundred feet. 
(5)  No person under the age of twelve years shall ride or propel a bicycle upon any street, highway or boulevard in the city at night after the hour of nine p.m. 
(6)  No person shall ride or propel a bicycle upon any public street, highway or boulevard in the city more than two abreast. 
(7)  Every person riding or propelling a bicycle upon any public street, highway or boulevard in the city shall observe all traffic rules and regulations applicable thereto, and shall turn only at intersections, signaling for all turns, ride at the right-hand side of the street or highway, pass to the left when passing vehicles or bicycles that are slower moving, and shall pass to the right when meeting. 
(Ord. 1486 (part), 1983). 
(Ord. No. 2143-16-89, 5-5-2014) 
Chapter 16.52 - PEDESTRIANS[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to regulate the use of sidewalks, streets, alleys and public grounds - See SDC 45.0201(44). 
Cross reference- Street and sidewalk use regulations - See Ch. 15.24 of this code. 

16.52.010 - Use of crosswalks. 
    No pedestrian shall go from one side of the street to the other except at a right angle at regular crosswalks at the end of a block upon any street in the business section or on any through street. A pedestrian shall use the right half of the crosswalk when crossing a street. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0110, 1950.) 
16.52.020 - Pedestrians' right-of-way. 
    The operator of any vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within any marked crosswalk or within any unmarked crosswalk at the end of a block or entrance to an alley, except at intersections where the movement of traffic is being regulated by police officers or traffic-control signals. Whenever any vehicle has stopped at a crosswalk or intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross a roadway, the operator of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0111, 1950). 
16.52.030 - Pedestrians walking along roadways. 
(a)  Where sidewalks are provided, it is unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction. 
(Ord. 483 § 16.0113, 1950). 
Chapter 16.56 - ACCIDENTS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Duty to stop imposed by statute - See SDC 44.0330; Duty to report accidents imposed by statute - See SDC 44.0331; Duty of garage keeper imposed by statute - See SDC 44.0332. 

16.56.010 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.56.010 which pertained to duty to stop in case of accident and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0168, adopted in 1950. 
16.56.020 - Duty to stop after accident with unattended vehicle or property-Leaving information-Report to police. 
    The driver of any vehicle which collides with or is involved in an accident with any vehicle or other property which is unattended, resulting in any damage to such other vehicle or property, shall immediately stop and shall then and there either locate and notify the operator or owner of such vehicle or other property of his name, address and the name and address of the owner and the license number of the vehicle he is driving or shall attach securely in any conspicuous place in or on such vehicle or other property a written notice giving his name, address and the name and address of the owner and the license number of the vehicle he is driving and shall immediately by the quickest means of communication give notice of such accident to the police department. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. 
(Ord. 1353, 1979: Ord. 1318, 1978: Ord. 483 § 16.0169, 1950). 
16.56.030 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.56.030 which pertained to duty to report accidents and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0170, adopted in 1950; Ord. No. 1164 (part), adopted in 1975; Ord. No. 1304, adopted in 1978; and Ord. No. 1330, adopted in 1978. 
16.56.040 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2143-16-89, adopted May 5, 2014, repealed § 16.56.040 which pertained to garage keeper to report damaged vehicle and derived from Ord. No. 483, § 16.0171, adopted in 1950. 
Chapter 16.58 - TRUCK ROUTES 

16.58.010 - Authority to post signs. 
    The commissioner of police and fire of the city is empowered to designate, from time to time, in his discretion, truck routes within the city. Such routes shall be plainly marked by adequate signs and may be changed from time to time as the commissioner of police and fire believes necessary and he shall promulgate such routes in writing and shall file the same with the city auditor. 
(Ord. 876 (part), 1965). 
16.58.015 - Designation of truck routes. 
(a)  The following streets within and around the City of Huron are designated as truck routes for trucks having a gross weight over six thousand pounds: 
1.  West Park Avenue from US Highway 14 to 21st Street SW. 
2.  21st Street from West Park Avenue SW to Custer Avenue SE. 
3.  Custer Avenue from US Highway 14 to 21st Street SE. 
(b)  Trucks having a gross weight of over six thousand pounds per axle may deviate from the truck routes to the extent required to reach a necessary destination within the City of Huron which is not located on the truck routes. But, to the maximum extent possible, truck traffic will follow, in order of priority, the truck routes designated above, then the principle arterials, then the major collectors, then the minor arterials, and then other local streets, as the vehicle driver attempts to make a delivery within the city. The city streets identified in each classification are: 
1.  Principle Arterials: 
i.  US Highway 14 within city limits; and 
ii.  SD Highway 37 within city limits. 
2.  Major Collectors: 
i.  Third Street SE and SW from West Park Avenue to the James River; 
ii.  Market Street SE and SW; and 
iii.  Old Highway 14. 
3.  Minor Arterials: 
i.  West Park Avenue from US Highway 14 to 21st Street SW; 
ii.  21st Street SE and SW from West Park Avenue to the James River; and 
iii.  Lincoln Avenue NW and SW from 7th Street NW to 21st Street SW. 
4.  All other streets are local streets. 
(c)  The designated truck routes within the City of Huron existing prior to the enactment and adoption of this section are no longer designated truck routes within the City of Huron. 
(Ord. No. 2145-16-90, 8-4-2014) 
16.58.020 - Truck drivers responsibilities. 
    It shall be the duty of all truck drivers within the city limits to drive and operate trucks having a gross vehicle weight of over six thousand pounds upon the routes hereinabove designated except trucks making local delivery and service calls. 
(Ord. 876 (part), 1965). 
16.58.030 - Enforcement. 
    The chief of police and all of the officers of the police department are authorized and directed to enforce the regulations above referred to and to direct all truck drivers, other than that hereinabove excepted, to travel upon such truck routes. 
(Ord. 876 (part), 1965). 
16.58.040 - State statutes or state highway department regulations. 
    Nothing in the foregoing section shall be construed to modify or change any of the regulations of the State Highway Department or the statutes of the state of South Dakota with reference to the gross weight permitted upon any highways within the city. 
(Ord. 876 (part), 1965). 
16.58.050 - Weighing of vehicles. 
    The chief of police and all officers of the police department shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any commercial vehicle to proceed to any public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining whether this chapter has been complied with. 
(Ord. 876 (part), 1965). 
16.58.060 - Penalty. 
    Any person or persons, firms or corporations violating any of the regulations hereinabove referred to by propelling or operating a truck upon a route other than that designated shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. 1707, 1993: Ord. 876 (part), 1965). 
Chapter 16.60 - SNOWMOBILES 

16.60.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires: 
    "Operator" means a person who operates or is in actual control of a snowmobile; 
    "Snowmobile" means any engine-driven vehicle of a type which utilizes sled-type runners, wheels or skis, with an endless belt tread or similar means of contact with the surface upon which it is operated; 
    "Street" means every highway and street within the city limits; 
    "Owner" means any person, other than a lienholder, having the property in or title to a snowmobile and entitled to the use or possession thereof. 
(Ord. 1013 (part), 1972). 
16.60.020 - Regulations. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile: 
(a)  On the portion of any right-of-way on any city street or avenue used for motor vehicle travel, except the most right-hand lane which is used for vehicular traffic in the same direction other than on expressways or state highways. While operating on the most right-hand lane as previously provided, at no time may snowmobiles be operated two or more abreast. Snowmobiles may operate in the road ditch where expressways or state highways are so configured within the city limits; 
(b)  No person shall operate a snowmobile on private property of another without the express permission to do so by the owner or occupant of said property; 
(c)  No person shall operate a snowmobile on public schoolgrounds, park property, playgrounds, slide areas, recreational areas and golf courses without the express permission to do so by the proper authority; 
(d)  No person shall operate a snowmobile in any manner so as to create loud, unnecessary or unusual noise so as to disturb or interfere with the peace and quiet of other persons. 
(e)  No person shall operate a snowmobile on any public sidewalk provided for pedestrian travel, or on boulevards within any public right-of-way, or on any alleys, except that travel is permitted on alleys when traveling from a place of storage to the nearest street; 
(f)  No person shall operate a snowmobile on Dakota Avenue from 15th Street North to 21st Street South, or on Third Street from Frank Avenue East to Lincoln Avenue West, or on 9th Street South from Lawn Ridge Avenue East to Lincoln Avenue West, except to cross these streets, in the shortest distance possible; 
(g)  No person shall operate a snowmobile within an area bordered by Market Road to the north, Illinois Avenue to the west, 7th Street to the south, and Idaho Avenue to the east, except under road and weather conditions as declared by the chief of police or director of civil defense to constitute emergency travel conditions authorizing use of a snowmobile, or when such vehicle is necessary as an emergency vehicle to protect the health, safety and welfare of any individual; 
(h)  No person shall operate a snowmobile in a careless, reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger the safety of any person the property of any other person; 
(i)  No person shall operate a snowmobile within the city limits without having such snowmobile registered as provided by South Dakota state law; 
(j)  No person shall operate a snowmobile on any city street, alley, avenue, or ditch, as an emergency vehicle or otherwise, unless the operator shall have a valid driver's license on his person; 
(k)  Snowmobiles may have a maximum of one additional rider, other than the driver. 
(Ord. 1923 (part), 2001: Ord. 1058, 1973; Ord. 1013 (part), 1972). 
16.60.030 - Exceptions to regulations. 
    Notwithstanding the prohibition of this chapter, the superintendent of parks and recreation shall have authority to supervise and regulate events or programs in connection with the events conducted by the parks and recreation department in which snowmobiles are used. The parks and recreation director shall have the authority to designate city park areas that he shall deem available for use of snowmobiles. If and when such park areas are designated, twelve year olds, or older, can operate a snowmobile in the designated area; provided that said individual is supervised by person who has a valid driver's license on his person. 
(Ord. 1013 (part), 1972). 
16.60.040 - Equipment required. 
    All snowmobiles operated within the city shall have the following equipment: 
(a)  Mufflers which are properly attached and which reduce the noise of operation of the vehicle to the minimum noise necessary for operating the vehicle, and no person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass or similar device on said vehicle, and no person shall use a megaphone or tuned-exhaust system or similar device on said vehicle; 
(b)  Adequate brakes in good working condition; 
(c)  A safety or so-called "deadman" throttle in operating condition. A safety or deadman throttle is defined as a device which when pressure is removed from the accelerator, the throttle causes the motor to disengage from the driving track; 
(d)  Any snowmobile being operated during the hours of darkness shall display a lighted headlamp and taillamp in accordance with SDCL 32-17 as may have been approved by the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles at least equivalent to that required for motorcycles; 
(e)  A pennant flag of red or blaze material, of a size not less than twelve inches by nine inches, properly attached at a height of not less than six feet from the ground level at any time when the vehicle is operated within the city limits. Also, each snowmobile shall have a one inch strip of reflectorized material on both sides of the pennant flag, covering at least three-fourths the length of the flag specified. 
(Ord. 1099 (part), 1973; Ord. 1013 (part), 1972). 
16.60.050 - Unattended vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or operator of a snowmobile to leave or allow the snowmobile to be or remain unattended on public property while the motor is running or where the keys for starting the vehicle are left in the ignition. 
(Ord. 1013 (part), 1972). 
16.60.060 - Unlawful acts. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile within the city limits: 
(a)  During the hours from eleven p.m. to six a.m. of any day; 
(b)  To tow any person or thing in or on the public streets or roads or other city property except through the use of a rigid towbar attached to the rear of a snowmobile. 
(Ord. 1013 (part), 1972). 
16.60.070 - Exemptions. 
(a)  None of the aforementioned provisions of this chapter are to be construed to mean that snowmobiles are permitted to operate on any public street or road or other public property within the city for the purpose of recreation, but rather the aforementioned provisions are intended to provide an exit out of the city and a return to the residence of the operator or his place of storage for the snowmobile, by way of the most direct and closest route available; however, those individuals who live outside the city limits shall have the right to operate snowmobiles upon the public streets and roads as provided in this chapter, when such vehicle is necessary as an emergency vehicle to protect the health, safety and welfare of any individual. 
(b)  Snowmobile clubs, organizations, individuals or groups of snowmobiles from the region are allowed to enter the community to access services (gas, hotel/motel rooms, food, restrooms, maintenance, etc.) located in the vicinity of 18th to 21st Streets along Dakota Avenue South and along 21st Street from Ohio to Kansas Avenues. Current restrictions regarding prohibition to travel on Dakota Avenue remain in place. Snowmobiles entering the community for access to services shall stay within the area bounded by 18th Street SW/SE on the north, Ohio Avenue SW on the west and Kansas Avenue SE on the east. A groomed snowmobile path on the boulevard will be allowed along 21st Street SE from the James River to Frank Avenue SE. 
(Ord. 1923 (part), 2001; Ord. 1013 (part), 1972). 
16.60.080 - Violation as misdemeanor-Punishment. 
    Any person who violates any provision of Sections 16.60.020 to 16.60.070, both inclusive, is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a penalty pursuant to the general penalty provisions in Section 1.04.130. 
(Ord. 1708, 1993: Ord. 1013 (part), 1992). 
16.60.100 - Traffic regulations-Violations as misdemeanor-Punishment. 
    Every person operating a snowmobile shall strictly observe all traffic signs and signals and all other traffic rules and regulations applicable thereto, and shall obey the orders and directions of any police officer of the city authorized to direct or regulate traffic. Any violator is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereto shall be punished accordingly. 
(Ord. 1013 (part), 1972). 
16.60.110 - Prohibition of operation. 
    Notwithstanding the above provisions, the city commissioners may at any time give notice, and prohibit the operation of snowmobiles within the city limits, when, in their opinion, the public safety and welfare so requires. The prohibition shall continue until the city commissioners remove the same. 
(Ord. 1013 (part), 1972). 
Title 17 - PUBLIC SHELTERS 
Chapter 17.04 - PUBLIC SHELTER MANAGERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Cities may provide for appointment of such officers as may be provided for by ordinance - See SDC 45.1103. 
Cross reference- Officers and employees - See Ch. 2.08 of this code. 

17.04.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Public Shelter Managers Ordinance of the City of Huron, South Dakota." 
(Ord. 818 § 1, 1963). 
17.04.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and terms, unless the context otherwise clearly indicates, shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein: 
(A)  "National emergency" means any attack or series of attacks by an enemy of the United States causing, or which may cause, substantial damage or injury to civilian property or persons in the United States in any manner by sabotage or by the use of bombs, missiles, shellfire, or atomic, radiological, chemical, bacteriological or biological means or other weapons or processes. 
(B)  "Public shelters" means any structure designated by the department of civil defense as and to be used as a public shelter in the event of an enemy attack or national emergency. 
(C)  "Civil defense director" means the duly appointed Civil Defense Director of the Huron-Beadle County Civil Defense District. 
(D)  "Shelter manager" means the duly appointed public shelter manager or managers as appointed by the local civil defense director. 
(E)  "Shelter use plan" means the rules and regulations promulgated by the Huron-Beadle County Civil Defense District pertaining to the operation, use and living conditions of a public shelter during an enemy attack or national emergency. 
(F)  "Shelter occupants" means the general public who are assigned to, or have by reason of an enemy attack or national emergency become occupants in any of the designated public shelters. 
(Ord. 818 § 2, 1963). 
17.04.030 - Appointment and duties of public shelter manager. 
    In case of national emergency, public shelter managers duly appointed by the civil defense director, shall open public shelters, take charge of all stocks of food, water and other supplies stored in said shelter, admit the public according to the city's shelter use plan and take whatever control measures are necessary for the protection and safety of the occupants. 
(Ord. 818 § 3, 1963). 
17.04.040 - Authority of public shelter manager. 
    Shelter manager or managers are authorized to use reasonable restraint against any occupant of a public shelter who refuses to cooperate in an orderly manner and abide by the rules and regulations which shall provide for routine living in a public shelter under emergency conditions, as established by the Huron-Beadle County Civil Defense District officials. 
(Ord. 818 § 4, 1963). 
17.04.050 - Penalties for violations. 
    Any occupant in a public shelter living under emergency conditions who refuses to carry out the orders of the public shelter manager and his appointed staff or abide by the established public shelter rules and regulations shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or a jail sentence of not more than thirty days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 1235, 1976; Ord. 818 § 5, 1963). 
Title 18 - BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health provisions generally - See Title 6 of this code; Fire limits and regulations - See Title 19 of this code; Rat-proofing - See Ch. 6.12 of this code; Zoning - See Title 23 of this code; Address numbering - See Ch. 15.08 of this code; Building moving - See Ch. 15.28 of this code. 

Chapter 18.04 - BUILDING INSPECTOR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees - See Ch. 2.08 of this code. 

18.04.010 - Appointment. 
    All duties and responsibilities of the department of building inspections are designated as the responsibilities of the building inspector. 
(Ord. 1625 (part), 1990: Ord. 1469, 1983: Ord. 483 § 3.0101, 1950). 
18.04.020 - Powers and authority. 
    The building inspector is authorized empowered, and required: 
(a)  To enforce all the provisions of ordinances of the city relating to construction, equipment, management and condition of all structures within the city of Huron; 
(b)  To maintain records on all matters pertaining to the enforcement and regulation of this chapter, which records shall be at all times available for inspection by the governing body; 
(c)  The building inspector shall have the authority of a police officer in the execution of his duties. 
(Ord. 883, 1965: Ord. 483 § 3.0103, 1950). 
18.04.030 - Supervision and regulation of building. 
    All erection, repair, alteration, moving and demolition of buildings within the corporate limits of the city of Huron shall be under the supervision and regulation of the building inspector, whose duty it shall be to enforce all the provisions of ordinances relating thereto, and from time to time make such rules and regulations as may be appropriate for the execution of the same. In case any difference should arise between the building inspector and the owner of any building, or any person engaged in or desirous of doing any construction, repair, alteration, moving or demolition of buildings, regarding the interpretation of any of the provisions of this code, or the enforcement of the same, appeal may be made to the board of appeals pursuant to Section 9.58.120, whose decision thereon shall be final. 
(Ord. 1828, 1998: Ord. 1625 (part), 1990: Ord. 483 § 3.0104, 1950). 
Chapter 18.08 - BUILDING PERMITS 

18.08.010 - Building permit required. 
(a)  No wall, structure, building or part of building shall be constructed or added to, or any permanent fixture, including heat producing appliances, heating, ventilating, air conditioning, blower and exhaust systems, or conversion units thereof, attached to such building until a plan or proposed work statement of the materials to be used, the proposed site of such structure and name of owner of the property to be improved shall be submitted to the building inspector by the contractor, builder or owner; which proposed work statement shall also state the value or cost of such improvement. If the building inspector is satisfied that such proposed improvement complies with the law and city ordinances, he may authorize issuing a permit for such work, construction or improvement. If the value or costs of the improvement for which a permit has been issued shall exceed the cost or value of the amount stated in the application for permit and the permit granted, the contractor, builder or owner shall furnish to the building inspector an additional statement of the cost and value of such improvement. 
(b)  For just cause a building permit may be denied for a location identified on the application. Just cause includes, but is not limited to the owner of the property, agent who submits the application on behalf of the owner, or a contractor identified on the application as being responsible for work specified on the application. 
(1)  Is in arrears on payment for any city bills, such as utility bills, miscellaneous bills or special assessments (including nuisance-related special assessments); or 
(2)  At the time the application for a building permit is submitted has failed to complete work with respect to a previous building permit within the time specified for completion on the previous building permit. 
(c)  The building inspector may issue a building permit which shall be valid for one hundred eighty days from the date the permit is issued. The applicant may in writing request an extension. For good cause shown, the building inspector may deny the request for an extension, grant one or more extensions for an additional period not exceeding one hundred eighty days each, or may refer the request for an extension to the city commission. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person, owner or contractor or builder to attempt to proceed with any work or improvement of any kind for which a permit is in this section required without first having obtained a permit for same. 
(e)  Any person who proceeds with work without properly obtaining a building permit shall be required to pay a late assessment fee in addition to the required fee for the building permit. The late assessment fee shall be based on the following schedule: 
(1)  If the value of the construction is zero dollars to forty thousand dollars, the late assessment fee shall be fifty dollars. 
(2)  If the value of the construction is forty thousand one dollars to eighty thousand dollars, the late assessment fee shall be one hundred dollars. 
(3)  If the value of the construction is eighty thousand one dollars to one hundred twenty thousand dollars, the late assessment fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars. 
(4)  If the value of the construction is one hundred twenty thousand one dollars or greater, the late assessment fee shall be two hundred dollars. 
(f)  Any person, owner, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall upon conviction thereof be punished by a fine not exceeding two hundred dollars or by imprisonment in the city jail for a period not exceeding thirty days. 
(Ord. 2006, 2005: Ord. 1964, 2003: Ord. 1939, (part), 2002: Ord. 1666, 1992: Ord. 1626, 1990: Ord. 884, 1965: Ord. 531, 1953: Ord. 483 § 3.0102, 1950). 
Chapter 18.12 - BUILDING CODE[3] 

Footnotes:

18.12.010 - Adoption of ICC 2015 Version Codes. 
(a)  There is adopted by the city of Huron for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of buildings and structures, including permits and penalties, located within the corporate limits of the city, that certain building code known as the International Building Codes, recommended by the International Conference of Building Officials, being particularly the 2015 Edition and any amendments thereto, and the following related codes and standards all published by the International Code Council: 
International Building Codes: Commercial Buildings & Multi-family Buildings 
International Residential Codes: One & Two Family Dwellings 
International Property Maintenance Codes & Nuisance Properties 
International Existing Building Codes 
International Energy Conservation Codes 
and the whole thereof and any amendments thereto, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended, of which not less than one (1) copy has been and now is filed in the office of the finance officer, and the same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length in this chapter, and from the date on which the ordinance codified in this chapter shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling in the construction of all buildings and other structures therein contained within the corporate limits of the city.

Such rules and regulations shall be consistent with the provisions of this chapter and the standards established in this chapter. 
(5)  Offenses. Any person who violates any provisions of this chapter or any provisions of any rule or regulation adopted and promulgated under this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day's violation is a separate misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 1969, 2004).

Chapter 18.16 - ELECTRICAL WIRING AND APPARATUS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- For provisions on electric signs, see Ch. 18.32 of this code; for provisions on air conditions and refrigeration, see Ch. 18.24 of this code; for provisions on officers and employees, see Ch. 2.08 of this code. 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ord. 483 §§ 3.0201 through 3.0235, as amended by Ords. 706, 793 and 886; and Ords. 970, 999, 1000, 1017, 1018, 1135, 1147, 1305, 1423 and 1424. 

18.16.010 - Electrical regulations. 
    All electrical wiring, apparatus or equipment shall comply with the rules and regulations promulgated and adopted by the South Dakota Electrical Board as provided in South Dakota Codified Laws and the National Electric Code 1993 Edition, Standards of the National Board of Fire Underwriters for Electric Wiring and Apparatus as copyrighted by the National Fire Protection Association, 470 Atlantic Avenue, Boston, Massachusetts 00210, which is adopted by this reference as though fully set forth herein. 
(Ord. 1781, 1996: Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.020 - Inferior electrical materials prohibited. 
    Every person before selling, offering for sale, or exposing for sale any electrical material, device, or appliance designed for attachment to or installation in or on any electrical circuit or system for light, heat or power, shall first determine if such material, device or appliance is approved for installation and use in the city in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. No person or his agent or employee shall sell, offer for sale, or expose for sale any such material, device or appliance which does not comply with all of the provisions of this chapter. 
    All electrical appliances or devices, including materials used in installation thereof, or in the installation of the necessary wiring for the utilization of electricity for light, heat or power, shall be only those which are approved for the purpose intended, and the maker's name, trademark, or other identification symbol, shall be placed thereon, together with such other markings giving voltage, current, wattage, or other appropriate ratings, as may be necessary to determine the purpose and use for which intended. No person shall remove, alter, change, or deface the maker's name, trademark, or other identification symbol, or any of the necessary rating marks required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.030 - Emergency shut off of electric current. 
    The building inspector shall have authority, whenever in his opinion public safety requires it and to require any person, firm or corporation using or operating any electric system, to disconnect the electric current therefrom, for such period of time as the building inspector may deem necessary; and the fire chief or other commanding officer of the fire department shall have authority in case of fire, to have the electric current cut off from any or all wires which he knows or believes are dangerous to life and property. Any person, firm or corporation who refuses to shut off such current in accordance with the order of the building inspector or fire chief of the fire department, or his assistants who may be in authority at the fire, is liable to penalty of seventy-five dollars for each and every hour during which the direction of the building inspector or fire department official shall be disregarded, provided that such penalty shall not exceed the sum of five hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.040 - Approval required for service connections. 
    No person shall make connection from a source of electric energy to any electric wiring, devices, equipment or electrical systems for the installation of which a permit is required, until a certificate of approval has been issued by the State Electrical Inspector authorizing such connection and the use of such wiring, devices, equipment, or electrical systems. When a certificate is issued authorizing the connection and use of temporary work, such a certificate shall be issued to expire at a stated time and shall be revokable by the State Electrical Inspector at his discretion. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.050 - Approval required for service reconnections. 
    No person shall make reconnections from a source of electrical energy to any electrical wiring, devices, equipment or electrical systems which has been disconnected or ordered to be disconnected by the electrical inspector, or the use of which has been ordered by the electrical inspector to be discontinued, until a certificate of approval has been issued by him authorizing reconnection and use of such wiring, devices, equipment or electrical systems. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.060 - Removal of dead wires and unused poles. 
    The building inspector shall have authority to remove or cause to be removed all dead wires and unused poles, and all wire and poles unlawfully erected and maintained in the streets and other public places in the city. No new poles shall be erected until first obtaining the approval of, and a permit for the same, from the building inspector in writing. This provision shall apply to such utility companies as electric power, telephone, cable television, etc. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.070 - Underground wiring installations. 
    Whenever the installation of electric wires underground shall be approved by the building inspector, and so requested by a utility company, then the person, firm or corporation maintaining or using wires above ground, shall take down and remove at their own expense all poles used for the support of such aboveground wires, and place their conduits and conducting wires beneath the ground in conformity with the latest approved and standard methods of installation for underground wiring systems. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.080 - Plans and specifications to be filed. 
    It is hereafter unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to lay any electrical conduits without first filing with the building inspector plans and specifications of the work to be done, and obtaining a written approval of the application and a permit for such work, which application so approved, shall be filed in the department of building inspections for record purposes. 
(Ord. 1628 (part), 1990: Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.090 - Excavation in public places. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as canceling the necessity of securing excavating permits prior to any excavations in public places as required by ordinance; nor as canceling the requirements for approval of working excavating plans for the proposed wiring installation project for which a permit is being requested from the building inspector. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.100 - Examination of applications for wiring projects. 
    The building inspector shall examine every application for the erection of poles or towers for the support of wires in or over any street or public place, or for conduits under any street or public place for such wires, and he shall report to the governing body any facts, which in his opinion, bear upon the question of granting or refusing to grant such application. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.110 - Furnishing information and location of facilities. 
    Upon the request of the building inspector, the person, firm or corporation operating electric or other wire systems upon, over or under any street or building, shall within fifteen days thereafter furnish accurate drawings showing the locations of their poles and the number of crossarms thereto affixed, and the number of wires thereto attached; the location of subways, manholes and other pertinent information related to the completed project, together with the location where service is rendered, viz: telegraphic, telephonic, electric lighting, cable television or for electric power systems. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.120 - Permanent rights not granted. 
    All wires used within the city for the purpose of carrying an electric current shall be subject to the following conditions: No permanent rights shall be obtained in the streets or public grounds by the reason of such use, and such wires shall be subject to change of location or removal, when deemed necessary; and in case of fire, if necessary, such wires may be cut or removed by order of the building inspector or officers in command of the fire department, without claims against the municipality therefor. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
18.16.130 - Inspector's authority in abnormal cases. 
    The building inspector shall decide all questions pertaining to the installation of electric wires, equipment and devices not referred to or provided for in this chapter or which is not covered by the National Electrical Code or state regulations. 
(Ord. 1472 (part), 1983). 
Chapter 18.20 - SOUTH DAKOTA STATE PLUMBING CODE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Sewers and water generally - Title 21 of this code; Officers and employees - See Ch. 2.08 of this code. 
Editor's note- Prior ordinance history: Ords. 1009, 1236, 1270 and 1425. 

18.20.010 - Title-South Dakota State Plumbing Code. 
    This chapter shall be known as the South Dakota State Plumbing Code, may be so cited and will be referred to in this chapter as "this Code." 
    The administration and enforcement of this chapter shall be the duty of the city building inspector who is authorized to take such action as may be reasonably necessary to enforce the purposes of this Code. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.020 - Scope. 
    The provisions of this Code shall apply to and govern plumbing as defined in this Code, including the practice, materials, and fixtures used in the installation, maintenance, extension, and alteration of all piping, fixtures, appliances, and appurtenances in connection with any of the following: Sanitary drainage or storm drainage facilities, the venting system, and the public or private water supply systems, within or adjacent to any building or other structure, or conveyance, also the practice and materials used in the installation, maintenance, extension, or alteration of the storm water or sewage system of any premises to their connection with any point of public disposal or other terminal. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.030 - Facilities. 
    It is recognized that certain facilities in or adjacent to public streets are referred to in this Code only a portion of which is under the ownership or the control of the owner or occupant of the building or premises to which this Code applies. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.040 - Plumbing contractor's license. 
    No individual shall engage in the business of plumbing in the city of Huron unless licensed as a plumbing contractor by the South Dakota State Plumbing Commission. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.050 - Supervision of work. 
    No individual, firm, partnership or corporation shall engage in the business of installing, repairing, or altering plumbing unless the plumbing work performed in the course of such business is under the direct supervision of a licensed plumbing contractor. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.060 - Code-Adopted. 
    The South Dakota Plumbing Code is adopted and all installations, repairs, and alterations of plumbing shall, from October 7, 1971, be performed in accordance with its provisions. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.070 - Code-Copies on file. 
    Two copies of the South Dakota State Plumbing Code shall be kept on file by the department of building inspections for the use of the public and shall be marked with the words "City of Huron, official copy." 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.080 - Issuance of permit. 
    No plumbing work, unless excepted in this chapter, shall be undertaken prior to the issuance of a permit therefor by the building inspector. A permit shall be issued to a licensed plumbing contractor, except as provided in Section 18.20.090. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.090 - Exception. 
    Any permit required by this Code may be issued to any person to do any work regulated by this Code if: 
(1)  They hold a valid license as provided by South Dakota Administrative Rules 20:53:05, or 
(2)  In a single-family dwelling used exclusively for living purposes, including the usual accessory buildings and quarters in connection with such building, provided the person is the bona fide owner of such dwelling and that the owner shall personally purchase all material and perform all labor in connection therewith. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.100 - Application for permit. 
    Application for permit shall be made on suitable forms provided by the building inspector. The application shall be accompanied by fees in accordance with schedule of fees. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.110 - Schedule of fees. 
    The schedule of permit fees shall be set by resolution of the governing body for water heaters and lawn sprinkling systems. 
(Ord. 2045, 2008: Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.120 - Plans and specifications. 
    No permit shall be issued until plans and specifications showing the proposed work in necessary detail have been submitted to the city building inspector and he has determined from examination of such plans and specifications that they give assurance that the work will conform to the provisions of this code. If a permit is denied, the applicant may submit revised plans and specifications without payment of additional fee. If, in the course of the work, it is found necessary to make any change from the plans and specifications on which a permit has been issued, amended plans and specifications shall be submitted and a supplementary permit, subject to the same conditions applicable to original application for permit, shall be issued to cover the change. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.130 - Repairs. 
    Repairs involving only the working parts of a faucet or valve, the clearance of stoppages, repairing of leaks, or replacement of defective faucets, fixtures, or valves may be made without a permit provided no changes are made in the piping to the fixtures. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.140 - Protection of water supply system. 
    The governing body shall make such rules and regulations in furtherance of the purposes of this Code and not inconsistent with the specific provisions of this Code, for the installation, repair or alteration of air conditioning systems, water treatment equipment, and water operated devices as may be deemed necessary to properly protect the water supply system. When the plumbing repair is fifty percent or more of the total plumbing, a backflow preventer will be required. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.150 - Inspections and tests. 
    It shall be the duty of the city building inspector to enforce the provisions of this Code and to make the inspections and tests required thereunder. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.160 - Entry. 
    The city building inspector shall, after proper identification, have the right to enter any premises for the purpose of inspecting any plumbing system at such times as may be reasonably necessary to protect the public health. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
18.20.170 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars, nor more than one hundred dollars or imprisonment for more than thirty days. 
(Ord. 1629 (part), 1990). 
Chapter 18.24 - AIR CONDITIONING AND REFRIGERATION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to regulate the construction and installation of electrical appliances - See SDC 45.0201(57). 
Cross reference- Electrical wiring and apparatus-See Ch. 18.16 of this code. 

18.24.010 - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise expressly stated, whenever used in this chapter the following words shall have the meaning given to them by this section: 
(a)  "Air conditioning" means the cooling or dehumidification, or both, of space for human occupancy. 
(b)  "Ton of refrigeration" means the heat required to melt ice at the rate of one ton in twenty-four hours. One compressor horsepower shall be considered equivalent to one ton of refrigeration. 
(c)  "Installed capacity" means the total number of tons of refrigeration installed on one air conditioning system. 
(d)  "Air conditioning system, or air conditioning installation" means one or more air conditioning units, the water for which passes through a common meter, whether or not the units are owned by the property owner, the tenant or a combination of both. It is intended that separate submetering for any property owner or tenant occupying different space in the same building could create separate systems; it is not intended that submetering of individual units serving the same space or adjacent space under one owner or tenant would create separate systems. 
(e)  "Water regulating device" means a regulating valve or other device, the purpose of which is to limit the maximum use of water to a predetermined rate. 
(f)  "Water conserving device" means a cooling tower spray pound, evaporative condenser or other equipment by which the water is cooled and recirculated, thereby limiting the use of water from the mains to that amount lost through evaporation. 
(Ord. 737, 1960: Ord. 716, 1959: Ord. 483 § 3.0459, 1950). 
18.24.020 - Regulations. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to have installed or to operate air conditioning or refrigeration equipment without first conforming to the following regulations: 
A.  PERMIT. All water customers who desire to install water utilizing air conditioning or refrigeration equipment are required to submit an application for approval of their equipment and obtain a permit therefor in advance from the city auditor and are required to give notice of completion of such installation to the city water service department. The permit charge shall be three dollars for less than three tons capacity of the equipment and six dollars for three tons capacity and over of the equipment. 
B.  WATER FROM CITY MAINS. All compressor types of air conditioning and refrigeration units having standard rated capacities of less than three tons, may be equipped with water-cooled condensers, using water from city mains, provided that not more than one such unit of such capacity and so equipped - or combination of units of such total capacity, whether connected singly, in series or in parallel - may be used in one air conditioning or refrigeration system. 
C.  RATE OF WATER USE - UNDER THREE TON CAPACITY. Any system consisting of a unit of less than three tons capacity or a combination of units totaling less than three tons is prohibited from using water from mains in excess of two gallons per minute, per ton. Each unit shall be equipped with an approved automatic water regulating device, so adjusted as to limit the use of water under maximum summer conditions to not more than two gallons per minute per ton. 
D.  RATE OF WATER USE - OVER THREE-TON CAPACITY. Any system consisting of a unit of three tons capacity and over or a combination of units totaling three tons capacity and over is prohibited from using water from the mains in excess of two-tenths gallons per minute, per ton. Each such unit or combination of units shall be equipped with a water conserving device. The water level control on the tank, tower, or reservoir, shall be so adjusted as to prevent waste of water through the overflow pipe. 
E.  EXISTING INSTALLATIONS. All units installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified herein and contrary thereto, shall be converted, modified or adjusted to comply as follows: 
(1)  Installations of less than three tons capacity shall comply with Regulation (C) not later than May 1, 1960. 
(2)  Installations of three tons capacity and over shall comply with Regulation (D) not later than May 1, 1960. 
F.  INSPECTION. The superintendent of the water service department and persons employed by him shall at all reasonable hours, have free access to premises supplied with water for air-conditioning and refrigeration purposes, to examine the equipment and to ascertain if there is more water being used than allowed by this chapter. 
G.  EXEMPTIONS. None of the foregoing regulations relating to the limiting and regulating the use of water by air-conditioning equipment shall apply to churches. 
(Ord. 737 (part), 1960: Ord. 716 (part), 1959: Ord. 483 § 3.0460, 1950). 
18.24.030 - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be fined not less than twenty dollars, nor more than one hundred dollars for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. The superintendent of the water service department shall have the authority to discontinue the supply of water to any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1236 (part), 1976; Ord. 737 (part), 1960: Ord. 716 (part), 1959: Ord. 483 § 3.0462, 1950). 
Chapter 18.36 - TELEVISION ANTENNAS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to prevent and provide for remedying any dangerous construction or condition of any building or any equipment uses therein - See SDC 45.0201(56); Cities authorized to provide for the inspection of buildings and the issuance of building permits - See SDC 45.02.02(5). 
Cross reference- General license provisions - See Ch. 5.04 of this code. 

18.36.010 - Title, purpose and scope. 
A.  TITLE. The provisions contained in this chapter shall be known as the "Television Antenna Systems Code" and may be cited as such and will be referred to herein as "this code." 
B.  PURPOSE. The purpose of this code is to provide minimum standards to regulate the construction, and erection of outside television receiver antenna systems, in the interest of safety to the public. 
C.  SCOPE. This code shall apply to the construction, erection, installation, alteration and repair of television antenna systems as defined herein and located or attached to or upon the exterior of a structure or building; and its provisions shall be supplementary to codes, rules, regulations, ordinances or laws, enacted, administered and enforced by the governmental authority exercising jurisdiction, or by such other governmental authorities as may exercise jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 613 (part), 1955: Ord. 483 (part), 1950). 
18.36.020 - Administration and enforcement. 
A.  GENERAL. For the purpose of administration and enforcement of provisions of this code the provisions contained in Chapters 18.04 through 18.16 of the Huron Municipal Code shall apply, except where specific applicable provisions are contained in this section. 
B.  ADMINISTRATOR. This code shall be administered and enforced by the building inspector or such official as is duly designated by the governing body, and such official shall be referred to herein as the building official. 
C.  PERMITS. Permits shall be required for the construction, erection and installation of all outside antenna supports consisting of tower or mast only, which will cost in excess of fifty dollars or more. The permit shall be the regular building permit used in the City of Huron, and the fee thereafter shall be one dollar. 
D.  APPLICATION FOR PERMITS. Applications for permits provided by this section shall be in the form prescribed by the building official. 
E.  PLOT PLAN WITH APPLICATION. Applications for permits provided by this section shall be accompanied by a plot plan showing location of the proposed site of the antenna system guy wire anchor points, lot lines or property, location of all existing buildings or structures, all high tension power or communication lines, poles or towers, all sidewalks, alleys, streets or public thoroughfares either on the property or within a radius of the proposed site of the overall heights of the system above grade. 
F.  PERMIT PLACED AT LOCATION. The permit provided for by this section shall be placed at the location of the site during construction. 
G.  LICENSE REQUIRED. No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of installing antenna systems in the City of Huron without first having procured a license therefor, which license shall be issued on application to the city auditor, and which license shall be revocable by the governing body for any violation of this chapter. 
H.  INSPECTION. The building official shall make an inspection of the site and the component parts of the system upon receipt of notification that excavations for foundation and guy wire footings are completed, or that the building or structure has been reinforced as provided herein at the points of contact of the tower or guy wire anchors. 
I.  FINAL INSPECTION. The building official shall make a final and complete inspection of the system upon receipt of notification that the system is ready for use. 
J.  APPROVAL. The building official shall approve the antenna system for use only after final inspection and determination that the system conforms to provisions of this code, the building code, fire prevention regulations, zoning ordinance, and upon receipt by the electrical inspector that it conforms to the provisions of the electric regulations. 
K.  MAINTENANCE. Outside television receiver antenna systems shall be maintained in a structurally stable and safe condition and the owner thereof shall be responsible for such maintenance. 
L.  CONDEMNATION. Outside television receiver antenna systems determined by the building official to be structurally unsafe shall upon order served on the owner thereof, or his agent, be immediately repaired to conform to the provisions of this code, or shall be condemned by the building official and dismantled, removed and demolished by the owner thereof or at his expense. 
M.  VIOLATIONS. It shall be unlawful and a violation for any person, firm or corporation, after the effective date of this code, to erect, install or construct an outside television antenna system without complying with the provisions of this code. 
N.  VIOLATION BY DISREPAIR. It shall be unlawful and a violation for any person, firm or corporation, after the effective date of this code, to allow an outside television receiver antenna system to fall into disrepair as to affect the structural stability of the system and endanger the safety of occupants of buildings and structures and the public generally. 
O.  VIOLATION BY FAILURE TO DISMANTLE. It shall be unlawful and a violation for the owner of an outside television antenna system to fail to dismantle, remove or demolish an outside television antenna system determined to be unsafe and ordered demolished by the building official. 
P.  PENALTIES. A person, firm or corporation who shall violate a provision of this code or fail to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than ten dollars nor more than one hundred dollars, or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each and every day that such violation continues may constitute a separate offense. 
Q.  RESPONSIBILITY. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of an outside television antenna system, or his agent, to determine the existence of regulations other than this code, the building code and the electric regulations, applicable to the erection, installation, construction or operation of outside television receiver antenna systems, and administered and enforced by any existing governmental authorities exercising jurisdiction. 
R.  ALTERNATE MATERIALS AND APPROVALS. The provisions of this code shall not be construed as prohibiting the use of a material, product, assembly or construction not specifically authorized herein, provided such alternate for use intended meets the requirements of this code as to public safety, and the building official shall require sufficient evidence to support claims for such alternates, or may demand specific tests made of the alternate before approving its use, or may require that the alternate material produce assembly or construction be subjected to examination and consideration by the building inspector. 
(Ord. 1236 (part), 1976; Ord. 797 (part), 1962: Ord. 613 (part), 1955: Ord. 483 §3.0602, 1950). 
18.36.030 - Definitions and abbreviations. 
    For the purpose of these rules, regulations and provisions certain abbreviations, terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall be construed as set out in this section. Words used in the singular include the plural and the plural, the singular. Words used in the masculine gender include the feminine, and the feminine the masculine. 
    ALLEY is any public space, public park or thoroughfare less than twenty feet but not less than ten feet in width, which has been dedicated or deeded to a public authority for public use. 
    ALTER OR ALTERATION is a change, addition, modification or change in location of a portion of the antenna system from the initial installation or design. 
    ANTENNA SYSTEM is a combination of any antenna elements, staffs, supporting towers or masts, guy wire assemblies, foundations or footings, electrical motors, appliances or connections and intended for use with television receivers. 
    BUILDING is a building, structure or enclosure housing the television receiver. 
    BUILDING CODE is such codes, rules, regulations, laws or ordinances enacted to regulate building construction, and administered or enforced by the governmental authority exercising legal jurisdiction. 
    BUILDING OFFICIAL is the designated official of the governmental authority exercising legal jurisdiction, responsible for the administration and enforcement of such codes, rules, regulations, laws or ordinances enacted to govern building construction, or a regularly authorized deputy. 
    ELEMENT is that portion or portions of the antenna system which is directly connected by lead-in wire or cable to the television receiver. 
    ELECTRICAL CODE is such codes, rules, regulations, laws or ordinances enacted to regulate the installation of electrical systems, equipment, or apparatus in buildings and administered and enforced by the governmental authority exercising legal jurisdiction. 
    ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR is the designated official of the governmental authority exercising legal jurisdiction, responsible for the administration and enforcements of codes, rules, regulations, laws or ordinances governing the installation of electrical systems, equipment or apparatus in buildings, or a regularly authorized deputy. 
    GOVERNMENTAL AUTHORITY is a city, municipality, village, town, township, county, state or national agency or subdivision thereof, exercising legal jurisdiction in the enactment of codes, rules, regulations, laws or ordinances. 
    GUY WIRE is a wire or cable extending in tension from an anchor point to an elevated position on the tower to afford stability and support to the tower. 
    HEIGHT is the overall vertical length of the antenna system above ground grade, or if such system be located on a building or structure, then, the overall vertical length of the system above that part of the level of such building or structure upon which the base of the system rests. 
    LEAD-IN LINE is the cable or wire connecting the television receiver to the antenna elements. 
    LIGHTING ARRESTER is a protective device designed to carry accumulations of static electricity and minor lighting discharges to the ground without going into or through the receiver. 
    LOT is a distinct portion or plat of land considered as a unit, devoted to a certain use or occupied by a building or a group of buildings united by a common interest of use, and the customary accessories and open spaces belonging to same. 
    LOT LINE is the line dividing one premises from another, or from public thoroughfare or other area. 
    OWNER shall for the purpose of this code, be the person holding title to the television receiver or an outside television receiver antenna system. 
    PERSON is a natural person, partnership, firm or corporation, and his or their heirs, executors, administrators, successors or assigns, or his or their agents. 
    PROPERTY is a lot, plot or parcel of land including the buildings or structures located thereon. 
    PROPERTY OWNER is a person holding legal title and having a vested or contingent interest in the property and buildings or structures thereon. 
    RECEIVER is the equipment or appliance used in transforming television impulses into audible and visible reproductions, and to the antenna element by lead-in line. 
    SHALL as used in the code is mandatory. 
    SITE is the location of the base of the antenna system tower. 
    STAFF is that portion of the antenna system to which the antenna elements are attached or are a portion of. 
    SIDEWALK is a paved walkway for pedestrian traffic, usually located at the side of a street or public thoroughfare. 
    STREET is any thoroughfare or public park not less than twenty feet in width which has been dedicated or deeded to a governmental authority for public use. 
    THOROUGHFARE is a public street or roadway, or a passage way for private use. 
    TOWER OR MAST is the support or extension required to elevate the antenna staff and elements to a height deemed necessary for adequate operation of the television receiver. 
(Ord. 1911, 2001: Ord. 483 § 3.0603, added by Ord. 613, October 3, 1955). 
18.36.040 - General structural requirements. 
A.  PROTECTION FROM CORROSION. Antenna elements, arrays, masts, towers, supports, brackets, guy wires, fittings and all component parts of the antenna system assembly exposed to the elements shall be constructed or assembled of noncorrosive metal materials or protected by a noncorrosive finish. 
B.  PROJECTION AND SETBACK. Antenna systems shall not be constructed, erected or installed so as to project over a street, sidewalk, alley or public thoroughfare, or over adjoining property, and the antenna base and guy wire anchors shall not be less than four feet from the property line within the setback requirements of the building code and zoning ordinance. This may be changed by special permission of the building inspector to meet local conditions. 
C.  DISTANCE FROM POWER LINE. Antenna systems shall not be constructed, erected or installed nearer to a power line above two hundred fifty volts than the overall height of the system above base, and the antenna elements, arrays, masts, towers or systems shall not be attached to or supported y towers or poles used in the transmission of power or communication lines, nor shall the system be guyed to such towers or poles. 
D.  MOUNTING ON BUILDING. Antenna systems shall not be mounted upon or supported by a structure or building unless the structure or building will carry the load in a safe manner and the provisions of this code will be complied with in the construction, erection and installation. 
E.  LOAD DESIGN. Antenna systems shall be designed, constructed, erected and installed to withstand the pressure of thirty pounds per square foot of the projected area. 
F.  SYSTEMS OVER SIXTY-FIVE FEET HIGH. Antenna systems exceeding sixty-five feet in height shall be of an approved type and the tower or system thereof shall comply with the requirements of this code. 
G.  GROUNDING. Antenna systems shall be grounded as herein provided. (Ord. 483 § 3.0604, added by Ord. 613; October 3, 1955). 
18.36.050 - Arrays and masts. 
A.  ATTACHMENT. Antenna arrays shall be securely attached to the antenna mast by welding, bolting or clamping in an approved manner. 
B.  SIZE OF MAST - ARRAY UNDER TEN POUNDS. Antenna arrays weighing ten pounds or less and elevated ten feet or less shall be attached to a mast of not less than sixteen gauge galvanized steel tubing of not less than one inch diameter, or material of equivalent strength. 
C.  SIZE OF MAST - ARRAY OVER TEN POUNDS. Antenna arrays weighing more than ten pounds and not more than fifteen pounds and elevated twenty feet or less shall be attached to a mast of not less than sixteen gauge galvanized steel tubing of not less than one and one quarter inches in diameter, or material of equivalent strength. 
D.  GUYS. Antenna masts of metal tubing shall be guyed at not greater than ten foot intervals and shall not be more than twenty feet in height; and, required additional elevation shall be obtained by mounting mast on supporting tower. (Ord. 483 § 3.0605, added by Ord. 613; October 3, 1955). 
18.36.060 - Attaching masts to supporting towers. 
A.  WOODEN POLES. The mast if attached to wooden poles, shall be secured with not less than two metal straps and clamps spaced not less than twenty-four inches apart vertically. 
B.  ROTATING MASTS. Rotating type masts shall be supported by a collar or bushing mounted on and securely attached to the supporting tower and the mast shall extend not less than twenty-four inches vertically below the collar or bushing to a socket fitting or plate. 
C.  MOUNTING ROTATING MOTOR. The rotating motor may be of the type attached to the mast above the supporting tower, or may be mounted on a platform or base attached to the tower or pole. (Ord. 483 § 3.0606, added by Ord. 613; October 3, 1955). 
18.36.070 - Supporting towers. 
A.  MATERIALS. Supporting towers may be of steel pipe, steel tubing or wooden poles, or of approved self supporting or guyed type assembled towers; except that single steel pipe, single steel tubing or wooden poles shall not be used to elevate antenna arrays to a height in excess of sixty-five feet from the base. 
B.  SIZE AND STRENGTH. Pipe and tubing shall graduate in size and strength with each section and all joints shall be secure and rigid. 
C.  JOINING SECTIONS. Sections of steel pipe shall not exceed twenty feet in length, and sections shall be joined by application of a socket welding reducer fitting, or other approved method. 
D.  WOODEN POLES. Treated wooden poles shall be of a single one piece timber, steps to be provided at a point not less than six feet from ground. 
E.  ASSEMBLED TOWERS. Assembled towers of approved types and guyed as provided in this code may be used to elevate arrays to one hundred and fifty feet, and the sections and legs of each section shall be securely joined by welding, riveting, bolting, or by application of welded lugs, or by other approved methods. Towers of this height must be approved by building inspector before erection. (Ord. 483 § 3.0607, added by Ord. 613; October 3, 1955). 
18.36.080 - Base supports. 
A.  SECURE MOUNTING. Antenna systems shall be securely mounted upon a bracket, plate, or footing designed to hold the system stable and solid and to withstand any overturning movement, except for guyed towers. 
B.  CHIMNEY ATTACHMENTS PROHIBITED. No television antenna supporting mast shall be attached to any chimney regardless of condition. 
C.  ATTACHMENT TO BUILDING. Antenna systems elevated more than sixteen feet shall not be mounted upon or attached to any portion of a building or structure unless the affected structural members are reinforced sufficiently to withstand the additional loads and stresses. 
D.  ROOF INSTALLATIONS. Antenna systems erected or installed on roofs of wooden structures shall be securely attached to or mounted upon a platform or plate, or an approved type bracket or base, designed to conform to the pitch of the roof and of sufficient size to make contact with not less than two rafters or structural members of the roof, and such base shall be anchored to the rafters or structural members by lag screws, bolts or approved type clamps. 
E.  WATERPROOFING. Areas of a roof or structure affected by the mounting of an antenna system shall be made waterproof by flashing or caulking or other approved methods. 
F.  CONNECTION TO VENTS OR RAIN LEADERS PROHIBITED. Antenna systems shall not in any way be attached or connected to vent pipes or rain leaders. 
G.  BRACKETS. Antenna systems mounted upon or attached to portions of a building or structure other than the roof shall be attached by use of approved standoff brackets securely fastened by lag screws, bolts or clamps. 
H.  FOOTINGS. Antenna systems based on ground grade shall be mounted either on a concrete footing or driven rod base unit, except that systems elevated more than forty feet and free standing systems shall be mounted upon a concrete footing. Wooden poles may be embedded in the ground in the approved manner. 
I.  WOODEN POLES. Wooden poles shall not be embedded in concrete footings but may be in approved footings. 
J.  GUYED AND FREE STANDING TOWERS. Legs of guyed and free standing type towers may be embedded in the concrete footing to a depth of not less than twenty-four inches or attached to extensions or fittings embedded in the footing to a depth of not less than twenty-four inches. 
K.  ANCHORS. Guyed towers or systems shall be properly anchored. 
L.  BUILDING PERMITS. Self supporting ground mounted towers shall be installed within regulations concerning building permits. (Ord. 483 § 3.0608, added by Ord. 613; October 3, 1955). 
18.36.090 - Guying. 
A.  MATERIALS. Guy wire shall be a minimum of six strand number eighteen galvanized or other non-corrosive material of equal strength. Thimbles shall be used at all anchoring points unless a smooth rounded surface is otherwise provided. 
B.  SEPARATION OF ANCHOR POINTS. Guy wire anchor points shall be separated by not more than one hundred and twenty degrees of the circumference of the system and shall be located at a radius of the tower so that the guy wires form an angle from the tower or mast of not less than thirty degrees vertically. 
C.  ROOF MOUNTED SYSTEMS. Guy wire anchors of systems mounted on roofs or structures may be anchored to the structure and shall be securely fastened to the structural members of the building and such structural members shall be reinforced and braced to withstand a tensile strain of not less than six hundred pounds for each attached guy wire. 
D.  ANCHOR LOCATIONS. Guy wires shall not be anchored to a pole or tower used for electrical or communications lines, and guy wire footings and anchor points shall be not less than four feet from the property line and within the prescribed setback requirements of the building code and zoning ordinances. 
E.  TURN BUCKLES. Turn buckles used on guy lines shall be safe-tied so that center section of turn buckle cannot turn. 
(Ord. 613, 1955: Ord. 483 § 3.0609, 1950). 
18.36.100 - Conductors, grounding and electrical wiring. 
A.  Lead-in Conductors Generally. Lead-in conductors or lines shall be approved type and shall be protected where exposed to mechanical injury and shall be equipped with a lightning arrestor and grounded as herein provided. 
B.  Support of Lead-in Conductors. Lead-in conductors shall be supported by approved type bracket stand-off insulators placed in an approved manner on the antenna system and exterior of the building or structures every four and one-half feet. 
C.  Attachment of Lead-in Conductors. Lead-in conductors shall not be attached to cross arms or supports used for wires or cables conducting power or communications, and shall have a permanent separation of four feet from all electric wires up to two hundred and fifty volts potential, and a greater separation from wires of higher voltage, nor shall lead-in make contact with eave through, downpipe, vent or water pipes, electrical lines, communication lines, ground wires or guy wires. 
D.  House Entrance. House entrance shall be porcelain or plastic tube or suitable substitute installed to permit lead-in to be protected from the elements. 
E.  Lightning Arrestor - Approved Type. Lead-in conductors and rotator cables shall be provided with a lightning arrestor of a U.L. Label. 
F.  Location of Lightning Arrestor. Lightning arrestors may be located either outside or inside the building or structure, except that it shall be as near as practical to the point of entrance of the conductor to the building, and shall not be located near combustible materials or in hazardous locations. 
G.  Grounding. Antenna systems, supporting towers and lead-in conductors shall be permanently and effectively grounded for protection. Grounding shall be with number eight or larger copper or aluminum wire connected to a ground rod three-eighths inch by six inch or larger. 
H.  Electric Installations. Motors, electrical installations and connections used in the operation of antenna systems shall be installed in accordance with the provisions of the electrical code. 
(Ord. 613, 1955: Ord. 483 § 3.0610, 1950). 
Chapter 18.38 - SMALL CELL WIRELESS COMMUNICATION FACILITIES 

18.38.010 - Purpose. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be known as the small cell facilities regulations. It is the purpose of these provisions to develop standards and siting criteria, and to establish removal procedures. It is further the purpose of these provisions: 
1.  To establish regulations and siting standards for small cell wireless communication facilities (SCFs), whether in the public right-of-way or on other public or private property, in a manner that will protect the public's health, safety, and welfare and maintain the aesthetic integrity of the community; 
2.  To facilitate the provision of wireless communication services; and 
3.  To provide regulations which are specifically not intended to, and shall not be interpreted or applied to: (1) prohibit or effectively prohibit the provision of wireless services; (2) unreasonably discriminate among functionally equivalent service providers; or (3) regulate wireless communication facilities and wireless transmission equipment on the basis of the environmental effects of radio frequency emissions to the extent that such emissions comply with the standards established by the Federal Communications Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2199-18-74, § 1, 1-7-2019) 
18.38.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings set forth below: 
    Antenna. Any communications equipment that transmits or receives electromagnetic radio frequency signals used in the provision of wireless services. This definition does not include broadcast radio or television antennas, antennas designed for amateur radio use, or satellite dishes for residential or household purposes. 
    Applicant. Any person who submits an application as or on behalf of a wireless provider. 
    City. The city of Huron, South Dakota. 
    Collocation. The mounting or installation of an antenna or a small cell facility on a pre-existing utility pole or SCF support structure and/or modifying a utility pole or SCF support structure for the purpose of mounting or installing an antenna or SCF on that utility pole or SCF support structure in order to transmit and/or receive radio frequency signals for communications purposes. 
    Department. The department of public works of the city. 
    Director. The director of the department. 
    FCC. The Federal Communications Commission. 
    Height. The vertical distance measured from the base of the structure at grade to the highest point of the structure, including the antenna. 
    Network interface device. The telecommunications demarcation and test point separating the wireless facility and the wireline backhaul facility. 
    Person. An individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, association, trust, or other entity or organization, including the city. 
    Public right-of-way or right-of-way or ROW. The surface and space above and below any street, sidewalk, avenue, boulevard, alley, lane, easement, right-of-way, highway or thoroughfare open for public use in which the city has an interest in law or equity, whether held in fee, or other estate or interest, or as a trustee for the public. 
    Small cell facility or SCF. A wireless facility that either meets both of the following qualifications or is within a stealth design that is consistent with the design guidelines: 
1.  Each antenna is located inside an enclosure of no more than three cubic feet in volume or, in the case of an antenna that has exposed elements, the antenna and all of its exposed elements could fit within an enclosure of no more than three cubic feet; and 
2.  Each provider's equipment enclosures shall be no larger than 28 cubic feet in volume.
